35095543.review:
A good turn based mix of RPG and Builder/Explorer.

Developing your village at the start takes some time, but as you gather more people, you will eventually be able to put multiple exploration groups out.

Combat is an interesting stylized card match. Half your squad is randomly in the front line (round up), and can thus attack twice in the first round.  The other half can only join confused, getting one attack in the first round, but can instead use their skills to modify the battlefield. I prefer to knock out my opponents cards when possible, and confuse powerful enemies, if done right, you can set up precise kills without wasting damage.

Do watch out, taking even a little damage can have negative effects, so save frequently. Iron man mode game, one save file, although there is an autosave.

Crafting in village is also an interesting part, since once you get mutliple resources, you can craft your particular item crafting to make exactly what you want. I recommend turning OFF use new items automatically, and manually turn on things you DON'T want to craft with, which is just about nothing. Let your people eat nothing but base food and burn cheap wood, save the good stuff for crafting.

I'll leave the story line to you, so as not to spoil it.

Overall if you like party management, resource gatherer, or explorer games, there will probably something in this one you will like, if you like all those, this is a definate get. If full price still scares you, get it on sale, I think you will be pleased.

Overall, I can say I highly recommend this game.  The amount of lore through the quests is very interesting and makes you want to try and see all events at least once.  The combat system is fun initially, but starts to feel grindy after a few times.  The downside is that different challenge types all use the same combat system just with different stats so if you fight someone or try and convince someone you do the exact same thing.  I also love it that every game is different and you can customize the difficulty to whatever your heart desires!

Pros:
  - Great lore
  - Unique combat system (although can feel grindy after awhile)
  - Customizable Difficulty with many starting options
  - Loads of crafting recipes
  - Loads of character types
  - No forced timeline (As in you have x amount of turns to complete things)
  - FREE DLC

Cons:
  - A.I. is virtually non-existant
  - GUI is... clunky, especially during crafting.
  - Replay value after maxxing out all Gods is very very low.
  - Multiprayer (Multiplayer) is dull.
  - Extremely easy  (Difficulty only seems to slow you down, not stop you)

I saw the kickstarter for Thea 2 and am probably going to back it.  I hope to see an improved GUI, better Multiplayer support like creating public lobbies so you don't have to find someone on your own outside of the game, more crafting recipes and/or materials, give children something to do, and maybe make it so that you don't end up doing the same strategy every time because it is the fastest way to win.

34897058.review:
I like Thea's concept, but the inventory micromanagement ruined the fun. The monstrous scale of micromanagement required is beyond ridiculous; and this from someone who loved the original Settlers and similar games. I have never, ever spent this much time trying to organize and reorganize inventories in a game. Not even Dungeons and Dragons Online which was pretty bad inventory management and incredibly time-wasting.

The devs could have created a way to optimize gear with one button, but chose not to. So instead you'll spend most of your time trying to optimize gear so your people don't die permanently faster than they otherwise would.

The game - beyond that major complaint - is fun and innovative, with definitely interesting twists on the 4X tropes. But because of the inventory problems, I can't reccomend the game. There are other, better 4X games out there to "one more turn" in.

34466002.review:
To make it short: this is a nice RPG/strategy/card/survival game, not perfect but which deserve to be supported. I would give 7/10. 
20€ is too much for this game, 10€ or less is more apropriate.


[u]Pros:	[/u]

+++ Very nice balance between a strategy game, a RPG, a card game and a survival game. This makes this game unique in its kind.

++ Nice gameplay and story.

+ The game shows its full dimension when played in hard mode. You will have to make crucial choices between defending your settlement and sending an expedition far away to gather resources and complete quests.

+ "short story" option: a real salvation for those who don't want to read tons of text during games.

+ Fine music and graphic design.


[u]Cons :[/u] 

-- Can be borgin with time, because something is missing in the game. Yes the point is that you are alone in a ruined world, but you REALLY feel alone. Maybe one town to manage isn't enough? Maybe developers should add factions with their own towns and teams (orcs, elves,...), adding some depth in the game with trading (really missing), alliances/wars ? or else.

- Random events feel quite harassing and sometime more challenging than the main quests. You almost cannot make one step without facing at least one (sometimes several..) and even if you build a strong team, it can be ripped apart unfairly in one round if you are unlucky.

-- (For French players) French translation is a joke and is unusable: they simply used google translate or worse, making the text full of non sense. This is shameful for a game you pay for... better switch to English.

- Skills are too numerous and not easy to understand. You never really know the power of your team (except for fighting) and if it can face a difficult challenge or not.

- UI is fine but it could be more optimised (lots of clicks and spent time to do few things).

- Only 1 save slot... Why couldn't we play several games with different parameters?

34430110.review:
Excellent game, 20 hours in. I have just scratched the surface, but the way this game is set up can keep you going for a long time. The map is randomly generated plus the events that the game tossed at you are random. 

In my first playthrough I combatted a lot without tactics, which caused me to lose quite a few characters. The game kept tossing me drama and my village ended up dead by some strange dark curse. Still this effort unlocked new bonuses for my god for new playthroughs. 

On my second playthrough I decided a more cautious approach. Dealing with situations using social or tactic options. A few examples..
I encountered a band of goblins with a strength greater than my band, I had to try a sociale bluf that is resolved in a card game (like every encounter). What the goblin have in strength they lack in speech and were easily scared by the strong vocal presence of the group. 

You fall into a ditch and discover an old entrance, will you go in or climb out the ditch? If you go in, will you take the left or right way.  Oh and the right tunnel reeks of death.  Every choice matters here.  

Other features that are nice: there are many different classes and even animals sometimes join you. I had read that also demons, dwarves or elves may join. You cant select your team, you will have to cope with who ever joins your cause. Only kids that mature can be chosen into a specific class if  you got the right building.  

All text is voice over by one person, which is not a bad thing suprisingly. 

The overall atmosphere is very good. This one village struggling to survive in a dark world. 

What is a bit annoying that the game only allows one playthrough at the time. You have to finish one game before starting another.

Overall, Recommended!

(If you hate card games, this isnt your game)

34282974.review:
Full disclosure: I received this game from Explorminate as part of one of the give aways - kudos to Explorimate!

This game has been on my radar for some time and I quite enjoy the approach and novel mechanics that it uses. In effect its you (or your village) against a harsh post-apocalyptic world where magic and life itself hang by a thread. Your actions play a pivatol role in determining whether the world will survive and if so, in what form. That makes for a great story and the quest system is excellent. Your ability to survive depends on leveling your villagers, acquiring the resources you need to survive, and researching technologies to give you the tools you need to resist the hostile world.

PROS: Great concept, fascinating world and lore, wonderful questing system, lots of "discovery" to be had, AI is effective, artwork is good, evocative, and does a decent job of conveying information, humorous
CONS: Repetitive gameplay (both strategically and tactically), patron diety choices seem to have negligible impact on game play, no competitive game play

This game will provide hours of enjoyment and so ultimately its worth the price of admission. The lack of competitive play and the repetitive game play make long term enjoyment problematic. I am excited to see how Thea 2 addresses these concerns and moves the series forward.

34165667.review:
This game took me a while to "get it", but once I understood the mechanics, I realized the depth of it.  Definitely recommended.

(Note: I dunno why the time counter shows I played 0.2 hours, it was definitely far more).

It is a blend between games like Civilization, Rebuild, Rimworld, and adventure games. It plays in a slavic/eastern european post-apocaliptic fantasy world. Instead of general "units", you have people with various strengths, like one might be great at gathering stuff, the other is very clever and can open up new solution paths, the third is a great warrior, etc. The game is a roguelike, so if a character dies, it stays dead.

You can make small parties that gather stuff away from your village,  hunting parties that can hunt monsters without actually getting into battle, or a general big party that can solve a lot of adventures. Crafting is also great, where different materials used will result in different items (if you make a mace out of gold, it will increase the wearer's willpower, if you make it from part bone, part metal, it will deal more damage, if it is mostly wood, it will be lighter, etc). Even buildings created from different materials won't be the same.

The game is not without flaws, like the UI is hard to use, it is hard to see how much movement points you have left, movement rules are a bit blurry, and requires a lot of micromanagement if you want to play optimally, but the overall strength of the mood and the refreshing nature of the game still makes it worth to play.

33958504.review:
tl;dr: I'm pretty happy with this game despite design flaws. It's a nice RPG/RTS with Cards, although it is not a CCG game. 6/10.

The main portion of the gameplay is city and party management with movement taking place on a hex board. While the management portion can be tedious, and the UI leaving much to be desired, there is enough good aspects to outweigh the bad. As for the combat mechanics, it could use some work, but it's simple enough to not take too long and it feels like it is relatively fair. 

I have yet to complete the game, so I can't comment on the rest of the story. However, The lore in this game is fantastic and one of the more enjoyable features. I've spent fair amount of time reading each of the stories and random occurrences. There's usually a few choices you can make on each story that gives you a different result, but other than quest rewards there isn't much of a lasting change to the overall story.

This is a pretty fun game, and though the art is great, it is fairly limited and assets are reused when telling stories. I'd like to see a sequel of this game that works out the kinks of this version. I've enjoyed the 40 something hours I've put into this, but I feel it could be a bit better. Overall, though, I recommend this game and highly recommend reading everything in the game. The careful attention in the writing and worldbuilding is refreshing. 6/10.

Ik heb er genoeg uren in gestoken om te zeggen dat ik het zeker een interesante game vind. In principe is het een single player 4X spel met CYOA (choose your own advanture elementen). Maar zoals met elke eerste iteratie van een spel heb je in het begin niet zoveel problemen met de tekortkomingen, maar geniet je wel van alle dingen die goed zijn. En dit zijn de positieve punten:

Je stuurt een groep van je inwoners op Avontuur. 
Crafting is erg leuk en simpel gedaan. Je gooit wat producten in de mix en kijkt wat er uit komt. Je leert langzaam wat de eigenschappen van elke resource zijn. 
De verhaaltjes zijn leuk en vervrissend element. Het is de basis van het spel en niet slap uitgevoerd. 

De slechte dingen zijn:
Combat word saai en is soms niet helemaal representatief van wat er gebeurd. Ook is soms onduidelijk wat je stats horen te zijn
Loot drops zijn TE random. Soms krijg je een heel goed zwaard en COOKED VEGIES nadat je wolven hebt verslagen. 
de UI kan nog verbeterd worden. Hij doet soms rare dingen. 
Je Village is een HEEL saaie plek. Je laat meestal 2 a 3 mensen daar en neemt de rest mee op avontuur. Je village zou steeds boeiender moeten worden.

33467055.review:
I don't often write reviews, but I felt compelled to for this game. You see, even if a game has great reviews, I usually read the negative reviews as they usually contain a few honest comments pointing out the flaws of what might otherwise be a great game. But with Thea, I am trully befuddled that anyone could leave a negative review. Sure, this game might not be for everyone... it's quite different from your standard fare. It's a bit of a hybrid in genre, a mix of RPG, 4X, and tactical card combat system. But it is excellent at what it is. It has a rich story and the only way it may be confusing to someone is because you actually need to pay attention... this may be too much for the instant gratification generation. 

I read of one reviewer claiming to be on turn 400 15h into it. You obiously skipped much of the story and many instructions, and then you claimed you were confused? I finished my first playthrough about 40h later at turn 190, and had no trouble with the end-game confrontation. My ONLY gripe is that I when hitting "end game" and getting my score, I wasn't able to go back and continue that game to finish a side quest I had left for later, but 45h into this game I find I am only just starting to explore this huge adventure and look forward to playing the many other gods available and the unique story they provide.

TL:DR Well worth getting

33395163.review:
An absolute must play before sep 23rd 2017 and beyond. 

The title of this game couldnt be more apt. Awakening... 

Now to start I must say the game has many aspects dealing with current ideologies and uh capita. The lore and symbolism can be relatively matched with the real world. I found my "awakening" when the lore of the giants was better explained. 

Found myself drawing lines with the giants we have in the world today (philanthropists and people with vast money and knowledge, may or may not move slow, but when they do impacts are heavy and leave shudders of tension through the ground for the rest of people to feel/notice etc).

 Now the diversity of ideas and races can be met by way of the old men in the tower, the different races, classes and monsters to combat, and the elven people in particular. They are dying from magic dying out because of the world tree burning, (equating to the pillars of life/civilization dying). (ah lets not forget the ice queen, loss of heart and all that...not religous but, Mathhew 24:12)

I have quite the interesting take on all of it, but will not type it out, for then what reason would you have to play and explore the lore of this most wonderous game?

In all honesty the game mechanics are good, especially if playing on the easier difficulties which certainly leaves time enough to ponder things and not having to worry too much on the life and death situations that arise. If you like playing on harder difficulties but your favorite character bites the dust, there is always that save that you forgot about an hour and a half ago (lol my tears so bitter).

I like the ability to have a band of warriors and gatherers sent on their way to an encampment area to gather resources, this adds a lovely bit of stress about who to send and why. Balancing your goals isnt tedious due to the random factor of events.

In conclusion...
out of all the civ building games and civ manegment tools, this is the one game that appeals most to me for everything worth note above.

33353797.review:
Thea: The Awakening wirkte auf mich auf den ersten Blick simpel und wenig herausfordernd. Das war ein Irrtum! 8-)
Mit fortschreitender Spieldauer  wird die Entscheidungsfindung immer schwieriger.

1. Nach was soll man forschen? Ressourcen, Geräte und Waffen oder Gebäude? Und was davon?
2. Was soll man in der Siedlung bauen? Gebäude, Rüstungen oder verbesserte Werkzeuge?

Das Herumprobieren, was man mit welchen Rohstoffen basteln und bauen kann, macht mir Spaß.
Während der Kämpfe sind mir verschiedene Vorgehens- und Funktionsweisen der Waffen aufgefallen. Wählt man in der Aufstellungsphase eine offensive Person, oder lieber eine taktische mit einer Spezialaktion? Kämpft man überhaupt mit normalen Waffen oder ist es ein spezieller Kampf mit Jagdfähigkeiten, Schleichen oder Willensanstrengung? Ich finde das hervorragend.
Entschieden werden muss auch, ob man mit dem Außenteam lieber Schätzen und Beute nachjagt, oder ob man seltene Rohstoffe sammelt. Beides ist wichtig, aber erstes bringt Erfahrung und Forschungspunkte, zweites ermöglicht bessere Rüstungen, Waffen und Werkzeuge oder mehr Essensvielfalt, die wiederum Verbesserungen der Bewohner mit sich bringt. Ein tolles Konzept. Und die Herausforderungen werden mit der Zeit immer schwerer. Man ist in gewisser Weise getrieben. Ich bin zwar noch nicht arg weit, aber ich fühle, dass ich mir nicht so viel Zeit lassen kann, wie ich eigentlich möchte, Da sind Dinge im Gange, die sich gegen meine Siedlung wenden. Und wenn wir uns nicht beeilen, dann überrennen sie uns.

33270546.review:
Introduction

Thea is some kind of mix between 'civilization' and 'king of dragon pass'. i also got a strong 'kingdom death monster' vibe from it. the game should be fun for anyone, who likes cardgamestrategy and simultations. but let me explain in detail:

Setup:

you are a god awakening from your slumber and lording over a small settlement of people. you decide what those people do, which means, some you send to explore, while others gather wood and food in the village.

The Game:

you gather wood and food by dragging the villager to the corresponding field, he then does this automatically wach turn, similar with the construction of buildings or items.
The fights are basically a cardgame you play each of your fighters, in each round and when both people do not have cards anymore the fightingphase plays out automatically. the cards you play are your settlers, whos strengths you customized with their class and items.
Those items you find, or make yourself, to make them yourself, your expedition usually needs to go out and loot them or gather resources to make them, since you can only have one town and this town is usually not at a good resource-rich spot.
While exploring, you will frequently find a lot of !voiceacted! events in which you decide what to do. (even after 44 hours, i most likely have not seen all events, though i have seen a couple of events twice or thrice)
All in all the gameplay does certainly not have a lot of action, i would even say, it has less action, than 'civilization V', however if you like to think and plan it is a lot of fun.

The Good:

-Lots of events and no real 'wrong' answer.
-great art
-Harvest moon effect (Once you start, you are reluctant to stop)
-decent tactical challenge during card battles(if the difficulty is done right)

The Bad

-You can not choose your city-starting spot. (i swear i would pay money for such a DLC, not being able to choose makes you unable to choose in big parts how hard your game will be, i for one would like to try a start, where my city does not have a food source.)

-Somewhat repetitive, if you know all the events.

-modifier during difficulty are unbalanced. (though i assume this is not a very important point for most people reading this review, just know you can make it very easy and rewarding for you at the same time, with the right costumdifficulty.)


Conclusion

I picked the game up in a (this) summer sale and can warmly recommend it, it certainly delivered for me.

But please devs, make a 'choose your city starting spot addon'!

33098571.review:
Absolutely fantastic game. Anyone who is a fan of turn based games, card based games, stat management, settlement management, or a host of other features should definitely get this.

I have hundreds of hours in the GoG version so I have no hours on Steam.

The only negatives I can state are:

If you get a bad start it can make the early game very hard/slow - and the game is unforgiving as it is. However, you can save your settings so starting a new game takes 30 seconds if you want to game the map generation.

The end game is really fun, and punishing - but after you go through levelling up all the gods and optimising your playstyle there isn't much beyond it since the story is quite linear - you're trying to decide the fate of Thea. You have lots of choices don't get me wrong, but you'll end up at the same point in the story whether it takes you 100 days or 500. That aside, if you are a completionist there are hundreds of hours worth of content here, and if you're not then maybe you'll get 30-60 hours which for the price is not bad at all.

33097977.review:
I would say this game is worth playing, but, only until the final completion of all three quests, lines, which can all be done on the same playthrough. I was irked by the fact that I could 'quit' after completing one, thinking I had to restart or I couldn't complete the other victory requirements until the end credits told me otherwise. 

 I like Thea in a, I have a gambling problem, sort of way. In many ways, it's a really easy game to lose early on and it requires losing consistently in order to come to understand how the game mechanics work. On normal difficulty, I think I had about 10 play throughs before I finally figured out a strategy to win the initial quest. Losing is a part of the game's progression and the gods that are suppose to serve as the player's avatar will level up and give you cheap bonuses. That part of the game I absolutely hate and I found myself resetting the playthrough in order to avoid getting freebies in order to avoid rewarding myself for failure. I suppose in the grand scale of Thea, if the player is suppose to be a diety then your followers really don't matter, you just keep picking up one tribe, one after another until you finally find a successful one, and that's incredibly meta.

 The game does a lot stuff like that, where you're the God(dess) guiding your civilization, but, at the same time, you encounter yourself or avatars of yourself and you're basically talking through your worshippers but at the same time getting critized / praised by yourself for the actions you take in accordance with other guidance you have recieved from another aspect of yourself. The game's tutorial mentions this, but, it can be a slightly jarring experience if you forget that warning.

 Personally, I think the game probably is at it's best when it's ramped up to the highest difficulty setting and it's also a lot easier on it's highest difficulty setting. Choices really matter then and the risk of losing your village members helps cement the feeling of caution against going against an opponent that on a lower difficulty, may not appear to be such a big threat. There's no deadline in Thea, no  countdown timer, so it's a game in which the patient will truly be the victor. In fact, it can become quite boring in time because it's a game in which micromanagement is a key factor to victory.

 Advancement of your civilization is based on research, which is done by going on quests, fighting or crafting objects and buildings. Fighting and quests are straightforward, so really in order to advance, you may need to have your craftsmen build 50 objects, but at the same time, you can recycle those objects, so the player has to manually go in, drop the shields into the recycling icon, and let the workers keep building objects. It's tedious.

 Even though I'm selecting a yes recommendation, I could go either way on this particular game. It's basically advanced solitaire and a way to suck up time, but, I don't feel like it'll ever be a cult classic or anything more than just a game.

33081504.review:
Gleich zum Anfang: Die Karte ist etwas wakelig.

Holz und Nahrung sind unbedingt erforderlich. Nicht immer nützt ein Heiler in der Gruppe auch wirklich. Drei oder mehr Krieger sind sinnvoll. Die Sammelfähigkeit ist wichtig. Kämpfe gegen Stufe 2 oder höher sind nicht immer siegreich und können zu Verlusten führen. 

Die Startstadt hat 2 oder 3 Ressourcen, die gesammelt werden müssen. Dafür sind von links, Bewohner in die Kästchen rechts zu tun. Runde für Runde wird dann automatisch eingesammelt und ist im Inventar der Stadt. Die Übersicht der verschiedenen Ressourcen erfolgt über das Menü (Button rechts unten). Auch außerhalb der Stadt kann abgebaut und gesammelt werden: Lager aufschlagen, Leute einteilen und los gehts! Es gibt Punkte durch Kämpfe, die für die Forschung verwendet werden. Erfahrungspunkte zum  automatischen Leveln gibt es auch. Es können mehrere Gebäude durch Forschung freigeschaltet werden; bis zu 10 Gebäude können insgesamt mit Rohstoffen und Arbeitern gebaut werden. Wer also 6 Weiden baut, hat noch 4 Gebäude frei. 
Es gbit ein Tutorial, das unbedingt zu empfehlen ist: Es gibt Punkte, Gegenstände und Ressourcen. Nach gewonnenen Kämpfen gibt es immer eine Beute. Auch können Schätze geborgen werden. Die Bewegungsreichweite ist gewöhnlich 5 Felder. Das PC Spiel ist Rundenbasiert. Die Karte ist riesig und es gibt viel zu entdecken: Aber Holz und Nahrung mitnehmen! Es gibt öfter mal einen Quest - einige davon werden sofort gelöst, wenn eine Antwort gewählt wird. 

Kein: Du musst das so machen und das musst Du da bauen. Es gibt völlig freie Entscheidung und gameplay. Zu bemerken ist, das es NUR 1 einzigen Speicherstand gibt. Ein neues Spiel wird immer mit einer auszuwählenden Gottheit gestartet und kann spezifische Vorteile durch Punkte einbringen, die im Verlauf einer Partie erworben werden. In der Startstadt ist dann schon Bevölkerung und eine Expeditionstruppe.

Klare Empfehlung! So was gibt es so schnell nicht wieder. Die Addon sind ratsam und eines davon ist nur in Englisch. Die Sprache wird mit der Landesflagge rechts unten ausgewählt.

33051510.review:
В этой пошаговой стратегии нужно выживать древним племенем в агрессивном мрачном мире. Всё это хорошо сдобрено славянской мифологией и язычеством. Отлично поработали сценаристы. Огромное количество событий и квестов + интереснейший сюжет. Так же понравилось как поработали художники, иногда просто сижу и рассматриваю карточки персонажей. Обилие характеристик у персонажей так же радует. У меня [b]был[/b] отличный ремесленник, но так же он [b]был[/b] лучшим охотником в племени.
Ну конечно, периодически пригорает от того что это всё же игра про выживание. Только раскачаешь партию персонажей, обвешаешь их лучшим оружием как внезапно происходит какое-нибудь [тут много сердечек]. И вот уже последний выживший со скоростью черепахи прёт гору оружия обратно в деревню.
Из минусов: 
Небольшая забагованность игры. Баги не критические, скажем так, раздражающие. Ну что то вроде "прокрутки" карты мира в самый край при сбросе события. И периодически при разыгрыше карты персонажа она оказывается за пределами экрана и оттуда виден только небольшой её край.
Немного непродуманный интерфейс. Например так и не нашёл как объединить 2 отряда на марше. Не хватает возможности забирать карту персонажа после того как её выложил на стол, но ещё не закончил ход.
Довольно быстро приелся саундтрек. Он действительно хороший, но мелодий маловато. Уже подумываю начать играть под свой плейлист.
В общем если хочется познать всю тяжесть быта древних славян, игру берите не задумываясь. 4 капустных поля из 5

32994420.review:
In due parole: Gioco stupendo!

Thea è un titolo particolare in quanto riunisce un gameplay strategico e gestionale ad uno di carte con elementi del genere RPG. Si impersona un dio o una dea che deve guidare il suo popolo per riottenere il suo potere perduto, attraverso mappe ricche di sfide, nemici, eventi e tesori. 
Ogni personaggio, dagli abitanti ai membri delle spedizioni, è singolare e può essere equipaggiato con svariate armi, armature, attrezzi da lavoro e ornamenti; ci sono svariate abilità, caratteristiche che essi potranno sviluppare, salendo di livello o in altri modi.
I combattimenti e il superamento delle sfide avvengono tramite un gioco di carte, in apparenza semplice ma che salendo di difficoltà dovrà essere ben pianificato; essi non coinvolgono solo la forza ma possono essere anche scontri di ingegno, di caccia, di tattica, di furtività e sta al giocatore decidere se imbarcarsi in una di tali tipologie, tenendo conto delle specializzazioni del proprio party.
Non commento niente altro perchè altrimenti dovrei incappare in spoiler, ma è di sicuro un titolo valido e abbastanza innovativo che consiglio a chiunque; non c'è l'italiano ma i videogiochi sono ottimi modi per imparare la lingua dunque sbattetevi un attimo che vi fa solo bene.

32963034.review: This game is so hard but too good. I was suprised with both the quality of stories in game and variation of quests. Much of the is text and card playing based but who says it is a bad thing. They really applied card playing inside a rpg very well...

32959504.review:
there's a lot to do in thea. from micro managing your village, your expeditions, making sure they're armed, and with enough food, and wood to set camp, all while roaming the vast expanse of the land. in the meantime, gathering resources, and building up your village, crafting tons of items ... and you keep going and going.

but one of the best feature i suppose, is the almost endless amount of random encounters you'll get each and every time you take a turn. it doesnt matter how long you've clocked, chances are, you still havent seen it all. and even within the same encounters, how it plays out could differ each time, based on so many various factors such as the god you worship, the skills of the characters in your party, the type of characters in your party, etc. all these things gives it a lot of replayability in itself.

the combat is also unique, presenting itself as cards to the players, and that too, requires some learning before you start developing strategies to beat those battles. while there are basic properties to them, and they're obviously not as large a variety like a proper TCG, it still makes it interesting enough.

all in all, thea is a unique experience to say the least. of course, there are some things i personally wished were in the game, such as the ability to build more villages, or a bit more depth to the battles, but those are minor gripes. and with some luck, we might get to see them in thea2.

also, for the price you're paying, the devs are giving out ALL dlcs for free! in this day and age, not many would do a thing like that. it's always nice to have devs that put the customers first. definitely well worth the support, especially if you're a fan of the genre.

玩了97小时。感觉这款游戏的优点缺点都十分明显。
先说优点：
游戏探索阶段，前十几个小时的游戏还是非常好玩的。需要发现的东西很多，建筑，铸造，材料，技能，战斗都需要一定时间的探索，并且探索的过程时时有惊喜。每得到一个新种族的角色都会高兴一番。剧情的选项很多，有很多随机触发剧情都很好玩，结局也多样。总体上说，这是一款良心游戏。
再说说缺点：
首先是这款游戏有些操作不方便的地方，就像有人说的装备替换问题，需要一个一个地看，队伍里人数少时还好，多了就极其麻烦。最重要的一点，玩到一定程度主线就没了，角色只能满地图乱走，而且有人后期人数增长过快，很容易失去更新装备的兴趣。我经常满心期待地开了一局，玩到后面就草草收场，似乎每局游戏都只是为了解锁新主神和天赋。但是玩到后来发现，每个主神说是好多技能，但是区别真心不大，后期基本就是每个角色敲一下，敌人就被消灭了。
总体上说，游戏是挺好，看起来做的处处用心，但是真心不推荐，着款游戏只能解决心里的一时之痒，但不能长久地留在心中。

32628524.review:
TL;DR Uniquely surprising 4X-RPG hybrid. A truly underrated gem that deserves to be played at least once.

Thea: The Awakening is a genre-blending strategic game where you, the player, are a God. But not any kind of God: you're among the few survivors of your consumed, dying world, in a quest to ensure the survival of your people and your own.

Your worshippers, from artisans to gatherers to warriors, are organized and together have managed to build a thorp, from where you will lead them across the land, deciding what to harvest, what to hunt, where to explore, and ultimately how to stop (or maybe even help) the cataclysmic forces that are destroying your world. There are other dangers here as well, like local bands and cities of goblins, lairs choke-full with man-eating spiders, treant-like demons of old and  other fantastic creatures that hide in the shadows and haunt the long, cold nights of your people.

Mechanically, the game is pretty close to other 4X games like Endless Legend or Age of Empires. However, the differences are welcome additions to a rather static genre, and standing among them is the simple-yet-deep mechanics of the combat/challenges you will face in T:tA, where a card positioning mini-game determines if your people will live or die.

Sadly, the game is not flawless, but whereas other games' mistakes come from its very design, here the formula keeps going on and instead it's the interface the one letting you down in your divine journeys. Fortunately, those are minor mistakes, easily ignored for a game that is definitely a must-buy to any strategy fans, and an outstanding addition to any game library worth its salt.

Get it before its sequel goes live, for bragging rights at the very least.

32617149.review:
Очень люблю эту игру. Заигрываю ее до дырок, и могу с уверенностью сказать, что лулзов там масса. Из последних:
- Ваши сельчане решили построить дом. Постройка обвалилась, но все обошлось, а строители даже бафнулись от испуга. Строители - пауканы Вася и Федя.
- Деревня гоблинов хочет меняться. Первая партия фиг... то есть доспехов на обмен уже выехала. В деревне уже вовсю крафтят еще фиг... доспехов. Крафтят даже те, кто обычно собирает овощи. Пауканы успешно приходят к гоблинам, обменивают шмот на драконтью кожу, параллельно с них снимают их счастливые пуговички, но это мелочи. Радостная, экспедиция возвращается домой. Берут вторую партию - и к гоблинам. Деревня с двойным усердием крафтит г*вно из палок. Пауканы снова отделяются от основного состава, заходят в деревню... а ее нет! Гоблины просто взяли нас и кинули!
- Ладно, тогда поторгуем с эльфами. Забрали из деревни 800 овощей, пошли меняться на дерево. "Используйте с умом, дети мои" - сообщает эльф, дает взамен с десяток золотой древесины... и оббирает экспедицию. Забирает лечо, салаты, бигос и даже водоросли. И ты стоишь такой, в каждой руке по драгоценной палке, а в инвентаре остались одни, мать их, овощи. 
- Окей, торговля - это не мое. Пошли по квесту. Чтобы почесать голову великана, пришлось идти по снежным горам в час по чайной ложке. Почесали, получили наводку, идем обратно. Все, снега скоро кончатся, но тут кто-то из твоих людей (наверное, орк Зог) замечает рядом кладбище. Окей, это интересно, подумали все. И пошли обратно в снег. 
- На кладбище покоится какой-то упырь, которого нельзя выпускать, сообщили умные члены экспедиции. Окей, тогда обберем тут все и свалим. Обобрали. Вместе с серебряными цепями, сдерживавшими гроб. Идеально.
- По дороге накрыли лагерь разбойников, тыривших у нас мифрил. Они пообещали больше так не делать, отдали топор-ребро в компенсацию и свалили в туман. Облутывая их притон, нашли клетку. Так в наш отряд присоединилась Жирная крыса. Жалко ее, дама все-таки. Теперь она Нежирная.
Обожаю эту игру. 10 обобранных пауканов из 10.

32569644.review:
Words cannot express just how much I adore this game. With over 100 hours on record, I've still only beaten the game a handful of times. Most of my time in this game is spent at one or two in the morning, half-asleep already but hand hovering over the "pass turn" button while I say "just ONE MORE turn couldn't hurt... then I'll go to sleep..." The game is addictive, it's funny, it's strategy and survival and 4X all rolled into one incredible package. Other reviews can tell you more about the mechanics and gameplay, all of which I highly reccomend, but I would like to take the time in my review to give a special shoutout to the writers of this game.

All the events, of which there are hundreds and hundreds, are well written, well thought out, and, many times, cause me to crack a smile. From meeting a bridge troll who asked my name, favorite color, how fast a laden swallow can fly, etc., to life-or-death delimmas concerning whether or not to attack slavers in the hope to rescue a few more people for my villiage (and people are a precious commodity) at the risk of losing the warriors I already have, to solving a puzzle box which led me to a village of Goblins, this game has everything you can think of and more. And there's more than one way to resolve the same event, too - not that you'll run into more than a handful of the same events more than once. You'll meet the Herbalist and the Dziody, you'll probably encounter the Hangedman and the Dwarven Smith with an eye on a Rusalka, but these events barely even scratch the surface of what you can come across, and it's all well written and fun.

I also adore the voice actor in this game - that's right, there's only one, a guy who does the voices for tutorial demons, old men and women, seductive demonesses, gruff orcs and dainty elves alike. I got this game far back in EA, before he was added, and words cannot describe how excited I was when I loaded up the game after an update to hear the game talking to me. It's just one beautiful little extra step that makes the world of Thea that much more alive.

All this being said, the replayability of this game is huge, and no two playthroughs will be the same. Everything is procedural - the world, the resources near your home, the events you trigger - and it's a rich and rewarding experience every time.

Lada and Morena are the best.

18/10 you should get this game.

En toute sincérité, ce jeu est une perle. Alors évidemment ce n'est que mon avis, mais si comme moi vous aimer les jeux de stratégie, de survie, avec du craft des ressources à récolter des bâtiments à construite, bah de 1 ce jeu va vous plaire et de 2 bah il fais encore plus que ca. En plus de son côté déplacement et ressource stratégique que l'on peut comparer à un civilization, ce jeu continent des élément de rogue like (chaque nouvelle partie sera differente, quasiment tout est généré proceduralement), de grandes inspiration de rpg (vos personnage peuvent xp, on des compétences, vous pouvez les équiper d'armes, d'armures, d'outils et j'en passe... on des races (humains, betes, elfes,etc..) on des "classes" ils peuvent être guerriers, paysans, artisans, soigneurs, etc...
Sa façon de résoudre les "rencontre" et "evenement" sont assez varier, cela peut être des test social, de discretion, de magie ou tt simplement un combat. Et la manière de résoudre ces test est assez original, cela se passe sous la forme d'un jeu de carte, pas trop complexe mais avec certaine petite subtilité.
Qui plus est, malgré la traduction en français qui n'est pas encore au point (mais qui ne cesse de s'améliorer grâce à la communauté) le lore du jeu (son histoire, son background quoi) est assez complet et est tiré d'un mélange de fantastique un peu sombre et de la mythologie nordique.
Pour conclure, ce jeu est une petite perle qui a encore une bonne marge de progression mais déjà extrêmement plaisant à jouer, alors si vous aimer ce genre de jeu n'hésitez pas et foncez il en vaut la peine.

Ps: faite attention plus on y joue plus on devient accro 😉

32379982.review:
Never has a game made me swap from loving it to never seeing myself playing it again as fast as Thea has.

I finished a playthrough in ~15 hours of playtime (I commonly left it running on a screen when I left for food or whatever), and was having a ton of fun with it. You have to pick a god to play at the beginning and only two are available to start, all of the others require raising a god to level 3 to unlock. 

Well, I'm on day 400-something following one of the two main quests I've unlocked. I come to what I assume is the end of one of them, and all of a sudden the game is over, I'm scored on things that were never told to me, and my score was apparently not enough to get to level 3. If I want to unlock a new god, I have to play the same game over again.

The challenge that turned out to be the game ender had a ridiculous scale in damage that was completely hidden from the player until it was too late which ended up murdering pretty much all of my party by the time I killed it. Had the game not ended, they'd have all died (in fact, when I tried the "continue playing" option, they just all did, as soon as the round was over).

I'm upset that the game ended without warning because I didn't get to follow the other quest I was working on to the end. Nothing in-game implied that this quest was the main quest-line (in fact, it actually seemed the exact opposite, that the other one was the "main" one). I'm upset that the game was scored on things that seem completely pointless (I was scored on the number of days I "survived", but after the early game, it is ridiculously easy for me to just keep hitting "next day" forever to increase that score), and it upsets me even more that there was no information that I was being "scored" on anything at all.

If the devs care at all beyond "they got my money out of me", they'll add some information about ending the game in. There are other issues I had with the game, but I can even get behind the "one save slot with no information about what is in it" thing if there was simply any way to know the game was ending.

When I got to the god page to pick a starter, I was looking forward to unlocking all the options. Throughout the game, I was having tons of fun and wondering how much different it'd be with different gods. I was finding places where I was like "hey, I'm sure if I was following X god, I'd see a different path here" all over the place. Then the game ended the way it did and now I don't know that I'll ever play it again.

32358811.review:
Thea is a 'survival' RPG card-based game that can be difficult to pick up at first, but turns out to be an in-depth game with surprising replayability. Many playstyles can be utilized during the game, though your people must be able to scruff it out with numerous invaders at any time.

This game is boatloads of fun, with many different ways to settle events that require different skills. It has a solid story that will keep you playing, though the narrator voices literally everything in the game, just with different accents, which comes across as silly at times. Regardless, the variety in which you can handle the game's many events is the main selling point here. These events are generally bad if you fail, making you lose many people or become debuffed. You can talk, use magic, sneak, hunt, or simply fight your way to solving Thea's many challenges, giving it a great amount of replayability. Granted, some challenges get repetitive, yet the sheer amount will push you to play a entire game a few times just to see the full picture.

I would suggest starting on normal difficulty, then working your way up to higher ones later. Even though normal difficult grants less XP, which is used to improve your God character for each playthrough, the learning curve for this game is intense and you will likely need to play a few games before you get substaintially far into the game.


You can create a village of blood-thristy warriors, or intellectual sages and engineers, peaceful gatherers, or magic-wielding witches. Though you need a somewhat diverse selection of people to survive, your stat focus will change the way you play according to the stats that your people excel in. Crafting or choosing the class of villager you want (from children growing up) allows for you to control this population diversity.

Overall, lovely game, recommend picking it up.

(caught the kid dissecting a frog, it was either doctor or the bags and a foot out the door).

31999702.review:
I enjoy myself a good strategy-turn-based game every now and then; my favorite one has been Total War:Warhammer since it's release, but this is less like that and maybe more like Armello?  Though if Armello had more of a campaign that you could play for as long as you wanted....?  Maybe?

Each new game you start the map, resources, party members, everything will be completely different, so re-play-ability is very high!  With stuff to work towards unlocking, etc.

If you like, or have EVER liked these things, you will thoroughly enjoy Thea: The Awakening.

The storyline and how you go about it reminds me a lot of:
Dungeons and Dragons  (Baldur's gate)

The combat is a creative card game based on the characters you have acquired and leveled up, similar to:
Magic The Gathering

The inventory management/loot reminds me of:
Diablo I, II, III.

TL;DR
If you are looking at this game with even the slightest bit of interest, buy it, try it out, you won't regret it; you'll be sucked in so fast.  Steep learning curve, but well worth the effort; fall in love with the world, care about your people, care about the choices you make, or laugh at the easter eggs.  Either way, win win winning!

31967938.review:
This is not a regular 4X game.
For starters you can manage only one village and not conquer the map with hundreds and thousands of units.
Your main mission is to keep at bay all the things that want to eat you and your children, next worry about story progression.
My playstyle is based on gathering high-end resources and building cabbage fields, because you have strength in numbers. Focus on the NON-fighting battles, because you can "sacrifice" someone in the card-game, but not get them wounded after the battle. And always craft/build something to get the science points and explore the trees.
Split your villagers into groups that firstly can defend themselves, secondly gather resources and with time you will make them strong enough to attack the major threats.
Remember: more expeditions = more events = loot loot loot
With 25 population I have a fighting, a gathering expedition and some crafters/gatherers in the village to keep everything safe and make science points.
Don't leave your village unattended, because you will lose children, food, weapons and resources to random events.
This is my first time playing card-game battles, but after some guides I got the idea and love the tactics into it.
Love the Slavic mythology part and the randomness of the encounters.

31931067.review:
Хорошая игра, точно стоит своих денег, 7.5/10.
Есть крафт, прокачка персонажей, инвентарь, постройка зданий, исследования, куча характеристик и параметров. 

Но вот меню так себе и определить сходу насколько подойдет твоя группа для выполнения задания например на выносливость очень муторно - нужно каждого персонажа протыкивать и среди списка иконок искать нужные тебе параметры, почему нельзя просто сразу их выделить, или показать в превью какие карты будут на руках в событии? просто разработчики об этом не подумали, или им не хватило на это бюджета.

Также ей нехватает информативности о событиях, ты никогда не знаешь насколько сильными будут карты противника, даже примерно, потому что скелеты с 3 черепками могут выкинуть на поле карты 3 с 45 хп и 30 урона, что очень много. При этом 3 при черепках крыс может оказаться 8 крыс по 10 хп и 5-10 урона, т.е. очень слабых. В общем я думаю многие кто играл в эту игру понимают о чем я.

Смерть персонажей, и вообще вся система брони, хп и обороны. Если выш персонаж вдруг потерял во время боя более 80% брони - он скорее всего умрет до выздоровления в 3 случаях из 5, если его вынесли с поля - он умрет в 8 из 10 случаев. Это как-то слишком жестко, даже хилеры не помогают, шанс того что у тебя умрет персонаж - просто дико огромен, учитывая насколько рандомно и трудно появляются новые персонажи. 
У меня при 3х пастбищах и 3х капустных полях за 100-130 ходов добавилось от силы 3-5 взрослых персонажей и несколько детей. Дети же взрослеют тоже по рандому и бывает это происходит очень редко. Добавьте сюда ещё и события на добавление ран персонажам, события на убийство одного из персонажей, события на удаление нескольких детей и получится что смерть каждого из персонажей очень ощутима, а происходит это довольно часто, даже если ты неплохо освоил механики. Это конечно заставляет тебя беречь их, но это также и становится причиной перезапуска игры, если у тебя осталось 3-4 персонажа в живых, то как бы всё, тебе проще начать сначала, чем 200 ходов восстанавливать до дефолтного размера экспедиции в 6 человек и 3х в деревне.

В общем - игра хорошая, интересная, своих денег стоит, но можно было бы сделать удобнее, юзерфрендли так сказать и в целом выжать из идеи больше.

31922476.review: This game soon became boring to me.

31920961.review:
Thea has a lot of good ideas and could be an absolute lovely game, if it wasn't for the so called "rogue-like"-factor.
I tried some rogue-like games but i wouldn't consider this one rogue-like, it's just random and not fair.
This game wants to be rogue-like by generating randomly occuring events which can be good or bad for you. But what's the point in this if you can just reload whenever you get a bad outcome?
What finally killed this game for me: I left my village unattended (did that several times before, without something happening), then suddenly i got the message that some slave driver is passing by and i should better watch them, with suddenly some group of random npc appearing nearby my village out of nowhere (!) and i lost the game straight away and when that happens the game just deletes you save file so you can't reload anymore after losing. Furthermore, i didn't even get an information what lost me the game so at first i was totally confused and angry. I searched the internet for the problem and it seems that this happened to several people before. The devs even responded to some of those and considered to add a message at the end of game to let the player know his village was conquered. This was 2015. Now it's 2017 and they didn't change anything. Same for the suggestion of some kind of "easy-mode" where you wouldn't have those rogue-like elements, but the devs don't seem to care for this. They have different difficulties, without save-options on higher ones so why not make an easier difficulty with multiple save-options and possibility to reload after losing? It's frustrating to get to learn the game, forge relationships to your people, name them and then lose everything. If you don't want this suggested easy-mode, at least tell the player that they don't have the possibilty to reload after losing and don't suggest you can always reload by implementing such a function at all.
To sum it up i played 12 hours for straight up nothing. Some would say you gain some points with the god you chose for that playthrough but i don't consider this a meaningful progress for such an investment of time. This game needs too much investment of time to be a rogue-like. If you end up with nothing after lots of hours i don't consider this "rogue-like", i consider this a "design flaw".

I read a negative review that summed that up quite well: Thea is a marathon and a rogue-like, two things that don't go together well.

What makes all this even more disastrous: When i searched for the reason i lost, i always read some posts (even of the devs) where they said "Well, the game is rogue-like [...]", BUT: For my languague (German) it doesn't say so on the shop page! There's a translation error where they translated "the tension and grit of a rogue-like" with "der Spannung und dem Schneid eines Schurken". The information that the game is rogue-like is straight up lost here! This is a no-go!

TL;DR: If you want to invest lots of hours into a game and if you can live with the fact that all your investment can straight up end in a sudden randomized lose, buy this. If you don't, don't buy it. And be careful with store page descriptions in different languages.

31869276.review:
Thea ist ein sehr liebevoll gestaltetes... Rollen-Rundenstrategie-Spiel, wenn ich dafür einen Namen erfinden müsste. Als ich es gekauft habe wusste ich nicht ganz, was mich erwartet, und nun hat es mich schon über 20 Stunden gefesselt.. und ein Ende ist noch nicht in sicht. Ich bin angenehm überrascht.

Zu Beginn sollte ich jedoch erwähnen, dass ich das Spiel auf Englisch spiele. 

[u]Spielidee:[/u]
Die Idee ist wirklich einzigartig und innovativ, und wirkt insgesamt wie eine sehr gut gelungene Mischung aus Spielen verschiedener Genre. Sowas in der Art habe ich bisher noch nicht gesehen, auch wenn mich natürlich einige Aspekte von Thea an Spiele wie z.B. Heroes of Might & Magic erinnern. Jedoch geht Thea einen völlig eigenen Weg und ist eigentlich nicht damit zu vergleichen.
~
Ebenso innovativ finde ich das Strategie-Kartenspiel, über welches sämtliche "Herausforderungen", egal ob Kampf oder Wortgefecht, bestanden werden müssen. Natürlich ist dies Geschmackssache. Und so wird dieses "Mini-Spiel" den Einen oder Anderen sicher irgendwann langweilen. Doch finde ich es  ok. 
[b](8/10 Punkte)[/b]

[u]Story:[/u]
Die Story bzw. die vielen Stories sind einfach nur super und haben mir Momente des Staunens, der Heiterkeit und des Mitfieberns beschert. Man merkt deutlich, dass die Entwickler in die Geschichten viel Liebe gesteckt haben. Und für die Lesefaulen ist fast alles vertont. Natürlich kommt es, wie bei vielen Spielen mit frei generierten Karten, auch Mal zu Wiederholungen. Doch passiert dies dank der Fülle an Geschichten nicht so häufig. Zudem bietet das Spiel einen Eventeditor, mit dem man sogar selbst neue Begegnungen designen kann.

Wie oben bereits erwähnt spiele ich es auf Englisch. Ich weiß nicht ob auf Deutsch die Geschichten und deren Vertonung genauso gut sind. 
[b](10/10 Punkte)[/b]

[u]Grafik und Sound:[/u]
Die Grafik... Nun die Grafik im Spiel ist ansich nichts besonderes. Das Spiel selbst ist schlicht aber übersichtlich. Der Fokus liegt eindeutig NICHT auf tollen Effekten sondern mehr auf den Geschichten der Begegnungen. Die für diese Geschichten beigestellten Bilder sind aber künstlerisch hochwertig und erinnern mich irgendwie an Dixit, falls das jemanden was sagt.
Der Sound ist auch ok, wenn auch nichts besonderes. 
[b](5/10 Punkte)[/b]

[u]Bugs und Gameplay:[/u]
Das Spiel läuft bei mir bisher ohne Probleme. Bugs sind mir nicht aufgefallen. Das einzige was ich hier noch anmerken möchte ist das Speichern-Lade-System. Man hat, abgesehen vom Autosave jede Runde, nur einen Speicherplatz. Das macht das Spiel etwas anspruchsvoller, aber mich persönlich stört das ein wenig. Ist aber Geschmackssache. 
[b](8/10 Punkte)[/b]

[u]Preis/Leistung:[/u]
Man bekommt für sein Geld ordentlich was geboten. Wenn man wie ich, gute Geschichten und Rundenstrategie mag, erwarten einen viele viele Stunden Spielzeit. Thea ist die 20 Euro definitiv Wert. Ich habe schon viele Flopps erlebt und so manche Euros verschwendet. Aber bei Thea ist der Preis definitiv fair und gerechtfertigt.
[b](10/10 Punkte)[/b]


[b][u]Fazit:[/u]
Ein super Spiel und für jeden zu empfehlen, der Spiele wie Hereos of Might & Magic, Master of Orion, Magic the Gathering oder einfach nur gute Kurzgeschichten mag.[/b]

31838263.review:
This is an interesting one.  The world has been buried in darkness, and evil stalks the land - all the usual stuff.
Now the light is coming back, and it's your job to lead your little village to safety, and bring back the power of your chosen god.

You've got a population of around a dozen people. Some will stay at the village and gather/build, and some will roam the world getting into all sorts of trouble. You can have multiple groups of wanderers. 

You can't get new villages, but you can upgrade your own.

Graphically it's quite like the later Civilisation games. The music has a nice Eastern European feel, but it can grate on you a bit after a while.  The whole game feels a little bit like you're playing in the same world as The Witcher, to be honest... but that's likely just due to the similarities in settings.

As you progress, your roaming forces will encounter things in the wild. You'll fight creatures, engage in 'decision-events' where you choose a course of action, and complete missions. This all advances your own skills, finds you new equipment, and improves the power of your god.   

The game has a research tree which - while fairly sparse - is a lot more than I was expecting.  Crafting is basic but fairly robust.

I didn't like the combat model.  Essentially each of your 'troops' is represented by a card. You have three attackers and three supporters. You place your cards down one at a time... your support cards can confuse an enemy, attack from afar, remove them from the enemy's deck, and so forth. Your attackers simply attack.   Each card, basically, has an attack score and a 'health' score. 

Honestly, I would have preferred to move pieces around tactically. The card system - while relatively easy to pick up, and nuanced in and of itself - is a bit jarring, to be honest, and breaks the immersion somewhat. It's like you've just dashed into a clearing to kill some vicious skeletons, and you all decide to play a couple of hands of poker to see who gets their heads chopped off.

However, Thea: The Awakening is otherwise a decent, fun, and deeper-than-expected game. It's worth it - certainly if the game is on special - particularly if you like the Eastern European feel.

31808226.review:
This game was one of those games that made it on and of my wishlist. I eventually bought it when it was on sale (for a very reasonable price) and started playing.

I like turn based games because they have this nice mix of tactical play with a casual speed (you never get 'overrun' like in RTS's) and have played a few in that genre (Age of Wonders being one of my favorites).

This game has seriously surpised me (in a good way). It has a lot more depth then you'd expect from a game like this. Especially the combat. That was were this game got my full attention and were I was very, very happy with. Because combat is more like a game inside the game that even could be a game on itself! Combat is done via a tactical card game where every character in your party is either used as offence or tactical cards. The offence cards are the cards that are played for fighting and the tactical crads use their abilities to change the board.

But you do not 'fight' all the time. Fights can also be social encounters, tactical battles, magical hex-breaking fights and many more. And here is were it gets that depth. Every character has its own traits that are suitable for any of those encounters, so mixing up your roaming party-members is very enjoyable.

And then there are all the items you can get which improve certain traits, and then there are all the random encounters that can be played out in many different ways.

And also... the storyline is interesting and very funny at times (when you put a reference to Monthy Python's Quest for the Holy Grail in an encounter you won me over big time...).

Only concern is that the campaign is not easy to finish and you will need quite a lot of time to get to an ending. This makes some of the enounters a bit repetitive.

But overall, yes, this game is worth your time if you like the turn-based RPG's with a nice touch on the combat mechanic.

(I nominated it for a 'Fall Award: Even better then I expected'

Poor balance kinda ruined it for me. A level 1 spider hits you for 4 damage, a level 3 mob might hit you for 30 damage, but your level 4 warrior hits for 17. You end up with weird battles. One hex you just mindlessly click buttons to win a battle and the next hex over has enemies that one-shot kill your party that you just spent the last 70 turns role-playing.

 Most turns are slow paced and directionless, clearing low level mobs that have no chance of hurting you, then you get attacked by a party that one hits you and forces you to re-start. End up being boring, knowing that your choices dont matter.

*Edit 1 Another thing that grinds my gears the battle system. I generally hate card based games, because it seems like you are wasting so much computing power trying to copy something that you do in real life (handle cards with little pictures drawn on them) only BECAUSE YOU DONT HAVE THE COMPUTING POWER TO DO IT BETTER. So you are using a computer to simulate handling cards when in real life you dont want to handle cards. You only use cards because you dont have a computer. It makes no sense... I digress. 

Thea's card based system does work for fighting battles. You just have to think, "ok these are my support classes", "this is really a dodge", "this is really a block", "ok, card order is initiative", and so on. Basically re-inventing the wheel, but it works. 

What seems down right wrong is that the game copies it's battle card system and uses it for everything else. Want to pull a sword from a stone ("physical challenge") it runs that exact same "battle" system with cards but changes your stats based on physical stats and not on your combat stats. Instead of the cards showing the enemies attacking you, it shows a generic card (chess piece) and you still use the same sorts of moves you would in a real battle. It represents you over coming the physical challenge, in battle form. Same goes for "intelligence challenges". YOU FIGHT A BATTLE WITH CARDS. Very un-creative and feels like they rushed the game and didnt bother to think up anything better.

The worst part of all, and the part that really makes it seem like a wrong decision to use card battles for everything, is that glancing at your characters it is hard to tell how good they will be a certain task. The UI and game in general gives you a good idea about the combat strength of your characters. You have a damage value on your character screen - one guy has a 32 another guy has a 11. Ok the guy with 11 is going to be worse in combat. Ui is clear on that. When you go into an "intelligence challenge" the card battle is based on other stats but it is not clear. If you look at the damage value for those same two guys in this new intellegence challenge the first guy might have a damage value of 5 and the other guy, who is smarter but worse in combat, will have a damage value of 14. Before I knew that the game just copies the battle system for all of the challenges, I though I had clicked on the wrong button...

*Edit 2 Another thing that bother me about this game is how tacked on the village and camp portions of the game seems. Leading an expedition and having an adventure is 99.9999% of the game, the village and camp part shouldnt have been added. You village is only allowed ten buildings (which you can tear down to build others), but once you build your ten buildings, your resources just start piling up and there is no use for the resources. Maybe is it just bad game balance.

 For example, I "gather" mushrooms near my village, I get 14 mushrooms per turn. If you build a field (as one of my ten building limit), the field allows you to harvest 1 mushroom. Thats right, just 1. A sinlge guy wandering in the woods can harvest 14x TIMES AS MANY MUSHROOMS. The only reason I could see to send out a harvesting party ("expedition") was to gather rarer food items so I could cook other dishes. By turn 80 or so I was playing it as a cooking mini-game, because there is nother else to do. By turn 90 or so, I had 150 turns worth of food and 200 turns of fuel (or some thing like that). This game really should have been made as a mobile game.

31756033.review:
Thea is a never ending bedtime story.  Mechanically, it's a really interesting mixture of a lighter version of Gwent and a strategy RPG.  A lot of the game is randomized, and with that, there are a lot of curve balls that come at you and force you to change how you're playing the game.  That means that on top of the well written and pleasantly voice acted stories that are scripted into the game, the more potent drama often comes from emergent content.  

For example, you might find yourself in a situation where your food stores have been wiped out in an event, so you have to send some people into exile from your village to die so that the rest have a chance at surviving long enough to forage.  So you death march them off to fight an impossible boss, and against all odds they win, and can come back to the village with enough meat, berries and rare loot to save everyone.

It's also a very unobtrusive game.  You can keep it in windowed mode, and it uses very few resources, so it's easy to take a break between turns, get some work done, and then pick up where you left off a few hours later.  The music serves as very pleasant background, and I've actually let it run overnight on accident a couple times because of how soothing it is.

I've completed the main campaign twice and failed it three times.  A full playthrough takes about 10 hours, but each time you unlock a new character, which changes the story slightly and presents different content and playstyle options.  Highly recommend this lovely, fun, relaxing game.

31722257.review:
Игра напомнила мне The Darkest Dungeon в худшем смысле. Не механикой, а тем, что игровой процесс также держится на двух столпах - рандоме и бесконечном фарме и дрочeвe. 

Сюжет. Он банален, абсурден и неинтересен. И за бесконечной карточной дрочильнeй напросто забываешь, что в игре есть какая-то высшая цель, а не банальная зачистка карты. Просто читать бестиарий в ведьмаке было гораздо интересенее, чем тексты местных квестов. Самих квестов мало, ролевая составляющая слабая.

Механика. Разработчики делали игру с оглядкой на множество жанров, добавили много возможностей, но каждая подобная фича реализована посредственно.

Карточная игра. Поначалу мне понравилась, но через 20 часов наскучила настолько, что блевать захотелось. 
Представьте себе шахматы, в которых расстановка фигур исключительно рандомная, как и направление движения. Представили? Когда у вас в начале игры сильный Ферзь будет прятаться за немощным Королем, а можно ли будет пойти фигурой вперед или назад будет также зависеть от воли случая. Вам по душе такие шахматы? Мне нет.

Статы персорнажей. Их много - это хорошо. Если сразу не отпугнуло, то захочется разобраться. Но все статы с прокачкой распределяются рандомно! И это ставит крест на развитии, когда ты абсолютно никак не можешь контролировать развитие отряда, только слегка бафнуть нужные характеристики шмотом.

Развитие деревни. И сказать нечего. Типов строений меньше десятка, вляиние строение на геймплей назначительное.

Крафт. Он есть и хорошо проработан. Подбирая компоненты, ты видишь как меняются характеристики конечного продукта. Разработчики также не поленились нарисовать отдельную иконку для каждой комбанации, написать отдельное описание. Это понравилось.

Случайные события. Их совсем не много, они банальные и сделаны под копирку, не ставят никакого сложного выбора перед игроком. 

Игровой мир. Враги спавнятся в любом место в любое время - чувствуется как убогая копипаста варваров в циве. Только если в циве ты зачистил лагерь варваров, то ты можешь спокойно отправлять рабочих. Здесь же может откуда не возмись снова появится паучье гнезно или еще какая зараза. Поэтому и бегаешь по карте туда-обратно.

Все свое недовольство выражать не буду. В игре доступна демо версия, каждый может пропробывать и сделать свои собственные выводы перед покупкой.

31703944.review:
Вся игра это начало любой компании в Civilization V, когда у тебя есть только один город и один юнит, которым ты разведываешь местность, плюс к этому тут есть текстовые квесты, которые заканчиваются убогим карточным боем. В общем не зацепила, совсем. Далее по пунктам.
[list]
    [*]Главный для меня недостаток, это карточная боевка (я принципе не люблю карточные игры, Hand of Fate исключение пожалуй, и то там боевка в 3D), так как почти все события, будь то «охота» на кабанов или дипломатия решаются при помощи карточной игры, которая мне надоела уже на третий раз, а если их пропускать, то пропадает большой кусок основного геймплея.
    [*]Нельзя самому выбрать место где основать поселение. Соответственно нужно рутинно бегать вокруг поселения и добывать ресурсы. Либо пересоздавать игру в надежде, что рядом появятся стоящие ресурсы.
    [*]Город только один и как я понял без возможности расширения его границ. Можно конечно строить лагеря, но все равно все сводится к ручному управлению. Было бы неплохо если бы ресурсы за городом добывались автоматически как в Civ5.
    [*]Нет ощущения экспедиции, как например в Expeditions: Conquistador. Просто ходим юнитами по карте и раскрывает туман войны, а добытые ресурсы сносим в город.
    [*]Боги, уровень, которых прокачивается только от проигрыша. Если бы была опция проиграть игру нажатием на кнопку, что конвертировалось бы в опыт, или бы уровень прокачивался по мере игры, то проблем бы не было, а так мне просто не нравиться эта идея.
    [*]Огромное количество статов у каждого персонажа, которые улучшаются сами по себе при повышении уровня. Я просто забил на это. Какой смысл следить за ними, если ты никак не можешь сам их изменить с новым уровнем.
    [*]Может кому-то это и по душе, но мне совсем не нравится одевать каждого крестьянина в городе.
    [*]Из совсем субъективного, я совсем не понимаю, что помешало сделать заполнение ячеек крафта, сбора и предметов инвентаря, по двойному клику на предмете. Приходится каждый раз перетаскивать с удержанием левой кнопки мыши. На тачскрине это бы было нормально, но тут это напрягает.
[/list]
Иными словами эта игра – гринд и рутина (что в принципе одно и тоже), за исключением интересных текстовых квестов. В общем – на любителя.

Так что если хотите поиграть в симулятор поселения, то лучше взять [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/242920/Banished/]Banished[/url] и [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/328080/Rise_to_Ruins/]Rise to Ruins[/url].
Если хочеться юнитами исследовать большие карты в пошаговом режиме, развивать города и нормальной тактической боевки, то есть [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/8930/Sid_Meiers_Civilization_V/]Civilization V[/url], [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/203630/Warlock__Master_of_the_Arcane/]Warlock - Master of the Arcane[/url], [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/228260/Fallen_Enchantress_Legendary_Heroes/]Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes[/url] и [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/237430/Expeditions_Conquistador/]Expeditions: Conquistador[/url].

31703917.review: I found it way too micro management-oriented, and didn't like the card combat system.

31698847.review:
TLDR
They took like 5 different genres and managed to squish em together into a really well done masterpiece! I give Thea: The Awakening a solid 5 outta 5!

Full Version
If you like dark fantasy, turn base games, tactics, cRPG style gear management and immersive mini choose your own adventure then chances are you will enjoy this.

The pace is slow. You manage a single village and send expeditions out to gather resources and do encounters around the map. Each game is unique because its randomly generated and the quest events you may or may not see are picked based on what tile they occur in and time of day and distance from map and many other factors... also there are many hundreds!

When you play a game you pick which deity your village is aligned to. All the xp you get in that game goes toward a passive tree for the god you played: play more with 1 god and your worshipers will be a bit better! Think of it like how FTL is a rouge-like but there's goals to work toward for unlocking new ships. Its a very enjoyable system! Rouge-likes and most 4x style games that don't have a point other then 'win or loose' don't intrest me so much. This one does it right!

Every combat encounter or skill check, such as tying to search an ancient library for any tomes you might have use of, is based on a card game. It was confusing to me at first but after some time I have it mostly figured out. The card game itself is fun and your cards are all based on various stats. Its very very well done.

But what I enjoy best is the random events and quests. The free DLC makes most of them narrated. They are written and voiced quite well. The graphics are just fine. Hand drawn art is good. Music is fantatsic. Crazy replay value. Non-liniar sandbox style game in that you can largely play the way you like within the game's ruleset: stay in your village and build up slow and safe or be a gathering/ crafting settlement... there's quite a few ways to mix and match playstyles.

Note: my friend owed me some money and when I saw this on sale for $9.99 USD I asked them to gift it to me (after I did some research on it). HIGHLY worth $10... heck its worth $20 easily. Three free DLC and there's even some player mods to add more events!

Now for the imperfections: Parts of the UI is clunky at times, such as adding resources to an expedition. I wish there were keyboard shortcuts for some common elements in the card game screen. While the in-game help menu is extensive its not explained very well in a few places so I felt newbish and had to bumble through some things till they clicked in my noodle. Some of the events do not offer many choices, just 'tell me more' and a 'okay' and 'goodbye.' I feel they should have made more dialouge paths for the smaller events. Fixable, but I should mention that I had to dramatically lower the music to make the narration intelligable. I am a bit over critical when it omes to gaming, though. The flaws I found were small compared to the whole package.

I would not recomend this to younger gamers who play action RPGs and FPS games. This is slow, tactically thought provocing and a story game. To those who play table-top RPGs I'll say tis game FEELS like its own self contained PnP campaign, though condensed. There's just a lot that can happen :)

Pros

31652179.review:
4X, PVE, RPG, turn based, Roguelight, Survival, startegy. 
Let me break this down. 
You explore, explote, ect ect. PVE since you don't fight other players or npcs. Then what is the point? With ever growing odds that you can change yourself you fight off ever spawning monsters that come to raid your village. On top of having to manage food grathering rates along with other items -for the most part using them to make weapons, armor, shields and buildings. Each /peon/ is a scaled down RPG char that you build up to be a beefy monster, or depending on their class since a gather should not be doing 9999 damage in most cases. When vary complex and fun. The issues is to figure it out with out failing at lest a few runs. This game have you covered though. With every game you get XP based on how well you did. You use this Xp to level up your god.

What is your god? Your god gives you special actions in the random events with quite a few making challanges either easier or flat out ignoring bad random effects with no skill check but this is vary rare. For the most part where you will see the most use is the mission for your god which is the same challanges for every god but gives a fat chunk of XP when done. When you level up you get buffs like +1 to this stat for every villager you have ect ect. After 5 levels you max them out and get really nice buffs with them that make future games with that god much, much easier.  Which is where the roguelight comes into play. 

I personally don't enjoy every 4X that I own but this one is quite frankly one of the funner ones even if I personally class this as a Surival game that you build up to being able to do well regardless of the bad things that will be thrown your way.

31382576.review:
I'm about 12 hours into this game, and I felt I had to comment about it.  It's very unique in that it blends together a number of gameplay elements from different games, and pushes forward some new ones of its own.  I would have to describe this as a "4X Survival" game.  The closest comparison I can think of is playing a game of Civilization (or, more appropriately, Endless Legend) with only 1 city element to deal with, while also mixing in a top-down RPG feel.

Oh, I don't know if the game is based on "Slavic mythology" exactly, but the names and themes feel very Slavic in presentation.  I consider this a big plus because it's a mythos that I haven't been exposed to much, and it's a twist on your standard elves and dwarves fantasy trope.  The art style is fresh to me, and no part of the game feels like a rehash of something else (aside from, you know, they have swords and stuff :D )

Games that I think inspired this game:  Master of Magic (ancient Microprose game), Age of Wonder, Endless Legend, Civilization, XCOM

I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys 4X games (Xplore, Xpand, Xploit, Xterminate), top-down RPGs, big picture strategy games, and turn-based games in general.

Thank you MuHa games, and I hope to buy future games from you.


Update after 120 hours in:  I've really enjoyed this game much more than your typical 4X game.  There is a lot of replayability because everything in the game is random, and each "god" you choose has traits that will shape the way you run your village.  This is the first 4X I've played that has an element of developing your meta-avatar between games, so each game you play "means" something besides just your score.  It's not a major element, though, so the full game is accessible with only one or two plays, but anyone, like me, who gets really into it will find some meat to chew on here.

My only wish would be to be able to buy more events via DLCs. 

All that being said, I highly recommend this game if you enjoy slower paced strategy games with an element of surprise.

31309936.review:
Thea这个游戏是个建立在西方奇幻世界观的基础上，借鉴了一些DND元素的4x游戏，你控制一个村子的所有村民进行跑团。

但是整个游戏还是偏向探索和跑团的感觉，发展的要素还是相当的少——
——资源可替代性强
——不能建立新的聚居地
——打出来的装备（尤其是高难度的挑战）可能比你花心思并且SL出高质量的还好
——小地图有很多资源会没有，地图大了把资源运回村子又很麻烦（所以为什么不能建立新的村子啊喂！）

值得一提的是这个游戏的战斗（或者说检定）系统。
村民有很多乱七八糟的属性，会在各种不同的场合派上用场。比如战斗能力用在普通战斗上，力量用在力量对抗，破门等事件，反应等用在逃脱事件，智力用在说服和机关等等。
所有的战斗（检定）事件你的村民都会变成一张卡，只有跟检定相关的能力会直接变成战斗力，你需要做的就是合理安排村民的出场顺序或支援效果。
刚开始可能会感觉有点迷，熟悉设定了以后还是感觉挺有意思的。
而且多数事件都会根据你队伍里人物的情况开放一些新的分支选择（这就是说为什么更像跑团）

这游戏还有双人模式，然而并没有人跟我一起玩_(:з)∠)_

目前来说感觉这个游戏的内容还是很少，不过这游戏要出2了，表示期待。

Неплохая пошаговая стратегия/ролевая игра. Под нашим (божественным) управлением деревня с группой жителей. Развиваем, одеваем, вооружаем их - и вперед - бороться с врагами Теи. Каждый житель уникален, терять его в боях нежелательно и обидно, восполнить потерю может быть не так просто.
