31153680.review:
Мой первый взгляд на игру был приправлен изрядной долей разочарования из серии: И вот на это я потратил деньги?
В глаза сразу бросилось изображение. Картинка на стратегической карте замыленная и не детализированная. Объекты слабо анимированы и не отличаются большим разнообразием. Потом я столкнулся с непонятной на первый взгляд карточной системой поединков. А я совсем не фанат карт. Долго разбирался, какие параметры на что влияют и в каких событиях. Короче, освоение было скорее трудным, чем приятным...
Но, вы знаете, господа, оно того стоило!
Доска для испытаний сделана отлично! Шикарные рисунки на картах! Довольно много событий, написанных нормальным русским языком! В меру адекватный рандом, который внезапно не убивает 2-3 часа реального времени в прокачке, разнося сильную команду исследователей в щепки. Гибкий подход к прохождению испытаний, который зависит от состава команды: Есть охотники - попробуй поохотиться, есть знатоки яда - отрави, есть вошебники - околдуй, ну или просто дай дубиной по репе - выбор только за тобой! Еще раз повторю: Рандом есть, его довольно много, но он не дико нагибучий. Игра дружелюбна к игроку: В текстах заданий есть подсказки, как его выполнить и какой командой это выгоднее сделать. К балансу у меня в целом тоже нет никаких замечаний.
Огромное спасибо разработчикам! Игра получилась на твердую хорошую четверку с плюсом: Добротно, крепко, со вкусом, но, на мой взгляд, подкачал графон. С нетерпением жду продолжения и DLC!

31065737.review:
The game is very different from others games I have played. You have a village with some people starting in it, and a group of people who you can use to explore, hunt, fight and gather. All "challenges" (which are not just fights, but also other things like diplomacy or sickness, which use other attributes) are turn-based combat regulated simply by the order of characters you and your enemy engage.

There is also a research component that can be advanced via crafting, for which you need to claim or gather resources. Researching helps you get better resources, buildings and crafting possibilities. In the end, you want one (or maybe even more) large group of well equipped humans/orcs/elves or whatever you managed to get on your side, to finish either the regulary story quest or the giant's quest, both leading to victory. There is also an "advancement" victory but it requires grinding to unlock, if you play on the highest difficulty.

The game is mostly fun due to the mix of characters you can get, due to the crafting, the village improvement, the randomness of the world and most of all the great amount of events and options during these.

I greatly enjoyed the game for the following reason:
+ True grimdark
+ Great setting
+ Lots of random events that keep things alternating, the choices in the events depend on your party member's skills and the writing and flavour is great in them
+ Crafting is fun
+ Love the characters and that you can get orcs, goblins, dwarves, even rats on your side
+ Awesome beginning of the game and awesome mid-game.
+ Good story, although I feel like it was not as captivating as it could have been. A lot of yadda yadda.
- End game becomes very repetitive, a bit imbalanced (too easy & too hard) and a bit lacking
- Victory is too quick and easy once you know the game, it feels like there are greater challenges in the game than the victory itself
- Gaining experience seems to do very little, in the end you replace your beginning characters, which you kept alive with so much energy, by better ones you attract through buildings or events.

30990409.review: Really enjoyed this game. It lends well to thinking of the individual lives you control. They are represented as 'cards' but have so many stats that is more like an RPG game. 30957944.review:
This game is a gem, not only due to its originality, but its immersive nature. A long time ago I played an old magic the gathering game called shangri-la. While the card and deck building aspect can't stack up to the complexity of Magic the Gathering, the seamless blend between deck building and base building is fantastic.  

While I strongly recommend this game, its only down side (and it is not that much of a downside) is replayability. The game encourages you to replay again and again, to unlock bonus feats that allow you to play at higher difficulty levels which in turn make the card game part of the game more strategic, however by the time you have replayed it three times (approx. 70 hours ish), very similar to when you have replayed FTL a few times (although they do mix them up a bit) you know the best choices for almost all the random stories and the best card/group combos, so it all gets a bit repetitive.

Even then, similar to  FTL, I can see myself brushing off this game in 3 to 6 month time, and playing it through again. It's that good.

I can’t wait for the sequel.

30881536.review:
This would be great game if it was made properly. However, besides the concept/idea, it doesn't offer anything too special. Graphics are ok, gameplay is ok, combat system seems a bit random and interfaces (such as inventory, village management and so on) are old fashioned and laborous to use.

The game also seems to use "rubber band" what comes to difficulty. Basically, you get punished if you play well and you get bonuses when you play badly. I can somewhat accept this for some genres (e.g. racing games), but for RPG strategy game this is basically deal breaker for me.

30826044.review:
Intriguing game, some great aspects, good graphics, top down camera view, card based combat.
Extremely difficult ramping vs time played ( occassional disastrous events ) even on easiest settings. Just trying to get healed of some small sickness pits your 5 to 18 'hitpoint' 5 to 12 'damage' squad agains some 30 'hitpoint' 15 'damage' plus some lower minions. No way to win and so you can't really get healed. Alt+F4 healed them fine.

Now if you get lucky enough to avoid the nastiest curses-sicknesses, you can gather enough resources to make your population able to get to the end. Just be prepared to lose a game now and then.

Overall, the challenge is sometimes out of what I consider a good range, but then again it makes winning much sweeter. So considering everything I've learned in the somewhat low ( for me ) game time played, I am recommending this game.

30760010.review:
Positives:
- Unique feeling 4x game.
- High early enjoyability.
- Easy to learn.
- There is a nice juicy plot and backstory if you enjoy that. If you don't they are easy to skip. Well done.
- No game impacting bugs for single player (there are definately a few exploits, but this isn't a multiplayer game, so you'd only be cheating youself out of fun).
- I enjoyed the Slavic pantheon, a nice change from seeing Zues, Thor, or Ra in every freaking game under the sun.

Negatives:
- Replayability is limited as each god doesn't feel unique enough. Also you are punished for trying all the gods and play styles because the level up mechanism on Gods requires you to only play that god or you don't get enough exp to have it hit level 5. I found the god level up system to be very poorly designed. I feel like if they released a good patch to the God mechanics I'd easily call this a $40 game, as it stands though the price is reasonable because it turns into a grinding game after about the first 50 hours of game play. That said, $20 for 40-50 hours of enjoyment is a fair cost.
- The different challenges (social, physical, hex, etc.) all have the same combat system. This makes it so that if you go for a different team composition, it still feels like the same play style. I'd recommend they shoot for fewer challenge types with more uniqueness to each type of combat.
- The game is definately more fun with less villagers as you don't have to manage as much equiptment juggling and you don't end up with surplus workers and crafters that you end up assigning busy work to. The default 10 villager start style should probably not be an option as it is a superior game with 9 or 7 villager starts.

30756266.review: One of best game for my opinion this year. Congratulations

30729869.review:
Thea: The Awakening is a hard game to define. It has elements of survival, card based combats, crafting, a deep narrative like an RPG, it uses procedural generation and has permanenth death, like a roguelike game. If you summarize all this, it would be correct to say that Thea is a "4X Roguelike" game, as these are the most apparent characteristics. Just like a 4X game, you'll need to explore, expand, search for exploits and exterminate to win. 

This is a cautious recommendation though. Thea is not a game for anyone, and even the most persistent will need to be patient while learning some tricks. Despite the simple mechanics and the robust tutorial, this game has a rather high learning curve. There are several times when the player finds himself in a seemingly impossible situation, even in the easiest difficulty setting, and it will take a good deal of strategy. If you're willing to be patient and experiment enough to know how to deal with each situation, Thea will become more and more enthralling.

Based on Slavic mythology, Thea tells a tale of a cursed world, and it's up to you to rebuild it before it collapses. Even using random elements, such as more than 100 missions and differentiated quests, there are some passages that are always the same and must be completed with each game to achieve victory. These passages are special missions that give continuity to the narrative, and there are several different endings for the player to discover, which increases the replayability. 

The gameplay basically has three pillars: collect, craft/ build and battle; Everything is done in your village and also during expeditions that you send to clear dungeons and complete objectives. There are several classes available, and you can choose the focus of your village when you start the game. Would you rather have more gatherers than warriors? Or it's better to focus on medics? Either way, whatever your focus is, the game distributes the classes well, and soon your village can have all of them; The focus you have chosen will increase the chances of a child growing up to become a chosen class when it reaches adulthood. Well, these three pillars are equally important, although it's possible to create a slightly more inclined strategy for some of them. Food and wood must be collected to support the population, and it's necessary to craft armor, items and weapons to equip your people, so they will be able to perform well in battles.

Speaking of battles, there are nine types of battles in the game. It's not necessary to resolve conflicts only in fights, but also in discussions (social challenges), challenges of strength, cure of diseases, among others. Each character class has the most accented skills in some aspect that will be useful for each different conflict. For instance, warriors are exceptional in fights and strength challenges, but on the other hand they can't cure sickness like medics, who are also good at social challenges. All these types of battles are resolved in a very strategic card game that was developed by people (from MuHa Games) who created Gwent, the card game of The Witcher 3, which recently became a game on its own. This system is easy to learn, but I'll tell you a detail that is not mentioned in the tutorial: Determining which card will be attacked (left or right) is done randomly, with a 50% chance of being left and 50% of being right. If there's a card between two cards, it can attack any of them, but if the card is the first card on the table, it will always attack the front card, just as the last card at the table will always attack the back card. With that in mind it is much easier to plan your strategy, since we have to take into account the two closest cards instead of just leaving a card with more health points always ahead, for example.

Although it can be considered a 4X game, the expansion aspect is not taken here in the traditional approach of this genre. This means it's not possible to settle or conquer new villages, and you will fight only against monsters, not other civilizations. The expansion in Thea is done at the population level. Gradually new children will born in your village, and every turn there's a chance to this child become an adult. It's not possible to interfere in this, but it's possible to build constructions that can attract more (already adult) people to your village, in addition to being able to attract some creatures to join you too. There's also no way to know when your character will level up. Extreme randomness, incidentally, is a watershed in Thea. It significantly increases the replay value, making each match unique, but on the other hand it can generate impossible situations, such as the fact that your village (which always starts at a fixed place that you can't choose) is located in a place that doesn't have food available, requiring restarting.

Thea seems to take the concept of roguelike to the extreme; More than Conquest of Elysium took. The game also adopts the roguelike save system, in which it's not possible to "save scum", all actions are permanent. I understand that this is a game design choice, because it was developed with this challenge in mind, but this makes some mistakes lead a match to its end, because the player will hardly be able to recover from a whole dead expedition by a dragon, for instance. This makes the game extremely brutal for people who are not familiar to games that feature permanent death, which unfortunately can take away a portion of the community that is passionate about RPGs and 4X, which are other strong genres in Thea, and can discourage some people to continue playing. In fact, Thea was made not to be beaten in the first match, even in the easiest difficulty. Each god chosen at the beginning of the game has five levels with buffs, which are unlocked as you accumulate points at the end of each match, even in a game you were defeated. In addition to premade options, you can customize the difficulty the way you want, but notice that even though it will not guarantee victory for a long time, it's a great tool for when you get more experienced and want to add extra challenges.

Thea has received several content patches and free expansions, so you don't have to spend extra money to experience the full game.

[b]Pros[/b]
* Addictive and fun to play
* Great card battle system
* Excellent tutorial
* Remarkable soundtrack
* High replayability
* Narrative very well developed

[b]Cons[/b]
* UI is a bit confusing and unintuitive
* Only one save slot, making it possible to only play one game at a time

30707155.review:
Dieses Spiel ist in meinen Augen eines der besten Spiele der letzten Zeit. Warum das so ist, werde ich gleich erklären.

Das Spiel läuft in teilweise sehr langen Partien ab, zu deren Beginn man sich eine Gottheit der slawischen Mythologie auswählt. Die Wahl der Gottheit bringt einerseits spezifische Vorteile für die eigenen Einheiten, andererseits beeinflusst es auch die Interaktionsmöglichkeiten bei bestimmten Zufallsbegegnungen. Am Anfang stehen nur wenige Götter zur Verfügung, welche sich auch nur auf Level 1 befinden. Durch das Spielen mit diesen Göttern schaltet man allerdings weitere frei, ebenso wie weitere Vorteile bei dem eigenen Gott.
Das Spiel selbst läuft als Rundenstrategie auf einem Feld aus Hexagonen aus. Man kontrolliert ein Dorf und seine Bewohner, welche man als Expeditionen über die Karte laufen, Kämpfe bestreiten und Ressourcen sammeln lassen kann. Zwar werden einem die Optionen anfangs nicht alle erläutert, man bekommt sie aber schnell raus, wenn man ein wenig probiert. Während der Reise kommt es immer wieder zu teils absehbaren, teils völlig zufälligen Begegnungen, welche in Textform (mit englischem Voiceover) erzählt werden. Hierbei bieten sich meistens unterschiedliche Herangehensweisen. Oft werden dadurch entstehende Konflikte durch Prüfungen (Kampf, Sozial, Physisch, Medizin, Magie etc.) gelöst, welche als Kartenspiel, in dem jeder beteiligte Charakter durch eine Karte dargestellt wird, ausgetragen werden. Diese lassen sich bei Bedarf auch überspringen, wodurch man direkt Folgen und etwaige Belohnungen angezeigt bekommt. Hierbei wird die Bevölkerung des Dorfes stärker, schlauer, geschickter usw. und schaltet außerdem Forschungspunkte frei, welche sich für die "Erntbarkeit" neuer Handwerks- und Baumaterialien, als auch neue Handwerksrezepte oder Gebäudepläne ausgeben lassen.
Das Spiel endet an einer von zwei Stellen, sofern man es nicht vorher bereitwillig abbricht, lässt einem aber immer die Gelegenheit, dennoch weiterzuspielen und seinen Spaß mit den Zufallsbegegnungen abseits der Story zu haben. Diese erzählen nämlich häufig ebenfalls sehr interessante, mal lustige, mal traurige Geschichten.
Man sollte jedoch anmerken, dass das Spiel wirklich viel Zeit verschlingt, wenn man bis zum Ende spielt. Ich habe mich ständig dabei ertappt, dass ich nur noch "eine" Runde spielen wollte, aus der dann eine ganze Stunde wurde. Das liegt nicht zuletzt and der malerischen Atmosphäre und angenehmen Musik des Spiels.
Hinzu kommt außerdem ein unglaublich sympathisches Entwicklerteam, welches intensiv auf Vorschläge der Community eingeht und das Spiel stetig kostenlos (!) erweitert.

Ich kann jedem Freund von Rundenstrategie und schön erzählten Geschichten, vielleicht sogar Leuten, die privat gerne Pen-and-Paper für sich entdeckt haben, das Spiel nur wärmstens ans Herz legen.

30697154.review:
В наше время трудно говорить об оригинальности, одни разработчики вдохновляются идеями других, порой добавляют что-то свое и на выходе мы получаем...

[h1]Графика:[/h1]

Не примечательна. Детализация низкая, текстурки смазанные, только арты эвентов и карточки персонажей претендуют на некое очарование.

[h1]Звук:[/h1]

Вполне себе. ОСТ хорошенький, с этаким славянским колоритом, звуки действий нормальные...Выделяется только великолепная озвучка "рассказчика", который озвучивает буквально все)

[h1]Геймплей:[/h1]

Итак...перед нами наша деревня! Существо, скорее похожее на беса начинает вещать - мол, Век Тьмы в самом разгаре, боги покинули земли, а потому нужно нам, простым жителям, каким-то образом выживать. Дальше вполне понятное обучение и полная свобода действий.

За кажущейся простотой скрывается целый вагон интересных механик и тонкостей.

Итак, деревня у нас одна...навсегда. В ней мы можем строить новые здания, дающие определенные плюсы, крафтить снаряжение, готовить пищу...крафт целая комплексная система и о ней скажу позже. Потеря деревни означает проигрыш. 
В деревню мы несем все, что плохо лежит или больше не нужно прошлым владельцам.

Основу нашей ударной силы составляют жители...и да не обманетесь Вы, ибо не только люди могут быть нашими протеже...добавьте сюда гномов, эльфов, гоблинов, демонов, зверей и прочую нечисть. Да-да! Наши знахари, ведуны, воины и прочие...будут жить без вопросов с любой тварью, которую мы умудримся притащить в дом) Впрочем важен скорее не внешний вид тварюшки, а статы...а их в игре огромное количество под разные виды испытаний. Кто-то силен, кто-то умен, кто-то владее магией, а кто-то просто прирожденный ниндзя. Притом каждый навык отвечает сугубо за свою сферу применения. 

Заговорив о статах, следует упомянуть о местной боевой системе! Это очень интересная и хитрая пошаговая карточная игра с большим количеством возможностей, завязанных на параметрах персонажей. Притом боевая система заточена не "только под бой"...она работает для любого испытания! Лучше всего будет посмотреть какой-нибудь ролик, чтобы иметь более четкое представление.

Крафт...очень важный аспект игры. Следует заметить, что крафт сильно завязан на материале. К примеру, можно построить смотровую вышку из костей животных, это приведет к тому, что вышка начнет "привлекать" зверей, а значит в нашем поселении может появиться какой-нибудь дружелюбный волк, медведь или еще какая тварюшка. А можно в основание заложить золото, на которое потянутся гномы...или темное дерево и привет гоблины! 
Похожая ситуация и с крафтом снаряжения, материал очень сильно определяет статы, тут место эксперименту (или походу на вики)!

Последняя часть, которую стоит упомянуть - эвенты! Они условно делятся на 2 вида - нормальные и упоротые. Притом бывают ситуации, когда первые перетекают во вторые и наоборот...К примеру, можно натолкнуться на сапожника, который готов убить сильного дракона, который утащил пару детей из вашей деревни, но потребует в обмен женщину из вашей команды! Какой будет финал? Да там около 6 вариантов развития событий, притом некоторые из них закрыты, если у вашей команды не развит определенный навык. Или же что вы скажете, если некий гном попросит организовать ему свиданку с русалкой?Или...а впрочем, к чему спойлерить)

[h1]Итог:[/h1]

Если Вы не против погрузиться в сказочный мир, где интересно и забавно переплелись славянская мифология и западные сказки, где за внешней простотой скрыты очень интересные механики, требующие времени для понимания!

Желающим сыграть в этакую смесь цивилизации и микро-менеджмента отщепенцев - милости просим сюда!

Я же поставлю 8 из 10. Если Вы сомневаетесь, то посмотрите ролики, оцените неплохой юмор эвентов и интересность боевой системы! А найдется друг, желающий сыграть - можете пойти в мультиплеер!

30694090.review:
While obtuse at first (and second, third, and fourth) and having a couple balance issues, Thea is deep and has a startling number of options to customize your play. The challenge card games that serve it for combat (of many natures, such as social, hunting, magic, as well as actual violence) is pretty decent as well. 

For fans of RPG games who enjoy a dose of complexity, I'd recommend this one.

30684212.review:
Game is a good hex/turn based/survival/empire building/explorer game.

Main focus of the game is to get your characters to level and gear up - foundation of many enjoyable games
Combat results are similar in auto and manual battles. 
You dont have to fight battles manually if you dont want to
Long term goals to work towards
You are continually setting out on new expeditions to explore and gain resources
The expeditions mean you are continually setting new goals and making decisions on what strategies to implement
The story missions are very flexible and you can ignore them to a large extent if you want 
The early game is excellent


CONS:
Many stats are effectively worthless
Loot comes too randomly and frequently. Would much prefer to get less loot that was actually useful. You will dismantle 99% of what you find. Risk/reward is not well balanced.
Random map each time but it  could be done better,
Much Micro-management in outfitting and assigning  your 24+ characters 
End game seems to be  the same on every map - maybe its just my desire to stick to an optimal strategy though

30629354.review:
I've been hunting for a game similar to Heroes of Might and Magic.  I'm not happy with where the franchise is going, so I've been looking for something similar to play.  I've found a few that were pretty cool...  But then I found this.

Thea: The Awakening might be my new favorite in the genre.  It adds a lot of depth, but it is also more manageable.

You have one city to manage.  There are a variety of building upgrades to research/build.  Certain upgrades unlock new classes.  Some provide skill/stat bonuses.  Other upgrades produce resources.  You can build one of each, or you can build multiples, though some effects do not stack.  You are limited to 10 total upgrades, however.

By default, you start with 10 characters.  Each character has a set of skills.  Any character can have any skill, but specific classes develop certain skills faster.  There are three base classes (warrior, craftsman, gatherer), but many additional ones which can be unlocked through building upgrades.  Some characters/classes can be acquired through events/quests, including classes from different races, animals, and monsters.  Your units progress individually, so each one is important.  Losing units hurts.  Spread yourself too thin, and you'll be in serious trouble.

You can assign your characters to groups.  The groups can walk around Thea, gathering resources, killing monsters, or just exploring.  You have to manage each group's food and fuel.  (each character eats 1 food per turn)  You will encounter random events along the way.    More on that soon.

There's a complex crafting & research system.  Crafting gives you research points which you can spend on unlocking new resources, crafting recipes, or building designs for the town.  There are about 3 dozen resources that you can collect. The crafting recipes allow you to arrange the resources in different ways to produce items with stats that you desire.  There are hundreds of combinations for each type of item.  (1h/2h sword, 1h/2h axe, light/medium/heavy armor, rings, etc)

The game's event system relies heavily on RNG, but it's not like FTL, where you're just waiting for the random event that's going to kill you.  Instead, the random events introduce new quests.  Sometimes they hurt you, but they give you the opportunity to recover.  There's almost always more than one way to approach a situation.  It might be the best event system I've seen to date, which is made all the better by...

The fantastic event editor.  You can craft your own events, or download them from the Thea forums.  You can use the event editor to craft your own quests with a variety of paths/outcomes.  It would be nice if they had workshop support.  They are making a sequel...  Perhaps the sequel will have workshop support.

(*There's only one significant problem with the event editor;  You have to exit the game in order for changes to take effect.  I didn't see this documented anywhere.  I found it on a forum.  But I pass it on to you here.)

If you're looking for a game with some similarities to Heroes of Might and Magic, but that puts much more emphasis on unit development (rather than developing one, or a handful of characters) give this game a go.  I highly recommend it.

This isnt a bad game. I want to make that absolutly clear. I dont recommend this game because its just a waste of time and a massive time sink for very little reward. 

Round after round I have gotten attached to my people (after I renamed them and equiped them to the teeth with badass gear) and then the rogue-like aspect to the game kills them off without even a wiff of a fight. Its just enough for you to get attached to some characters just to have them die and break your heart.

I think I spent 50% of this game straight angry as hell, 40% determined beyond reason (once again, no real reward) and 10% bored out of my skull.

Turn after turn I collect these resources across the map with a well equiped watch, just to have some random encounter kill off one of my party members without even getting the chance to defend them. Of course thats if I get enough people to launch this sort of expedition. Normally I am forced to leave my town defended by only 3 or 4 people and they get trapped under a house falling over or something and someone dies. Annnd now there is only 3 to defend against that 3 skull enemy. Great.

One of my games (of which there has been meany) I actually beat two of the quest lines after 250(ish) turns and just shy of 50 hours of play (of which the end sequence said humanity is doomed and I failed). The next game, after 200 turns, i didnt even have 10 villagers at one given moment and every expedition was met with such a resistence that my pathetic human warriors had a lifespan of roughly just 5 turns.

This game is a marathon with a rogue-like core. Two things that do not work together.

To the devs - great game, wouldnt change a thing. Its difficult to the absolute definition of the word. Its just not something Im interested in. I have little time to be pissed off (reality does that just fine) and 70 hours of play has left me scared. I will not soon forget this game and in the end - maybe thats the purpose; Because of that, i cant recommend someone else go through the pain I have. В замечательной Цивилизации III, например, двадцать пять различных ресурсов, хотя при желании их можно было бы сократить до трех.

30518592.review:
Game needs a new title, and I encourage the game Developers and Publisher to consider what I have written here.  

I say that up front, but in fact this game is a hidden gem in the gaming world.  Many may be turned off by the game's name, which is obscure, and/or the female wearing a warrior bra as part of the title page of the Steam Store page that offers Thea for sale.  Publisher - you are losing tons of customers by advertising this game as if you're trying to attract a "dumb" crowd that cares about scantily clad women, when your game is exactly the opposite - this game has as much depth and breadth as the Civilization series or other complex strategy games.  While you don't get to control the individual character growth, you do see randomized level-up across all the characters that you control, to include children that grow into adults (or grow into something else magically), and you can obtain additional characters through events or randomly attracted to your town, that also end up leveling up along the way.  This "mass RPG" aspect is one of the winning points for me, that you have such a diverse crowd you can develop to try and move your civilization ahead.

So, what other names could/should this game have been called?

Well, howabout just "Thea" as a one-word game title, because the colon followed by "The Awakening" makes one wonder if this is a game add-on, or part 2 to a series, or such.  Can't stress this enough to both this game company and other would-be game developers and publishers - you need to simplify your game titles!  And - don't use women as objects to try and sell your product any more!  There are many moms and dads out there - bypassing this game for that reason alone, if they review a game for potential purchase by their kid (for those that actually play their real life role as a parent).

Ok, enough critique, as to the game itself, this game is more addicting and fun to play than the Sid Meier Civ series, to me personally.  That says something - I've put in far too much time in the Civ series in the past.  The mix of exploration, mass RPG of a player-controlled crowd, card-based tactical play, randomized events, and progressive accomplishments of varying starting gods makes for an engrossing experience.  You can end up trying out numerous combinations in the crafting menus also, and the repeat play potential is huge here - some gameplay may only last a short time, whereas you may go for days on another attempt, but all the while you can opt to end your game at that point, which contributes points to your current "god" in play to progress to a better starting point or other stats boost for the next startup - and that's across up to 8+ gods in 5 tiers each.  

I bought this at 50% off full price for just under $10, a steal at that price considering the amount of game-life and time available here.

30514974.review:
After finishing the game once and instantly starting a new game, I figured I might as well give this game a review.

So, what is Thea: The Awakening? In short, it's a turn-based strategy game with a light card game mini-game mechanic  to spice things up. The game itself is set in very flavorful fantasy world full with all kinds of mythological creatures. Instead of the typical greek or Christian mythos though, the game seems to mostly use what I figure are slavic / russian mythos. For example, the game uses the term "Demon" to describe many creatures you meet, but they really have nothing to do with the Christian understanding of the term, but rather the term encompasses anything from nature spirits to vampires, hostile to neutral and beneficial things, including servants of the deities.

The background plot in nutshell is that some event severed the bond of mankind with your pantheon and it was only recently, with sun re-merging that you have re-established some small connection with them. The player takes the role of this awakening god, seeing the world through their follower's eyes and subtly guiding the survivors in efforts to uncover what has happened and possibly fixing the world.

Gameplay-wise, the game works a bit like Civilization games on the surface. You have a randomly generated world map, a village and a handful of survivors. Your villagers need food and fuel to survive. These needs can be satisfied by assigning your villagers to work whatever resource nodes happened to spawn within your village's gathering range. For any resources outside your range, you need to send expedition's to gather. This is actually where nearly half of the game happens: controlling your expeditions around the map, searching for points of interest, questing and clashing with hostile forces.

The other half of the game is resolving these Challenges, as the game calls them. Rather than rolling a dice, you play a card mini-game. And this is where the juicy bit of the entire game lies: every time you fight a challenge, your deck of cards is formed from the members of the expedition. Having a Fight challenge? The weapons, armor, trinkets with Fight-related bonuses? All that directly translates to the power of the card that represents that particular member.

To make matters more interesting, Fight is not the only challenge type that exists. Rather, you have a variety of challenge types, from Physical challenges to Intellectual and Social ones. Usually when you're initiating an event you get to choose which type of challenge best suits your party.

The mechanics of the card mini-game are always the same regardless of the Challenge type you choose, but the numbers and abilities on your cards depend on the type of challenge. While in basic Fight challenge your attack damage would depend on your character's innate Damage-skill, weapon and item bonuses, you would instead use Intelligence-skill in Intelligence challenge. In Breaking a Curse challenge that Intelligence would instead grant you Counter Offence-support ability instead. As such the members of your party determine what the best approach to each situation would be. The game encourages you to build diverse groups, to better handle variety of Challenges.

Another reason to spread out your skills from just pure beatdown is that Fight challenges are exception to the norm in that all damage your cards take ALWAYS translate into damage and potential character deaths after the Challenge. The game VERY rarely deals instant removal of party members via challenges, but any character whose card was defeated or heavily damaged in a Fight has their health reduced to critical levels. Each turn there is a chance for every critically wounded character to die, rolled separately. The chances of this happening can be lowered by having a character with Medic-skill in the party, but it is still no guarantee of their survival. While this means that even losing a Fight challenge doesn't automatically mean you lose everyone in the expedition, their chances of survival are that much lower - well, not taking save-scumming into account.

Which actually leads to one very odd design decision that the developers did with this game: you can only ever have a single regular save + auto-save. Outside force-quitting you only have the option of Save and Quit to close the game. When you finish one of the main objectives of the game, you get to choose between finishing the game or continuing. If you choose to finish the game, that's it - the save file is finished and you can't continue anymore, as the game warns you.

The other somewhat questionable design decision is that while the game features 8 gods to play as with their varying bonuses, the game randomly(?) unlocks 2 of them for you at start. Each time you play through the game you unlock more. Considering my first playthrough took me 16 hours or so, this means you need to be somewhat dedicated player to even have the chance to see what all the gods have to offer. Oh, and in those 16 hours I apparently only unlocked 3/5 bonuses for the first god I first finished the game as.

To sum things up:

Pros:
- Rich fantasy world based upon less commonly used real-world mythos
- Variety of quests and random events to discover and react to, from funny to absurd.
- The skill sets of your characters in your expeditions actually matter. Bringing a bunch of pea-brained warriors to Intelligence challenge is not a good idea, for one.
- At the same time a very simple and very complex card mini-game instead of your typical random dice roll system.
- Narrator who narrates ALL events as they happen, including lines of the NPC characters. Great for atmosphere of the game.

The in-between:
- I'd imagine the card game can be a total hit-or-miss. It makes or breaks your experience with the game, since it's constant part of playing the game.
- Only a single save-slot. A bit roguelike-ish decision without going all the way thanks to being able to save/load.
- Losing Challenges is rarely a big deal. At worst your team gets critically wounded and you have the chance to lose people.

Cons:
- A single playthrough of the game is a bit long-ish for requiring you to unlock the gods to play them.
- Controls on the map can be unresponsive. Often you need to hold and drag mouse cursor on an enemy next to you on a map since simply right-clicking them doesn't always seem to work.
- It is hard to figure out just how well-suited your team is to a challenge. While the game does show you what skills give what benefit before starting the challenge, you don't get to preview your deck for a given challenge. With the amount of skills out there, it becomes really cumbersome to figure out your strengths and weaknesses in any exact manner.
- After a while you start getting repetitive random events. The problem is compounded by the fact that each entity (village and each expedition) gets a random event rolled separately for them, so you will end up seeing a lot of the same common events.
- The auto-playing of Challenges seems very random at times: it has both lost easy challenges and won challenges I felt were nigh-impossible to win manually.
- Related to the above, the challenge rating of encounters is occasionally off by a mile. I've faced 2-skull challenges that were harder than 4-skull challenges. This is most evident when rating non-Fight challenges: a big scary orc army with 4 skull-rating can destroy your team in a Fight challenge. The same orc army's Social challenge may also be rated at 4 skulls but they barely scratch your team that isn't even built for social challenges in the first place.

Overall verdict: Heartily recommended, with the cave-at that if you DO NOT like card games I would recommend you to avoid this title. While I've listed more cons than pros, the cons are mostly annoyances rather than real problems. The game could definitely use some polish and quality-of-life improvements, but it is very enjoyable package as-is.

This.... this is a tedious mess. Half the game is sending out "expeditions" (read: resource grinding parties that go back and forth back and forth ad nauseum from resource nodes you need to gather from) and recovering from wounds from monsters that hit like trucks while praying for the first 200 or so turns that some random unreasonably brutal event doesn't fuck you over (like having your well poisoned and having literally all of your villagers severely poisoned. with events that require something like 6 people with like 10 INT to actually succeed at in order to cure them that you have to journey to. Oh, and guess what! you won't know you need those 6 people with 10 int til you actually get there, having been misled into thinking it's a gathering challenge because you are collecting herbs!) and the other half is micromanaging everything else with the only break being an occasional, tedious card battle system that you're probably gonna eat a lot of wounds on if it's anything serious and be back to camping for 10 turns. Assuming no one immediately dies of wounds. gag. why is there even a turn system in this game...? There's no one to take a turn against. It's just another button to press over and over and over.

From what i've seen, it'll be turn 1000 before anything actually interesting begins to be remotely possible. It's so fucking slow. Also, this game is heavily reliant on crafting, yet it doesn't actually incorporate anything INTERESTING into it's crafting system. Like oh joy I can make a slightly different sword using monster bones instead of vanilla bones. So exciting. I can't wait to unlock all these amazing research options, like a cabbage field or some fucking clay. This style of game just does not lend itself that well to being a crafting game. It's like some strategy game trying to shoehorn itself into some crafting niche and failing at doing so and just being tedious and annoying to play the whole way through. It may seem like a mod for civ 4 or 5 but it certainly did not leave me saying "Just one more turn!"

oh well. here's to Thea 2 maybe getting this whole mess right somehow.

30468940.review:
Having played the game for a bit longer now I wholeheartedly recommend Thea: The Awakening.

Whilst there is an initial challenge of learning several things at once, after getting over that hurdle you are thrust into a really solid game with a unique style that I thoroughly enjoyed.

Do not be overawed at how different it is or the learning curve I mentioned because it is really just a small blip that just requires you to think a little bit instead of rushing headlong into the game.

It is fun to develop a village and explore a randomly generated (I believe) world in this turn based strategy game. The focus is on survival and there is no shortage of enemies to slay and resources to gather.

Combat and challenges come in the form of a card mini-game where your villagers have various stats and abilities depending on their equipment and attributes. That is the basic explanation, to find out more play it yourself.

You will find yourself taking turns rather quickly and can easily sink hours into the game, but, you could just as easily play it for a quick 15 minutes if you have somewhere to be.

This is an awesome game and I highly recommend it to those who enjoy the various genres of survival, strategy, civ-building and even card games. At the moment it is my game of the year that I will sink my after-hours into for the forseeable future

30456275.review:
Part Card Game, part text adventure, part resource/loot management, part strategy game.

Card Game Combat:
The card combat is a little confusing and I've engaged in a few fights where I had zero chance of winning. But it never felt frustrating or unfair. Once you learn the game mechanics you can make sure to avoid fights you can't win.

Text Adventure:
Strong story elements. The random encounters are fun and creative. The story is intriguing enough to push you to play for the objectives, yet not demanding enough if you just want to run around and explore. I never minded reading the story but they give you the option to skip the sections involving a lot of text.

Resource Management:
You'll usually never be in danger of starving or running out of fuel for fires, but the really fun part is managing your loot. Do you give the two handed spear with piercing to your warrior or craftsman. Does this character need to be a tank or damage dealer? Do I need to spec this person for sneak attacks or tactics? After a certain point you will have too much equipment and the game would benefit from a rarity system (so you can easily see what to trash) but I really enjoyed getting a new character and then trying to figure out the how to outfit them

Strategy:
It was fun exploring and making expeditions. Encounters were random and very rewarding when you found you had the proper team members present to provide hidden text options. Diversity is key and I enjoyed trying to stack my expedition so that it was ready for anything it encountered

Conclusion:
Absolute steal if it is on sale but totally worth it at full price. Play throughs can be short or long, depends on how motivated you are to complete the story objectives. I beat my first play through in under 20 hours but will definitely be going back for more. Its a very rewarding game. Overcoming a certain text/card challenge or bringing in a big haul with an expedition is very satisfying

30285295.review:
I really enjoyed this game and definitely felt like I got my money's worth out of it. I am really hoping that the developers make a sequel and build off of feedback from this game to make an even better version, because I think it is really ambitious and interesting in its own right, but has enormous potential be even better. I think with some work and polish, it could be come its own franchise to rival Civ or the Endless series.

It is probably more useful, though, to say a little about the game. The best way I can describe the thoroughly unique experience of Thea is an unlikely meeting of worlds between a game like Civ, Endless Legend and / or Age of Wonders, and a game like FTL: Faster Than Light or Convoy. It’s a rogue-like 4X exploration game, with loads of replay value both in terms of single-session variety and meta-game progress.

[b]Tl;dr of the rest of the review: You choose a god from a bunch of gods, they all have different powers and can level that god up by playing the game. You lead a village of survivors, gather resources, craft items, build buildings in your village, and explore the world to encounter creatures, monsters and challenges. You gain research points to unlock more things to gather, craft and / or build and you gain levels to improve your villagers. You overcome challenges with your villagers through a card system that works for skills and combat. There’s lots of events, lots of choices and quite a bit of variety. The game could be better by a little more variety in events that happen a lot, a little more variety in the story events, and a better inventory management system. Overall, good game, would recommend. [/b]

(Long review below: thanks for reading)

You act from the mixed (and admittedly somewhat confusing) perspective of what I can only assume to be some kind of avatar of a given deity. Each deity has their own specialties, and benefits they grant to those that are dedicated to them. As this sort of Avatar, you function as the leader of a band of survivors eking out a living in the aftermath of a sort of global calamity. The worst seems to be passing, though, and your small village is able to bravely venture out into the renewed world. This experience is put into action through a few mechanics. 

Firstly, you have to manage your settlement. This involves striking a balance between leaving adequate (and appropriate) characters in your village to gather resources there (they give you a couple of basics available to get recurrently in your starting local, usually wood and some kind of food) while also having a strong enough adventuring party to brave the wilds in such of other resources (the VAST majority of resources you will need to progress have to be gathered outside of your home). Managing your settlement involves assigning the people who you choose to leave behind to gather, craft or construct. Every character has a wide array of skills (all of which may be levelled up each time your community gains a level) but only a couple of these apply to these efforts. There are different classes that your villagers will be members of that will determine where they are best suited. Gathering obviously gives you resources, crafting produces (based on what blueprints you have unlocked) the huge assortment of types of equipment that can benefit you, and constructing allows you to add structures to your settlement, which grant a variety of boons ranging from chances to get new villagers, children, and / or resources; bonuses for skills and stats of new children who have grown up there; different class options for children who grow up in town; or boons for your community of other forms. Crafting and constructing are the two main ways to generate research points which allow you to unlock new gathering, crafting and constructing options. That’s it in a nutshell, but obviously there is nuance. You can spend a LOT of time just fiddling with your settlement as time goes on.

Secondly, you explore the world and attempt to overcome various tasks, events, challenges and quests. The world can be of various sizes depending on how you set up your game initially, but personally playing on default settings I didn’t even come CLOSE to fully exploring it. It is rewarding, challenging and has that same feel of the first 200 turns of Civ or Age of Wonders. This is also where a lot of the FTL / Convoy piece comes in, with different choices available in the many, MANY scenarios you can encounter. Encounters may simply random, happening as you travel, or they could be guided by quests. Each god / goddess has their own unique quest chain, then there is a main storyline that sort of parallels it that is similar for all playthroughs, and there is the free DLC for the game, Rise of Giants, that spices things up (and sometimes makes it really, really hard) around the 150 – 200 turn mark. Sometimes these quests and events resolve simply by making certain choices, but largely this is where we encounter another really unique but (in my opinion) very well done mechanic of the game: the card system. 

This is the third mechanic of managing the game and it’s a big part to be sure. Rather than dice rolls, pure RNG or an active-time combat system of some form, skill challenges and combat alike are resolved using Thea’s unique card-based system. Without getting into the nitty-gritty, each character has lots of skills and those various skills contribute to their attack, shielding, health and utility options that they have as cards. You and your opponent (which is sometimes represented by abstract cards representing the challenge at hand, while other times directly personifies an enemy or adversary in front of you) take turns playing your cards hoping to best the other. Again, I don’t want to go into the details because there is nuance, but I find it really refreshing and solid overall. I would recommend trying it or at least watching gameplay videos before you go “ugh, card-based system – PASS.” I almost did that but I’m glad I gave it a chance.

The last mechanic to mention is the meta-game. When you beat the game (or lose I think?) you get given a score based on how long you lived and what you accomplished (big bonuses for achieving one of the victory conditions, and big bonuses for completing the giant quest content) and that gives your god or goddess experience. With that experience, they gain levels, adding new cool benefits that they offer if you play under that god in future playthroughs. They can earn up to five special traits this way, potentially allowing you to turn up the difficulty and endure even more challenge! To this end, as well, increasing the difficulty gives you a multiplier on this final exp, while lowering it makes you receive less exp (though not in a hugely punishing way). Hooray for replay value!

Okay, wow, that’s already a long review so I’m going to try and wrap up. Thea is really solid and has tons of replay value. But it is not perfect (what is?). Many of the events that happen most commonly lack variety (one particular even involving boars comes to mind for me) where it could have been so easy to simply code in a few more varied outcomes to keep you on your toes. I feel like they lost a bit of this because they insisted on having voice acting for a lot of the script. Personally, I feel they could easily forgo that part and focus on writing, since I realize it is burdensome creating that type of variety while also having a voice actor. I’d way prefer they prioritize the former than the latter. 

(My review, perhaps unsurprisingly, is too long for Steam. For the rest of the review, if interested, please see the comments)

This is a great game with an unfortunately terrible name.

It plays out most like a Heroes of Might and Magic game, but with less focus on unit churning and much more focus on optional development. The conflict resolution uses a unique system that takes a few attempts to fully figure out, but which I found to be a nice change of pace. There are a whole boatload of research options, from the ability to harvest better resources, to building options, to crafting options. I'm very impressed by the sheer amount of quests, classes, weapons, items, food, and everything. Lots and lots of content here. Everything is well thought out. Rewards from encounters keep things engaging and I even managed to recruit a monster into my party after one of my fights given that I had developed and brought a witch along with me, which was a pleasant surprise.

On top of everything, it has solid rogue-like unlockable bonuses in the form of various gods, so even if your game doesn't end well, you'll have made some progress towards your next attempts.

I'm also appreciative of all of the free content released post-launch. Very classy move.

Highly recommend!

30071487.review:
I put about 12 hours into Thea, mostly playing in co-op with a friend. This game does not make a great first impression. There are quite a few systems in play that do not feel well explained even after reading all of the tutorial tool tips available. In fact, my co-op partner ended up watching a 1.5 hour video on the game on youtube to learn the ins and outs and explained them to me.

Once we got into it, we found some of the story events interesting, reminding me of the random events in the Banner Saga series. However, often we found ourselves in extremely punishing situations. The "skull" difficulty system for fights is not that reliable. I lost many many villagers, irrespective of whether I camped after the fight to maximize their recovery. You don't even have to leave your initial village to get into trouble however, as some of the catastrophic world events (fires and plagues) come to you. "You have lost 5 children." Ouch. In a town of maybe 15 humans total, that's a doozy.

The gathering/crafting/building system was somewhat unique and warrants some praise, but the research tree is quite slow. You soon find that you'll need to constantly be crafting with the rarest materials you have available to obtain research points at any reasonable speed. However, the research tree itself is not particularly exciting, and I couldn't really get excited about any of the options available.

In the end, I think this is what soured me on the title. Interacting with the gathering, crafting, and building system made up a lot of our play time, and it just wasn't very exciting. I can put a research point into some type of metal, another point in a type of sword - then I need to send out some villagers to get some of the metal to put the sword together, but I just didn't find this engaging or particularly rewarding.

I wanted to get out into the map to experience the random story events, but any missteps were so incredibly punishing that I spent the majority of the game sitting around waiting for wounds to heal or for additional villagers to arrive that might allow me to maintain my village and still send out an expedition. Additionally, the fog of war and day/night cycle leave you feeling as though you haven't explored anything, even if you have travelled many hexes in either direction. There is no permanence to the map. I can see how some players might find this "emergent," but it just made me feel ineffective.

Thea has some good ideas, with some reviewers calling it "an entire game about the first few turns in a Civilization game." However, this game never got me to say "just one more turn!"

30008397.review: In Thea you play the people of a little Slavic village trying to survive and prosper amongst the mounting threat of the mythological monsters around you.  Your village becomes your home base, while you send foraging parties out to brave the wilderness and see what resources they can discover.  It often ends in tears, until you find your footing.  The combat system is unusual and takes a little getting used to before you get good at it, but persevere and it can get quite rewarding.  The crafting system allows you to build up your village's assets, harvest better ingredients, or make better equipment.  There are loads of options and choices, and you rapidly become involved in strange happenings at the instigation of your patron deity.  Your choices matter.  It has tactics, strategy, you name it.  Thea is a game that builds complexity on simple ideas and does it well.

29996507.review:
Thea is, if nothing else, an interesting and worthwhile experience. I'll do my uttermost to break down why that is in the following paragraphs. Essentially, there is no specific aspect of Thea: the Awakening that is totally good or totally bad; each aspect has its own high and low points.

Lore: The lore in this game is rich, rich like red velvet cake with mousse baked inside somehow. It's based on Slavic mythology, and having done some cursory research, I can say that the game does take significant inspiration from Slavic and Eastern European mythology. Elements such as Striga and Zmey, as well as gods such as Perun and Veles, are taken more or less straight from the original stories and myths. Creatures such as Vily and Hohlicks, however, I couldn't find an origin for, but those who are better versed in the mythology might know where their inspirations come from. Certain other elements, such as Kostey, seem to be modified from an original story; in Kostey's case, it seems to come from the story of Koschei, an Eastern European sorceror who was unable to be killed except by finding a needle that contains his soul. The lore of the game itself, regardless of how closely it follows actual Slavic mythology, is incredibly engaging, and one of the highest notes of the game. The voice-overs also deliver the narration passing fair, but I'm 99% certain that the British-accented narrator is mispronouncing some things. Regardless, the lore is really compelling and the stories worth following. The main plot concerns the end of the world, and your peoples' attempt to rebound from it. This actually does a lot to set up the main rogue-lite mechanics of the game, as it means that survival will be deathly important.

Marriage of Mechanics: This one's gonna be complicated, mostly because this game is very unique. Basically, the game is an attempt to marry rogue-lite persistent elements with 4x gameplay. Bascially, when you first boot up the game, you choose from one of two randomly unlocked god characters each of which give you bonuses in game. Then, once you win, lose, or quit your run, your god gains experience points, and levelling them up grants them additional bonuses which they confer on you in later runs with them. You unlock other gods upon hitting certain thresholds, usually hitting a certain level with your currently unlocked gods. The actually gameplay consists of managing a single village in a 4x world, trying to gather resources, explore the map, and complete quests, chief among them being the "Cosmic Tree" and "Return of the Giants" quests. The best analogy for the game I've found is that it's the opening exploration phases of a game of Civ, but it's the whole game. While some of the mechanics can be a bit obtuse, the game does a great job with its tutorial, and by the end of it, you'll have found your footing. These mechanics do indeed grant the game additional, tangible replay value. After all, when you complete a game of Civ, nothing presists beyond, save perhaps for a vague sense of accomplishment and a desire for another round. Having persistent, efficacious avatars to level up and play as grants this game actual, physical reason to keep playing. When someone asks you, "Why have you spent 67 hours on Thea?" you can say, "I was trying to level up Horos to his final form." But when someone asks the same about Civ V or VI, all you can say is "Sid Meier owns my soul." However, there are problems that arise on repeated playthroughs. Because the game doesn't provide infinite story or quests, it can take only a game or three to exhaust most of the side quests and lore. This can make one feel as though after a few games, one has seen all that there is to see, learnt all that there is to learn. In a way, the wealth of in-game content works against the meta-game's avatar persistence, as after seeing all the game has to offer in terms of quests and encounters, playing subsequent games can feel like you're only trying to level your god. In other words, the rogue-lite and 4x mechanics experience the seven-year itch after a few games. My suggestion to the devs would be to have more god-specific quests, or additional quests relevant to your god's experience level, or additional quests that only unlock at certain difficulty levels. Now, this seven-year itch is mitigated somewhat by the inclusion of an "Event Editor", which allows users to create their own quest-lines, allowing for theoretically infinite content. However, the interface for the editor isn't exactly user-friendly, and without apparent workshop support, it may be difficult to find user-made content.

Combat and Challenges: Combat in this game resolved via a neat little card-based minigame. Whenever you encounter an opponent on the overworld map, your party and the enemies engage in card-based combat, with your party members and the opponents represented as cards with abilities based on their stats. You have an offensive hand and a tactical hand. The cards from your offensive hand you may play directly on the field, where they engage in combat with the opponents' cards. Cards in your tactical hand can use tactical abilities, such as delaying an opponent's attack, or discarding a card from an opponent's hand. It's actually a fun little mini-game! Other challeneges, such as Stealth challenges, Hunting challenges, and Intellect challenges, are resolved exactly the same, except against the challenge itself rather than an opponent. However, the mini-game can get rather repetitive and wrote, and sometimes doens't actually work as an abstraction. For example, how does having additional people help with a Stealth challenge? Well, in this game it does help! Somehow. These situations can be seen as less a flaw of the minigame and the result of fridge-logic instead, but it can still be jarring to some players. Regardless, the mini-game does its job well enough.

Ease of Play: The game's interface is pretty easy to wrap one's head around, and as mentioned before, the tutorial is pretty good. As for the actual game... Well, there's a reason I've referred to it as "rogue-lite", as opposed to "roguelike". I personally found the game a smidge too easy on Normal mode, but it might provide a meatier challenge to someone who is unfamiliar to 4x games or survival-based mechanics. As for me, even when I messed up in a major way, it was never enough to stop my run. Someone looking for a greater deal of challenge should either look elsewhere or play on a higher difficulty level.

To sum up, Thea: the Awakening is altogether an interesting idea competently executed. It's a fun game, and the lore and mechanics are rich and deep enough to warrant repeated playthroughs. It does suffer somewhat from having limited quests and content, and the endgame can be a bit of a slog, but a few tweaks in future endavours from the devs could mitigate that somewhat. I would definitely reccomend this game, if only because few, if any, games have attempted what this game has.

29938959.review:
I love this game!

The story is pretty good, but the encounters are what make it, you have so many varied types of encounters and outcomes. You can plow through fighting tooth and nail, or you can preserve your parties health and numbers by using tact and subterfuge against enemies.

The game allows you multiple characters (you play as serveral differnent gods to choose from) that level up through gameplay, so you can unlock new and unique bonuses of each different god you may play as they gain levels, or unlock new gods to play as.

There's a pretty good sized map with lots of resources and random events to check out.

The main story itself is pretty good and remains interesting. I beat the main story through on two of the gods, with my 60 hours of play, though I spent lots of extra time messing around on my first play through, exploring and leveling up party members. And believe I still have four more gods to play as.

If you like games like Might and Magic, it's kinda like that in a way. You build up various buildings using different building materials in your village that can do things like attract people, animals, or even demons to come join your village and make your people stronger in numbers.

There's a wide variety of characters that can join into your party, anything from witches, demons, beasts, and monster, ghosts, ghouls, legendary creatures, elves, dwarves, mages, and on and on... keeps things interesting.

The hardest part is finishing the playthrough and picking a new god to start again, cause by the time you're ready to do that you have the most badass party imaginable full of shades, vampires and all kinds of heavy hitters that you don't want to let go of, but that's the game and you get to start fresh and find new party members to continue on with.

Very happy I bought this title. 

There's plenty of replayability. Interesting game style all it's own with familiar enough themes that you don't need much guidance to get started, and fun encounters and an interesting non-combative resolution options if you have characters with the right skills, like the music and the art is fresh and enjoyable. 

All around a game done right.

29900912.review:
Do you know the first turn in Civilization games? Where you have one settler and one warrior, and you have the choice to either build your first city on the spot or start exploring and hope for a river? Thea is an entire game built around that concept. And if that doesn't convince you this is an amazing game, then you, sir, are a filistine.

On the whole, Thea is in the same street as 4x strategy. You build a civilization by gathering resources and advancing through a tech tree. Most events and encounters offer combat and non-combat resolutions, which are both resolved by playing a card game. The difference between combat and non-combat lies mainly in the skills involved and the fact that characters don't risk getting wounded if you choose non-combat.
A big difference between Thea and ordinary 4x is that Thea is strictly PVE single player. There's no AI opponent to outsmart. There's also a much greater emphasis on story and roleplay elements. You could probably piece together all of the narrator's dialogue to create a good 5 hour audiobook. There's multiple options to solve 95% of all challenges and diversification is strongly encouraged. 

The system for crafting items and managing food is deep and immersive. allowing you as many options as there are different resources. And there are a lot of different resources. I don't know how much number crunching was required to reliably create situations where you have to choose between matching X or Y with N or P, where people choosing XP can still scrounge up some N or Y from other sources to meet their basic needs. It's an incredibly refined experience and I respect the amount of work required to create it.
There is still a fairly easy 'complete' strategy that'll win you the game regardless, but I won't spoil it and it's not a big hindrance to the overall fun.

While the majority of the storytelling is great, the finale left me a little befuddled. Without going into specific spoilers, I'll say that the various options to complete the main questlines all seem to lack definite impact. The score screen says I've done the thing I was supposed to do, but it doesn't really feel that way. There's no gameplay feedback and ultimately the whole thing leaves me a little unsatisfied, at least until I start another game.

Summary: Excellent game, recommended to those that like 4x strategy and rpg's.

29733206.review:
This game looks a lot like a 4X game.  It looks a lot like a 4X game.  It has the same presentation structure as a 4X game.  But it's a village and expedition management game.  It's not until I was in my third playthrough (having aborted the second early because I wasn't happy with it, and had gained enough deity XP that I'd have a helping hand if I restarted with the same one) that I started to work out what that means.

If you've been hoping for a sequel to King of Dragon Pass, then this isn't that.  But if you thought that KoDP showed us that there are whole new directions that nobody is exploring, then Thea: The Awakening is exploring a similar space.  I'm excited for the sequel - and I'm going to keep playing after finishing the 'victory' quest, in the hopes of doing something about the giants this time.

29642460.review: I really like this game.  You have a home base and there are several character types that are good at things like fighting or gathering or building etc, and you set some of them to build things in your town which you will need.  You will then create a party or two and search the map and have encounters and get resources or items.  The difference here is that your enounters get resolved via a card game... it's not as boring as it sounds.  Your characters have many stats and you get a choice of what type of enounter you want to have... for example will you fight the goblins, or try to poision them, or try to parlay with them?  Depending on what you chose different stats come to play.  There a decent amount of strategy involved in the card encounter portion, nothing fancy, but satisfying.  To be honest it's not a "just one more turn" kind of game, but I do come back to it repeatedly and play... There's something chill and relaxing about it that I like.

29413053.review:
I've played through Thea a couple times now on two different computers, and  while it runs a bit slower on my (admittedly older) laptop, I can still play the game fairly well even if the hardware isn't up to today's standards. Granted, I'm not running it at any of the higest settings. :)

As far as gameplay is concerned, I've enjoyed the struggle to keep my village alive and expand my benevolent survival to as many stragglers as I can pull in. Granted, for some reason, Fat Rats keep showing up to populate my village... But that may just be due to all the food that I have. (And the fact that I've got Attract Beasts+ on at least one of my buildings)

The skills are interesting and varied and although level up is random for each member of your village and exploration party, it does seem to be good as far as building on whatever skills your people have, whether naturally gained or from various stat boost via your crafted equipment. Some of the harder skills to find are the ones that make the game easier to deal with in the long run, so learning all facets of the crafting trees are essential to the game. But with low speed that you earn skill points to unlock crafting options and the multitude of items to spend on (buildings, crafting recipes, gathering materials) it does force you to pick and choose between all the options; will you use it to gain the ability to harvest better materials or learn recipes for buildings or equipment? The order that you choose can sometimes sink your game before you even get very far and although it can be frustrating, I've had fun learning how to make do with what I have and to compensate through encounters.

Encounters are sometimes a major point of pain and rage, and sometimes edge towards over simplification due to the various methods the developers have given us to utilize. Skills come into play here and rewards and hazards vary depending on how well developed your party is in any given skillset. As a rule, higher level parties with more members tend to do much better at surviving, though with the expansion of the giants, even high level parties don't have the luxury of just sitting on their laurels if they want to survive.

The save feature is a godsend.

The only thing that I haven't like about the expansion so far is that the earthquake events seem to happen way too quickly during gameplay.

Aside from that minor inconvenience, I've definitely enjoyed my time spent in this dark world and would recommend that anyone with interest pick it up. It's worth it!

29408986.review:
I love this game for its setting, its quirky humor, and its uniqueness. Turn-based survival is not a common genre, and the fact that this game is hard to describe is one of the things I like about it the most. It is more of a roleplaying game than a 4x strategy game, and has more in common with Don’t Starve and Darkest Dungeon than Civilization.

In this fantasy themed (though not even remotely stereotyped) world, you are tasked with rebuilding from a nearly world ending calamity. Most of the game revolves around resource and people management, as you send your villagers out to gather the materials you need to both stay alive and rebuild your village. The further out you go, the more dangerous it gets, but the better materials you can find. As you progress, many different stories emerge, and you learn all about the calamity that befell Thea, and what you can do to help (or hinder) its rebirth.

You get attached to your villagers very quickly (they are by far your most valuable resource), and even though they never speak or interact with the story directly, they develop personalities nonetheless. The world of Thea can be very unforgiving, and playing through adversity is a major theme of this game (people die, and that is just part of life). While the main storyline is the same each time, there are different ways to approach it. The side quests and God quests are quite varied, and, based on how your characters develop, may change dramatically from play through to play through.

Combat is a fascinating card game, that is initially a bit hard to understand. Once you grasp the basics, it becomes an interesting puzzle each time. Then, just when you think you have it figured out, it throws a curve-ball at you (often resulting in the deaths of beloved villagers). I also love that it is the same basic interface regardless of what kind of combat you are engaged in (fighting, negotiating, sneaking, etc.) but your characters strengths and weaknesses change based on what what you are trying to do. This means that a character with low HP and damage might be worthless in a regular fight, but could carry the team in an intellect challenge, and is thus just as important to the overall party.

My only real complaint about the game is that sometimes, especially in the late game, there becomes more to manage than the interface can really handle. You will spend a lot of time scrolling through an overflowing inventory, trying to keep track of an ever growing number of unique villagers with a somewhat staggering list of different skills. There are tools and filters to try to assist with this, but even so, it is a challenge (and hardly unique to this title).

Regardless of that, I have spent many wonderful hours wandering the wilderness of Thea, and I look forward to many more to come.

29383613.review:
This game has become an obsession. Where's the 12-step program? Seriously, who's the Betty Ford of gaming? I need her.

Thea has that addictive, just-one-more-turn quality that keeps me clicking way past my bedtime. It's by no means perfect, but I'm enjoying it so much that I just chucked some of my hard-earned cash into the developer's "coffee for coders" electronic tip jar.

The premise is unique--not quite an RPG, not quite a 4X title, but an utterly appealing middle path. You can build up your one village, your people, and their gear after the manner of a 4X title, but not establish an empire. The quests are varied, interesting, and lead to meaningful (and sometimes agonizing) decisions. There's more lore and backstory than I wanted to read, but it's reasonbly well written (for the most part) and has a fascinating flair borrowed from Slavic mythology.

A few complaints: the interface is utterly clunky. It often takes six clicks to do what should have been easily accomplished in two. I really hope they will either re-open development on this game and give it another round of polish, or work to streamline things substantially in their next game (which I will definitely buy). One example: say you want to rip up a particular character's outdated shield for its components. You can't do it from the equipment screen. You have to close that screen, flip over to inventory, find the shield, drag it to a box, and click on a dialog box. This could have been done so much more elegantly with a "scrap" button in the right click information dialog for the item. There are dozens of examples of this sort of poorly-thought-out UI choice--that's simply one of the most egregious ones.

The look of the game is gorgeous, but it's not very deep. There are lovely line drawings of all your characters, for example, but when you swap a fighter's starting sword for the big honking new axe you just found, you're still left staring at her sword-wielding drawing.

The voice narration, similarly, is very well done but shallow. There's only one narrator, and while he's outstanding, the game really could have used a full cast production.

The quests, card-based battle system, and crafting system are deep, complex, and completely satisfying. I get the feeling I could play another thousand hours and still be learning the intricacies of the crafting and battle parts of the game.

The actual characters you control, however, feel shallow. They only rarely feature as individuals in any of the quests. You learn little of their backstories. They needed to be fleshed out and developed, so that when one of them dies (which is inevitable), it means something more than just losing a generic warrior or gatherer.

Oh, and a note on DLC. They released it for free! Take note, Stardock and Paradox! If you do enjoy the DLC as much as I did, be sure to leave a tip. (Buy the "coffee for coders" DLC.) Let's reward them for being pro-gamer!

Overall, an outstanding effort. I'll be watching eagerly for this developer's next effort. And, while I realize it's unlikely, I wish they'd revisit Thea and give it another round of polish. Then it would easily be better than a lot of major studio games I've paid $60 for.

Admittedly the learning curve is a bit steep and I had to try the game a few separate times before it stuck, but once it did, hours of exploration, interest, and excitement awaited. Thank you devs for a well-thought out, fun and lasting addition to the turn based strategy / rpg canon. Cheers!
