I absolutely loved this title!  One of the best Indie games I've played in the last 5 years.

This one is a really novel and innovative blend of 4x and RPG game.  The writing is excellent, and combines well with the game mechanics to create a constant sense of adversity and even despair.  (e.g., "Feeling a little cocky about how quickly you're getting your city built up now?  Maybe we'll just have a RAIN OF FIRE descend from the heavens to see how your villagers and their nice little buildings hold up!")

The card-game mechanic, while it took me a little while to get used to, ended up working out fine for me.  I also appreciated how easily it lent itself to story-telling.  In Social challenges, one of my lead characters (a Witch, by profession) had crazy "Will" and she just wore people down through negotiations!

This game seems MUCH deeper than I thought after my first 15 hours of playing it.  I'm only now realizing that I've only scratched the surface after my first main effort of surviving 141 turns!

I LOVE THIS GAME!!!

29281553.review:
I’ll recommend the game for those that think a strategy-card game, that incorporates roleplay elements in a Slavic fantasy world could be interesting for them. This game really has the “Just five more minutes…” kind of feel for me. Where I end up playing far longer than I probably should have into the night.

Let’s get the negatives out of the way first. And they are just negatives for me, they might be positives for you. I feel there is a bit too much randomness in combat at times. Since if the enemy or your unit attacks the card to the right or left can often end up being the main deciding factor in combat, or the enemy getting a type of bonus damage can be devastating, it feels like you have less control at times. I have tried reloading after a battle that ended in crashing defeat, because I thought, I might be able to win, if I tried a slightly different tactic. Only to see the enemy’s strongest monster having a different type of damage, which turned the fight overall into a cakewalk.

Then there are the skulls, which is the way the game shows a challenge’s difficulty. They feel wildly inconsistent at times. One group at a certain level might wipe the floor with my party, while another won’t even be able to injure a single person, despite having the same skull-level.

But while playing the game those problems don’t really feel that big.


On to the more positive side of things. I like the pantheon, where you pick your main deity. Each with different personalities, and they even open special approaches to some events out in the world. 

I also find the world, and especially the demons interesting. Much like with the witcher series, it introduces me to some creatures from folklore and mythology, that I am just not familiar with along with some of the more common fantasy species. I do wish you could start off as something else than human. You can get other types of creatures in your party, either through events or the type of building materials, but you will still be a human village. But I think it could be fun to just start out as an orc or elf village. Maybe in a sequel or DLC.

Last a little side note. This might be due to my own stupidity, but the inventory menu wasn’t so logical for me at first. Moving many stacks of materials from one group to the other was very slow, until I, mostly by accident, discovered I could do it by just holding shift as I clicked. :P

29238631.review: This game is fantastic.  It's like Oregon Trail meets Age of Wonders.  The beginning of any game is very fraught with worry and peril, but you're rewarded for carefully choosing encounters.  This game's for thoughtful players looking for a 4X game with a heavy story focus.

29231945.review:
It's hard to put into words what my Time Played for this game isn't already showing you.  This is a fun, addictive game.

It's a rogue-like turn based strategy game with a focus on crafting.  There is a huge variety of materials, weapons/armor, and underlying stats for all of your characters.  Some unique stats include things like Traps, Attractiveness, Stealth, Perception and a ton others, and they each have their own roles to play in different battle types.  In some encounters you can choose to outright Fight (favoring stats like armor, strength etc) or do a Social challenge, where your individual stats with Speech and Attractiveness play a large roll.  If you see the card based battle system and are hesitant about buying this due to the complexity, don't be.  The tutorial is really helpful and the in game links to YouTube are clutch.  

The lore is also well written and very interesting.  I have completed a few runs now (although none with completing all 3 main quests) and I think on average I have completed about 15% of the events, which means there are a ton of events I haven't even seen yet.  If you have played Eador before (highly recommended, see my review) you'll appreciate the wider range of random events to help keep the game fresh.

The only thing I would have liked to see is a small amount of individual character customization beyond just what to equip.  I don't know if choosing stat gains at level up would potentially unbalance the game or not, but that would have given a more personal and accomplished feel to the characters at an individual level.

29222010.review:
Um es klar zu sagen: Thea ist kein schlechtes Spiel. Die Entwickler hatten einige super Ideen (#kampfsystem) und man merkt wirklich, dass sie das Spiel mit Begeisterung entwickelt haben. Ob Ihr damit aber Spaß haben werdet, hängt davon ab, ob Euch die zahl- und abwechslungsreichen Events von dem extrem repetitiven Gameplay ablenken können. Das war bei mir leider nicht der Fall - die Folge ist, dass die Lust bereits nach wenigen Stunden vergeht.

In Thea spielt Ihr eine Gruppe von Überlebenden eines Kataklysmus - dessen Ursachen zu ergründen ist eines der Ziele des Spiels. Ein Teil Euer Schützlinge bleibt im Dorf und sammelt/stellt her/baut, während Ihr die restlichen auf Expeditionen durch das Umland steuert und gegen Monster kämpft und Quests löst. Dabei werden ihr ständig mit spannenden Events konfrontiert, die auch schnell zum Tod von Gruppenmitgliedern führen können. Die Kämpfe werden mit einem richtig coolen Kartensystem ausgefohten, bei dem leider der Zufallsfaktor eine Rolle spielt, die aber trotzdem sehr viel Spaß machen.

Das Problem: Nachdem die anfängliche Begeisterung verflogen ist, fiel mir auf, dass ich jede Runda das Selbe mache: Die Expedition wird i-wo hingeschickt, und die Dörfler bekommen Anweisungen, welche Mahlzeiten sie kochen sollen. Letzteres gilt als Herstellen und lässt sich (im Gegensatz zum Sammeln) nicht automatisieren, und wird folglich zu einer extrem lästigen Pflicht - und durch das Craftingsystem zur Klickorgie beim Zusammenstellen der Zutaten. Da Ihr keine neuen Städte gründet und auch keinen echten, sichtbaren technischen Fortschritt habt (das Aufdecken neuer Ressourcen oder Freischalten von Gebäuden ließ mich erstaunlich kalt), fallen wichtige Motivationsaspekte des 4X - Genre weg.

A propos Genre: Das Spiel als "Survival" zu bezeichnen ist grober Unfug - tatsächlich handelt es sich um ein Abenteuerspiel mit Craftingsystem und Strategie - sowie RPG - Elementen auf einer Open World. Ja, Eure Schützlinge müssen mit Essen und Brennstoff versorgt werden, aber das ist in der Praxis lediglich eine simple logistische Herausforderung - "Survival" klingt aber marketingtechnisch besser als "Logistik".

Obwohl das Spiel wie gesagt nicht schlecht ist, ist der Preis mit 20€ trotzdem eindeutig zu hoch - 15€ würden es eher treffen. Also lieber auf Sale warten!

29211812.review: Simply love this game. One of the best, if not the best of the genre. Learning curve is a bit much at the start but within a few hours it all makes sense. Totally in love with this title. I waited for a sale but had I have known it was this good I wouldn't have waited. Overall 9.5/10.

29198620.review: A gem hidden in the mire of TBS games. Has a somewhat steep learning curve for new comers, but if you pay attention and listen to tutorials, it is not too hard to grasp.

29168502.review:
Игра на любителя. Собрание редких аспектов, от которых большинство геймеров воротят нос: сам жанр пошаговых стратегий, обширная система крафта, сложная ролевая модель для каждого из более десятка ваших жителей, длинные тексты квестов, которые реально нужно читать, если хочешь выбрать верный вариант поведения. 
И если вы не готовы тратить по несколько минут на каждый ход, чтобы просто проверить, чем занят каждый житель, запоминать наиболее удачные сочетания материалов в крафте, читать тонны текста - то вы начнете искать, к чему придраться, ставить вышеописанные аспекты в минусы. Вобщем, игра вас огорчит. 
Но если вы тот самый любитель всех этих прелестей, вас эта игра приятно удивит и станет одной из самых любимых. Как для меня.

29158975.review:
이 게임은 정말 갓겜입니다.

고난이도 플레이를 하신다고 가정하겠습니다. 시작은 무조건 워리어 스타트입니다. 7명 스타트 기준으로 워리어 스타트를 해야 시작할 때 워리어가 3명입니다. 몬스터들이 정말 미친듯이 성장하기 때문에 다른 스타트를 하면 고통받습니다. 또한 시작하셨을 때 기본적으로 마을안에서 캘 수 있는 자원이 만약 나무가 아닌 석탄이거나, 채소,과일등이 아니고 채집하는데 많은 비용이 드는 자원이면 재시작 추천드립니다. 고난이도에서는 마을 밖에서 채집을 할 수 있게 인원을 배분할 여유가 없습니다. 처음 시작할 때 아이를 2명 데리고 시작하는데 둘 다 워리어로 갑니다. 300%이상 난이도에서 플레이할시 전부 워리어 찍어도 몬스터들 성장을 못 따라갑니다. 그래서 강한 몬스터들은 피하고 상대할 수 있는 몬스터들만 잡아내면서 성장을 노립니다. 시작시 채집가가 2명 주어지는데 각각 채집도구를 만들어서 장착시켜 목재와 식량을 한턴만에 수집할 수 있게 만들어주면 초반부에 굶어죽을 일은 없습니다. 크래프터는 1명이 주어지는데 보통은 조리를 하거나 (식량 효율이 좋아집니다.) 쓸모없는 자원을 이용해 장비를 만들어서 연구포인트를 올려줍니다. 초반에 얻는 연구포인트는 cabbage field를 만들어 아이와 사람이 합류할 확률을 높여줍니다. 여유가 생기면 목장도 지어서 사람이 합류할 확률을 조금이라도 높여주세요. 이 게임에서 인력보다 중요한 것이 없다고 해도 과언이 아닙니다. 다음은 대장간이나 배럭을 지어주시면 됩니다. 장비는 창을 연구해서 창을 좋은 재료로 만드시는 걸 추천합니다. 게임 내의 전투는 서로 여러대를 주고받는게 아니라 공격력이 강해 1방, 2방으로 보통 죽습니다. 그래서 선공을 해서 먼저 죽이면 전투를 굉장히 유리하게 가져갈 수 있는데 창을 장착하면 상대가 마지막에 낸 카드에게 공격력의 반만큼 딜을 주는 동시에 그 카드보다 먼저 공격합니다. 평가중에 퍼스트 액션의 중요성을 논하신 분이 있는데 퍼스트 액션이 강력하긴 하지만 크래프터가 여럿 낀 파티로는 전투 진행이 힘듭니다. 그렇기 때문에 워리어에게 창을 장착시켜 비슷한 효과를 노리는게 기본 전략입니다.초반부에는 장비를 만들 여유가 없기 때문에 루팅된 무기들을 이용해 전투를 진행하시다가 몬스터들의 공격력이 강해지는 중반부 이후에는 양손도끼와 창을 이용하는 것을 추천합니다. 

이 게임에서 확률과 상관없이 100% 등장하는 퀘스트는 3가지로 메인퀘스트와 신성퀘스트, 거인퀘스트입니다. 메인퀘스트와 거인퀘스트를 클리어하면 게임의 승리조건을 만족한 것으로 여겨지고 거인퀘스트는 후반부 퀘스트이므로 보통은 메인퀘스트를 먼저 진행합니다. 그리고 신성퀘스트의 난이도가 메인퀘스트보다 낮지만 보상이 크기 때문에 기본적으로 신성퀘스트 클리어를 노리고 보상을 받아 메인퀘스트를 도전하는 것이 좋습니다. 고난이도 클리어를 위한 추천 신은 lada와 perun입니다. 몬스터들이 워낙 강하기 때문에 세이브 로드 신공을 이용하지 않으면 전투만으로 모두 무찌르기는 정말 힘듭니다.  그렇기 때문에 피해를 입지 않고 전투를 승리할 수 있는 다른 방법들을 선택하게 되는데 3가지 퀘스트 진행시에는 전투와 social(논쟁정도로 해석가능합니다.) 챌린지를 이용할 수 있습니다. perun의 경우 기본적으로도 보너스가 엄청나게 강력한데다가 신성퀘스트 클리어시 받을 수 있는 Zmey's old minion이 social 챌린지에서 역시 엄청나게 강합니다. 메인퀘스트시에 사람 수만 충분하면 social 챌린지로 쉽게 깰 수 있는데가 자이언트 퀘스트시에도 거인의 도움을 받는 선택지를 이용해 social 챌린지를 클리어하면 한 명도 죽지 않고 클리어 보상으로 거인이 파티에 합류하게 됩니다.말이 필요없는 가장 강력한 신이라고 할 수 있죠. lada역시 social 챌린지에 관한 보너스를 많이 주고 랜덤으로 등장하는 이벤트 중에 드워프 강도를 만나는 이벤트가 있는데 lada는 퀘스트 클리어시 드워프가 파티원으로 합류하게 됩니다. 이 게임에서 엘프,드워프 등의 종족은 인간보다 훨씬 강력하기 때문에 드워프 합류 퀘스트의 이점은 무척 큽니다.

게임 내에서 만나는 인카운터가 무척 다양한데 선택지가 중요하기 때문에 고난이도 클리어를 원하신다면 위키를 보면서 플레이하시길 추천합니다. (하지만 업데이트가 되지않아 모든 퀘스트가 있지는 않습니다..)

다들 즐겜하세요!

29157513.review: Card based combat is a bit odd, managing resources is a bit tedious, but I really like the idea behind, lore & artwork are refreshing, well done.

29156548.review: 游戏可以很好玩，就是中国的朋友不那么幸运了没有中文。

29138532.review:
Не без своих шероховатостей конечно, но игра отличная.
     Получилось написать немало, но послушай. Сама игра почти что полностью состоит из тонн текста, так что привыкай.

   Атмосфера. Играется так, будто бы находишься в некоем сказании или же мрачной сказке. Вокруг полно разнообразных мистических существ, древних сущностей и различных народов, пытающихся изменить этот мирок под себя, загубить его окончательно или же просто выжить. Способствуют погружению отличные рисунки и иллюстрации и приятный голос рассказчика, который озвучивает практически каждое событие в игре. И как я уже упомянул, игра текстовая, так что тут пригодится хорошо развитое воображение, что конечно же может оказаться фатально, для некоторых.

   Геймплей. Всегда имеем лишь одно поселение, в котором временами строим полезные постройки и производим снаряжение. Там же собираем пару отрядов и отправляем их на исследование мира, стараясь обследовать интересные места, руины, логова монстров и вообще всё что встретим. Попутно собираем ресурсы, дабы не помереть от голода, дрова, чтобы было из чего разжигать костёр и вообще всё остальное, чтобы было из чего стоить полезные постройки и производить снаряжение. Чтобы потом собрать пару отрядов и отправить их на исследование мира, обследовать интересные места, руины... ну вы поняли. Лично мне не хватало возможности основать ещё поселения, или же, хотябы, форт/аванпост/заставу, но карты тут не то чтобы большие, так что ладно. 

   Боёвка. Вооружённые столкновения, магические ритуалы, скрытность, охота, убеждение, травничество, испытания на выносливость, тактические изыскания- всё это оформленно в виде карточных игр, для каждой из которых требуются свои характеристики персонажей. Думаю хватит пары-тройки битв, чтобы уяснить общую суть здешних правил. Благо что всё не столь сложно, но и не столь просто как кажется. Лично я бы предпочёл пошаговые бои, без каких либо карт, ну да ладно. 

   Вариативность. Практически каждое событие, коих превеликое множество, имеет от двух до, примерно, восьми вариантов развития, многие из которых аукнутся вам ещё нескоро. Наличие оных зависит от характеристик вашего отряда, божества, наличия определённых предметов/персонажей, принятых в прошлом решений и т.д. Количество неактивных по вышеперечисленным причинам вариантов, указанно в скопках. Правда без обьяснения причины. Но так как рандом тут лютый, то события могут повторяться часто. Хорошие и не очень. Имейте ввиду.

   Крафт. В принципе, всё и так можно найти в разных сокровищницах или выбить из монстров, но смастерить вещички можно на порядок лучше, были б ресурсы. Да и наготовить еды перед походом, лишним точно не будет. Другое дело что не все предметы одинаково полезны, но это скорее зависит от вашего стиля игры. Хотя лично мне не понравилось меню крафта и инвентарь отрядов в целом. Ресурсов и предметов постоянно огромное множество, а разгребать всё это слишком неудобно.

   Музыка. Очень подходящие и красочные композиции, первое время слушать одно удовольствие. К сожалению, игра рассчитана на долгое прохождение и от этого большая их часть приедается. Но даже тогда ничего, лично меня, напрягать не начало, что радует. В боях дело дело обстоит чуть похуже, но в целом, всё очень неплохо.

   Реиграбельность. Заканчиваем своё приключение в качестве одного из богов- открываются новые возможности для него же, чтоб новый заход был пободрее. Или же выбираем только что открытое нами божество, дабы поглядеть, как история может повернуть в этот раз. Но хей. Тут только один сценарий?! Да, там полно различных развилок. Да, можно спокойно продолжить играть после, как бы финала и обнаружить что впереди ещё половина игры. Да, тут полно случайных событий и новый заход может быть абсолютно непохожим на предыдущий. Но история то одна. Может в будущем что-то изменится и нам дадут таки выбор глобальных сценариев, но пока что сей факт меня печалит.

   Если учесть что все длс для игры абсолютно бесплатны (кроме Coffee for Coding, которое просто донат для добродушных разработчиков) даже порекомендую к приобретению за полную цену. Тебе читатель, спасибо за внимание, а вам разработчики, за отличную игру.

29135515.review: At first 3~10 runs (depend on how you give up a run) the game mechnic may be hard to learn.  And some event arts are repetitive and confusing. But  it gets more much fun after you get how the mechanics work. Highly recommended.

29132301.review:
Incredibly fun game, totally has me just wanting to take one more turn, play one more game.

The game has the 4X style hex based movement...however you're not building up new towns, you're more splitting up one set of people to stay back at your town while others go forth to gain material and kill off enemies for loot.

You have a gathering/crafting/building tree that you unlock through gaining research from building stuff.

It's a very nice balance between keeping your home safe, while adventuring forth to get new items to bring back to upgrade your town and your party to defeat stronger and stronger enemies.

And the voice acting is just so good.

Definitely a worthwhile game.  Just shy of 100 hours, and I'm not seeing myself stopping any time soon.

29131303.review: Jogo que mistura RPG, estratégia em turnos, sobrevivência e combate com cartas ao mesmo. Muito bom com bastante variedade e jogabilidade. O único senão para o falantes de língua portuguesa é que ele não tem tradução para a nossa língua. É uma pena, pois quem não sabe inglês vai perder boa parte da história do jogo que é muito interessante.

29124879.review: Engaging game with much replayability.  I like the multiple units and ability to replay on different maps.

29120895.review:
Повелся на положительные отзывы и купил. Зря.
Игра явно страдает от непродуманности общего геймлея. Набор из нескольтких игр, который никак толком не состыкован в единый механизм.
1. Общая карта, развитие города, отряды, добыча - явно тяготеют к стратегической игре если и не 4X, то хотябы на уровне 1-2 цивилизации. На выходе 1 (ОДИН!!!) город, который можно развивать, большая карты с кучей ресурсов и микроменеджмент лагерей сборщиков. Забыли пригнать домой и они насобирали 100 тонн камня? веселый менеджмент побегушек туда с угадай-сколько положить (нельзя было сделать кнопку "нагрузить до грузоподъемности"??????).
2. Битвы. Недокарточная игра, потому что до боя нельзя отгадать какие у кого будут абилы. Параметров и людей множество, людей тоже много. Следить за этим уже надоедает и вем шмот пихается на глазок. Бои играются автоматом и рандом лечтистя чере Save/load. Явно самый лишний и слбый элемент в игре.
3. Еда и топливо. Вообще задумка хороша (самому даже в голову когда-то приходила), но реализация явно хромает из-за излишнего менеджмента. Это явно не то уложнение, которое добалвляет фана игре. Нужны кнопки вида "загрузить паек/топливо на 5 дней".
3. Квесты и события. Лучшее, что в игре есть. И из-за чего терпится всё остальное. Вместо бесцельных шатаний по пучтой карте можно было свести до механизма Hand of Fate или FTL и игра бы не пострадала.

Если бы населить глобальную карту событиями и симуляуцией жизни вроде Космических рейнджеров (конкурентные группы других богов, стырые ковены со своими целями, торговые/военные союзы, толпой отбится от фауны, защищаться от марадеров и попутно тянуть глобальные квесты) то игра была бы бомба. А так слишком скучно гонять одинокий отряд по карте туда-сюда и надеяться на рандом в битвах. Слишком.

29103393.review: Extremly fun feels unfinished near end game but fun nonetheless

29102710.review:
[b]Thea: The Awakening[/b] ist ein Survival- Strategie- RPG- mix

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Das Gameplay des Spiels ist einfach zu erlernen und schwer zu meistern. Man steuert eine Gruppe aus überlebenden des Zeitalters der Dunkelheit, welches über Thea hereingebrochen ist und hat die Aufgabe, diese kleine Scharr am Leben zu erhalten,herauszufinden, was Thea zugestoßen ist und das wieder in Ordnung zu bringen.
Zu diesem Zweck erkundet man die Gegend, kämpft gegen allerlei Monstergezücht und sammelt alles, was sich als nützlich erweisen kann von bloßem Brennholz bis hin zu Waffen und Rüstungen, die die Apokalypse überstanden haben.

Zu Beginn wählt man eine von zwei zufällig freigeschalteten Gottheiten aus dem Pantheon Theas, das aus insgesammt zehn Gottheiten besteht. Die Götter untersheiden sich in ihren Eigenschaften zunächst kaum, aber je weiter sie in ihrer Stufe aufsteigen, indem man als Diener der gewählten Gottheit Theas Gefahren überlebt, desto mehr werden Ihre Unterschiede sichtbar. Eine Gottheit beispielsweise verleiht ihren Schützlingen Schadens und Rüstungsboni im Kampf, eine andere verbessert die Fähigkeiten ihres Volkes beim einsammeln von Rohstoffen.  

Eines der Glanzstücke des Spiels ist das Crafingsystem, mit dem man nicht nur allerhand Sachen bauen kann, sondern auch hierfür unterschiedliche Materialien verwenden kann, was die Eigenschaften des fertigen Gegenstandes entscheidend beeinflusst. So haben Waffen aus Schwarzholz einen giftigen Effekt, während andere mit erhöhtem Schaden zuschlagen, aber nicht nur Ausrüstung, sondern auch Gebäude lassen sich auf diese Weise bauen, so kann ein Gebäude, für dessen Erbauung Bestienknochen verwendet wurden, wilde Tiere anlocken, die sich der Sache des Spielers anschließen. Eben so können Boni, die die Gebäuse sowieso verleihen durch seltenere Materialien verstärkt werden. 

Bevor man jedoch Zugriff auf erlesene Materialien hat, muss man erlernen, diese abzubauen. Das funktioniert, indem man mit Hilfe von Forschungspunkten, die man durch den Bau von bestimmten Gegenständen erhält, im Forschungslevel aufsteigt und die so erlangten Punkte entsprechend investiert. Auf diese Weise erlernt man auch das Herstellen von Gegenständen und errichten von Gebäuden. 

Ein Kernelement des Spielst stellt das Kartenbasierte Kampfsystem dar, welches relativ einfach zu erlernen ist und bei verschiedenen Gelegenheiten zum Einsatz kommt. Ob nun ganz klassisch beim Kampf, bei anderweitigen Körperlichen Herrausforderungen oder anderen Gelegenheiten. Die Mitglieder der eigenen Gruppe dienen hier als Karten, deren Offensiv- und Deffensivwert sowie andere Eigenschaften von verschiedensten Parametern abhängen. Welche das sind, hängt von der Herrausforderung ab, der man sich stellt. Oftmals kann man wählen, wie man verfahren möchte.
Möchte man mit den Banditen verhandeln oder erledigt man sie einfach? Das liegt in der Entscheidung des Spielers.

[b]Zusammenfassung:[/b]
[list]
    [*]+komplexes aber Benutzerfreundliches Craftingsystem
    [*]+viele verschiedene Quests und Szenarien, die oft mehrere Vorgehensweisen bieten
    [*]+freies Speichern und Laden
    [*]+frei deffinierbarer Schwierigkeitsgrad

    [*]-viele Charakterattribute, man verliert leicht den Überblick
[/list]

[b]Fazit[/b]
Thea: The Awakening ist ein Survivalgame der etwas anderen Art. Durch den Genremix ist es nicht nur für Survivalgamer sondern auch für RPG und Strategiefans interessant und bietet aufgrund der Zufallsgenerierten Weltkarte ein immer anderes Spielerlebnis und ist toll für zwischendurch oder zum dauersuchten geeignet.

29062314.review:
C'est l'un des meilleurs jeux auquel j'ai jamais jouer. Je lui ai mis plus de 200 heures, je l'ai poncé en difficultée 350, et j'ai aucun regret sur chaque minute passée sur ce jeux, ni sur le clavier que j'ai casser, ni sur les 11 boites de xanax que j'ai consommé.

C'est un jeux designé pour les HCG, même si il peut-être abordé en tant que casual. Il est fait pour le challenge, la souffrance, la colère et la frustration. Et c'est ça qu'est bon.

Il demande énormément d'investissement pour être maitrisé, mais très peu pour être compris. Les artworks sont magnifiques, le thème est interessant et peu connu, et le studio de développement est génial avec une bonne politique qui ne se fout pas de la gueule des joueurs. 

Voila.

PS : La meilleure divinité pour le 350% difficulté (maximum quoi) c'est Lada au niveau 5. Ne me remerciez pas, et acheter le jeu avant que le 2 sorte en aout. Après, allez acheter le 2.

Thea is a choices matter RPG that beautifully got blended into turn based strategy. Tons of quests, narrated by one surprisingly good voice actor, the events and the story can get you lost in a magical world.

The game was off putting at first. Not because it is difficult, but it is really new and different. I did not like it for the first 2 hours much, seemed to weird, but there more I gave it a chance, there more appealing and interesting it started to become.

29051665.review:
I am so sorry I didn't buy this sooner.

There is so much right with this game.

A friend of mine wanted someone to try co-op with, and for 10 bucks(on sale) I figured I'd give it a shot. But I had literally never heard of this game before. 

So I booted it up in single player before my bud was off work, got a little of the basics down, played 3 hours. Then another 2-3 with him. Then another couple after he went to sleep. 

Started looking at some guide type content for it that night. Realized it has been out for a SOLID YEAR and I hadn't heard a thing about it.

It's a fucking travesty that Thea hasn't had it's praises yelled from the highest roof tops. The oddness of the narritives and setting, the variety of gameplay elements to consider, the level of investment I feel playing this game puts it far beyond a normal gaming experience. 

I think the disconnect in terms of sales is that watching videos about Thea it looks like a card game, when in reality it's an rpg with some random number generation thrown in, and a big focus on turn order. Fan's of Darkest Dungeon, Mount and Blade, Hand of Fate, and narritivly driven rogue lites will have a blast with this game. 

I'm sure it tops out at some point, becomes repetitive, boring at some level as all games get. But I've just started and I cannot beleive I've never heard of this game before. I'm blown outta of the water. 

Congrats to MuHu for creating such a marvelously crafted game. Anything they put out in the future will have my full attention, and any money I can put into the developers pockets will be gladly handed to these folks in the future. 

I owe you folks another 10 dollars at least(on account of the sale) that you can redeem the next time you release anything. I'm so thankful people still lovingly craft games like this. It isn't even  in a genre I normally enjoy, but when something this good comes out it doesn't really matter what your preferance is. 

If you give it a shot you will enjoy it.

28997354.review:
"Thea" is definitely good for several play-throughs, and worth the money at full price. The quest writing, the music and the voice talent are all really, really excellent. I give it 4 out of 5 stars. The game has the potential of becoming a classic, 5 stars, a really great game, if they add more quests and if they balance the early, mid- and end-game better. By the end-game, I am winning all fights/quests easily on auto-resolve, however this may be due to the AI fighting my side using the best card combos? Also, it would be great if you could start play as the other races, e.g., Orcs, Goblins, Elves and Dwarves and not always have to start as humans (this would requiring play balancing as the other races are typically stronger and end-game characters). Try it, you will like it if you like games like Civ, and especially if you like card combat games.

I have played "Thea" all the way through three times now. It took me about a day each time, but I was progressively making it harder each time.  I haven't really figured out the card combat that well, but there is a good tutorial on their wiki site. If you like card combat it looks quite interesting to try and figure out (I just have never gotten into it). Your RP characters are your "cards" and at the beginning of a engagement they are split into two decks, offense and tactical.  Playing the offense cards is obvious but playing the tactical abilities of your characters/cards takes some learning.  There is one round of laying out cards, and then two rounds or combat, and if there are still characters left, you start over again.  However, you don't have to do the card combat, as you can auto-resolve all engagements.  Once I have built up a reasonably tough "expedition" team, I mostly just auto-resolve engagements. This also makes the game go much faster, if that is your desire. 

 Below are a few things I learned on each play-through. You can start the game as many times as you want for the first turn, so try to start with at least three materials to gather within your town's zone of 7 hexes, i.e., vegetables and wood and another building material besides wood, like sandstone, clay, or granite (in that order), and herbs, leathers and/or metals are also very good. Don't leave your town undefended as you only get one town. Keep gathering and producing things as much as possible every turn. More production leads directly to more research points. Use your earned research points allocation smartly between resources you can gather (look at resource map first), crafting new items (don't pick swords if you don't have metals, etc.), and building your ten buildings. I tend to build several gardens first to attract human children and adults and destroy them later to build different buildings or better gardens (using better materials). Do craft better gathering and crafting tools as soon as possible, the better materials you use the more effective the tool/weapon/armor/shield/charm is. 

Try to construct buildings as quickly as possible (but the better materials you use the more benefits they give so try gathering those first, which means you may have to select them first with your research points, so plan ahead).  Trying the different construction materials for buildings is also fun, as some might give you access to children, Humans, Elves, Goblins, Beasts, etc., depending on the type of material you have available and use.  Or you might get a much better sword or armor by changing up the materials (three types per item).  You have an unlimited party size, so outfitting your RPG characters is lots of fun assigning weapons, armor, charms, tools, etc. There are weight constrictions (strength) on how much each character can carry, so pay attention to that when assigning armor, etc.  You have to take wood (<10) and food (as much as you can spare while leaving carrying capacity, in other words, your expedition, between its outfit, wood and food should equal about half you carry weight, so that you have capacity to carry back stuff you have gathered or gained in fights/quests).  

While building a party of mostly warriors with stats in damage, armor and shielding will work, you should also bring along other characters in your expedition(s) that have other stats (herbalism, divination, dexterity, sneak, magic, etc.), because you can solve quests not just by fighting, but also in other ways. In other words, a fight against a dragon might be 5 skulls versus 2 skulls to sneak past him if you have that skill improved on a couple of characters. I like to take a mix of fighters, hunters, a medic (so you can camp and heal while out of town), and any other beings you collect along the way through quests (e.g., Witches, Humans, Elves, Goblins, Beasts, Demons, Giants, Trolls, Orcs, Dwarves, etc.). Camp immediately after an engagement during which your party members were seriously wounded, or they may die.  

There are two primary quests, one for your god and the other to quell the giants, do those carefully as they are both worth extra victory points. If you play on the lowest two difficulty settings you can save before most every quest, fight, etc., that you initiate, so you can replay if you screw it up.  However engagements can be initiated during the AI's turn, and they frequently are, sometimes several in a row, so save often. If you play on the last two settings, you do not get to save then you permanently suffer the consequences of the quest results if you lose (cursed, killed, wounded, sick, etc.). On the other hand, since many of the quests repeat, most of the fun is in the first play-through when you don't know which paths work best to choose when answering the quest's questions.  There are different consequences (I.e., better rewards or more painful results if you choose A, B, C, or D). It is worth continuing to keep playing after you have "won" to build up the victory points for the total for that god (there are 8 in all that give you different starting benefits).

When crafting items, there are typically two types of ingredients and one catalyst.  You have different choices of materials for the first ingredient and then again for the second ingredient (and sometimes they overlap, e.g., you could use wood and sandstone, or wood and wood). The catalyst only affects the quality (but only after you have built the smithy, so only use wood until you do). Coal and gold make good catalyst. Never destroy items, instead break them down into their components to reuse, preferably in town so you don't have to carry them around, but you will have to do this at times while on an expedition to keep below your carrying capacity. Your party eats one food per turn and burns one wood per camping turn (to stay warm and cook food). They don't burn wood while moving but they do eat food while moving. You have to camp to gather materials and to heal (very important as new characters are slow to be attracted to your town in the early game). You can move 5 hexes per turn, but there are terrain affects (though apparently just for movement and not for combat).  You can barely move or cannot move at all, if one of your party is carrying too much weight. Inventory control for the expedition party is important, compare items and disassembly the poor quality ones. Keep an eye on the weight of an item as well as its other stats, as a level 20 axe may look great, but not if it weights 200 pounds and none of your low level characters can carry it. Warriors can carry a two-handed sword in one hand and a shield in the other, while Dwarves can carry a two-handed hammer in one hand and a shield in the other (and you would think that Orcs could then carry a two-handed axe, but they can't, go figure). Anyway, you can tell I enjoyed the game. Have fun!

28972204.review:
Bon ...
pour faire rapide :
- la traduction est pénible et parfois incompréhensible voire à contre-sens, c'est insoutenable à la longue.
- l'interface de gestion souffre de problemes de logique mineur genre nécessité de confirmer la sortie du panneau pour valider l'allocation d'un personnage à une tâche ce qui fait qu'on ne sait pas toujours il est bien alloué à une tâche.
- Le système de combat est ppfff .... comment dire ... bordélique et non intuitif voire incompréhensible genre les carac des persos changent suivant le combat et certains personnages disparaissent durant le combat mais n'on pas de blessures à l'issue donc WTF?, il n'y a pas de gestion des blessures et des soins : non.
- Le brouillard de guerre permanent sur les terres déjà découvertes c'est lourd et pas esthétique du coup la carte est toujours toute grise : c'est laid.
- la sauvegarde est une horreur ! pas de points au  choix et une recharge qui ne relance pas forcément le point sauvegardé !!!!!

En clair, Le jeu n'est pas fini et nécessite d'être beaucoup beaucoup amélioré au niveau de l'ergonomie.
Pour autant, le thème est super, les idées très bonnes, le style original et l'ensemble intéressant mais tous ces points sont pour l'instant largement minorés par rapport à une prise en main pénible et un gameplay inconfortable et une sensation de hasard et d'incompréhension des ressorts du jeu. 
Plus de stress que de plaisir à jouer => c'est non.

à noter : aucun bug système, c'est un bon point.


Note à ceux que mon avis ne satisfait pas : si  vous avez rédigé une évaluation positive, je ne suis pas venu y commenter pour dire combien vous pourriez avoir tort.

28915457.review:
Hi les gens...

Dans le genre livre dont vous êtes le héros mais en mieux/ les dessins et la musique sont immersifs/ les histoires intéressantes....L'univers fantaisistes sans être trop kikoolol ou niais...le craft et la recherche présente.

Alors que dire si ce n'est que malgrès tout..on sent encore des rigidités qui sont les signes que vous subissez encore la griffes des developpeurs/ comme autant d'empreintes qu'ils veulent posséer et contrôler/
Les sauvegardes sont limitées/ les choix dans l'unique  ville restrictifs en nombre de batiments/ alors que la liste en propose plus/...Si certes l'on joue et démolit comme on aime..pour construire encore mieux/ Le levelling de vos créatures est souvent aléatoires et de contôle/ on s'aperçoit que vous subissez l'aventure sans vraiment avoir beaucoup de choix....

Bref/ c'est un très bon jeu et les dessins comme la musique sont magnifiques/ mais il manque malgrès tout une dimension qui est celle des grands jeux que l'on refait sans détour/ 

C'est un pas vers l'imaginaire avec des évenements aléatoires très bien conçus/ mais hélas trop réstrictif dans les aptitudes obtenue que l'on aimerait choisir/
Pourquoi mon araignée a-elle hérité de la capacité soins? pourquoi un guerrier se voit-il en level up  gagné des capacités d'Harvest? et inversement pourquoi un personnage que l'on destine au craft gagne-t-il des points de force utile uniquement au combat?.....
Tout ceux-ci dépeinds l'univers de ce jeu/ du possible mais c'est à vous de faire avec; si cela ne vous convient pas....!

Cela dit il reste dans l'ensemble très bon/ et les perfectionistes devront fermés les yeux sur bon nombre d'erreurs de traduction/ c'est un peu à l'image de cette univers/....On essaye d'être charmé par autre chose comme la sensation que notre village est l'unique hameau du monde!

Le coté immersif étant néanmoins le point fort comme un bon livre qui vous direz: "tu commence une histoire...ne t'arrête pas"...Mais le fait de ne pas pouvoir relire un passage au choix ou choisir vraiments ses aptitudes/ restent très frustrants/ comme les morts sans autel de ressurection ou de dieu réincarnant...bref/ il faut jouer de minutie; dommage/

Pour le reste il est dans l'époque des jeux...pas en reste...au damne des développeurs qui aimeraent toujhours qu'on ne compare pas!
Pour son intérêt il vaut le détour/ pour son manque d'envergure et  quelques petites frustratons de poids/ il reste dans le lot de sjeux corrects mais pas vraiment sensationelles!!

Et ceux qui me trouvent dures devraient voires plus de jeux et de moteurs d'animations!
15/20 (parce que les dessins sont souvent à la hauteure de l'histoire)

28880067.review:
First off, Thea has a strange learning curve to it. The tutorial is good, the game isn't hard to pick up, and it has a quasi Heroes of Might and Magic/DnD feel to it; yet you will get wrecked the first time you come into contact with a 4 skull group of enemies.

You don't "win" Thea, you just do a little bit better each time. 

Eventually you will finish the Cosmic Tree quest and you unlock more attributes of each god you play as. Then you turn up the difficulty and try a more stealth approach with a different god. 

For $10 Thea is a good game to buy. The card "battle" system is unique and uses the skills of your group in different challenges, the game can be very hard at times, and you feel good when you can successfully charm a group of bandits out of their loot because one of your group has +5 attractiveness. 

Nothing like medieval pimping to fully round out a DnD game.

28849578.review: Great mix of 4x, rpg and card game. Want to put poison bait down to take out the Wolves you just found? Fight it out with the cards to see if your plan worked. Took me a while to get round to buying this game but I'm certainly glad I did.

28763987.review:
I saw this game being played on Aavak's Youtube channel and instantly wanted to play it for myself. 

The graphics in this game are lovely. The cards are beautifully drawn and all your villagers seem to have a distinct personality which makes them really enjoyable. The map is gorgeous and captures the feeling of a world coming out of twilight. Combat is reasonably difficult, but once you learn how it works, it's great fun. Though if you accidentally get yourself into a difficult fight with a group that's not ready for it, it's nerve-wrackingly exhilerating. 

My main problem with the game is equiping your villagers. It's so hard to figure out if you have weapons with better stats or figuring out if a character has outgrown a weapon or not. But, that's my only complaint thus far. 

I highly recommend this for anyone who likes story-heavy turn-based games.

Started the game with the intention of potentially not liking it, but maintaining an open mind knowing this is a small dev team working on something relatively unique, and making sure to pay attention to as much as I could while I was playing it. Made a few early mistakes due to my lack of knowledge, especially on gathering and how important that is, but moved past it.

I'm probably only a quarter of the way through my first game around turn 190 and I'm hooked. There is nothing else like this that I've played, and for a good reason. The amount of content in this game is insane, and nearly all of it is voiced. I love how the battles work too, but I wish the non-combat battles were just a little bit easier to understand, as well as some of the rules for how many cards can be played when, etc. Being nitpicky.

I'd write more and more in depth but my eyes are burning from playing this all day, so I'll be brief;

Followed sales for this game for a while, decided not to bite until just now, and realized how big a mistake I've been making. If you've played games like Endless Legend, Fallen Enchantress Legendary Heroes, and Age of Wonders 3, but wanted more of a storyline and only needing to manage a single city, this is the game for you.

Thea, where have you been all my life, and why did I not give in to you sooner? I've been a fool.

28730187.review:
看了下这个游戏竟然玩了300小时了，写个测评吧。

首先这个游戏我是推荐的，即便抛开个人对这款游戏的特殊青睐，从比较中立客观的角度来看，它仍然是个值得一玩的有趣游戏，而且打折期间入手的话性价比很高。

这个游戏的本质是一个“跑团编辑器的官方展示模组”，不过不必担心你对自创模组没有兴趣或者是找不到人联机，因为我也是，但我仍然玩它玩得不亦乐乎。

于是我们不妨专心谈谈它的单机官方模组，这个游戏是什么样的，有趣在哪里？
实际上这是一个生存要素比较重的团——和很多单机跑团一样，玩家管理一支队伍而不是扮演某一个冒险者。游戏在初始便给予小队一个主营地，主营地不能移动，能进行简单的建设(但建设不是这个游戏的主要内容)，能贮存不限量的物资——而游戏的生存要素在于队员们每回合都要消耗显著的食物资源，以及地图上有着对早期玩家来说十分强力的游荡怪物，时不时会进犯在外冒险的小队或是营地，并且怪物强度会渐渐随着回合数上升。
为了应对游戏中这些挑战，就必须提到游戏中的“采集-制造”系统，这也是这个游戏的主要玩点之一以及最有趣的部分之一。在游戏伊始，玩家只能采集各种食物和各类“低级“素材，将素材运回主营地便可依图纸制造成装备。图纸对素材只有类别的要求，因而制造是相当自由的。而成品的属性则完全取决于使用了什么素材，每种素材在应用在不同类型的装备上时会体现出不同的特性，而其中设定又颇有逻辑可言。随着游戏的进行玩家会不断获得知识点数以解锁更多配方图纸和更高级的素材。但由于素材资源点的分布极为随机，这使得每一局的最佳策略都不同，玩家必须根据本局便于获得的素材来考虑优先解锁什么装备图纸，因为不同的素材利于制造的装备不同，而不同的装备又影响到小队的战斗方式和最佳小队成员组成，玩家需要通盘考虑，这便是有趣的部分。

在玩家度过了颇为紧张的中前期，积累了一定小队实力之后就可以开始冒险，跑主线任务。不过必须提一下的是主线任务并不是这个游戏的最终目标。这个游戏的最终目标本质上是“得分”，建设、制造甚至提升队伍规模都可以得分，玩家随时都可以结束本局冒险，只要你觉得目前拿的这些分够了。只不过主线任务的分非常多而且性价比非常高就是了。那么拿分有什么用？

这涉及到游戏第二个有趣的部分——神系。在每局游戏开始时玩家需要选择你的小队信奉哪一个神，不同的神掌管不同的领域，有不同的个性，为玩家带来不同的能力加成，以及在游戏过程中带来不同的神系主线任务（故事）。不过在第一次玩的时候多数神都是锁定的，解锁了的神也只提供最低级的能力加成，想要解锁更多神和更多能力就需要靠分数。
由于不同的神带来不同的能力加成，以及不同的神系任务（也就是不同的挑战），所以不同的神系开局的策略可能完全不同，这是神系之所以有趣的原因。

那么说到冒险、做任务的部分——首先这个游戏和传统的跑团模式相似的一点都是，它的冒险是基于“选择-检定”这个模式的。以传统游戏举例：你遇到一群地精，你可以选择一声战壕冲上去战（检定地精是否被你吓到），也可以偷偷摸上去刺杀(检定你的潜行和隐匿能力是否被发觉)，也可以上去say hello看能不能来一场紧张刺激的py交易（检定你的交涉能力等等）……这个游戏也是非常类似，只不过它有个创新——它把所有的检定都变成一次战斗，同时它把战斗变成一种普通的检定（听上去像一句话
什么意思？你不妨这样想象——你的小队现在要解开一个谜题，比如一个打不开的盒子。传统的游戏可能会给你特写这个盒子然后让你去发现其中的机关，但是抱歉，"这检定的是你的智力不是你的小队的智力"（by设计师）这个游戏的解决方式是，你的小队以他们各自的智力为战力去与名字叫“谜题”的怪物战斗，打赢了就算解谜成功 :D 没错，解谜的方式就是“打死谜“，偷袭的方式就是“打死侦查”，交涉的方式就是“嘴炮轰杀”，是不是特别的简单粗暴但又有微妙的代入感？
所以这样一来战斗的地位就与检定平齐了，既然任何鉴定都是战斗，其实你也可以看成战斗也不过是对“攻击“做出的检定。
这样做的好处有二，第一，非战斗检定的地位提升了，小队建设的多样化成为可能；第二，摒弃扔一次D20或者5D6这种检定方式之后，不仅非战斗检定的随机性大大下降，而且检定成为一次战斗也变得更有内容以及为有趣了。

那么这个游戏的“战斗”是怎样的？实际上很简单，设计师设计了一个游戏内置的小游戏——一个卡牌对战来表示战斗（不，我知道你想说什么，不是昆特牌）玩家的卡组就是由小队成员们组成的，每张卡的各项数值就是队员的技能值。所有战斗的战斗模式是统一的，但具体人物的哪些技能值被应用则不同——例如任何战斗卡牌都可以进行“援护”这个动作给队友卡牌增加抵挡伤害的护盾值，只不过在“战斗战”中援护的数值就是由护甲和盾牌上的护盾值提供的，而在“嘴炮战”则是由人物具有的“乡野常识FolkLore”提供的，在“偷袭战”是由人物的敏捷值提供的（依旧是微妙的代入感）。这使得玩家在建设小队的时候思考范围大大提升，不仅要考虑在战斗中队员相互间的配合，还要考虑在完全不同种类的战斗中每个队员不同的定位。

总之，本游戏在检定和战斗上的创新，我个人是给好评的。也是我对它青睐有加的主要原因。

最后，说完了游戏在“设计上”的概念，简单说说它在“实现上”的素质。作为一款独立游戏，可以看到制作人的用心，不过低成本制作的原因，整体制作质量和大作自然不能比。首先值得表扬的是游戏基本没有bug，这也是能看出用心的地方。音乐很好听，但一共可能就3、5条循环放。人物卡肖像非常酷，但装备、技能和素材图标就相当一般，UI也比较粗糙，整体美工风格也有不统一的问题。不过随着更新这些问题似乎在得到改善。

事件的叙述和NPC说话几乎是全程配音，这个好评。不过好笑的是所有NPC都是同一个男声的配音（就跟真的在跑团，有个DM似的），配女人的时候调门拉高三度就敷衍过去不说，竟然还有一听就是站话筒老远在喊的，还有什么给交涉战配些“呜呜哦哦”的效果音的，全都雷的不行。只能说设计师幽默感太谜

28650167.review:
A strange one this...in a good way if you play it enough to give it the chance it deserves. I can best describe it as a cross between King of Dragon Pass and games like Endless Legend or Fallen Enchantress. Hex based combat is replaced by a novel card game mechanic that takes a little getting used to but since I played it for 6 hours straight on the first sitting I can say it's definitely worth a pop if you're looking for something a little bit different. 

The tutorial is a bit of a mixed bag because, although it's well presented and voiced, it's not all that clear. Apart from the fact that going through the motions of the tutorial creates some atmosphere and gives you a few experience points you would probably be better off just pottering around learning for yourself - which is pretty much what you will end up doing anyway.

There is also some slight confusion with equipment because strong warriors can use some of the weaker weapons that are marked as two handed as one handed weapons but there is nothing, other than experimenting, that sets the ones you can or can't do this with apart.

You will often have to take a step back from the main quest line to grind up your level and equipment rather than attempting the impossible and permanently losing characters. If you don't it will set you back a fairly long time. It's easy to not realise this fact in your first playthrough as the difficulty spikes CAN appear without warning or through understandable errors on your part. You will also want to stay away from every kind of "challenge" that is not a straight fight until your party progression will make the other options easier than fighting later on in the game.

Story progression is interesting if not exactly stellar and that pretty much goes for the game as a whole. Expect something solid with almost never ending replay value and great originality but don't expect a world beater. 74%

28634376.review: Too Much Addiction in this Masterpiece!

28622146.review:
I played the demo and then bought this game and now played through the night in one go... Its currently 07:15 and what can i say? :D

Wow! just wow.

It feels a bit like pen and paper to me with the tests in different skills like speech, hunting etc 
but you do not roll a dice instead you do a 'fight' in that skill to check if you failed or not which is sooo much fun :)

Actually to me the game feels like a 'pen and paper' with the stories and encounters also 

it feels like a gamemaster reads where you are and what is happening :) there is a narrator reading the text for you and he is not annoying but pretty fun to listen to :)

The majority of encounters has different dialogue options or things that you can do and alot of them are 'hidden' it tells you how many are hidden but not what they might be. I think it has to do with the skills of each member in your party (speech, strength etc)

So the encounters and stories have tons of ways to play out.

The stories are great... The encounters magical there are so many items its crazy. 

It feels like thousands of items ( and i start to think that is true) then there are so many resources, different items you can craft, technologies, buildings to build in your settlement etc. Lets just say there is tons of content in that regard.

The god system to me is very interesting also. You pick a god that leads his people. Each god grants your people different bonuses.

After each game the god you played gets xp so he levels up unlocking new bonuses so the next playthrough wont be the same! Oh and you also need to unlock the other 6 gods as only 2 are avaiable from the start. Tons to do.

Also the world is generated randomly every time and you can choose how big the world is. So no playthrough is the same.

The survival element fits very good into the story and world i wont spoiler anything here so you just have to trust me here. Sometimes its rather sad when your awesome powerfull warrior woman dies. Or your party dies because of a illness :D

You want a party that has alot of different skills like one guy with high speech stats, a healer, a hunter etc. So you can react to situations that may come up.

The combat system is done via cards. 

Each companion is a card and each enemy is a card. Of course every armor/weapon you gave your characters makes their card stronger you and your opponent have a offensive and a tactical hand. With the tactical hand there are some special skills that you can use.

AND they did all dlc for free. I hate beeing ripped off by companies with mini dlcs everywhere so you pay 100€+ in the end but this model is very fair. I mean this is a quality product and then all dlc for free? Just awesome.

If possible i will buy the coffee dlc 2x after christmas if not then at least once.

They deserve alot of coffee. Good coffee thats for sure.

So if you like turn based games with tons of content, lots of choices, good story, sandbox world,  a survival element and free content updates go for it.

I hope this review helped you in your decision to buy it or not :)

28511912.review:
About time I wrote a review for Thea. I have played the game for 900 hours now and I still don't see myself getting bored with it anytime soon. More on the replayability later but first a quick overview.

Thea: The Awakening is a turn-based survival strategy game on a procedurally generated hexagonal world. It plays a lot like the early exploration phase in Civilization. The main difference is that the game is about survival instead of expansion. You won't build an empire with a large army, instead you have to defend your only village from evergrowing threats while also finding the time to go out and gather materials and do quests so you can become stronger. If you don't keep up with the enemies in terms of power they will overwhelm you but don't worry, there are many difficulty modifications. You can play on 50% (very easy), 350% (very hard), and anything in between. The game has a lot of RPG elements, an excellent crafting system, and a card game to resolve various types of conflicts. The game combines regular fantasy creatures such as orcs and elves with slavic mythology. If you don't know anything about that you'll meet a lot of new creatures here such as Stryga's and Baba Yaga's.

I would say easy to learn, hard to master applies to this game. It has a short tutorial that explains all the mechanics very well, and for me the game was much easier to learn than most 4xs. But figuring out the best way to deal with all the situations you get into takes much longer. The devs have really listened to the community and as a result the game is very balanced now, so there aren't a lot of wrong decisions you can make. There are many different strategies that can lead to victory and you often have to improvise and use a plan that works in your current situation, every game is completely different and you can't just do the same thing every time.

There is so much replayability and variety in this game. The world is randomly generated and so are all characters, your own as well as the enemies. Sometimes you'll have great materials near your village and sometimes your village spawns in the middle of a snowfield and you'll have difficulty moving around. Because of this the game will continue to be challenging and even if you have beaten it on max difficulty you may still lose the next game. Just starting a new game and seeing what your characters are like, what items you start with and what the world looks like is already a lot of fun.

Apart from that there are more reasons why the game has such great replay value. There are many different kind of characters you can get. You can attract orcs, dwarves, and other creatures depending on what materials you use for your buildings. You can also get new characters in random events. There are hundreds of random events that can occur and if that's not enough for you you can always download the ones made by the community, or create your own. Believe it or not, despite my 900 hours of playtime there are still several creatures that I've never had in my party and several random events that have never happened to me.

The story is alright and it is written in a rather unique way with a lot of humour. The random events can also lead to very interesting situations. There are multiple endings depending on the decisions you make and you usually have several options to resolve conflicts. Maybe your party isn't very strong but has great social skills so you can use diplomacy instead of weapons. Or maybe you have a stealthy party and can sneak away from the bad situations. As I said before, no two games are the same and you'll often have to look at your party and see what strategy works best in the situation you're in.

About the card game, your characters basically turn into cards during conflicts and you have to use them to destroy the enemy cards. Their stats and abilities depend on the stats of the character as well as the type of challenge. The mechanics of every challenge are the same but they all use different stats. It can be a little confusing a first but you can auto resolve if you don't want to do a battle. However this can be risky and can lead to unneccesary deaths so it is recommended to learn the game eventually. Personally I did not like it at first but after playing it for a while it became a lot more enjoyable. I still auto resolve the very easy battles since they can be done without risks.

Now about the crafting system, there are a lot of materials in the world that you can find either by gathering them from the ground, beating monsters, or from random events. When you do these things you get research points which you can use to learn how to craft/build new things or find and gather new materials. The items and buildings you make will have different stats depending on what materials you use for them, there is a lot of variety between the items and you won't be able to make the same things every time, instead you have to work with whatever you happen to find.

One thing people don't like about the game is the micro management. You have to make every character gather or craft and although you can make them continue indefinitely, you still have to give them new tasks often, for example if you run out of materials or if you want to craft something else. Note that this only takes a lot of time when all your characters are in the village. Most of the time you're out on expeditions so you won't have to deal with this. But when you do have your entire party in the village it can get very tedious, especially in the late game when you have 20+ characters.

Another thing I don't like about the lategame is that it's very hard to lose once you've stabilized. The challenges will continue to be hard and you will still lose battles, but actual game over almost never happens when you reach the end game, because you'll continue to attract new characters to replace the dead ones.

There are many other amazing things in the game that I haven't mentioned yet such as the card art and the music but you'll find out all about them when you play the game.

Last but not least, I just have to say something about the devs. They are a small team but they are honestly the best company I've ever seen. They have listened to the feedback and implemented many suggestions, and it has really paid off and made the game so much better. They are very quick to respond despite being such a small team. It has happened to me more than once that I reported a bug or made a suggestion, went to sleep, and woke up the next day to that bug already fixed or the suggestion already implemented. And it's not just me, I know many others who had similar experiences. Aside from that they made all their DLCs free and only gave us ways to donate when their customers were practically begging for them.

I don't expect anyone to do this but I would actually recommend to wait until the winter sale is over so you can buy it for the full price. When I bought the game almost a year ago I had just missed the steam sale and in hindsight I'm very glad I paid the full price for it, the game is worth far more than that.

28488826.review:
I really enjoy this game despite a few interface quirks and initial learning curve. I recommend this for someone who enjoys deep strategy games and roleplaying mechanics, who enjoys discovering new and complex game mechanics and doesn't need exciting animations but loves intersting stories. For me, definitely worth it and a great game.

Because the game mechanics are so original the more time I've put in the more rewarding my experience has been. Although the main story was only interesting the first few times around, this still promises many hours of gameplay just to see the main content. After 70 hours I feel like I've only seen a fraction of the additional side content and the giants expantion, which was added FOR FREE is pretty awesome.

The game has two aspects of play: the turn-based, tile-based movement of expeditions and assigning of tasks, and turn-based, card-based engagements which act as an absctact reprentation of the actual action in a given situation, from desperately fighting werewolves in the streets of your village to verbally outwitting a thunder god. 

Essentially each character has a set of stats in any number of fields, from attack to herbalism to attractiveness, which are then augmented by equipped gear. When the experience meter is filled all villagers gain one or two points in a random stat(weighted random? Another thing I haven't figured out). You can see all the potential stats using the filters at the bottom of the character cards (extremely useful!). These filters also go a long way to explaining the relationship between a given stat and it's affect during an engagement; this would be straightforward if combat were the only engagement but - it's not! As your party develops and the game proceeds you will have the choice to resolve engagements in various ways (do you want to use sneaking, hunting, poison, hex, or just fight it out?). Each of these types uses statistics in completely different ways so a huge part of the game's overall strategy involves creating expeditions that can handle different engagements, crafting gear and equiping to specific characters so they excel in certain engagements.

An engagement itself can is either auto-resolved or manually resolved with a mini card game. Each character becomes a card and is split between offensive and defensive hands randomly; the enemy deck is similarly split. The engagement plays through turns made up of play actions. The number of actions available each turn is determined by some algorithm comparing the relative sizes of the remaining hands; I haven't researched this extensively but basically if you have twice as many cards in hand you get twice as many actions each turn. 

This is a good example of the obscurity of the game design: After all my play time I still don't reliably know how many actions I will have any given turn even though this knowledge is critical to effectively planing an engagement. I suppose I could look up the nitty gritty details of engagements but it would be nice if this information was more apparent within the game as it's happening. 

Because of all this the game mechanics are a double-edged sword: They are unique and fun but also obscure to the point of frustration. I think this is where a lot of people will dislike the game even if they enjoy strategy RPGs and awesome Skandinavian mythology.

Personally as much as I dislike the game's complexities it is rewarding to slowly gain deeper understanding of them and the larger strategy of the game in turn. 

The late game starts to drag because one village starts to feel restrictive, although you can have as many expedition parties as you wish it would be rewarding to be able to establish an outpost near some high-value but distant resource and then maybe hire a goblin band to transport the resource to your village. You can basically accomplish the same thing with two dedicated expeditions if you have the logistical will to accomplish it but I feel like there is a lot of untapped potential in terms of the development aspect of the game.

Overall I'm extremely happy with this game. I'll just end with some random tips I've learned, sometimes painfully...

- Research: You get one research point by filling the research meter, which can be allocated to three different areas. You get research meter points by crafting things (you can see the value as one of the stats in the top when in the crafting screen along with the weight and % good quality) so the better the stuff you make the quicker you get research points. Any engagement usually gives a bit of research meter as well as experiance.

The three aspects of research are:
-    --Buildings: Become good mid-game but aren't worth it early for the resources they cost unless you have rediculous amounts of stone on hand. The better the resources you use to make a building the better the benefits from the building. This is especially good for the cabbage patch, where crafting with an exotic food will give a huge benefit over using cabbage.
-    --Crafting: Really important but dependant on which resources you have easy access to (are close to your village). You can click a crafting research to see which resource types are required for it (e.g. straw indicates any straw-like material, such as bamboo or wicker). So it's best to scout around first and then plan a crafting strategy (e.g. maces vs. axes vs. swords)
-    --Resources:  Most important early game but it's easy to get in over your head if you research and advanced resource early because each resouce requires a set number of gathering points to get the amount of the resource. So wood takes 60 gathering points to collect seven pieces, but ancient wood is something like 350 gathering points for 5 pieces. You need to level up gatherers and equip them with good gathering tools before you should invest in late game resources, but it's good to plan how you will exploit these if they are close to base. Also resouces only appear once they are the next available resource in the tech tree.

- Gathering: You collect resouces by assigning villagers as gatherers; obviously gatherers are best at this but any villager can collect for a base of 5 (or 2 as a supporter); for each additional villager assigned to collect a resource they will contribute half of their gathering stat (e.g. Pamlya has 5 gathering so as primary will give 50 gathering points to a resource; as a support she will add 25 gathering. Bolytstlava has 1 gathering and Ygrette has no gathing so if they both support Pamyla the total would be 57 (50 + 5 + 2).

- Resource Management: This took me a long time to find in the game, yet is really imporant. For each group including the village you can set which resources are consumed for fire and if new resources should be autmatically used (the little checkbox, wish this was more obvious because it's so helpful). I immediately set all groups to only burn regular firewood, uncheck everything else, and set to not use new things. Otherwise your villagers will end up burning that sweet dryad wood you got from killing that vampyre. Same thing for food, you can select which foods are consumed and if new foods should be automatically consumed or not. Nice if you're saving a specific number of somehing for crafting or reserving a food type for expeditions.

Thea the Awakening has been one of my two favorite Indie games that I have purchased in 2016, (the other being From the Depths).

Pros:
Masterful art design- the game is simple to run but its simple visuals are augmented by beautiful ink artwork for every character enemy an scene.
Excellent score- The music and sound is done as well as the best AAA games out there.
Deep gameplay- There is no single strategy to win and you have to learn your strengths and weaknesses to survive. It is fun and challenging and varried enough to bring you back for many new playthroughs.
Setting- The game world is constructed like a well written novel and feels natural and believable at every point.

Cons-
Learning Curve- the only con I can think of is the learning curve. this is not a game you can pickup and master in 20min. you will fail and have to reload or restart at least a few times before you get the hang of it but I like games with a challenge and if you make it through the heartache you will be rewarded.

Overall: I highly reccomend this game to anyone who is interested and doesnt mind loosing their first run. 
10/10 from me

28247814.review:
A surprisingly good 4x game with strong RPG elements. I had not expected it to be this interesting and good. Rule and take care of your village and villagers. Over time, you will get attached to them and any death wiill hurt.
Mini-card game to resolve conflicts and fight is nicely strategic and does matter. It is a little confusing the first hour or so, till you figure things out
I have spent many hours doing the old "one more turn" routine over and over again.

Few tips for starters:
- set your gatherers (people with gather skill - shows as an icon next to their picture while in gathering menu) to gather wood and food
- make your crafters craft food, crafting tools and gathering tools (and give the tools to the villagers that need them)
- create your own expedition with at least one gatherer, one healer and most others Fighters (I usually leave one figter in the village later) - give them cooked food and wood (50 wood and 100 cooked food will suffice for starters)
- explore around you with the expedition and try to find good resources to gather - then set up a camp and gather. Encounters and fights will come all on their own anyway.
- Protect your healer and after a fight - if someone is hurt, set up a camp and let them heal.
- Run around less during nights and more during days.
- Check and update the equipment on your villagers (mostly warriors) often as you get loot often too.
- Research new buildings and crafting in the research (other tabs)
- Good luck and have fun.

28241463.review: This game has a lot of excellent ideas and implements most of them very well. If you like strategy and card games and lots of events, this is for you. 28220860.review:
Ainda não sei bem o que pensar deste jogo. Estou jogando há umas 10 horas e ainda não passei do primeiro mapa :O
Basicamente é um game de estratégia em turnos, estilo Civilization, ambientado numa fantasia medieval. A novidade é um minigame de cards, visando a resolução dos combates e outros desafios, inclusive sociais, rolagem para envenenamento, caçada e etc, cada qual com um atributo especifico.

Como era de se esperar a história é bem descartavel e o foco aqui são as mecanicas. Os mapas são gerados aleatoriamente conforme alguns inputs de dificuldade que você selecionar. Existe uma main quest em cada um, que requer um grind consideravel para vencer os desafios. O mapa é bem grande, mas sua exploração e coleta de recursos é bem lenta. Isso é um grande problema - coletei recursos longe da base, agora é preciso seguir o longo caminho de volta. Estou recomendando - provisoriamente - esperançoso que acontece algum mind-blowing...

PS. Após jogar mais demoradamente (umas 25 horas) e conseguir terminar a primeira partida ou mapa, não posso recomendar esse jogo. Por que não? Porque ele se resume a isso: a um mapa aleatório com a quest principal repetida. É fraco em estrategia, com poucos elementos de variabilidade, side quests repetidas. Não vejo motivos para continuar jogando, pois será a mesma chatisse novamente - ir pra lá e pra cá no mapa e subir o nivel das cartinhas. Simplório.

28182731.review:
Kurze Spielzusammenfassung:

Man soll man seiner Gottheit helfen, die eigenen Anhänger aus der Dunkelheit in ein neues Zeitalter zu führen. 
Der Spieler verwaltet dabei eine menschliche Stadt und kann Expeditionen in die Welt aussenden, um zu erforschen,  Ressourcen zu sammeln oder Monster zu jagen bzw. Aufträge zu erfüllen. 
Dabei können in jedem Zug Zufallsereignisse auftreten, sowohl bei den Expeditionen sowie in der Stadt selbst, die zu Guten oder auch weniger erfreulichen Ereignissen führen können.
 
Die Anhänger müssen rollenspieltypisch mit Nahrung und guter Ausrüstung versehen werden, die man in Begegnungen erhält, aber auch in der Stadt selbst herstellen kann, nachdem man diese erforscht hat. Forschungspunkte bekommt man durch Ereignisse. Erwähnenswert ist, dass wenn die Anhänger keine Nahrung haben,  die Leute anfangen zu verhungern und dabei auch die maximalen Trefferpunkte sinken, was sehr ärgerlich und unbedingt zu vermeiden ist. Anhänger unterscheiden sich in verschiedene Klassen wie z.B. Sammler, Jäger, Heiler usw. und haben je nachdem verschiedene Start Atrribute.

Bei Begegnungen, kommt das Kartenspielsystem zum Einsatz. Dies habe ich nicht so sehr verinnerlicht,- es gibt jedoch die Möglichkeit Kämpfe und Begegnungen automatisch vom Computer beenden zu lassen und sich so mehr auf den Aufbauaspekt,- und Zufallsreignisse die in jedem Zug auftreten können zu konzentrieren. Wenn der Computer die Begegnungen abschließt ist das Ergebnis hier meistens fair und war jedes Mal besser als wenn ich selbst versucht habe die Karten zu spielen ;-).

Einige negative und positive Punkte:

- Die Götter sind mehr oder weniger gleich und unterscheiden sich quasi nur in den Bonis für die Anhänger (schnellere Forschung/Ressourcenabbau etc.), die durch gesammelte Punkte freigeschaltet werden. Hier fehlt auch ein wenig Hintergrundstory um beurteilen zu können für was der Gott nun genau steht, wie die Beziehung zu Thea und anderen Göttern ist usw. 

- Man kann nur eine Stadt gründen, wird diese erobert ist das Spiel vorbei. Das ist grundsätzlich nicht negativ, jedoch gibt es quasi keine feindlichen Zivilisationen in dem Spiel, die selbst über Städte verfügen und gezielte Offensiven gegen die eigene Stadt führen. Angriffe auf die Stadt erfolgen lediglich durch umherstreunende, nicht koordinierte Monsterhorden, solange man aber einige Bewohner zur Verteidigung zurücklässt, kann man eigentlich auch nicht verlieren.

- Das Interface für die Gruppenausrüstung & Inventar ist etwas unübersichtlich, wenn man Gegenstände zwischen der stadt und Expeditionen austauscht und seine Anhänger mit den neuesten, besten Gegenständen ausrüsten möchte, gestaltet sich dies teilweise in viel rumgeklicke, was ich aber nicht als so störend empfunden habe.

-- Langzeitmotivation: durch fehlende Zivilisationen (Quervergleich mit Civilizations) und den primären Fokus auf die Zufallsereignisse geht Langzeitmotivation verloren, weil man die Ereignisse und Story irgendwann kennt. Es fehlen  rivalisierende Zivilisationen/Rassen die einem das Leben zusätzlich schwer machen.

- Es gibt nur einen Kontinent der von Wasser umschlossen ist, aber keine Schiffe bzw. die Möglichkeit andere Kontinente zu entdecken

+ zahlreiche gut gesrciptete Ereignisse mit unterschiedlichen möglichen  Ergebnissen, die teilweise auch durch vorherige Handlungen bestimmt werden.

+ Gute übersichtliche Grafik mit Tag Nacht Modus (im Dunkeln sieht man nicht, was sich auf dem nächsten Feld befindet, daher sollte gut überlegt werden ob man mit der Expedition nicht lieber ein Camp aufschlägt und rastet)

+ Karten werden immer zufällig generiert

+ Möglichkeit auch Elfen, Dämonen, Zwerge, Orks, Geister und wilde Tiere zu rekrutieren

+ Gutes Tutorial (kann auch übersprungen/ausgebelendet werden) und Einführung um das Spiel zu lernen

+ verschiedene Siegesbedingungen

Fazit:

Thea ist ein überraschend gutes Spiel und macht hochgradig süchtig. Oft ertappt man sich dabei, dass man viel länger spielt als man eigentlich wollte ("nur noch dieser eine Zug..."). Für Spieler die Rollenspiel, Aufbaustrategie und Fantasy mögen, führt an Thea eigentlich kein Weg vorbei. 
Wie bereits oben erwähnt ist das einzig wirklich negative die Langzeitmotivation aufgrund fehlender, feindlicher Zivilisationen. 
Dieser Aspekt ist z.B. in Civilizations besser gelöst. 
Hier wäre z.B ein guter Ansatz gewesen, dass man z.B. auch eine Goblinstadt spielen kann und auch andere Rassen wie Dämonen, Orks etc.jeweils eine feste Stadt haben mit denen man bei Bedarf per Handlungsfenster  handeln oder auch Krieg führen kann. 

Trotzdem gebe ich für das Spiel eine klare Kaufempfehlung und hoffe in der Zukunft auf zusätzliche DLCs und einen zweiten Teil.

28088478.review:
I don't regret purchasing this, because this is innovative in a good way, but I don't particularly care for it and can't recommend it.

The game is split between the two meta phases of the roguelike "learning" (when you play blind) and "knowledge" (where you make concious and deliberate decisions), which will find you going from a sense of wonder to not having anything major to do.  It uses a 4x/Civ style map to navigate and locate resources, but the layout of the map can entirely invalidate the collection of said resources, because they have to be retrieved, turning large portions of the game into waiting games.

The resolution of combats/challenges also seems heavily random.  Combat itself will commonly feel tedious, despite its interesting play.  It lacks UX features which would allow it to go faster, and you might then find yourself using auto resolve, despite the risk, to just get through it.... and then you'll eventually find out that auto resolve scales faster than your ability to perform.  (Example: worst case chance of manual combat early game is some damage, but it'll be major damage in auto.  Late game it'll be risking people dying as a best outcome for manual, but auto can result in unscathed)

While the game gives many paths through it, they're all shadows of eachother, so while there is Fighting, Hunting, Stealth, and other challenges, they use the same mechanics but are derived from different skills, which gives a lot to keep track of when you're not actually doing different things.

At the end of the day, this is not much more than a Survival game crossed with 4x, but that doesn't mean it's all that bad, I just find the "playability" elements to be very tiresome.  A lot of information isn't conveyed, a lot of what you do is waiting for animations, a not a lot of the time really feels different from the rest.  Numbers change, "new things" become available, but it doesn't fundamentally change all that much from turn 1 to turn 200, aside from world scaling with you.

The game has a lot to offer for people that like micromanaging, because proper management, and a little luck, can lead to drastically accelerated progression, but the overall experience is just way too slow for me to get much out of the learning loop.

I have no real technical complaints outside of the game not having a very refined UX element, making clicking confusingly ineffective and easy to click on the wrong thing, and difficult to investigate the things you want to look at, wiht too much reliance on those hard to access tooltips to get anywhere.

If you're into the methodical nature of survival games, I can imagine you'd like this, but I can't swing it.
