I really enjoyed this game at first, but after the time i have already put in i don't really see myself playing anymore. I have beaten the game and i think i'm at like 40 hours of playing multiple games. There are MANY RANDOMIZED events that can happen while roaming and resting. Maybe i was playing wrong or too defensive, but i could only do a couple moves a day and then i still had to wait for gathering to happen. While waiting im just spamming the "Next Turn" Button until like 10 days passed so i have enough material to do something. After 10-20 hours of actually playing the events i found myself always pressing the "Auto-fight" button because it was much faster and unless it was a rare fight with supremely strong monsters i had nothing to worry about. It is different from most games i've played so that was unique and fun. 
Pros:
-Card type battle system (If you like card battles)
-Starting point changes, which changes how you play slightly
-Random events (for hour of 'seemingly' different play)
-nice enough graphics
Cons:
-it's a little difficult up until you level a few times then difficulty drops significantly
-You either go for buildings, or gear, or gathering. going for multiple will exponentially increase needed play time to get anything important.

It's hard to come up with exactly what i mean, but i think that's it. I would say up until the time i beat the game it was an 8/10 easy. I do recommend for at least one play through, but after beating the game i don't see replay value. I still think i got my worth out of it.

25678446.review:
Good Stuff: Nice worldbuilding - kind of like Elder Scrolls and Witcher, this world has a pantheon of original gods, elves, orcs, humans, and demons (though demons seem to be magical monsters which are naturally occurring or created by gods, and some are benevolent).  The art is fun, though I was slightly confused that my human villagers apparently included people who looked like dwarves alongside much taller people.  I did notice two places where the text describes a demon as having yellow eyes, but in the art the eyes are not yellow - perhaps that will be a minor bug fix in a future version.

Not So Good Stuff:  This is quite a slow paced game, both for getting research points and for the time each battle takes.  The micromanagement of crafting and gathering and equipping characters is also part of the slow pace, though certainly this type of gameplay is part of the RPG and strategy game paradigm.  I lost both my first two games due to having more villagers killed of than were born or willing to join me; the second game I almost starved right at the beginning because my starting location didn't have any food but seaweed.  (This is for a game on normal difficulty and all settings default - there are some options for increasing animation speed and customizing difficulty that I haven't tried yet.)

Despite all the micromanagement during the game, you don't seem to be able to micromanage the starting set-up, like by placing your village or choosing appearances for your villagers.  You can re-name them though, that part is nice.  There might be a way within the game to build a second village or move your village, but if there is I didn't find or unlock it.  You also cannot manage save files - you can't even quit without saving if some disaster has just occurred.  I can see how this fits with the idea that each game unlocks new options in future games, but it's still frustrating to lose half your villagers, especially when pursuing one of the main quest lines, so it's not like you were doing something you weren't supposed to, and be unable to hit the undo button.

The combat also is a bit front-heavy; it doesn't add new features as you level up, so the complexity can baffle new players and at the same time players can get quite bored with combat before getting even halfway through a complete game.

Overall: This is a lovely game if you are a patient person who likes micromanagement and simulating a fantasy village, and doesn't get traumatized if your characters die unexpectedly.  I am not necessarily this kind of player, but I'm sure someone is.  I recommend new players play on easy difficulty, not normal.  If anyone is interested in modding this game, I would love to see a pack of colored versions of the villager art.

25674236.review:
Welcome to the land of Thea, it may look familiar, but it is entirely different. The creators of the game managed to piece together a unique and engaging world through well written texts, very atmospheric music, and an integrated crafting system. When I came across the quest in reference to Monty Python’s Holy Grail, it simply killed me, they shall have my heart-felt praise forever. 
The difficulty curve is brilliant, even small tweaks to the array of mechanisms could offer a whole new style of play. The True God of Thea level is nigh impossible without a good understanding of the core functions. The level of customization allowed for each of your villagers will be a blast for anyone with a taste for a good-old rpg setup, and the effects of random events and player choice could truly alter the ability of a character, making them unique and a real loss upon death, which maybe frequent. The card mini-game for fights and challenges are simple but versatile, bringing out unique customizations while maintaining overall balance. It works. 
The devs even give us the ability to create custom events, which I must say is pure awesomeness. The ability to write your own lore and obscure cultural references into the world of Thea is unbelievably satisfying.

A very engaging, very challenging game.

Lots of resource management and planning, and it all goes to hell because you took a risk that you shouldn't have. xD

The game is a lot of fun. It's quite long so be prepared to stick around for the long haul, and don't expect to be finished with it very fast.

Lovely music and the game is quite pretty to behold. The event text is well written and voice acted, and the game is very easy to pick up and learn.

All of the essential information you'll need about what's going on is usually readily available, besides sometimes if you get caught off guard and don't see the difficulty of the enemies who engaged you. (Kinda a big deal in deciding whether to auto-battle or not)

A few things to note:
-Playing only in multiplayer you won't be able to earn achievements.
-You can't see the events or battles of other players, which would be nice when you're about ready to end your turn and waiting.

Definitely worth the price of admission. :)

25467305.review:
TL&DR: Definetly worth your cash at this price and it has amazing devs.

I've been wanting to write this review for days, but everytime I put it back because "just one more turn and I'll close the game" turns into a loop that goes well past midnight. The game is amazing and they have been adding content steadily for the past year or so. The exploring gameplay is interesting and challenging. The combat encounters require thought and planning and the non-combat encounters give you this feeling of "Yeah Morgana the Witch sure is pulling her weight by protecting the party from the horrors of the Darkness.". Furthermore, the resource gathering is addictive and a constant (fun) effort to balance "Just a little bit more mithrill" and "I should probably get all of this stuff to my crafters back home."

The devs are evidently roleplayers who are in touch with their community, and the game presents plenty of oportunities to roleplay if that's the kind of thing you like. Want to play a super-racist band of human warriors? Thea's got you covered. Want to play a group of magic-tree-hugging elves? Sure, build your entire city out of elvenwood and the elves will come. Equip your dudes with armor or shields made of magic bones, and they are now magical combatants.

I do feel like the game could benefit from different starts (I'd like to start with a dwarf-only group, or maybe a Goblin-only group) pehaps attached to the different gods. And having a bigger random encounter pool could also enrich the gameplay. I also feel like the stat system could be presented somewhat more effectively, maybe color coding the stats depending on how good a character is at that specific skill, to make discerning which characters are good at what at a glance much easier. But I'm nitpicking here. At a 20$ mark this game definetly has given me way much more fun and roleplay oportunities than many AAA titles. And while there is plenty of room to grow and improve, i'm more than happy to go along for the ride!

25458243.review: Merveilleux jeu qui renouvelle avec créativité les concepts du 4x et du RPG. Vous voilà transporté dans les ténébres d'un monde médieval hanté par des créatures fantastiques mais soumis aux régles les plus réalistes de la survie. A vous de gérer votre petit village et d'envoyer ses habitants affronter l'inconnu. Prenant et dépaysant. Mais attention ce jeu est difficile, même dans le mode le plus facile. Un conseil : apprenez la patience. N' envoyez pas vos personnages inconsidérement dans des aventures dont ils ne reviendront pas. Fortifiez vous lentement et avec sagesse. Dans ce jeu les blessures ne disparaissent pas d'un coup de potion magique, elles mettront du temps à cicatriser et encore faut-il avoir un médecin sous la main !

25457683.review:
One of the finest single player TBS games to come out in the past decade. I've enjoyed this game very much, and am on my 4th playthrough. Although there are many repeating storylines, I find a new gem every game. This keeps me wanting to explore the world again and again, and the developers seem to update the game fairly often to keep the game feeling fresh.

Pros:
Deep crafting system
Excellent stories throughout
Challenging RNG
Hauntingly lovely music
Voice actor is wonderful (Some don't like him, but I do)

Cons:
Combat gets repetative
Starting location generation can kill a run before it starts
World map artwork feels flat (Get used to hitting the R key)
Every village is the same (Wish your buildings material choices would change the town apperance)


If you are into turn based strategy, with a strong desire to think out your long term goals, and you enjoy playing through games multiple times, then this is the game for you.

25425457.review:
My first impression of Thea was from a Youtube video and I came away thinking that it looked a little confusing, but interesting all the same - and my first game bore that impression out, however I was playing the vanilla release and hadn't installed the Free DLC for Thea. Before downloading the FREE DLC I would of given it a solid 6/10, however with the DLC it gets a 9/10 (it only misses a 9.5 or 10 because I havent tried Co-op yet, not because of any shortcomings on behalf of the game.) 
Thea is an in-depth turn-based strategy game revolving around Crafting, Survival and Quests set within a rich lore-filled world. Throughout my first (post-DLC) game I enjoyed the hell out of it and spent almost 18 hours completing every quest, exploring the map, researching and crafting gear and the only part of it I was disappointed with was that it came to an end. (You can keep playing for a good long time, but 150 turns after finishing the quests and storyline stuff I figured it was time to finish up and start fresh.) 
For a $20 game I got 20 hours out of it on my first play through using a single god, well worth the money - And theres 5+ other gods to play and level up.
Thea: The Awakening is an excellent game, absolutely worth the money if you enjoy Turn-based strategy, but if you cant part with $20 do yourself a favour and wishlist it so you can pick it up on sale.

TL;DR - Awesome game, Well worth $20 dollars, and all the DLC is FREE* and EXCELLENT. 9/10**

*Theres one DLC that costs money - its adds no game content but it serves as a way for you to support the fantastic devs and pay for the Free DLC they released if you wish to do so.

**Haven't tried Co-Op yet, but if its promise lives up to what the solo game delivers it would merit a 9.5 or 10 /10.

25372917.review:
The game is interesting, I guess kind of like King of Dragon Pass crossed with a bit of a 4x game, maybe a bit of Fallen Enchantress in there stylistically, a bit of FTL sometimes mechanically, it's hard to pin down. Fundamentally it's a game where you are presented with lots of choices in random situations and various numbers influence what choices you can make and which ones will work, the bulk of the challenge, such as there is, involves being able to intuit what numbers challenges are going to require from you, and making sure you have the right numbers in your group (because the game has a lot of different numbers to keep track of and is not especially good at showing which are relevant and when, it takes a long time to gain a feel for this)

Where the game falls flat is that there is so much randomness involved that you are frequently given challenges you can't realistically beat, other than by doing back in time and swapping out your group for another one, with another set of abilities. The game requires you to build specialized groups to be successful at a particular type of challenge, but will randomly throw unavoidable challenges at that group which they cannot solve with their skillset, building a generalist group is not practical unless you have a huge number of people, so mostly your success is determined by whether or not the game wants to roll a "rocks fall everybody dies" event on your group, replacing rocks with "obscenely strong enemies which are only weak to diplomacy or a special option you don't have" or something similar. I particularly like the event that can trigger from any point after the game begins which poisons your entire party unless you beat a strength challenge, which can only be cured by travelling across the world to a specific place and beating a challenge which your party members might not be able to do, or even get to in time. Or the other event that does the same thing to your home village without even a chance to avoid it. The game has a lot of that sort of thing in it.

The game is charmingly if a little cheesily written and obvious work has been put into giving lots of different approaches to situations, but precious few of them are going to be practical for any given group, and if you're given an event that your group can't handle, you can easily lose half your accumulated strength, so much of the game depends on just whether or not the dice want to kill you that the rest of the game feels irrelevant, you can spend all your time making interesting choices for marginal gains and losses, only to have the game decide it just wants to kill half your people and end your playthrough 200 turns in. It would perhaps benefit from being a better developed strategic game, where you could see threats coming and plan an approach, but the game really likes to just trigger random events when you start a new turn, or move one square, or an enemy decides to move into your square, or due to dialogue choices, or more or less any time. Imagine Civ 5 if enemy armies just sort of teleported around your city every now and then and you had to figure out how to beat them, it doesn't work very well, or fit with the perfectly functional strategic layer.

TL;DR, game is Tomb of Horrors, Civilization of Dragon Pass edition. If that's your cup of tea, well, I hope it's less frustrating for you than it is for me, I guess?

25337826.review:
If you liked Defiant Development's "Hand of Fate" game you'll probably like this... essentially every encounter in this game (which outwardly appears to be a Civilization-like game) boils down to a wonky, confusing, and terribly uninspired card game.  What a yawnfest.

Don't be fooled by the hex-grid map with characters wandering across it--this is not an adventure game (unless you count "choose your own" adventure... I certainly don't).  This is a card game which attempts to festoon itself with a research tree (like civ), crafting (like everything trying to capitalize on the success of Minecraft), and something that attempts to pass for "adventure".

This might be forgivable if it were an interesting or entertaining card game.

It isn't.

I think this game is just awful, and for my part I think if you want to play a really good card game there are several available (Magic Duels and Hearthstone spring to mind).  As far as the Civ, Crafting, and Adventure aspects go, there are so many other titles which do it better I can't see why I would bother with "Thea: The Awakening".

It's ironic that a game entitled "The Awakening" was so boring I nodded off while playing.

However, I appear to be in the minority given the rave reviews.  I recommend watching some extended youtube of this game before purchasing, if only to set your expectations accordingly.

25231641.review:
Interesting game, a very non-traditional 4x game, that has given me back the "Just One More Turn" feel that we all like to have.  You have a settlement, you collect food and wood, you have an expedition that sets about exploring the vast country side.  You make decisions on where you want to research, what you build and craft.  This game is a micro management game as you do need to produce and craft in order to drive research.  While you do get research from fighting, better to keep your crafters busy.  In order to keep your crafter busy you have to gather, either during battles with booty, or setting up a camp with your expedition and bring more exotic materials in.

Combat is simple, with a card like game play reminiscent of MoG.  It is a bit confusing at first, but after a few battles it really is not that hard.  There are plenty of events, monsters places to explore to help you gain experience and loot.  your Settlement has to be looked after, so while you may want to send your warrior party out as an expedition, you may want to ensure your crafters and gatherers have weapons and skills.

There are battles other than just fighiting, all similar but you can have social, hex, tactical battles so you need  a good rounded party.  This game has a lot going on, and so far it is a lot of fun.

25225364.review:
I can't reccomend this game.

The way the difficulty is in this game is VERY poor game design, basically it scales. However, if you get behind(And in the higher difficulties you always are, through the BS events that you have no control over and usually end up losing about 4 people due to poor RNG, nothing you can do about it.)and/or have less than 20 people by turn 100 in the higher difficulty(And you basically can't get 20 people that early, because again, events are BS, and even if they aren't you usually only get about 3~ people by that time.)

Not only that, but the combat is pretty shoddy.

And, here is the kicker, if you thought vanilla civ 5 was bad in where it placed your first city, imagine you are FORCED to settle where ever it places you, even in flatland desert without any hills or anything in miles. You can't move cities in this game, where you start is where you are. That's it. I have had starts where I had a single resource of food, that's it. Nothing else, no string, no wood, no nothing. Because reasons. You can NEVER make new cities, you can only set up camps, which, again if you have less than 20 people in that camp, you will be killed. In a game where getting people past 15 is nigh impossible, even with insane attraction rating in villages.

As I said, everything is scaled. Everything. When you have more people, you get less coming in from the world and less children grow up(Did I mention RNG?), but the less you have the more you get. But that's by no means any sort of realistic expectation when your party is killed by 4 skulls at turn 80(Imagine in WoW if you had a fel reaver drop kick you are level 10. That's what this is comparable to.)You probably won't get anyone new, because again, RNG.

So with all these complaints, I can't say this game is worth it. It's an indie game, I should expect it, but these flaws are painful. When they actually fix some of these issues, adding in growth maybe or something, I will change this review.

From what I saw there were several options I found to cause a differnt ending to the main story, however as the game tells you how many options are not avalible, I saw there were a huge more number of possibilitys on what I could do to change the ending.

I have barley touch the surface of this game and I want to keep going back for more. I was dumb at the end and simply ended the game as it was and completly ignored the DLC content. There is plenty left for me to do even after I completed the story.

Did I mention that you can play Co-op with another person? It's not the easiest thing in the world to setup as you have to grab the dlc and download it to be able to launch the game as multiplayer however it has given something for me and my brother to do every so often. I don't know if that has another story to it though.

Either way, I came to this game thinking it would play like Civ and I have enjoyed playing it so far and listening to the story, which in most games I just skip over. The story telling in this game is excellent.

If you are half tempted to get this game, make sure you give it a try.

25178779.review:
Pour caractériser le jeu, je dirais : jeu de rôle  (même si vous gérez ou groupe, et non un seul perso) dans un univers mytholgique, basé sur de la gestion,  de l'exploration et surtout du crafting. 

Jeu étrangement prenant malgré son côté, par certains aspects, fruste... Au début, on peut se dire qu'il manque certaines choses. Comme remarqué par des critiques, ce n'est pas vraiment un jeu d'expansion, puisqu'on commence avec un village (toujours baptisé du même nom, quelle que soit la partie !), et qu'on n'en crée jamais d'autre. L'expansion est limitée par la capacité du joueur à monter une expédition suffisamment autonome pour atteindre des régions lointaines. Mis c'est précisément là que le jeu devient ultra-prenant...

Grâce à des arbres de développement bien conçus, agrémentés d'un art-work qui assure vraiment, on développe les capacités (très très étendues) de collecte, de craft et de construction de son village. C'est vraiment passionant, car il faut des matériaux de meilleurs en meilleurs pour faire du meilleur stuff, mais celui-ci est requis en retour pour acquérir trésors mais aussi aller chercher des matériaux meilleurs etc. Bref tout ce qu'on veut dans un gameplay de gestion (l'aspect "économique" des ressources de baseest en revanche limité, mais c'est selon moi contrbalancé par la recherche d'aliments rares, et la cuisine), avec des vilageois qui progressent ainsi en capacités (avec des caractéristiques très nombreuses et précises). Petits bonus, comme le fait que certains bâtiments construits en matériaux précis attirent orques, elfes, démons etc. Le village développe ainsi lui aussi sa capacité à se défendre, parallèlement à celle du groupe d'expédition, ce qui est nécessaire avec la montée en puissance des monstres errants : c'est clairement un jeu de survie, et l'univers, par rapport à cela, est bien conçu.

C'est l'autre grande force : les récits, narrations, quêtes et événements aléatoires. On est clairement dans un jeu qui connait l'importance du conte, du "lore", avec de la narration et de l'écrit, et ça fait du bien, même si certaines histoires sont parfois un peu tirées par les cheveux. Plusieurs artistes ont contribué aux illustrations, parfois naïves, toujours très expressives. L'ambiance est très contes et légendes, univers mythologique, dans un cadre culturel slave. Les persos et monstres ont des noms russes, inspirés du folklore pour les seconds, et c'est très frais.

Les combats sont résolus par des jeux de cartes : qu'on ne s'attende pas à des animations . Celles de la carte du monde sont réduites à leur plus simple expression. Le prix tient compte de cela : tout le éveloppement du jeu a visiblement été focalisé sur le côté artistique et sur les mécanismes. Mais le combat par carte est bien fichu, simple et prenant, même si je ne sais certes pas s'il dépassera les attentes les vrais amateurs du genre (ne m'y connaissant pas assez) ; moi j'ai trouvé ça suffisant en termes de choix tactiques à faire -quel combattant placer où, etc. Et là encore, très grand coup de chapeau aux illustrations des cartes des persos ( eux-mêmes très très nombreux) et monstres. Enfin, il faut noter que les "combats" peuvent être aussi des joutes oratoires, d'intelligence, de "force" physique (bras de fer etc ?), sur le même modèle que les combats à mort et à l'arme, mais résolus avec d'autres caracs : sociabilité etc. Cela apporte une autre dimension narrative, dans un monde qui n'est pas que combat, et permet de mettre en valeurs d'autres caracs et compétences de nos villageois. Ne pas se leurrer ceci dit : le combat physique demeure la règle, et on ne peut pas avoir un gameplay vraiment centré sur la joute oratoire par exemple.

J'y ai joué des 100nes d'heure, malgré la répétition de la quête principale, ce qui est dire sur le côté prenant de ce jeu, et visiblement je ne suis pas le seul. Jeu passionant, au gameplay bien équilibré, très honnête pour son prix, clairement à essayer ; et puis à mon avis il faut encourager ce genre de jeux, qui savent accorder une part à la narration sans sacrifier au gameplay.

25171302.review:
I bought this game when I was made aware of the added co-op free DLC that was made for it. It does something I've always loved and is rarely done in city-management style games, even in RTS; allow you to have two players co-op through the main campaign.

The game has a lot of rogue like elements, and rewards replaying with out-of-game advancement in the form of levelling up the gods that represent the player. You start with two gods unlocked, and unlock more as you level up gods. In co-op, both players share the same god and level up that god's progress. Progress is saved on a per-host basis, meaning that both players can have a saved game, or if you have a consistent partner you can just both use the same one to maximize avancement.

The gameplay itself resembles something along the lines of King of Dragon Pass. You busy yourself with building up your home town while sending out expeditions to gather resources and adventure across the landscape. Random events occur in a mostly-positive ratio to mix up the gameplay. Unlike King of Dragon Pass, however, your individual villagers are much more important, and you're dealing with very small numbers of people typically. You start with 10, and build up from there, and have to split them up to make expeditions. There is a story through the game, involving finding out why the world ended, why the world started recovering, and working to make that recovery permanent(or not?). It has a nice blend of fantasy elements, and like KoDP its emphasis on magic is both subtle and highly impactful. You don't really cast spell, per se, but magical skills can make huge differences on how events play out.

A few tips I would give to anyone looking to play it, I highly encourage you play a game or two single player to get a feel for it before playing co-op, and THEN look at some guides to see what you were doing wrong. It's a complex game and actually ends up having something of a build order to it. Once you have that done, co-op will go much more smoothly. You wouldn't want to fail someone who's relying on you afterall!

tl;dr: Thea is a somewhat complex but inventive co-op adventuring city management game. It's roleplaying elements go down to individual villagers and their equipment, and the story is well written and imaginative. The interface could use a little work, but it's very functional and intuitive. The music is good, and the artwork that represents the game elements is pretty great.

25103055.review: GREAT game! This is the ultimate "one more turn" turn-based 4X game, with a variety of refreshing elements. First of all, there is a FASCINATING card-layer to how events and combat are worked out... I was really impressed with this. Every person has their own skills and stats in your settlement, so while all your fighters might fight well, and crafters craft well, and gatherers gather well... the REAL fun comes from needing to think about a variety of skills to have in your group to handle obstacles in your choice of ways, or certain challenges that require magical, technical, or obscure knowledge to tackle. The Card-Combat game is the same no matter if it's a regular battle or disarming a deadly machine or unravelling a hex, but the stats for each character's cards are different based on their skills and the challenges at hand. So maybe you can kit your party out so that everyone is decent in a straight up fight, but all of a sudden in a social or stealth challenge your front line fighters are taking a huge back seat to a couple of clever or specialized folks in your group. It's LOTS of fun and there is a lot of depth to it. You might have characters that do a GREAT job supporting front liners just like you have front liners that are GREAT if supported but meh otherwise. The card game is split between "Frontline" and "Tactics" piles of character cards... so you have to decide if you want to bring in tactics people "tapped" and get stuck in, or have the tactics guys buff your guys, nerf the enemy, change turn sequence... so much stuff. A guy with a bow and strategy skills can buff damage for a person on the front line, confuse an enemy, or allow your guy to hit first... all sorts of choices going on, which sometimes turns into "I have two people who have the lore or technical skill to unravel this challenge, how else can I set up the other guys to buy them time to do that?" The card layer is REALLY nice. Unlike many 4X games where you build lots of towns, you only have one town which you improve with better technology and materials you gather in the world. Crafting equipment for your people is also LOTS of fun... your adventuring party brings back all sorts of wood, food, metal, stone, gems... a wide variety of all sorts of commodities to play with. Then your crafter can go to town finding interesting combinations of the materials for weapons, armor, jewelry, shields. It's not just about what makes a sword sharper or an armor hardest though -- with the right elements and skill you can get armor to boost attractiveness for social challenges, add magic skill so even regular brute fighters have a better shot at helping against supernatural or magical threats, and a variety of other skills and abilities that have an influence in combat and challenges (like "leech" healing when you do damage, or "feint" or "Sturdiness" or "Stealth" -- all of which have different impacts in tactical challenges, regular fights, magical combat (hexing), etc. The world and story behind it are engrossing enough, and there is a sufficient beastiary and fun loot and lots of events that give you choices and risks to take, as well as all the dialogue being decently voice acted. There are multiple endings and really a lot of depth, as well as a pantheon of gods which give your followers more and special bonuses the more you "Level them up" by succeeding in the game. Few 4Xs have me startng a new game right after I finish the old one... but sometimes when I play this game I'm just psyched to unlock another god, or play again with the new powers my leveled up current god now has from my last game. This game was a TREAT. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

This is a lovely game with wonderful devs. They regularly update the game and go well beyond what I'd expect to help their players. They care, and that means a lot with all the unsupported schlock out there.

Anyway, the game itself is sort a 4x...  Except there's no eXpand. You only have one village and getting another villager is a pretty big deal. The research tree is large but well considered. The two major mechanics are a skill influenced choose-your-own-adventure (fully voice acted), and what I think is an extremely well done card based conflict resolution system. I say conflict resolution because it's used for sneaking, parley, outwitting, etc and continues to work great, although there is a small learning curve.

There is a lot of game here for $20, my only.... Negative, if you can call it that, is that I cannot even guess how many hours of voice acting have been put into this game. How much money and time and effort, and it's well done. But... It's a rogue-like, permadeath with progression, so you will end up seeing some of the same quests over playthroughs (a la FTL). Many times, if you know the quest, you're just going to click through it. So I've shut off the voice and I wonder how many others have as well after hearing it so many times.

But like I said great game much fun to be had!

24800725.review:
Thea is a great game.  I'd describe it as "Master of Magic and Sid Meier's Colonization had a baby, and that baby grew up to be a survival game." The setting, a post-apocalyptic fantasy world inspired by Slavic mythology, is pretty unique. The combat system -- which manages to use a single, card-based mechanic for combat as well as social and skill challenges -- is pretty fun once you get the hang of it. There is an absurd amount of crafting. The game narration is read by a single voice actor; this is usually charming but occasionally gets irritating. The map art is a bit muddy and it can be difficult at times to identify key terrain features, but the event and character art are all hand-drawn and uniformly good.

Downsides: each characters has tons and tons of stats, and even after a few playthroughs it can be very difficult to keep straight what some of the more obscure ones are for or how they affect the game. Resource gathering and management can become very tedious, especially if you get a resource-poor starting location and have to rely heavily on expeditions. A few of the random encounters are painfully unfair (if you ever had a small party hustling back to the settlement before nightfall run afoul of the Shadow Giant, you'll know what I'm talking about -- and those damn Dwarven Bandits can be really rough on an unprepared group).

Also, for your own sanity, don't research roasted meals immediately. You will become consumed with providing your townsfolk with a hearty variety of sausages and casseroles. That way lies madness.

[h1]═══════════════════════════════════[/h1]
[h1]OVERVIEW[/h1]
 
[b]Thea: The awakening[/b] is a turn-based tile-based survival strategy game with a card game system.  The game focuses on haveing your heroes go adventuring through the lands of Thea, fighting monsters, exploring ruins, removing curses, meeting weird creatures, getting loot, taking care of your people, and tryign to survive while getting stronger to save the world.
[h1]═══════════════════════════════════[/h1]
[h1]PROS & CONS[/h1]
 
[h1]Pros:[/h1][list]
[*] unique characters and creatures
[*] deep crafting system
[*] rogue-like elements
[*] Great art work
[*] unique combat card mini-game
[*] lots of events with many outcomes
[*] unique encounters
[/list]
[h1]Cons:[/h1][list]
[*] random encounters can screw you over with no recovery
[*] lack of control over character progression
[*] combat encounters are either too easy, or too hard.  no middle ground
[*] a single game can run for too long.  clashes a bit with the rogue-like elements of the game
[*] visuals are a bit murky on the over world map
[/list]

[h1]═══════════════════════════════════[/h1]
[h1]SUMMARY & FINAL RATING[/h1]

24656634.review:
Amazing game! Highly recommend!

A fantastic 4X game that really challenges you. You start off by selecting a god who is then tasked with making sure his people survive and grow.

You have builders, gatherers, warriors, hunters, mages, demons, and all kinds of other creatures that can join your village. You gather resources, send out parties to gather supplies or fight enemies. You build and craft new buildings, items, weapons and armor that you can then equip to your people to make them stronger. Your villagers level up over time increasing their stats.

There's a ton of quests all voiced which will have you choose different outcomes based on the skills of your party members. Want to sneak into a camp instead of a direct assault, or talk you way through the enemy? You can in some cases. Some paths lead to little rewards, while other paths lead to better rewards. There are plenty of choices that lead you to wonder what the other choice would have given you or done to your party member.

Combat is sort of a card game where you have a few starting characters, and other characters that can use different abilities, or enter the battlefield themselves. Equipping shields mitigates damage, and other characters can provide protection at the expense of entering the battle.

Lots of combat choices, and it takes a little while to master. It's fun to watch but I find myself skipping the early battles and really playing the combat in the later battles with 2-3 skull enemies and above.

Villagers can be killed permanently from their wounds in battle and you are always struggling to gather enough food and wood to stay alive (not really that hard once you get the hang of it).

I haven't done much of the story, but it's a very intriguing world, one which I hope to enjoy for many hours to come!

Do yourself a favor and get this game, support innovative developers like this!

24608266.review:
This is a game about inventory management, random events and clicking end turn until crafting and resource gathering timers are done.

When I started the game up I had high hopes.  The world seemed interesting and it looked and sounded nice.  However I was immediately overwhelmed by an abundance of stats, resources and strange encounters.  The game isn't overly difficult as it turns out, but the hopeless tutorial and poor user interface make for a very steep learning curve.

The heart of the game is crafting.  Send your villagers out to gather lots of resources, then bring them home and craft items to make them more powerful, allowing you to research better items and repeat the whole process.  Each recipe has many possible results depending on what resources you use.  This means there is a nice variety of items to make, but unfortunately you need to gather every possible resource and then combine them manually, one by one, until you find the best option.

While your are going about your business you will be given quests and be afflicted by various random encounters and wandering monster attacks.  This is where the abundance of stats come into play.  Each encounter can be resolved by various means according to what your expedition is good at.  Sadly (and obviously) you cannot plan for the random encounters and even if you could, trying to balance the numerous stats of 6+ different characters would be a nightmare due to the lack of any sort of expedition overview.

The actual resolution is achieved through a card-based mini-game.  These all work the same way, but the names of abilities and stats are different depending on the encounter.  While tactical play is possible, the mini-game is moderately interesting at best and slow and tedious at worst, when it needed to be amazing.  You can auto-resolve, but this just makes it even more of a dice roll.

Inventory and equipment management was a huge let-down and a major part of why I cannot recommend this game.  The interface is as you would expect in an RPG with a single character, but here you are managing 15+ characters and sending out expeditions of 6+.  As a result, the vast majority of my time was spent in the equipment screen, trying to make everyone effective without exceeding their weight limit.  In the end, too much work and not enough play.

Klein, fein, nett. Mit Thea kann man sich wunderbar einige Stunden beschäftigen, denn dieses Spiel verlangt einem eine gewisse Leidenschaft für Micromanagement ab. Jeder Charakter (Krieger, Arbeiter, Handwerker, Hexe, etc...) kann ausgerüstet und mit Artefakten und Schmuck behängt werden, um die Talente und Fähigkeiten zu verbessern. Ich hatte viel Spaß daran, über unzählige Runden hinweg die ideale Kombo zusammen zu stellen, wobei Thea einem viele Freiheiten läßt. Eine Gruppe von Kriegern, die alles umkloppt? Oder Konflikte doch lieber mit Redegewandtheit oder Heimlichkeit lösen? Je nachdem, wie viele Stärken das Team hat, erhält man in den Quests und bei Begegnungen eine ganze Reihe verschiedener Dialogoptionen. 
Je höher die Stufen, desto knackiger die Kämpfe, die man entweder selbst via Karten-Minigame lösen oder dem Computer überlassen kann. Es empfiehlt sich auf jeden Fall oft zu speichern, denn meine Helden wurden nun schon mehrfach von einem zufällig auftretenden Riesen zu Brei gematscht, von einem Drachen gefressen oder von einer Krankheit über mehrere Runden dahin gerafft. :)

24571606.review:
[b] I put down the Witcher 3 Blood & Wine for this[/b]

Short: It's great and a unique blend of 4X, RPG, crafting and card game and quite some survival aspects. Plus it has pretty good quest writing to my mind and some of the nicest devs around.

If you played games like Age of Mythology, Elemental/Fallen Enchantress, Warlock, Endless Legend etc. and always felt like you liked the questing and hero leveling a bit more than the main game - then this is for you. You are on the road with your group/expedition all the time as you complete quests and chase rare materials. There is an abundance of events. My game says I participated 15% of all events... and I paricipated in A LOT OF EVENTS already. They are wonderfully written and the speaker is pretty good.
In my favorite quest a dwarf smith wants to date a somewhat evil forest spirit. This one then wants you to help "rescue" children from evil orcs, plot twist the orcs are nice and you can convince them to leave the children with you. I still meet the orcs every now and then and they give children into my care.

Yes I said "convince" - in Thea fighting isn't the only way. Depending on your party and the event, you can take part in many different challenges: fight, hunt, hex, social, sickness, sneak, physical, tactical.. there are so many possibilities with different outcomes and different quests also offer many different paths. The story is rarely black and white but has many sides to it.

Crafting is also great, even builings are "crafted" and have different properties based on the source material. There are so many options. 

Truly great game, the one downer for some people might be that all challenge types are resolved via the same card game (but different skills count for different values then). The card game is fun, complex and I like card games. E.g. given the right characters you can make your opponent discard an offence or tactic card, disable an enemy card for a turn, move one of your cards to first position etc. 

Oh yes, devs are nice, in touch with the community, collect money to get new art in the game etc... they deserve every penny. Go buy this game!

24566821.review:
[i]What is Thea?[/i]

Thea features a unique mix of gameplay elements from fantasy RPGs and 4X games. Its core conflict resolution mechanic is a deceptively simple card game, which is easy to learn but hard to master. 

In a nutshell, your villagers gather resources to craft better gear which they use to overcome various challenges like bandits, ancient tombs, giants, werewolves, dragons, and witches who are trying to steal your children. 

You send expeditions (parties made up of your villagers) into the wilderness to find rare materials and deal with problems or quests head on. If all goes to plan your party won't be cursed, poisoned, robbed, severy wounded or worse.

[i]So is this game any good?[/i]

The game features evocative art and a nice soundtrack. Quests are excellently narrated. The game doesn't take it self too seriously and there is plenty of humor. It is highly replayable due to the randomized nature of the encountered events / resolutions. It has the same strong "one more turn" drive that Civilization has (incidentally, a game of Thea also takes about as long as a game of Civilization).

Highly recommended.

24546943.review:
I tried to like this game, and it has a lot going for it -- a hex-map turn-based survival game! -- but an uninformative interface and some irritating gameplay features made me put it down.  

You start out as a god in control of a single village which serves as your home base, populated by a starting band of villagers of varying skillsets.  These villagers trek out into the world under your control to gather resources, defeat enemies, and solve mysteries.

The basic problem is that, as you play, the world slowly gets more threatening.  To stay ahead of the curve, you need to continuously level up your villagers.  Unfortunately, once you're well into the game, these initial villagers become irreplaceable because you can't level up replacements fast enough to keep up with the world; if your main party takes a beating, you will likely be in a losing battle against the world and consigned to a grinding loss.

Also, the game's interface doesn't provide enough information to deal with the massive number of encounter types.  The game displays the absolute difficulty of an encounter (1-5 skulls) but doesn't provide any information on your own party's abilities or even what skills are relevant.  Determining your party's suitability to engage in a tactical vs hunting vs intellect  vs sneak challenge is extremely tedious at best, and can't be done at all once you're presented with an encounter option.  Combat can also be quite frustrating because of the near total lack of information about an enemy.  I easily dealt with several two-skull challenges in one game only to be demolished by a two-skull encounter with a radically different enemy composition--details about an enemy party are presented only when it's too late to decide and even then are incredibly vague.  And no, you can't scout them out beforehand.  

I liked the crafting/resource gathering aspect, and the combat/encounter system was interesting but had started to wear out its welcome when I gave up.  The designers also clearly put a lot of effort into the story and writing, but it wasn't enough to keep me engaged.

24541441.review:
I would liken this to King of Dragon Pass, or other sort of RPG and exploration type of game. The obvious similarity, as pointed out by many others, is to the exploration phase of Civilization, when much of the world was still shrouded in the fog. 

Here the concept: You start with a village in the aftermath of a world destroyed by darkness. Now, your aim is to survive, thrive and eventually defeat the big bad. There is a village simulator, in the sense of producing resources, crafting, and keeping the village alive and healthy. You lead expeditions or parties of characters out to explore the world, find treasures, search ruins and destroy evil. You have to balance the 2, as well as many other luxuries - but you won't have the resources or time to obtain them all in a desolate and unforgiving world. 

Pros: Good world-build and narrativising. The lore really sets a sense of dread and devastation at every turn. 
Solid mechanics, from combat to research to building the village.
Some complexity, but aided by clear and extensive tutorials (and even video tutorials). Combat is quite different from most other games, but the tutorial clears the confusion after a battle or two. 
Varied encounters, enough that it doesn't devolve into a nonsensical choice merely between 'search for goodies' and 'leave'. Has any gamer ever picked the 'leave' option??

Cons: This has been likened to a rogue-like, in that you will lose often. However, what is good for me is the meta-ability to power up your villagers after every game, based on how well you have done. I am sure there's a mode/mod for the full rogue-like experience of having no advantages if you prefer that too. 

For me, the innovative gameplay and emphasis on narrative makes this interesting and fun enough from other games out there.

24535077.review: 游戏做的很棒，很耐玩~可惜没中文但是对我不是特别巨大的障碍非常推荐入手

24524850.review:
Hablar de Thea the Awakening es hablar de un juego que aglutina lo mejor de los juegos de rol (permite niveles de dificultad ajustables, con opciones customizables y por tanto permite el modo "hombre de hierro" donde no se puede grabar excepto cuando sales de la partida, etc), lo mejor de los juegos por turnos de exploración tradicionales (como la saga Civilization o la saga HoMM, Endless Legend, Fallen Enchantress, etc) y todo ello mezclado con un combate táctico por cartas muy original que no sólo se produce cuando hay una batalla, sino que se usa para realizar acciones de sigilo, de caza, para superar una enfermedad o maldición, incluso para representar el esfuerzo físico que supone el intentar superar un derrumbamiento de un edificio o unas ruinas, o incluso con tal de evitar la muerte de un personaje a manos de una tormenta, etc. El hecho de que el juego permita enfocar los combates de muchas maneras y con decenas de habilidades (magia, inteligencia, atractivo, habilidad en la caza, conocimiento de hierbas, voluntad, medicina, locuacidad/don para el habla, destreza, concentración, sexto sentido, táctica, fuerza física, etc, etc. etc) da vía libre a que el jugador puede personalizar a sus personajes, dotándolos de instrumentos para convertirlos en mejores guerreros o en hábiles cazadores sigilosos; o en verdaderos intelectuales capaces de superar pruebas que parecen imposibles de tener que usar la fuerza bruta.

El juego ha experimentado un gran cambio respecto a como salió. Hacer una review a fondo en Steam es algo complicado porque me dejaría muchas cosas por explicar. El juego está actualmente a un nivel que pocos juegos alcanzan. No sólo han sacado mucho más contenido gratuito (DLCs gratuitos, ¡sí señor, como oís!) sino que además han lanzado un multijugador cooperativo en la que dos jugadores están al mando de un poblado cada uno, estando ambos cercanos uno al otro. La gran cantidad de quests, eventos e historias que tienen lugar, que a su vez tienen múltiples soluciones (hay quests en las que llegan a haber hasta 14 o más opciones pero que pueden no estar activas dependiendo de las habilidades de que están dotados nuestros personajes en ese momento) ya muestra la profundidad y trabajo con el que se ha tratado el juego. 

La gran cantidad de recursos para recolectar, muchos no están activos al inicio hasta que no se investigan y de desbloquean, permite una enorme cantidad de recetas para craftear (desde platos combinados de comida hasta escudos, lanzas, armas a dos manos, joyería, armaduras de todo tipo, lanzas, mazas, etc) y de resultados muy diferentes en función de los materiales utilizados. No sólo eso, se ha incrementado respecto a como salió en Acceso Anticipado la cantidad de edificaciones que se pueden construir, incluyendo tótems, un Meeting Hall, una especie de "perrera" para atraer animales y bestias, etc. Además se ha hecho un lavado de imagen del árbol tecnológico así como de muchas de las ventanas del juego (mejora de la interface con introducción de filtros y pequeños detalles). 

No sólo eso, dependiendo de los elementos usados en el crafteo atraeremos a habitantes muy variopintos a nuestro poblado. Si forjamos muchas herramientas/edificions con oro los enanos se sentirán atraídos y vendrán a unirse a nuestro poblado (y los enanos son verdaderos "tanques" en combate). Si usamos madera élfica serán los elfos quienes vendrán y así un largo etcétera, incluyendo goblins, orcos, seres mitológicos (desde animales salvajes hasta grandes bestias), etc, etc.

Las quests y muchas cosas que ocurren en el juego beben de juegos clásicos como "King of Dragon Pass". Un encuentro con unos orcos por ejemplo, puede dar lugar a situaciones dispares en las que se puede uno acabar dándose de leches con ellos o bien atrayendo a uno de los orcos a nuestro grupo, incluso abriendo opciones a poder colaborar para rastrear un tesoro en unas ruinas o incluso a ser protagonistas en una quest. En una de las quests, por ejemplo, unos orcos nos entregan a unos críos para poder completar otra quest pero a cambio de que los cuidemos bien. Pero, si luego "perdemos" a esos críos los orcos recuerdan que nos los dieron a cambio de mantenerlos a salvo de manera que cuando nos los volvemos a encontrar esta vez serán hostiles (y entonces el juego nos da la opción de "convencerlos - combate social" o bien luchar a muerte - "combate puro y duro"). Esto es un ejemplo de lo que significa jugar a Thea.

El combate táctico por cartas es muy bueno, no sólo porque tiene mucha chicha sino porque la gran cantidad de habilidades y usos que podemos dar a nivel táctico con las cartas permiten resultados muy buenos cuando a priori la cosa parece perdida. La IA además juega muy bien y habrá momentos en los que nos dejará con la cara de tonto. No se puede hablar mucho del combate porque es algo que hay que experimentarlo.

Me dejo muchas cosas pero sinceramente es uno de los mejores juegos que tengo en la biblioteca de Steam y espero darle muchas más horas de las que llevo de momento, que me parecen muy pocas.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dODFv4U_yvI

24503940.review: This game is challenging , depending on the setting you chose of course, and quite interesting to play.

24500243.review:
This game is fantastic. 
I've heard people say that it's just one of these typical early access strategy games, but I disagree with that opinion.

Thea is an turn-based strategy game in a pre-industrial, mystic attached world. You play as one of 8 unlockable gods from which each one has special bonuses. In the begin you get two of them randomly unlocked. You start with a little village which you can devide in different groups to explore the land, gather materials and food or fight enemies. Combat happens through card games whereat the villagers in your group are your cards, but you can also choose to skip the games if you are not into this style of fighting. I suggest to at least try this out once because it is really enjoyable.
Beasts attack more often at night - unfortunately the "nights" are longer than just one round (it's the human's fault, but shh... spoiler!).

The game has an amazing, unique combat system which allows you to fight with many different options. You can fight directly in willingness to take chances and maybe let some of your villagers die or you can try to find a solution in challenges that are social, sickness, hunting, magic, physical or logical. Because of that each of your villagers is important in it's own way and has it's own skills. Villagers can level up and gain new skills or improve old ones - randomly generated so that no villager has the same skills as another. 

There are many different classes of villagers, so many that I didn't get all of them in my 19h playtime. You beginn with 3 classes: warrior, gatherer and craftsman. Later on you get healers, hunters, witches, wise mans, inventors, animals, bandits, ghosts, demons, dwarves, elves, orcs, mystics and more. Some of them you get through quests, some of them settle down and some are childs that are coming of age. For childs you can choose which class they will become - in the begin there are just few options, but the more buildings you explore and build, the more choices you have.

You can explore recipes by gathering exploration points which you get by doing quests or going through experiences. There are 3 kinds of recipes: One for better items you can gather, one for things you can craft with your craftsmen and one for the buildings.

There are 3 different ways to win the game (yes, the number 3 has a deep meaning in Thea xD). One is by pure domination - that means, you have explored a lot and a well build village with a big population -, one is by solving the worlds tree quest and one is by solving the giant quest (which I think is the most difficult way). There are a lot more quests than these, one for example deals with the god/godess itself, but you don't need to solve them to win. 

Thea has an interesting point of view - villagers matter, each one of them is important. You have a different perspective than in games like Anno, because although you are a god you don't look down on the people - you play them. I sympathized with the villagers a lot more than with the ones in other games, also because of the character design through which each of my people becomes unique (different cards with different names, designed fitting to the different classes).

I could tell a lot more about Thea, but I think these were the most important things to say.

All in all it's a really fascinating game with a thrilling story and a dark, mystic atmosphere. If you love to explore, I certainly suggest you to try it out. Also if you love to play with cards, read interesting quests, make your own choices (yes, choices are important!) and improve your villagers.

Big kudos to the developers.

I will now continue playing Thea.

24463222.review:
Yeah hmmm....

I love it when games dare to be different, and Thea certainly does that, but the card-based combat system is just too damn confusing. It sort of works when it's an actual battle but then one of the game's early text adventures sends you into a dungeon where you find a library filled with dusty scrolls. You might be able to save those scrolls... by fighting them. Your combat stats count for nothing, your non-combat stats (intelligence in this case) are moved to the fore and then you fight the scrolls. It's... I don't know. 

If the non-combat-combat sessions would be represented differently there may be a pretty good game here. If they then also fix the terribly small click area for moving parties across the map, I'll happily come back on board.

24462569.review: An interesting mix between 4X and RPG. Despite the fact that a playthrough only takes a few hours, it does not get boring even after playing it through 10+ times. The reason for that is the sheer amount of possible random encounters, the random map and the different gods you can select as your protector. After playing 50 hours, I can assure you that this game is worth your money.

24457136.review: If you've ever played Civ V, remeber the feel of first turns. FoW everywhere, 1 city, excitation when entering the ruins, but at the same time danger from barbarians and other civs. This is basically Thea all the time. Although more complex (your people have like 20 different stats, each matters in different challenges) and confusing during first playthrough, it's definitely worth learning. So many little stories and adventures (Dwarf Romance!) and devs are constantly making more for free.

Зашёл на часик, вылез через день. Пожалуй, лучшая рпг-стратегия последего времени. Огромная реиграбельность. Просто не хочется покидать Тею. Музыка, текст, сеттинг - всё на высшем уровне.

24429390.review:
Одна из лучших игр, в которые я когда либо играл.

Колебался перед покупкой, поскольку разработчик мне знаком не был, игра имела довольно простую графическую составляющую, да и смахивала она сильно внешне на цивилизацию 5.
Однако просмотрев несколько обзоров и почитав отзывы решился - и не пожалел. 
Не дайте себя обмануть кажущейся простотой геймплея! Игра затягивает на долгие часы, и интерес к ней растёт от партии к партии.
Мало что общего с цивой, очень приятная атмосфера, музыка подобрана отлично. А после дополнения, в которое добавили несколько новых треков, стало намного комфортней (раньше было треков 5, которые откровенно говоря приелись). Кроме того появился русский язык - что не может не радовать.

Отдельно хочу отмеить разработчиков - активно общаются с народом на форуме, постоянно допиливают игру, выпустили бесплатное (!) обновление, которое позволило намного продлить длительность партии.

Игра еще всё же сыровата - над ней нужно поработать, достаточно много косяков и мелких недоделок (к которым я обычно критично отношусь), но даже не смотря на это мне очень понравилась.

24428723.review: trés bon jeux , original et trés interressant ,  à part la traduction polono-française qui laisse a désirer , jeux digne de toute ludothéque .

24415995.review:
Für perfektionistische Spieler die gern 1-3 Abende an einer Runde basteln sehr gut geeignet.
Man kann Monster kloppen, Rohstoffe abbauen und die perfekte Strategie ausknobeln, wie und in welcher Reihenfolge man was erforscht und welche Rohstoffe man für den schnellsten Fortschritt baucht.
Es gibt zwar viele Götter für die man spielen kann, aber die Rätzel/Aufgaben ähneln sich doch sehr stark, so besteht der Anreiz alle durchzuspielen nur im eigenen Drang der Perfektionierung, oder einfach zum Zeit totschlagen... und genau das ist z.B. die einheitlich-verschiedene Ausrüstung der Kreaturen ;)
Sehr negativ fällt die völlig willkürliche Einblendung der Spielauswertung auf, welche ein Spielende suggeriert und sich auch nach diversen Versuchen nicht nachvollziehen lässt, man sollte diese einfach ignorieren und die Runde weiterspielen so lange man mag.
Weiterhin negativ ist, das es keine individuelle Spielstandspeicherung gibt - immer nur eine aktuelle Speicherung - mehr nicht.
Im Endspiel, wenn der Speicher bereits sehr viele Rohstoffe enthält, wird das Zerlegen von unnützer Ausrüstung (der Ordnung halber) zum Geduldsspiel, hier ist die Programmierung so grottenschlecht, das man sich an C64-Zeiten erinnert fühlt.
Summa summarum: Für perfektionistische Spieler, die gern in Ruhe nebenbei eine Runde spielen wollen sehr gut geeignet, mit den genannten Einschränkungen muss man ebend lebend können.

Pierwsze wrażenie może wprawić w lekką dezorientację, ale po ogarnięciu podstaw mechaniki gry nie ma żadnych problemów z cieszeniem się z rozgrywki. :)

24413739.review: Amazing and original game. Reminds me of playing D&D dungeon with the narration. Honestly give the game a try, the tactical depth and thousands of choices that are available add to the replayability. Also did I mention free DLC's?

24400091.review:
Mit der Kategorie habe ich es ein bisschen schwer, da ich - wie einige andere hier auch - gerne ein "neutral" abgeben würde. Ich hatte mich nach 20 Std erst für negativ entschieden. Nachdem das Graphikproblem aber bei mir war (ein völlig neues Seherlebnis :-) ), habe ich mich nun doch für positiv entschieden. Das Spiel entwickelt eine Tiefe, die sich erst nach und nach erschließt. Erst wenn man die Regeln der Kämpfe (Mini-Kartenspiel) kennt, kann man strategisch handeln. Dennoch, die Balance beim Kartenspiel könnte besser sein. Ein bisschen wird das im nächsten Schwierigkeitsgrad erhöht, da dann die Anzahl der Partymitglieder begrenzt ist.

Deshalb pro und cons separat aufgelistet. 

Benötigte etwa eine halbe Std. um mich im Spiel zurecht zu finden. Trotz Tutorial sind die ganzen Funktionen am Anfang sehr unübersichtlich. Seid tapfer. Es wird besser. Auch das Kartenspiel hat es in sich. Man muss einfach viel lesen, bis man weiß, wie alles funktioniert. Dann durchaus anspruchsvoll und sehr kniffelig. Besonders, wenn man nicht kämpft, sondern die anderen Optionen ausprobiert (schleichen, zaubern, jagen usw.). Wozu man aber fasst schon gezwungen wird, da einem sonst die halbe Mannschaft wegstirbt.

pro
- Sehr schöne Geschichte. 
- Endlose Gegenstände und Kombination beim Herstellen
- Auch wenn es nicht animiert ist, immer wieder schöne Sequenzen der Ereignisse. Große Vielfalt der Monster und Ereignisse. Wobei sich inzwischen schon einige Dinge wiederholen (20 Std. Gameplay).
- Anspruchsvolles in-Game Kartenspiel für die Kämpfe / Entscheidungen.


con
- man kann durch die Wolken nicht viel auf der Karte sehen, insbesondere in der dunklen Tageshälfte. Es fehlt auch ein Gesamtmaßstab oder eine Karte zur Übersicht. Im Prinzip läuft die Gruppe durch Nebel und man weiß nicht, wo die Gruppe ist, bzw fängt man an zu scrollen, wo der nächste bekannte Anhaltspunkt ist. Wenn man per Leertaste von Gruppe zu Gruppe oder zur Stadt sspringt, sieht man i.d.R. die anderen Expeditionen nicht. Blöd.
- Die Balance ist einfach sehr schwer. Am Anfang läuft man ständig Gefahr unterzugehen. Sehr lange mit etwa 10 Charakteren herumgeeiert. Jedes Mal, wenn ein Kind erwachsen wurde, ist mir wieder irgendwer weggestorben.
- Balance kippt irgendwann, wenn die eigene Party 15 - 20 Chars groß ist. Dann bekommt man die meisten Gegner klein.
- Die Random Ereignisse passen nicht zur eigenen Party-Entwicklung. Gerade am Anfang muss man jede Runde abspeichern bzw. den letzten Spielstand vom Autosave laden, sonst ist man Ruck-zuck weg vom Fenster. Marodierende LvL 4-5 Parties (Skala 1 - 5) greifen die Satdt an. Wenn man verliert, dann greifen die auch mehrfach kurz hintereinander an, bis kein Char mehr übrig ist. Monsterstärke sollte sich an der eigenen Stärke orientieren oder aber die Monster könnten stärker werden je nachdem wo man regional erkundet. So aber, muss man in den ersten hundert Runden Glück haben ider immer mal wieder neu laden. Nervig.
- Schade, dass die Charakterentwicklung völlig random ist. Was nützt eine bestimmte Klasse, wenn die Attribute wild verteilt werden?
- Mir fehlt, dass man mehrere Städte hat........ aber vielleicht kommt das noch. Man wird wegen der Ereignisse gezwungen m.ow. in der Nähe der Stadt zu bleiben. Da man die Stadt nicht selber platzieren kann, können wenig oder nicht die richtigen Resourcen zugänglich sein.
- Bevölkerung wächst zu langsam. Habe nach 20 Std. (250 Turns) erst 30 Einwohner.


Zu Anfang sehr schwer und immer mal wieder Frust. 
Nichts gegen schwere Spiele. Aber auf "normal" erwarte ich nicht, dass ich ständig speichern muss. Schlimmer als damals bei Sierra-Games. Da wusste ich wenigstens vorher, fass den Knopf nicht an oder geh nicht an die Steckdose. Aber hier stirbt die ganze Gruppe aus heiterem Himmerl. Oder wird vergiftet und weit und breit kein Heiler in Sicht. 

Unterm Strich aber trotzdem fesselnd. Und noch längst nicht alles entdeckt oder verstanden.
Eine Mischung aus Civ und RPG in märchenhafter Story.
Nicht perfekt, nicht rund. Aber spielenswert.

24381969.review:
TLDR: Buy this game, 10/10, it's awesome. A dash of 4X, a dash of RPG, some lovely art, voice-acting and a nice system as a whole come together for one of the more novel, engaging and enjoyable experiences I have had in a while.

I have played through a few rounds of thea now, having to restart due to a patch during my most recent advanced game; that didn't bug me in the slightest. My god's level advanced a bit and I got to play things slightly differently... and it was fun!

I play a lot of games, make the odd game and think (and occasionally write) about games, the people who play them and what it says about our culture. Of late, this has been depressing. Thea is the exception. The game has familiar elements, but it is fresh, combines things in novel ways and has an excellent narrative; it feels like it has created a new gaming experience. It's also an enjoyable gaming experience, and it's well worth the sticker price (but we all like steam sales).

Think an early civ game for exploring and resources, but you can't build more cities, and your troops are unique and varied. The choices and combat immediately show the departure from a purely civ-esque game. Along with the narrative--nearly all excerpts are pleasantly voiced by our storytelling narrator--the combination of events and their subsequent choices, and the combat engine give a very strong role-playing feel.

Unlike most RPGs, you do not have a character, you have a population. However, your people are all very individual. They have classes which give them tendencies towards subsets of the large number of skills. Your people all level up at once, and there is no choice in progression, but the type of people in your population tend to skill up based on what they are. Your witch might improve in magic, but is not likely to make gains in crafting. You can thus level-up your population as a whole, taking fine-grained control of how it develops by carefully tending your village.

The technology aspect lets you shape your city in terms of buildings, which affect who flocks to your city, and how people are raised there, as well as buffing for certain skills. You can also use technology to expand resource availability, a key element of the game. Lastly, you can advance technology to allow you to craft different varieties of things, from food, to weapons, armor and utility items.

I enjoy how Thea combines its variety of resources with its crafting, building and support systems. You unlock a type of thing to craft, but what you can craft and its properties are dependent on which resources you use, allowing a great deal of creation and customization. Even the buildings can pick up useful ancillary effects when you make use of novel construction materials. I am eagerly awaiting goblins after redoing several buildings with obsidian. Thea allows for variety in food production, and encourages its use by giving bonuses based on the variety of food. Your people eat food every turn, so your village and expeditions need to carry a varied supply if you want all the bonuses.

All challenges, be they combat or diplomacy, unfold using the same "card-based" combat system, different skills serving different purposes, depending on challenge-type. I find it easier to think about the combat system without inheriting any hang-ups from false associations with other card systems. The key thing is that what you can do is dependant on the skills of each unit involved. Your units are split into one of two groups, a combat group that gets to attack in two combat rounds, or a tactical group which can use its skills to augment various things or enter into the fray for the second combat round (soaking up damage in both rounds). Some skills are rare, so an approach that works well in a fighting challenge can be pretty useless in other types of challenge. Events give you some choice, depending on skill levels and group composition, as to what types of challenge you can use to resolve the various events, and the rewards (and failure penalties) can vary based on this. I find this mixes it up well enough that combat remains interesting.

Science itself, like experience, is doled out through the various events. While challenges gives you lots of experience, allowing your population to go up levels, technology comes in smaller amounts. The majority of technology comes from the crafting system. Rarer/bigger/better things, both buildings and equipment, give you more technology. Each level of technology takes more points, but if you don't deviate to expand resource availability, or the items/buildings, you end up building things you do not need, just to get tech points (a costly distraction). It leads to choices, but they feel like choices that affect the approach you want to move forward with, not the ability to move forward. I have tried a few different approaches, and aside from adjusting which skill challenges and some of my tactics, there was no issue, so it does not feel like you can easily make untenable tech choices. This really improved replayability for me, and encourages players to pay attention to the lay of the land early on.

One of the things that I felt were maybe less polished was the ease of remembering outcomes of choices in events. There are events all the time, and they keep things interesting, and are part of what makes the game great. While it does seem that there is some variety in outcomes, I felt that it was a bit thin.  When you find the herbs, you proceed to fight the spider-queen. It's never anything else and it always plays out the same (enemy numbers are the same). I have not looked at the event scripting system (which appears available directly, good for the devs for doing this!), but many events seems light, and easily gamed.

If you do not know that you can speed up the challenges rate of doing combat rounds, you are going to be irritated. Watch it play out slower a few times to get a feel, then speed that up or you will drive yourself nuts and waste lots of time, distracting you from an otherwise lovely game.

Making sure you are crafting a variety of foods is a nuisance. I recommend putting it in its own tab, then iterating on ways to make it more useable. The variety of foods and recipes is very good, it just needs a better interface.

The spear-based combat is broken. There are not enough fatty-filled combats to make the more direct-damage alternatives (even with what appears to be epic bonus potential) worthwhile. So far, this remains true on hard-mode as well. You can get 2-3 rounds of combat instead of 1-2, effectively. This needs further balance, particularly with high-strength characters.

Swarms of units generally win. It would be nice if there were size limits on expeditions, or more limits on cards-in-play during challenges.

That said, the positives massively outweigh the areas that need improvement. Buy this!

24373688.review:
TL;DR: If you love challenging crafting/strategy/rpg-type games with a decent amount of RNG, this is phenomenal.  As a barometer, the other video games that I have spent a lot of time on in the past few years are: X-Com, Darkest Dungeon, Life is Strange, This War of Mine, and Hearthstone.

Thea: The Awakening is a wonderful game.  Before I continue extoling its virtues, let me pause and say that it is also a flawed game that clearly does not have the limitless resources of a blockbuster company.  It is hard to make an argument for certain gathering certain resources and trying certain playstyles (I’m looking at you, nimblewood, and you, bows, and you, all types of stone that weigh too much and prevent me from walking back to my village!) especially as you play on the harder difficulty settings.  If you play through a long game (my first game that I won was by turtling – to give a sense of that, it took me almost 2,000 turns to survive and build up.  There were a lot of mistakes made and ill-timed adventures that led to clicking my way to a bigger population) you will see the same quest many times over.  It is also a punishing, challenging game, especially if you are the type of gamer who likes to start their games on “difficult” (*raises hand*) – but to me, that is a positive.  I list it up here just because this will not be a game to play if your frustration threshold is low.

Now that I have talked through the game’s major challenges, let me talk through its high points.  The developers have really hit the nail on the head with their “leveling system” over multiple playthroughs.  Even after losing a game after a hundred turns in, I can watch the experience bar on my god shoot up, giving me a new trinket or additional buff on my next playthrough.  The gods themselves are wonderful – anyone who is a fan of mythology will appreciate the pantheon presented in the game.  The story is interesting– a lot of text, but even skimming through it will give you a few chuckles.  The best part is that after every playthrough I want to immediately start a new game.  Will there be an ever-elusive source of silver near my village?  Will this be the game I finally manage to recruit an elf to my side?  Will I survive on Godlike difficulty?  What are the resources like?  Each time I boot up a new game it gives me that sense of being about to take the edge of a quarter to a scratch-off ticket.

Let me conclude this review by saying that this is a game that makes me want to see more from its developers.  This is the first time a game has made me think I am doing a disservice by not writing a review (indeed, my first steam review) and it is also the first game that I’ve donated money to the devs to afterwards in the hope that they can continue producing lovely content.  If you’re still waffling at this point – just give it a try.
