24361920.review:
Short review:
Incredible game. The game world is laid out sorta like Civ or Endless Legend - a hex based grid with resources, events, enemies scattered about. The big difference is all you ever get is one city. You use your citizens to gather, build, explore, fight, and do quests. Sort of a mash up of a 4x and a survival / base building game. The game's mythology and atmosphere is extremely interesting and well done. Very highly recommended, one of the best games I've played recently.


Long review:
There is a main story quest (several if you count the DLC lines, all of which are free) and you'll constantly be encountering various other events. Some are repetitive, some only happen once. But they all generally offer many different ways you can solve them, often based on the skills of your characters.

Combat is handled via a card system - each of your units (and enemy units) is represented by a card. They're randomly split 50/50 into attack + support. Attack guys can only jump into the field of battle, and support guys can either buff/debuff or jump into battle with a 1 turn cooldown. Each side takes turn playing 1 card (or 2+ if they have lots of units) and once all cards are played they are resolved in order, attacking randomly whatever enemy card is closest to the left or right of them. There are only 2 turns per combat round (after all the cards are out) and then you re-allocate the existing cards.

On top of that you'll often have different combat options presented to you - social, physical challenge, actual fighting, hexing, poison, etc. Each depends on a different set of stats on your characters and there's a LOT of stat types. It can be a bit overwhelming at first but I think it adds nicely to the depth of the game. In actual fighting, every time your guys get hit they take wounds, which can result in death if the wounds are too severe. The other challenges are generally a better option since you can take "damage" without wounds - but if you fail there will be penalties which can be quite steep, and often times you'll end up having to fight after failing. So even before you jump into battle you're making decisions on how you want to approach encounters.

Your units level up universally. So your in-town crafters will still benefit from your raiding party's escapades. Oh and if you craft using better-than-basic materials you get a lot of tech and XP, so an important strategy is to farm a bunch of mats to spam junk items to level up your crew.

I'd say the most frustrating part of the game is the very beginning. It's very easy to lose units, especially when you're new and don't know what events/fights are risky. Losing 5-6 guys early on is essentially crippling. But losing 2-3 early is recoverable, and you just have to embrace the fact that you're going to lose some of your guys from time to time.

The game's atmosphere and story are excellent. I really felt like I was in a world wrapped in magic and mythology. The main story was also quite interesting and I've seen very different endings based upon what starting god I chose and the way I approached the main quest.

The starting god you choose does make some difference to how the game plays. At first you only have 2 choices and you unlock more by playing. The gods themselves level up as you play under their banner, but it takes a LONG time to unlock their bonus tiers - or even just to play a full game. Which is fine, I don't think 15+ hours for a single game is unreasonable for this type of game, but that only unlocks level 2 or 3 out of 5 for a given god. So unlocking the top tier buffs will take quite some time.

Co-op works well, I rarely had desync problems, and when they did happen I was able to exit + restore at worst losing 1 turn. The biggest issue is you can't do anything when your partner is doing their start-of-turn events, that plus the regular turn-based game imbalance (sometimes one person has a lot of stuff to do when the other person is ready for the next turn instantly) makes for a lot of down time. I got some good mileage out of my smartphone while playing co-op. But I think that's just the nature of this type of game played multiplayer, so I don't have any complaints.

There is strong replayability here, every time I play through I think of different ways I want to build up my town or different starting loadouts I want to try. On the other hand, while the world layout changes, the main quest stays generally the same, and you sort of get used to the types of enemies and side quests. So after beating the game 3 times I'm ready for a break - but I'll definitely be playing it again in the future.

Overall one of the best games I've played recently. The combat system was surprisingly enjoyable, the game combines some of my favorite elements of base building + survival + 4x games, and the whole thing is wrapped up in a fantastic world of atmosphere and lore. If you're interested in this game at all, I very highly recommend you get it.

24326276.review:
[b]TLDR;[/b] Tense, RNG heavy experience with heaps of replayability and diversity, the ability to create and share around custom content, and FREE DLC/great developers. 8/10

Thea took me by suprise:

Its suprisingly addictive, I've put nearly all my gaming time into it since i got it.
Its suprisingly deep, to be expected of a 4x type game, but some features of the game took me off guard. (Voiced main story quest line), quality music, etc
It's suprisingly brutal. I made one rash decision to take a 4 skull fight a little to early, my main party of 8 got wiped to 4 in a crushing defeat, the 4 that died were my best fighters. Have had to make do by hunting/social/intelligence/poison interactions rather than straight fighting monsters. (Having two healers is great)

Needless to say, i could go on...

Thea is the first 4x game i've liked since Civilization V, and the best rougelike experience ive had since FTL. IT has some flaws that i don't care to list in detail at this moment but overall the good vastly out shines the bad.

[b]As said in the TLDR:[/b]
This game was made and is still updated by some truely outstanding developers. They're still working and updating this game and releasing their work for free while only offering a "Donation to the Developers Coffee Fund DLC" for compensation. Also, I've definitely noticed that theyre involved in the community. Most player requests and recommendations are taken to heart, and the devs can be found on the steam forums frequently. Cant say enough good things about the this games developer support.

[b]Summary:[/b]
A huge 8/10 for me, and i like to think i'm very picky. The points i take off are purely opinion of course.

One point I knock off of it is because I'm a graphics nerd and would like to see the game made prettier on the map (the artwork is great). 

The other point is because I am actually not a fan of the card game you play for combat for two reasons.
Firstly, I simply feel like it's confusing and clunky on the user interface end, I personally would enjoy some more traditional "old school" rpg combat on a 2d board or something. I realize that a combat revamp would be a large amount of work and probably not worth doing as a lot of the community likes the combat, but I still would prefer something different.
Finally, it's too exploitable with the "First Action" ability and great hammers powering through mobs in straight up combat, while every other non-cheese strategy isn't really good in the late game even on moderate difficulty.

EDIT: 7/17/16 Fixed lazy grammar mistakes.

24323372.review:
Довольно инерестная игра. Сразу захватывает игровой процесс и продолжается на многие часы. Особенностью игры является обилие квестов, которые делают игру менее предсказуемою и более интересной (не устаешь от однообразия). Также в игре реализована довольно интересная система крафтига -  можно всячески комбинировать разные материалы, в пределах создаваемой вещи, или здания, для получения новых эффектов, или усилений.

   Игра несколько напоминает Endless Legends, только без возможности создания нескольких городов и гораздо меньшей веткой развития. Город позволет возводить не более 10 построек, хотя их можно всячески перестраивать, чтобы получть другие возможности. Отсуствуют пошаговые графические бои, которые заменены на карточные (тут слышится отголосок "Ведьмака"). Отсуствие создания городов несколько компенсируется возможностью создавать лагеря  экспедиции в любой точке карты юнитами, но они крайне подвержены нападениям всюду бродячим монстрам и случайным событиям, которые могут их разбить. В добавок к этому юнит может носить лишь ограниченый запас ресурса и более редкие ресурсы требуют более продвинутых сборщиков или дополнительного времени на их сбор (естественно после исследования возможноти их сбора). В общем, мороки добавляет, хотя этот недостаток несколько компенсируется возможностью выжить после проиграше в битве с любыми врагами. Но каждый юнит на вес золота, так как их производить нельзя, а их появление , рождение и взросление абсолютно случано и малопредсказуемо (есть постройки, которые добавляют вероятность, но спустя 150 ходов ни одна постройка не принесла мне ни одного ребенка или дополнительного юнита в игру - всех дополнительных получил только через квесты). И прокачка каждого довольно долгий и также малопредсказуемый процесс. Все юниты требуют постоянного наличия в "рюкзаке" еды (разная еда дает больше бонусов юниту). Существует возможность создавать в ручную лишь одно сохранение (по крайней мере в режиме "реализм") и загрузка довольно продолжительная.

 Советы : 1)если хотите быстрее проводить исследования обратите внимания. что создание изученых зданий и предметов дают гораздо больше очков, чем бои и квесты (это единственные способы, замеченые мною, для получения очков исследования).
                2)в режиме "реализм" в городе вы сможете создавать не более одной постройки одного типа (может пригодится перед созданием игры - этот параметр не изменяется после начала кампании).
               3) создание еды (а не сбор) более экономно: с 4х компонентов - 8ть тарелок, которые весят по 1кг (другая еда, кроме водорослей, минимув в два раза тяжелее).
               4) солома вест 3кг (вместо 10ти, как дерево) и более пригодна для дальних путешествий експедиций сбора ресурсов.

Пожелания создателям - добавить возможность 1)создания нескольких городов и количества, 2)вариаций возводимых в них построек (постройки не самый важный параметр изменений). Города очень практичны на больших картах. Также добавить возможность 3)разбора предметов на части (например с уменьшением количества получаемых компонентов). С прогрессом многие предметы становятся абсолютно бесполезными. Было бы практичным также создания некоего подобия 4)рынка для обмена или продажи не нужных вещей, или ресурсов. Очень не хватает в игре 5)в описи ресурсов количества очков, необходимых, для его сбора. Эти изменения были бы также кстати, если один из ключевых параметров игры является приближенность к реализму в игре (многие моменты им пропитаны).

Даже без этих изменений оценил бы игру на 10 из 10, так как довльно редко можно найти игру, которая была мало похожа на другие (со своими исключительными изюменками) и затягивала на многие часы игры, отсутсвием однообразия. Хотя игра была бы еще интересней, если бы внедрить ранее упомянутые изменения. Покупой доволен на все 100%

24309485.review:
Italiano (english on the bottom)

TL;DR Piccola gemma, ancora da rifinire ma godibilissimo. Da prendere.

Il gioco presenta una serie di aspetti al tempo stesso classici e originali. Andiamo per ordine. Thea è fondamentalmente un gioco di ruolo/strategia a turni, su uno scenario fantasy. Il vostro mondo è stato distrutto per ragioni che indagherete nel corso del gioco, attraverso una quest-line principale che si snoderà nel corredo di tantissime quest secondarie.

Partirete dal vostro villaggio, che potrà racimolare solo le risorse nei pressi, ma potrete mandare dei gruppi di avventurieri in giro sulla mappa esagonale per cercare di prendere materie prime di cui avete bisogno. Vi serviranno per ottenere cibo ed equipaggiamento. Una delle parti migliori per me è la profonda caratterizzazione dei personaggi, che dovrete equipaggiare con gli item che più li aiuteranno nel ruolo che volete loro assegnare. Ad esempio, va da se che i guerrieri probabilmente si concentreranno su danno e tank, ma ci sono tantissime altre classi da equipaggiare: un medico potrebbe essere un ottimo oratore con un grande carisma, o un hunter lo farete specializzare nel seguire tracce, ecc. Le possibilità sono pressocchè illimitate, e le build oserei dire quasi infinite, a seconda di come volete utilizzare i vostri party.

L'equipaggiamento ottenuto sarà man mano migliore, come loot ottenuto da scontri più difficili o con il progressivo avanzamento dei vostri fabbri che partiranno da semplici spade, vesti e armature per poi specializzarsi nella produzione di armi magiche notevoli, insieme ad accessori di qualità superiore se fornite loro la giusta infrastruttura e le migliori materie prime.

Le quest potrete affrontarle in maniera diversa, e a seconda delle vostre decisioni si potranno verificare esiti diversi per la stessa quest. Non è necessario combattere per forza: a volte per evitare perdite potrete decidere di usare altre qualità che non la forza bruta (social, sneak, hex per dirne qualcuna). Così da evitare di perdere delle vite.

Il combattimento è un gioco di carte, originale e un pò complesso da spiegare qui. Per quanto una volta afferrato il concetto sia abbastanza immediato. Avrete il vostro mazzo (composto dai campioni che compongono il party) diviso in maniera casuale in carte "offensive" e "tactical": le offensive hanno praticamente l'iniziativa, una volta scese ingaggeranno le carte del nemico adiacenti. Le tactical possono fornire diversi tipi di supporto (dopo verranno scartate) a seconda della loro classe/build (danno, tank, perdita iniziativa avversario, ecc) o le potrete scendere sapendo che al primo turno non attaccheranno. Ogni combattimento si divide in due round, fino a quando uno degli opponenti non elimina tutte le carte dell'avversario.

Un pò troppo lunga questa recensione, e c'è ancora dell'altro..!

La vostra popolazione potrà aumentare sia perchè avete dei bambini nel villaggio, che una volta adulti sceglieranno una classe (guerriero, medico, costruttore, strega, ecc) o perchè eventi casuali e/o quest vi porteranno altri personaggi ad unirsi a voi. Mi è sinceramente dispiaciuto perdere qualcuno dei miei campioni in un raid andato male! Scegliete bene cosa fare perchè le morti sono irrimediabili.

Molto bello anche il modo di combinare diverse "ricette" per ottenere lo stesso item, a seconda delle vostre materie prime disponibili. Potrebbe essere magari una spada con 6 danno, ma vi accorgerete che con una piccola variazione (usando l'ambra al posto del legno magari) vi da 6 danno e +2 destrezza. Insomma crafting molto avvincente e centinaia di item tutti da scoprire.

Credo non ci sia l'italiano come lingua, ma controllate, potrei sbagliarmi. Comunque sia, se non ci fosse, è un'ottima occasione per imparare l'inglese divertendosi.

Davvero un bel prodotto, semplice e bello. Provatelo!

English review:

This game is a little gem. I love the way you have to plan which resource to gather and what to research, while trying to unfold the story in a way which doesn't harm your parties too hard, and trying to slowly make them gain a better equip. The customization of equipment is amazing, also the way you can develop your men and women trying to get the best out of their class. Questing, gathering, explore in a fantasy world. The number of quest is huge, and you can solve them in many different ways. This mean actually that quests may have a different outcome, depending of what you decide to do. Those choice are also influenced from what the involved party can do. If you like fantasy, old-times roleplaying atmosphere, challenges and decision making, try it.

You can face a challenge in many ways: the classic combat, or tactical approach, sneaking or with diplomatic approach and more. Each one of your people will have his/her different qualities: for example it comes naturally that a party mostly made of warriors will fight its way out, but if you mix the party with some socially skilled guy you may have to solve a situation by just talking. Combat it's not always the best solution as it may result in the death of some of your party members. Trying to keep a party balanced is a very challenging aspect of the game. I felt actually sad when I got a girl or a guy killed after an underestimated/unexpected combat situation.

The developers wrote awesome stories which unfold randomly aside the main quests, it really comes to their honor how much well done and deep the quests are. You'll find yourself amazed by the number of available and unavailable options (you get a  note about that) while solving a quest.

Make your villagers survive in a uneasy enviroment, while developing amazing stories, research and craft their items, will keep you busy playing for hours. Absolutely to try.

24297632.review:
Now this game is realy something special. It is a masterpiece combining parts of our Slavic mythology, gathering and hoarding all types of stuff that can be crafted to all types of items with their unique abilities. Also the turn-based style of gameplay and combat can be very addictive. 
Yes, after hours and hours spent chasing resources and solving various random and planed encounters you will get the feeling, that the events repeat it self. They are, but after 500+ turns spent in the game and in your scoreboard shines 22% events encountered, well, there is still a lot more to discover. And atop of all mentioned, there are seriously great painted pictures in the game, not just only models of items and characters, but also encounters (even land looks well made). 
Also ehat needs to be mentioned is great soundtrack and a fact, that practically whole game (every written letter except the texts connected with return of the giants) is spoken and the people behind those voices did a perfect job.

In summary I love this game and recommend it for everyone who loves turn-based strategies or crafting games.

24294882.review: I love this game, and you will too.

24290722.review:
To-the-point review.  Because this game deserves all the press it can get:

Pro:
This is a very good game.

At launch this was a well polished and enjoyable game.  Dev's are capable and professional, as well as dedicated to providing a great product.

Two DLC's.  Both released for free, and they were significant in scale and content added to the game.

This is not a card game, it's a tactics game that uses cards to represent actions/characters.

Game lore, art, and stories are beautiful.

World is immersive, and gets you invested in small details.  The loss of a favored character can be pretty devestating.

Very diverse story and event lines.  Many ways to resolve a single scenario.  You can't (or maybe, shouldn't) just punch your way through everything you encounter.  Befriend that demon, poison those wolves, outsmart the bandits, fight the rock monster.  Or any combination of those you may please.

Auto resolve battles

Sorta newgame+ features

Cons:

After a few play throughs it is likely you will have experienced most of the game's events in vanilla mode.  Though, you may not have experienced all of the events branching outcomes, it will still feel familiar.  The free DLC's and added mod support have done quite a bit to alleviate this and made the game much more unique on each playthrough.

Some events can be pretty RNG, and with the serious consequences this game conjures, that can be a bit scary at some points.  Then again... this might be a good thing.  Surving in a dying world might just be a pretty RNG kind of experience.

24282103.review:
Я довольно редко покупаю игры вообще ничего о них не зная - и в случае Thea: The Awakening получил маленький и неожиданный для меня сюрприз. 
[list]
    [*]По сути это 4X-стратегия, но очень сильно отличающаяся от своих соседей по жанру. На руках у нас одна деревня, несколько жителей и недружелюбный мир вокруг. Здесь нет противников кроме нейтральных монстров, нельзя построить вторую деревню и создать империю, а каждый из немногочисленных подопечных не просто "юнит", а персонаж со своим набором характерестик, от которых зависит его эффективность в испытаниях. Кроме простых и понятных "боевых" испытаний, есть проверки на общительность, магию, охоту, выносливость, итд. И разноплановая партия имеет гораздо больше опций - можно вместо простой рубки заболтать врагов, отравить, прокрасться, использовать тактику или колдовство.
    [*]Сами испытания проходят в виде карточной игры. Ваша партия делится на две половинки: одна станет, собственно, "ударной силой" (даже если подразумевается испытание на речь), а вторая будет оказывать поддержку первым и мешать в меру сил врагам. В общем-то неплохая система, но тактическому планированию немного мешает рандом: порой случается что в активной части колоды остаются неподходящие для испытания персонажи, а поддержка может выйти самолично на поле, но при этом пропускает первый ход.
    [*]Вообще игра насыщена случайными событиями. Наш отряд будет постоянно находить интересные места и встречи. Даже никуда не ходя, время от времени то буря налетит, то эльф попросит накормить, а то и ведьма детей будет воровать.
    [*]Отдельно отмечу поддержку игры разработчиками. Уже вышло два DLC с дополнительными событиями и сюжетной линией, ввели кооператив, добавили локализацию и возможность создавать собственные квесты.
[/list]
7/10 - для долгоиграющей стратегии в ней немного контента, и партии отличаются друг от друга только "божественным заданием", которое у каждого небожителя своё. Но на пару вечеров общества Зари, Симаргла, Бабы-Яги и русалок вполне хватит

24276266.review:
This game mixes up the turn based strategy formula a lot, basically mashing it together with some more role playing elements and many kinds of non-combat challenges.  The gameplay itself is unique enough to be genre-defining. On top of that, they root their game in slavic mythology, which I have never seen in a game before. As a fan of games rooted in mythology, it's amazing how refreshing it is to see a whole new and VERY different set of mythological figures coming into play.

I wouldn't normally review a game after so little gameplay, but this game has continually impressed me and I am confident that it will continue to do so. The developers have made all of their DLC free, except for one that basically just gives them more money. I really enjoy this payment model.  I will personally be buying an extra copy of the game, now that they've added coop support via the MultiPrayer DLC.

24241969.review:
I really had high hopes for this game, being a fan of pretty much every genre it attempts to blend together, but it just didn't do anything for me. It wasn't actively bad, it was just very boring. The town management aspects were very simple, and you really only had to make any decisions in that regard when you unlocked a new crafting or building recipe. The quests and storylines were somewhat interesting, but felt like they were pretty much all fetch quests or "oh, you found me, but you really need to go to this other place and talk to this other person" kinds of events. The card game that you use to resolve any encounters (which is probably the aspect I was most excited about) ends up being very boring and borderline annoying, to the point that I found myself having the game auto-resolve encounters just to avoid it. That was the point that I knew it was time for a refund.

I feel like this game had the potential to be something great and refreshing, but the mechanics and the way the elements of the different genres were integrated led to a bland game that was generally uninteresting to play.

24221606.review: Great game. many hours of exploration, crafting, technology developing, fighting. almost everything you can ask for! can even kill dragons in the game!

24217281.review:
Do you like hex board games? Crafting mechanics? Random events? Do you like saying "Just one more turn" 50 times until realizing the shame spiral you've fallen into? Then this might be the game for you. I wasn't sure how I'd feel about it at first but I found myself completing turn after turn and falling into it's spell until, lo and behold, it was the next day! 
It's a fun game all around with a lot of mechanics going on; it's not so many that you can't keep things in order but not so few that they all get tedious too quickly. All at the same time you're crafting weapons, gather materials, exploring the world, and running into new events. Each game has it's own deity with buffs that level up based on how you're playing through the game which, subsequently, give you more buffs in new games. 
The events editor really helps with keeping the game interesting. If you don't feel like making your own, you can download events from online sources. While it is fun to make your own, it is not entirely straightforward; it involves a lot of trial and error and there are still many aspects of the editor that just aren't well explained and you may never use. That is, unless of course you're good with coding and logic. 
One gripe is that the random events begin to get repetitive after a while. Seriously, I got ambushed by dwarven bandits so many times that I eventually just started killing them instead of sparing. It said I had completed 20% of the events but I kept getting the same ones over and over again after I'd completed most of a game. 
Also, the voice-over for some of the text probably could have used a woman's touch. Seriously, the guy sounded awfully weird when reading some of the female voice... 
Either way, all around fun game and I hope new things get added in the future. I've spent over 100 hours in this game and I intend to spend a lot more.

24211108.review:
Thea: The Awakening est un OVNI. Beaucoup de jeux rentrent dans une case en terme de concept mais ici, on trouve des éléments inattendus , gestion de ville et de ressources, du RPG, un jeu de carte, du rogue like... et le tout se mêle de manière harmonieuse.

Beaucoup d'autres commentaires ont pu déjà détailler tout ce qui fait de Thea un jeu agréable à jouer, qui donne envie de jouer "encore un tour" et de relancer une partie encore et encore.

Ce qui fait que j'y reviens tient en peu de choses ;
- Un concept original, en terme de gameplay
- Le côté purement ludique d'un univers basé sur les mythologies slaves, assez peu connues et qui donne envie de s'y intéresser
- La partie RPG, toutes les quêtes peuvent être gérées de multiples manières, certaines simples et définitives ("un nain vient dans ma ville, je bois un coup avec lui, ou je l'assassine ?") mais qui peuvent, avec certains critères (divinités, race de personnages présents caractéristiques...), permettre de les tenter de toutes les façons, de partie en partie, voire, pour certaines quêtes, plusieurs fois par parties. Et la partie aléatoire supplémentaire augmente encore la variabilité des résultats (le fameux nain a décidé une fois sur peut être 15 quêtes de rester dans ma ville)
- Les graphismes. L'ambiance est là, et les graphismes sont cohérents, pas de visuels explosifs et tout ce qui fait le marketing de certains jeux récents, on est sur du médiéval fantastique à l'ancienne. L'immersion y gagne, je trouve. Et personellement, les graphismes des cartes m'évoquent Fantasy General, un jeu antédiluvien avec le même genre de crayonnés qui m'avait marqué il y a plus de 15 ans.
- Ca a été dit et redit, mais une équipe de développeurs qui continue de débugger, améliorer, rajouter des petites bricoles, comme des DLC complets, le tout gratuitement, c'est rare, et un studio qui fait ca mérite d'être suivi de près.

Bref, un jeu sur lequel je continuerais à jouer, en attendant les prochaines évolutions !

24198245.review:
Thea: The Awakenening was a fantastic game.

You play as a fallen God who must lead his worshippers on their path to restoring Thea after the Darkness lifted. It's a turn-based game, akin to Civilization, however, unlike Civilization, you only have one central town. As you gain babies and random characters through events, you can form parties to go out and collect resources from the land. As turns increase, monster difficulty and quantity increase as well. This provides quite a challenge, it can also be quite frustrating when starting a new game because your villagers are weak and lacking ability at the start. I had to restart the game at least 4 times before I finally understood how to properly "start" a game without losing time and villagers.

Although the learning curve was moderate, it's not entirely difficult, especially for moderate gamers.

Also, the writers for this game did a fantastic job with the dialogue for random events and story events. I can't stress this enough. This game brought me back to the old days when people played dungeons and dragons on pen and paper. Events were always exciting, even the occasional repeat generally played out differently most times.


Pros:
- Different Gods to choose from, each with unique abilities and dialogue options
- The story is amazing and extremely well written. Reminds me of DnD back in the day.
- Variety of resources, each add their own special attribute to whatever building or item you're crafting.
- An incredible amount of random events. The game never really feels stale.
- Randomly generated map (albeit, limited).
- Free expansion pack, adds event editor and a second storyline (definitely worth it).
- Each God has their own quests in addition to the storyline which makes the game more goal driven, thus making it more fun and engaging.

Cons:
- Difficult to start a new game, progresses very slow in the beginning. This was off putting during my first few play throughs. Once it picked up though, I had lots of fun.
- Only two stories. Although extensive, you'll be left wanting more of the developers creative, immersive writing.
- Managing characters can be a challenge, especially when you're handling multiple parties, their items, and trying to bring resources back and forth. Challenging, but doable.

Overall, this game was definitely worth my time and money.
I definitely recommend playing through at least one game.

It was a truly immersive experience, especially for people who enjoy reading (like me)

24191431.review:
In short Thea:The Awakening is the first dozen or so turns of Civ 5 spread across an entire game and given a ridiculous amount of depth.

And while that's accurate of the gameplay, this description is woefully short of what Thea:The Awakening actually is. Truly it is a turn based, --decision-- game. Not strategy. You have choices with quests, which items to give which person, what resource to gather and what god to invest your time into. Overall if you are a 100% completionist you will get a silly amount of hours out of this game. And if not it's still worth the price.

What many reviews may not describe however is the repetitivness that is inevitable with these kinds of games. Thea:The Awakening does its best to mitigate it, but in the end you will have quests repeat and resources pop up to the point where you can auto-pilot your way to victory. 

On the other side of the coin however the devs for this game believe in free DLC and with the shiny new event editor you can create and download custom made quests and storylines. So there are plenty more hours ahead for me and many others.

All in all, great game, good price and whole heap of potential on top of that. 10/10

24155539.review:
I think the most relevant thing to say here is that, by july, 2016, after getting this game on Summer Sale and playing it through twice, I couldn't find ANY of the flaws the "bad reviews" mention. For example, one of them states that, some 7 months ago, there were 3 villager (character) classes available. Now, there are about 15 (rough guess).

Thea may not look like much at first--the name and graphics didn't cause much of an impression on me either at first--but don't judge it too fast. This game is rather unique, and quite good.

HOW IT WORKS (A.K.A. "THE GOOD STUFF"):

As you've probably read already, Thea: The Awakening is something like Civilization with a single city and, instead of armies, you put up one (or just a few) parties of villagers up, fit them with the best items you could find/craft, and send them out to explore the world, gather food and materials, do quests, face random encounters and events.

Battle takes place on a tabletop, with cards, and this aspect is also very interesting. It works unlike any other card-battle system I've seem so far (and I'm a fan of card games), and requires some thiking even after you've mastered it.

Through research, you can unlock new crafting recipes (heavy armor, one-handed axes, two-handed staves, etc.), new materials to mine, or new construction blueprints. Choosing what to get and when makes a big difference, for you don't have a bunch of idle research points just lying around.

When crafting anything, you choose what materials to use--a base material, a secondary, and a catalyst that has minor influences. How good the item will be depends directly on what you craft them with, and this adds an interesting layer of strategy/lust for the finest materials.

Villager classes (what you can choose your children to become when they grow up) are unlocked with certain buildings--but the real badass characters you get on some quests/events or by building the right structure with the right materials to attract them.

When one of your Dwarves or Baba Yagas (there are more "special-classes," don't worry) die, you curse out loud and decide to wear black to work the next day.

Also, after each game, you'll unlock a new God to play with and/or some new power(s) (it all depends on how much exp you got) to start with next time--some concrete reward for going as far as you can.

THE "NOT-SO-GOOD":

Regarding difficulty, it could be a little harder. I won both games I played (Normal and Difficult settings). If you get a decent start and don't screw up hard, you're fine. After you've figured the whole game out, it's easy.

The main quests could/should be a lot longer.

I wish there was a bigger variety of random events available. They aren't few, no, but... you know, "the more the merrier". This is not so hard to do--you can actually create your own events in the game, but I'd rather have more of the profissional stuff (btw, they are all voiced, and the acting is pretty good) and the same odds as everyone else playing the game. Some events in which you could blindly navigate some deep cave or dungeon, with several fights in a row without leaving nor healing, for instance, would make things considerably more interesting and add more difficulty. Some unique (non-craftable) item drops on such events would also be a nice addition...

Altough you get a new God/new Godly powers after finishing a game, I wish each different God had a somehow deeper impact on the game/your play style (like new starships do on FTL, for instance). The bonuses each of them give vary, but not enough to deeply affect gameplay, and your chosen God also affects a few random events. As far as I can tell, that's pretty much it.

SUMMING UP:

Thea's concept is very interesting and, if not perfectly, still very well executed. A good game, well worth it's price, packing some 50 hours of fun and completely bug-free. I thoroughly enjoyed my ride, and I can see myself coming back to it in the not-so-distant future to play some more.

24151183.review:
This game shows an excellent way of improvement for traditional 4x genre. Really worth a try for all strategy game fans. 

The main complaint I have for most 4x games is the stupid AI. Thea however, wisely avoid the AI development issue. You don't have an opponent in this game in fact. What you only need to do is "outwit the nature". Gathering resources, crafting equipments and following the quests, every elements in this game is by no means a compitition with others. As a result, it brings me a pure relief and enjoyment when playing without any anoyance from bad AI. To exclude boredom with no opponents, this game introduces some RPG elements, form your own expedition team and you are going to adventure the world with a lot of bump-up events and charactor interactions. 

Although relaxing, the tactics and replayablity is also good. Unlike most other strategy games that basically you are going to unlock 80%+ of the technology, units and buildings at the end of the game, research points are so limited in this game so you need to think carefully which tech line you are most craving for. The card game combat mechanism is easy to understand but hard to masterfully manoeuvre. There are a lot of different combat methods you can choose other than merely a nomal fight. This choice depends on the technology you picked, equipments you crafted/looted and your expedition team comps strategically.

The graphic of Thea is decent based on my point. The resolution is mediocre but you can find rich details everywhere. Each character has their unique sketching pictures. Village events have their own watercolor paintings. The apperence for weapons and armers crafted by different materials are also diversified. An armer crafted by wood looks wooden; a sword crafted by gold looks golden. Everything in your sight in accordance with the melodious BGM fits well with the in-game mythical environment.

The story line is... okay, a well written story, traditional myths telling way. Most text is dubbed with a man's deep voice, even for side quests and village events. It sounds a little bit bizarre when a woman character is talking... anyways it is a good feature and helps reading the long text very well. Your choice for the dialogue, in most cases, does not influence the result quite a lot. Actually, only the decision of combat method at the end of each dialogue really matters. This is clearly a drawback for any RPG. But for Thea, a blend of 4x and RPG, it is just a flaw acceptable.

This game is updated frequetly and players are free to discuss their thoughts with devolopers through steam forum. Excellent game already and might become better in the future. Highly recommended.

24139169.review:
I really enjoyed my time with Thea: The Awakening but I don't know that I'd recommend it to someone else.

WHAT IS IT? 
It's a sort of blend between X-Com and Faster Than Light, in a medieval fantasy world. You research items and things for your team of tactical warriors, but you don't actually get to perform many tactical decisions. The character classes are just placeholders for what passives they might level up, so the tactical depth is nonexistent. You're better off clicking "autoresolve" for every battle, I think.

WHY IS IT GOOD?
The game's story is really developed and a lot of fun. The strategic component of the game approaches the complexity of a 4x. It's really quite great.

WHY IS IT BAD?
The tactical game falls down. Thea tries to introduce a card-based battle system to appeal to players that way, but ultimately, you have little choice in terms of tactics - the fight is always about who you brought to the fight and how they're equipped, not what they do.
While the strategical concept of levelling Gods and their individual stories is interesting, without a certain depth to the rest of the game, this replayability suggestion falls flat.

SHOULD I BUY IT?
If you like games that are more strategy than tactics, and you enjoy replaying them, yes. However, one of the Civs may be the better game for you. If you like tactics over strategy, you need to give this a pass. It looks good... but it's not quite the itch you're wanting to scratch.

FINAL WORDS:
I really enjoyed my time with Thea. It's a great game. But it's uncertain where it stands in the terms of games, and it doesn't go far enough with either strategy, story, or tactics. I don't regret my purchase, but I'm a weird sort of gamer that really likes board AND video games.  If you don't share that mindset, you'll probably just get frustrated, with either the lack of tactical component, or the boredom of the strategic component.

The narration, while only spoken by one person (I guess) is very nicely done and induces the feeling to play a nice round of a roleplaying game just at home with friends and listen to the game master.
The game does not tell you quite much, but you will find out over time. While I made some "mistakes" in the beginning (overlooking that there are more "tech trees" than ressources), I never felt the need to start over. I di dhowever quite often load an old game since the outcome of some actions were totally strange to me (unless i started to understand combat). The turn based combat with cards is completely new to me (tur based veteran), but highly entertaining, And even the salest trinket starts to make much more sense than "Strength +1".

All in all this game is a gem, a work of love and devotion, constantly updated, presented in a very personal and charming way and I can really highly recommen it.
But if you are looking for a super plished AAA titel with high production value, you will not like this game. It needs time on your side too and the will to explore the game as well as the lands it offers to you.

24136640.review:
Edit: Initially I wrote a review without having played the DLC. While very little actually changed apart from additional content dealing with giants (which, if I'm being honest, the game would feel incomplete without), my review is basically the same, and remains positive.

PROS:
* Combat is fun, and better yet, you can skip it with Auto-Resolve if you're positive you're going to win... or just don't feel like facing your demise for long. 
* Fully narrated by one guy. Like a true Dungeon Master, he also does the "voice acting" for all the characters. This is a huge pro for me just because it adds even more to that campy storytelling element that's so rare these days.
* Difficulty is highly customizeable each play-through.
* Very deep game system overall, though it can be a bit overwhelming at first.
* Comes with an event editor.
* Crafting system is simply fun to play around with.
* Nice ambient soundtrack.

CONS:
* Can only have your starting settlement, which is kind of a drag. For larger maps it'd be nice to have two or even three villages. But this is a very different beast from the sort of base expansion type game you'd expect from other 4x titles, with more of a focus on your expeditions.
* In order to start a new game, you must erase your previous one. I get that from a roguelike perspective, but I wish I could save a world.
* Kind of short, but there is the iffy replay value. You're just playing mostly the same events in different ways and varying difficulties. 
* The UI and input could use some cleaning up. Would some more keyboard input hurt? Most of your input is going to be with the mouse.

Overall though, this game is worth every penny. It might put you off at first but you'll find yourself drawn back.

BUG:
The further you get into a late play-through after hundreds of turns, you'll notice the UI start to hitch in the inventory/production/expedition screens. Initially I thought this was a memory leak, but I never experienced a crash; I'm not sure what exactly causes this, but it's probably just from having too much stuff. Equipment and villagers both count as inventory items, so maybe that's it? If you dismantle items you know you won't use as you go along you should alleviate the bug, and there's a neat shortcut to do so when you acquire them.

24063159.review:
Every now and then I get the urge to go RPGing, and Thea totally scratches that itch. From copious creatures, characters, resources, crafting recipes, and loot - to innumerable quests, encounters, and events, there's enough to keep me entertained for hours on end. 

Nearly all of the events play out as narratives read by a talented elocutionist. If it's something new, I sit back and enjoy. If it's an event I've already seen a few times, I just select my choice and speed through. One of the nice things about Thea is that many of the smaller encounters are recurrent so if I screwed up the first time and got my butt handed to me, eventually I'll get another chance to either try out a different choice, or split and run 'til I'm better prepared. Sometimes I auto-resolve a conflict to save a bit of time, but other times I might have a better shot at success if I manage things myself. Even though every clash is a card battle, there are strategic and tactical aspects that can help reverse adverse odds.

There are always different ways to solve a problem. If you're running with a pack of nerds, you can have them try to think their way out of a crisis, or if you've got a few socialites in the party, maybe they’ll succeed in talking you out of a big mess. It’s also pretty satisfying to stomp around the park with a bunch of hamfisted meatheads - ghosts, ghouls, goblins, giants, and drakes be damned. No need to walk softly when you've got a big mithril stick!

Tons of replayability too - each deity will add a slightly different flavor. On the easier difficulties, you can save right before you do something overtly stupid, and reload once you've received confirmation that, why yes - that really was dumb. On the higher difficulties, you're pretty much skunked if you underestimate a challenge. Some of the toughest foes will dust a party of 20-30 well-equipped high level characters. And that sucks, because after a while, you’ll likely grow fond of each villager. The character art is varied and fantastic, and there are so many different ones that I haven’t run into some of my favorites again after three playthroughs and nearly a hundred hours.

The devs are creative and clever, and have to be the most generous team out there – offering multiple DLCs for free. Great game. Great devs. Great fun.

In the event that my mind swaps bodies with some other gamer - I’ll definitely buy it again.

I absolutely adore the game, but I do not think it is for everyone.
I adore the graphics, pictures and storylines - they are very climactic and immersing. Unfortunately, there's far too little diversification in soundtrack - but a few melodies, and it can wear down on you.
The mechanics are interesting, sort of cross between RPG character management - only you have a lot of them - survival and civilization game and card game instead of regular battles. Since I suck at any, even semi-rts, elements, I love this shift to a card game. 
It is fairly difficult, actually, even though you can adjust it to suit your mood/skill level. Feel like playing bloodbath on hardcore settings? Well, prepare for a world of pain, people dying left and right, and I have lost the first few times with the mod. Feeling like a breezy playthrough on easy? Well, it is there for you...
Personally, the micromanagement and crafting are what makes the game for me - but for some, it is clearly a problem. There's a lot of it. Each and every villager needs to have their equipment upgraded and adjusted multiple times throughtout the game, you need to gather resources and craft and it all requires your attention. 
Some claim that the menu is not user friendly, but I have never had a problem, so I can't say. 
I love the new expansion, and, more importantly, the new keyboard shortcuts. For those who didn't know - hold r + mouse click = recycle; hold d + mouse click = delete. It is so much time saving, I can't believe they didn't think about it from the start - but now that it is finally there, a lot of annoying clicking and dragging has been removed, which makes the game much more enjoyable.
For me, the game would be rated 8.5/10 - I need more quest diversity and more soundtrack to give it a full 9; but otherwise, a lot of fun.

Thea The Awakening is a hidden gem that I hope many more people can experience. The devs did a brilliant job combining different game elements into it. I'd simplify it as a strategy/management/survival game, with some optional card game combat system thrown in for those who like to play it out.  I've already put 50 hours into the game and am looking forward to future titles from the creators along with any dlc they might provide!

Pros: 
Free dlcs
Slavic Lore based
Easy difficulty is actually rather challenging for the first few playthroughs
Hardcore mechanics (villagers die forever) and even more hardcore mechanics that you can toggle on/off (no saves etc)

Cons:
Only one village can currently be constructed, a bit of a pain when you play on the largest map type

Lack of game information for those that like to min/max- but I personally enjoy this element. No one to tell me what the best choices are I have to learn that for myself and deal with the consequences!

Co-op needs a bit of work, but I'm glad they included it ( for free at that!). I would not suggset playing co-op first, you should save that for when you and your partner are already more experienced. After that throw it on the most difficult settings and go ham.

All and all it's worth the price and then some, Thea is a work of art.

23993859.review:
This a strategy game based on Slavic mythology where you play a god watching over a small village of humans who are emerging from an apocalyptic disaster that cut off the world from the afterlife and unleashed monsters and beasts everywhere.

Gameplay revolves around these things:

- Managing your community and its resources. Setting villagers to gather, craft, and build improvements.

- Sending out expeditions to gather resources, explore ruins, and complete quests.

- Getting into conflicts with roving bands of monsters and beasts.

The game has a lot of depth. You have a bunch of different types of villagers with their own strengths and weakness, and there are a lot of different types of conflicts you can find yourself in that makes them all useful. You can be out in the wild and run into some wolves and be glad you brought your hunter, or encounter a goblin raiding party and be glad your scavenger is there to help you sneak past. You can always just do a straight up fight, but fighting is the only type of conflict that can potentially kill the members of your expedition so it's always worth it to try something else if it's an option, but if monsters get the drop on you, you have to fight so it's worth it to bring some big lunky warriors with you every time. Though when decently equipped all your villagers can be a serious threat.

The conflicts also play as a complex and interesting card game, with your villagers making up your hand and split into offensive and tactical cards, with the offensive cards being your villagers doing and taking damage, and the tactical cards being your villagers using special abilities to change the shape of the conflict. Your big lunky warrior can wade in and club the crap out of people in your offensive hand, or use an ability that lets her shield a teammate and add to their armor for a round in your tactical hand.

And a significant portion of the game is crafting and building up your village. In order to do this you need to find different resources on the map and send your expedition to gather them. Those ingredients can then be used to make different types of food (the more varieties you have, the better bonuses your village and expedition gets), weapons and armor, and buildings to attract people to your village, craft better items, get defensive bonuses when monsters attack, and so on. The quality of materials matter, with better quality materials needing to be unlocked through your tech tree (which advances through crafting and adventuring). All items call for certain combinations of types of materials, so you could make a club with a wood and bone, but if you use regular wood and regular bones you're going to get a different (and lower quality) item than if you made it out of ancient wood and dragon bones. And while your villagers do level up, a lot of the later game quests require having truly badass gear to beat some of the challenges so you need to take regular breaks from questing in order gather resources and upgrade your expedition's gear. Similarly, better quality materials make for better or different buildings, so a pasture which normally attracts more humans to your village might attract elves if made with elven wood or orcs if made with... something I haven't figured out yet (BUT MUST).

It's a unique game, and the developers are regularly pushing out new updates with new content for free! Though they have a "Coffee for Coders" DLC that will let you support them with more money if you want and give you access to all the character and monster portraits to use however you want. And I appreciate that for all the different character types they have a variety of ages and genders in the portraits (though my favorite is the huge shirtless muscle warrior). I'm really happy I picked it up.

23931482.review:
A quite unique game. It's all about resource and citizen management, with exploration and story-telling quests.

You only have one village (and never settle any), which can have a maximum of ten buildings in it (each of which can be knocked down and replaced). Your village is mainly full of warriors, gatherers, and crafters, as well as a few other "classes" such as scavengers and undead.  The warriors defend the village from attacks, the gatherers collect nearby resources (such as wood, leather, or various food items), and the crafters make buildings, cook food, and crafts weapons, armour, and tools.  The crafting is particularly interesting because the better quality of the items used (scaled leather against basic leather, for example) determines the final quality and benefits of the buildings and crafted items.  Different cooking recipes are made by varying the ingredients used, and the more the number of different food stuffs available to your people, the more bonuses you receive.

Both science and experience are achieved through battles, questing, and making items. Experience is awarded to everyone at the same time, and levelling up is done automatically.

To quest, or to gather resources out of reach of your village, you put together a party of people of different skills (warriors and gatherers, mainly). The party will need to carry enough food and wood to survive, and can collect more as it travels.  They can then battle creatures, activate quests, or set up a camp and collect nearby resources which then need to be taken back to the village.

Battles are interesting in they are simulated using cards randomly split into two small decks. The first mainly uses the attack and defence stats. Both player and opponent take turns to place one or more of their cards down (left-to-right), before battle is started. When all the cards are dealt the battle starts moving along from the left, and each card's attack damage will decrement the neighbouring opponent's card's defence value (randomly left or right), and if that value reaches zero then the card is removed. A few other attributes such as if the weapon is a piercing (in which case when the card is initially placed, it will go before the opponent's last placed card and deal it half the weapon damage immediately) are also taken into consideration. The second deck is the tactical deck, and each card can be used to, for example, add to your last dealt card's defence value, or randomly remove a card from one of your opponent's deck.  As each battle is made up of two rounds (before the whole process is repeated, until one side has no more cards left), you can also place your tactical cards into the battle.  However they will start "confused", and so will not attack until the second round (but can be attacked, and thus possibly removed, during the first round).

When the battle is over, some of your characters may be wounded, and it's a good idea to have a decent medic in your party to quickly heal the wounded in a camp. If the defence value fell too low, a character may die. But even if a defence value falls to zero, your medic still might be able to bring your character back to full health.

Battles are not always about fighting.  Sometimes it's about hunting, quarrelling, sneaking, or poisoning. And each of these will use different character stats (the hunting for example, will use your gathering skill to determine damage).  This makes it important to have a good mix of people in your village and parties.  Non-fighting battles do not end with any damage to your characters, but the consequences of losing such a battle may do (for example, losing an argument and being thrown out of a tower).

There is no save/load feature in the game.  If you make a mistake, you have to live with it.

The music is great.  Very Dom4-ish.

The DLC is virtually all free, and the developers apparently have added a lot of content since the initial release.  The only DLC they do charge for is a small (optional) donation DLC for those who wish to thank them for all the free content --- apparently requested by their customers.

If you like resource and citizen management, it's a great game and well recommended.

This game is good, damn, I mean pretty good.
I've play lots of 4X games, such as Endless series, Civs, AoW, Warloc.
Almost every 4X game treat the civilians as a number, and the army as an unit.
And the player never care about their unit has been killed -- they can always train more units in the next turn.

But in Thea, it's total different.
Every civilian has their own name, own skill, their background, their path of life. They are not just a number.
And also, you will find out you can not train any military unit in this game. 
Of caurse, a solder not just a solder, he(she) is a civilian too!
You have to select some civilians who "know how to fight", group them like an army, give them weapons -- customize for everyone.
And that's all? No. They need supplies, and they have to carry the supplies by their own.
If they carry too much, it might even overweight and hard to move the army!
The most important, they're live humans, they might hurt, they might bleeding, and they might killed when the player can not take care when they wounded. 

OMG, what's wrong with the developers?!
10/10 no more reason. Please have a try.

23810005.review:
Thea has great potentional, but a horrid excecution. The game completely lacks any intutive inventory management system, yet realies heavily on crafting and dividing gear amongst your sometimes 40(!)+ characters. Furthermore the game does not have a real difficulty. Instead, it relies on randomised events and luck. Regarding the different events themselves, this is good, but the RNG also affects the stats and levels of the enemies in these events.

With that, slap on a completely ruined save function that seperatly saves autosaves and manual saves without letting you choose what to load, and you have a game that has many different elements of frustration. The UI and external problem rips you out of the game, they break the third wall like reflections of a movie set breaks a good film.

I will revisit Thea and my review should there be a development on these issues.

Thea is affordable, and because of the fair pricing I feel that I must recommend the game. Despite these massive problems, it's still a game to pick up. But the game does not warrant a good review with the current problems at hand.

23805242.review:
Thea: The Awakening is indeed something special.
When you first play it, it does seem like your typical 4X-Game, however the longer you play it the more its RPG-Elements become apparent.

You play as a deity, a guiding spirit of a village that survived the long darkness. Your job is to lead your people, so that they may survive, learn what happend to the world and how to fix it.

The game requires some micromanagement because you don't control an abstract mass of units like in "pure" strategy games. Each villager has a (choosable) Name, can and should be individually equipped, will level up from time to time and has a long list of stats that play a role in challanges (which are represented by a well-thought-out card game) and also in story events.
For example: You find a house and your expedition explore ways to get in. If you have a character with a magic stat of at least level 4 you get the option to disable the defence in a magic challenge. On the other hand, if one character has a dexterity attribute of 7 you may also just lockpick your way in.

The Deity you choose provides global bonuses (especially if it is leveled up and played again) but also influences the story and events. Each one has its own devine quest and events while even standard events may offer different solutions and outcomes depending on the deity. That alone enhances the replay value greatly.

The main story is also non-linear, meaning there is often more than one way of solving problems and  more than one way of comleting both, the main game story as well as the giants story.

All in all, I can highly recommend this game to anyone who likes strategy or rpg games and is not afraid of a somewhat steep learning curve.

23798636.review:

Its such a clever game and if you like hex turn based games give this a go but its so much more than that with rpg progression and crafting elements.

My favorite thing in this game is the narrator who voices over all encounters it really adds to the atmosphere and reminds me of the days of paper based D&D. Found myself actually starting to give a damm about my villagers :)

23772659.review:
Take a 4X game, and remove the entire thought set that runs through your mind about making more settlements and training troops.  Instead, replace those with a more RPG-esque exploration of the world using teams of characters from your settlement, which grows quite slowly.  It strongly emphasises exploration and story, while minimizing expansion elements.  It also throws in a little more resource management to the mix, requiring you do decide how you will acquire those resources, and sometimes forcing you to decide if you want them, or want to address a threat.

Add in a strategic system for card battles, lots of flavor in questing, the ability to add in your own elements with the event creation system, make every action a choice where you can mess up or do well... and sometimes where your choice is a matter between trying something very dangerous or avoiding that danger, and mix it all up with a hefty dose of awesome.

That's Thea.  If you don't like slower paced strategic games, it isn't for you.  If you do, then you will probably enjoy yourself with this title.

For more detailed information, I have written about this game for Gaiscioch Magazine, and you can find those writings online, which will give you an overview of each portion of the game and some screencaps.

23769098.review:
"You've stumbled across a game. You slowly peak into the store page only to discover the game is in fact an ancient labyrinth. Indeed! What you initially thought was a home for bandits is truly a deepening maze, ready to test your wit and bend your mind, challenging any notion of greatness you once thought you had. A dank smell surrounds you and your men, a shared sense of foreboding fills your lungs; yet, in the world of Thea, with danger comes reward...and with reward comes treasure and weapons and shit! You know this venture will not be easy, and you can't help but question if you'll even survive. Do you have what it takes? The risk is certainly great, and any reward is uncertain...but the darkness calls you in.

1. Enter the game.

2. Be a baby and go back to your flashy RTS."

You decided to enter the game. You go left. Right. Left. A wall. When you turn around, an army of undead rise from the dirt you had just walked over. You're trapped. Combat begins. Do you sacrifice your lowly gatherer to gain the advantage or hope your mightiest warrior has what it takes? Should you give up a card to move another to the front of the line? Or would it be better to use it to confuse the opponents last card and force them to lose a turn? Perhaps you should use it to help shield a weaker card. Or should you wait until the next round and hope for the best? Only you can decide...and those are a few examples of the options you have.

If you're into the turn based 4x map genre and don't need flashy action to give your strategic mind HOURS of entertainment...this game was made for you. Enter the game, conquer the labyrinth.

23760754.review:
I love the idea for the game and most of the game itself but it does have a giant flaw. Gods take too long to level and until you get specific ones to a high enough level, you can not really do any different play throughs because you don't start with the right skills for them. For instance, having magic in your party lets you get a lot of other magic characters in random events. Without magic you will probably go the entire game without getting 1 until you make the highest level weapons/armor at the end of the game. Not having any magic means you can't do any of the magic paths and you miss out on say ~15% of the options. Same goes for folklore, hunting, etc. So each game ends up being the same unless you get incredibly lucky.

Maxing out a god could let you start with a special character but it takes entirely too many throughs of the same content to get. Think 5-25 playthoroughs of a 7-15 hour game before you start unlocking cool stuff. And if you use that cool stuff you don't further your gods at all, it's just a waste of time. 

If this system got fixed(Honestly leave it and just add a console unlock all gods option for when we get sick of it or something) this would be one of my favorite games, as it is I can't recommend it because every time I think of how easy it would be to enjoy this game more I get frustrated by the god implementation.

Edit: http://steamcommunity.com/app/378720/discussions/0/361787186431954562/ this lets you get around the god aspect as the Dev below has pointed out so I am changing the review to positive.

I really can't remember (today) where did I find this game... it was recommended by Steam or saw on a website. It doesnt matter, the game is REALLY good. I will try to describe a little of what I feel:

- It remembers you part of Civilization gameplay (management, reasearch and units movement)
- It remembers you great RPG storytelling during your journey through encounter events
- It is easy to get used to it and you can choose, at your own pace, the difficulty of the game (but only at the beginning)
- Large world, perfect for what I like
- Combat uses a card system, but this same system is used for random events (if you need to hunt something, you need to "defeat" dexteriry or something like that, it remembers me the old school RPGs). It can be confusing at first, but at third or forth play it will be nice
- There is a crafting system, it is nice (but no more than that)
- Great story, events and random enemies encounters
- Character progression

ALSO, devs created new DLCs for FREE, with actual new features and new things (not just free garbage). Kudos to them.
Really recommended 9/10.

23727994.review:
A neat little adventure game that perhaps mixes Civilization with King of Dragon Pass, Thea offers an interesting world with poor graphics and simple resource-management, but unique (albeit frustrating) combat, great events, interesting story, and decent crafting.

The game is definitely worth giving a playthrough, but in the end it is rather easy and unfortunately features very little replay value as you encounter many of the same events, have essentially the same characters, discover a world that is the same, and have little impact on said world while experiencing alternate story endings that are not satisfying enough to justify additional 30+ hour plays.

23658474.review:
TL;DR: I love the game. Awesome Game and developpers. Free DLCs. Coop. Buy it.

Story : Slavic mythology is not your common background for a game. I love mythology and I discovered a new one through this game (and some researches of my own)

Mechanics : It's 4X. The mechanics are great. Explore, go through tons of events. Build your team, be careful what you fight. And it gives you the "one-more-turn" feeling so it's doing it's job.

Challenges : The card game is well done. At some point if your team is good you'll prefer the auto-resolve though, can get a bit repetitive. But the auto is smart enough to get your team through without casualties (given the team is strong enough) which cannot be said for auto-resolve of other games I played (you know the one: ten times stronger than the monsters and somehow lose half your team/health).

Performance : Running smoothly. Problem is when you want bigger maps. You get bigger loading times (kinda logic), depends on your computer but anyway if you don't "cheat" by save/load every decision/fight it shouldn't be a problem.

DLC : They released free DLC which is a good change from other developpers even if it was risky as they explained in a note (one must live ^^). But they kept their words anyway, and all the additionnal content is free.

Overall : Has its flaws but so many good things to compensate. Try it, adopt it. Worth the price. If it's on sale you have no excuse !

Just impatient to see what they'll come up with next.

Note : More hours on record offline :)

23648943.review:
My first ever game review and it is for this is amazing turn-based strategy game.  Now, this is not to say that everything is perfect but I have ZERO regrets for purchasing this game.  This is not CIV Fantasy nor is it a Master of Magic clone/ wannabe.  It has its on take on the genre, is original and a breath of fresh air. 
In brief, the game takes place after a world shattering event bringing about eternal night.  After a hundred years of darkness, the sun is finally returning and you are a god looking after a small village of ragged survivors. Your task is to guide them in this new world and help them thrive. 
Unlike most games, you cannot expand beyond your initial village and your starting position is fixed by the game. You will send your people out in parties to gather resources, complete quests and fight/ negotiate with the inhabitants of this fallen world.
Tactical combat is resolved via a card game system.

Pros
General comments
- Game runs well and is very bug free. The developers are extremely fast in the response to bugs.
- Developer engages with the community, with many enhancements and improvements resulting from their interactions.
- MUHA gave out a complete DLC for free, with another on the way. Their commitment towards a quality product and a value product is amply demonstrated.

Gameplay
- Multiple gods, each with its own peculiarities incl special quests, gives extended play value.
- Customise play difficulty allows each player to select the level of challenge appropriate for them. A casual player can tone down various settings while hardcore strategy fans can crank those settings up. Among the elements you can tweak include ironman mode, the toughness of quests and combats, construction/ material gathering times, max number of people in your exploration parties, aggressiveness of monsters, rate of the world evolving (before tougher monsters/ lairs appears) and more. For me, it is clear the developer wants player to enjoy playing the game at their choice of difficulty.
- Challenges are well balanced for the most part. Although I find that certain late-game challenges can be tough for physical combat.
- Card game tactical combat. Personally, I don't mind the card game but it can get repetitive for some players. It is relatively simply and astute players can find ways to exploit the system weakness. 
- Quests - the are plenty of quests for your survivors to embark on. And almost all quests can be solved in different ways, depending on your exploration party's skills and equipment. With the additional of the Giants DLC, more quests and events are added. 
- Craftng. There are lots of things to craft and unless you are playing with the most difficult settings, where you need to optimise your party and items, all items are helpful and useful.  I like craft and equip based on RP purposes and can still win the game even at 200% difficulty.

Cons - still not everything is perfect. Personally, I am iffy about the following.
- Card game challenge - While the game allows you to tackle all challenges using different skills, all challenges are resolved using the same card game challenge.  The card game can get old fast. Also some players may find the card game visually unexciting cuz you don't get to see graphics of your fighters (etc) smashing monsters.
- Tech tree - A number of the techs (esp at more difficult settings) is ignored by many players as you do not get enough returns. Each tech you research means the next tech takes more research points. And research points (and XP) are only generated through encounters, events and crafting.  In some games, players tend to rush certain techs before the game world evolves to much (with high-tier monsters). I won the majority of my games after researching about 1/2 the available techs.
- Auto-combat is very much touch and go because (I think) the mechanism ignores the use of skills and equipment abilities.  And for some reason, auto-resolving against skeletons (even when there's 3 skeletons and 16 of you) and certain undead can result in heavy damage to your people no matter how powerful or leveled-up.

Overall, I give this game a two-thumbs up. No hesitation to recommend this game. My proverbial hat is off to MUHA Games.

23648712.review:
Что не понравилось:
-1. Описание немного не соответствует действительности:

"...стратегический игровой процесс с напряженными захватывающими приключениям..." -- Игровой процесс не напряжённые и не захватывающий.

"...Конфликты вы можете разрешить при помощи дипломатии, незаметности, убийства, охоты и других способов, доступных вашим людям. Сражение – далеко не единственный метод!..." -- Между всеми способами решения проблем (бой, колдовство, дипломатия, тактика, незаметность и.т.п.) почти нет отличий. Всё сводится к карточной игре, которая очень быстро надоедает, и тогда счастливый обладатель игры начинает всё чаще нажимать кнопочку "автоматический бой", которая автоматом выдаёт результат без карточной игры.

И много других мелких несоответствий, которые следует записать в отдельные минусы. Дело в том, что написанные в описании плюсы, на деле плюсами не являются, или же даже оборачиваются минусами.

-2. На дворе 2016 год. По оформлению, стилистике и геймплею игра тянет лишь на год 2005.
-3. Отдельным минусом запишем геймплей - он настолько плох и неудобен что и без того скучный игровой процесс надоедает ещё быстрей.
-4. Огромный однообразный мир.
-5. Слишком много рандома.
-6. Раздавать поручения рабочим (сбор, крафт, строительство), водить отряд бойцов по карте и читать кучу текста - все удовольствия за 400 рублей.
-7. И много чего ещё не понравилось по мелочам, но это уже скорей дело вкуса, и, конечно же, следствие всех выше перечисленных минусов, ибо если игра в целом норм, то на незначительные минусы как правило можно прикрыть глаза. Но только не тут.

Что понравилось:
Сложно сказать... Скорей всего ничего. Можно похвалить за огромное кол-во предметов, событий и прочего контента, а так же за редактор этих событий, но это всё ничто без успешной основы игры.

Разработчикам:
По крупицам перебрать и переработать игру, а лучше - на основе данной задумки (описания) выпустить новую, качественную, хорошую.

Итог:
Крайне не рекомендую. Есть много других хороших игр.
