23627534.review:
Poor guy who had to read out all of those lovely, funny and magical texts. And I'm not refering to my review... but go ahead and read on...

This game has me losing sleep ever since I started playing. It's amazing, funny... and I'm german so I don't like to sweet talk everything by nature BUT this is as good a game as you can imagine.

Why? 
It really is [b] unique [/b] for once. I usually can't stand the always mentioned "unique crafting system", "unique gameplay", "unique whatever" in every game description I read and the following disapointment when I realize it is just the same as always with some minor changes one would normally never recognize at all. In Thea however both the [b] fighting system [/b] and the  [b] fighting styles [/b] are unique. It takes some time to get used to it and to realize how you can efficiently use your characters, but even after nearly a hundred hours of gaming time fighting strong foes is still enjoyable. In short first you choose the type of battle: Do you want to engage the enemy, sweet talk him, sneak beneath his eyes? Or do you rather choose to use your supreme intellect or tactical wisdom? The battle itself is designed as a card game in which you try to place your cards ahead of you opponent so your cards will counter the effects of your foe, will be used as a sacrifical pawn to save your more important cards or boost some of your other cards while not actually taking part in the battle. And afterwards you will really know if your intellect was so supreme...

Secondly, [b] the story [/b]. It's not that the setting of a world fallen in darkness trying to withstand the evil forces is new but the way it was implemented which makes this game so adorable. The story is well written and good to read and although your choices in the main story do not effect the gameplay that much you can still choose between lots of different outcomes. Anyway, the main story is not was makes up the story in my opinion. It is the random events which occur during the game. The number of total events is vast, the number of choices in the events just adding to the complexity. I have never gotten more than a 19% event participation in all of my games. And it's just plain fun to uncover all the different outcomes. If you're repeating an event, choosing the same answer usually leads to the same result, sometimes not. Sometimes choosing the absolutely wrong choice leads to a couple of completly new choices, sometimes  it's just awfully wrong. There are so many possiblities and all of them match the setting of this wonderous world. Really well done! 

The [b] gameplay [/b] is typically round based while you're moving your expiditions in a hexagonal structured world. While doing so, you're finishing off opponents, gathering resources, scouting the world and trying to boost your village and people by crafting new equipment to fend off the everlasting presence of the dark forces. The characters have names, a huge variety of skills and you follow them from birth to death while trying to ward of the latter as long as possible. The longer you prevail the stronger they get, you grow fond of them, you boost them but finally the inevitable happens they die. Just reload? Sure, no problem or did you decide to raise the [b] difficulty level [/b] by switching off the manual save function? That's what I love about this game. You really can adjust the difficulty to match your current strenght. Begin with the easiest world possible, get to know how this game work, get to love Thea. Then, change world size to really insane levels, change strenght and aggresivity of your opponents, add reality, switch of save mode, add bloodbath and die trying to survive in world made to kill every last memory of human kind. 

By the way, human kind? Why meet the usual collection of fantasy creatures like elves, orcs and dwarves. Persuade some more goblin green skins into your team, save beasts, mystical creatures, ghosts... I get the feeling you can nearly get every crawling creature you encounter to join ýour team in one way or another. If you're clever enough, that is.

This game is really worth it's money. More so, even. For reality reasons I should say that I feel the end game somehow gets to easy, but since my results so far suggest that I'm more focused on dying on hard difficulty than staying alive, maybe I'd rather not mention that. 

Get this game and get to love Thea.

23602587.review:
Thea ist ein tolles Spiel, mit dem ich für einen so geringen Preis schon ähnlich viel Zeit wie mit Witcher 3, Fallout 4 und ähnlich guten großen Titeln verbracht habe. Ich besitze das Spiel seit dem Release auf Steam, ursprünglich noch in Englisch. Mit dem kostenlosen, nachgeschobenen DLC wurde das Spiel komplett und sehr gut übersetzt, weswegen ich nun auch für jene, die dem Englischen nicht mächtig sind eine volle Kaufempfehlung ausspreche. Ich selber werde es trotzdem wieder  auf Englisch umstellen, es hat dann meiner Meinung nach mehr Flair.


Das Spiel ist ein Rundenbasiertes Strategie-Überlebensspiel, welches sehr gut gemacht ist, wenn ihr Details über das Spiel wollt, es gibt sehr gute Youtube Videos und das zur Verfügung gestellte Material der Macher ist auch sehr gut.

Was mich besonders begeistert ist, dass an dem Spiel immer noch gearbeitet wird. Nachdem ich 80 Stunden in das Spiel gesteckt hatte dachte ich das wäre es für das Spiel und es wäre das Geld vollkommen Wert gewesen, doch nach einiger Zeit merkte ich, wie stark noch an dem Spiel gearbeitet wird und dass da definitiv noch mehr Spielzeit für mich drinsteckt.

Guckt es euch an, wenn es euch gefällt holt es euch, denn es wird noch besser!!

23590311.review:
I'd recommend this game for sure. Having so many resources, availability of different combat tactics and random events are making this game not too easy but really interesting and dynamic. The flaws for me is a pretty short main storyline (still interesting descriptions and dialogues with a humour where it's supposed to be) and the availability to load your prev save to predict some undesired events. I know that losing one of your people whom u've been rising from the first days is cruel and will make it more like "Don't starve" but will make every event more necessary. As about main storyline (or even counting sub quests) you could look at the game "Space Rangers 2" which is also has many text missions. The problem for me was completing the main task but having the skill tree on the 20% only making every game is too short, I've continued to play only to rise the population and open the whole map etc.
Having the Giants DLC has made the game longer for sure but it was still possible to kill them without having a bunch of excavated mithril or dragon skin.
I had some problems in before: game crashed on the exit and crashed once during the fight.
So according to what I've listed I'd give a 7 / 10 score to that game. Hope it'll be improved later as there are many possibilities to develop

23564418.review:
This is a surprising and welcome combination of a card game and a top down strategy game. While it succedes and surpasses most games that are similar in this genre it struggles to create a game that will win your heart.

I am enjoying the time I spend in this game. It's put together with all the right parts and if you spend the time with this game it will reward you for your time spent. 

The issue is that the interface is good but it could have been much better. The other issue is that the learning curve is tricky - you will need a lot of practice to fully understand the game. There are no great tutorials out there - unless maybe you watch a few bunch of hours on youtube. So ultimately you will have to overcome the wierd user interface with the tricky learning curve to fully enjoy the great game that lies underneath. 

It is an interesting game and I appreciate the individual elements that make it what it is. I just don't find myself obsessing on it for more than a few short sessions. It's not a AAA blockbuster for sure but I keep hoping that it could be more when I play it.

23532666.review:
I had a rather unique experience with Thea tha I thought I would share.

Purchased this game a few months back and played for 4 hours. Thought it  was neat, but I grew attached to the few people you start with and after they died a few times/i lost a few times it got put on the side for other games.

I got bored 4-5 months later and decided to give it another shot, and maaaaan did I not realize what i'd been missing out on.

Once you realize the vast amount of choices and just how much each action you take affects them it opened up a whole new world for me.

You start with a few people in a dark unforgiving land. You manage them, collect resources, research, craft like crrazy, build and equip and try to survive.

You will lose people, this land loves to make you lose people. Whether it be giants who step on you, goblins you couldn't talk down, hags, bandits....they will die. If you can get past that and play as your village and understand you history will be dark at points it becomes an incredible, amazing story of survival.

I had one group that suffered disaster after disaster (incredible difficulty modification allows for a truly realistic game), but they found a source of elven wood nearby. We slowly built our elven village, but really wanted the mythril that wasn't too far so we could make better equipment. Expedition after expedition failed and we were down to just a few people left, not even enough to safely try again, but elves kept seeing this elven city and appreciating it so much they would join me. In one last brave attempt to get the mythril, the last of the humans perished and I realized I had only elves left. They're a magical race with a high social ability, so my new expeditions of elves were able to banish undead/spirits and talk their way out of danger most times. 

Having this kind of story, while having to break out the pen & paper to manage how to craft their equipment, and a dangerous unforgiving world  holding the materials i need for said equipment. o man, do yourself a favour. Buy this game and give it time to unveil it's magic,

Update - Free DLC (New content plus cooperative--no small task), and quick fixes to outstanding issues. These developers are on point.

23525962.review:
Thea: The Awakening macht viel Spaß.
Anfangs wählt man eine Gottheit aus und je häufiger man als diese eine Gottheit spielt, umso mehr Fähigkeiten schaltet man frei.
Man hat eine Siedlung und schickt ein Expeditionstrupp los, um die Welt zu entdecken und Rohstoffe abzubauen.
Andere Siedler bleiben zu Hause und kümmern sich um Nahrung, Brennstoff und Ausrüstung wie bessere Rüstung oder Waffen.
Die Kämpfe werden als Kartenspiel dargestellt, welches man bei leichten Kämpfen auch überspringen kann. Bei stärkeren Gegnern sollte man der Automatik nicht so vertrauen ;) Außerdem empfiehlt es sich gerade anfangs die Kartenspiele selbst zu spielen, da man so die Auswirkung der verschiedenen Waffen und Rüstungen gut sehen kann.
Während man die Welt immer weiter aufdeckt, findet man Orte an denen die Hintergrundgeschichte erzählt wird. Oftmals muss man bei Dialogen selbst Entscheidungen treffen, die den Ausgang verändern können.
Die eigene Siedlung kann durch Nachwuchs weiter wachsen und durch Zuwanderer - hier kann man auch echt coole Kreaturen erhalten. Da auch die Siedlung angegriffen werden kann, sollte man immer ein paar gute Kämpfer zurücklassen!
Es gibt nur einen Speicherstand, aber wenn man ein Spiel aufgibt erhält man für die Gottheit, die man anfangs wählte, Erfahrungspunkte und schaltet so nette Fähigkeiten und Boni frei.

23457035.review:
Thea combines elements of the turn-based strategy and RPG genres in a refreshing way, without unnecessarily dumbing-down or streamlining.

You start with a town in a fantasy world (inspired by Slavic mythology) displayed in a hex grid, and some units near your starting position. Various resources are indicated by resource icons. Looks like Civilization at first, but Thea is actually quite different:
[list][*]Every unit has a name and its own stats, equipment, class (fighter, hunter, witch, gatherer...) and race (human, goblin, orc, elf, demon...)
[*]You cannot expand your town borders or found another town, instead you create expeditions to either solve quests or gather resources around the map.
[*]Instead of a civilization, you choose a deity that can be leveled up, gives your people bonuses and influences the quest decisions you can make.
[*]The research tree is divided into resources you can gather, items (mostly weapons/armor) you can craft, and various buildings for your town.[/list]

While exploring the world of Thea, you will find enemies and buildings displayed on the map, as well as random encounters.
[list][*]Each encounter is very well-written and illustrated by a skilled narrator.
[*]You usually get to decide to resolve the situation in one of various ways - with magic, fighting, strategy or talking, among others.
[*]The encounters usually lead to a (very fun) card game, but the stats used in each situations are different. Your gatherers might loose a straight battle, but maybe they can convince the opponent to join your town instead?[/list]

I strongly recommend this games to fans of both genres - TBS and RPG gamers alike!

23448686.review:

Even main campaign plot is cool.

Приятный саунд, система крафта и множество игровых событий отлично дополняют этот набор, к тому же в игру введена система, при которой различные игровые ситуации могут решаться не только грубой силой. У игры хорошая реиграбильность: несмотря на то, что за 3 прохождения я испробывал все ветки развития и выполнил основные квесты, я обязательно еще ни раз вернусь к ней. 23335518.review:
An excellent game. There is seriously too much to talk about. So I\'ll try to briefly cover the main parts.

There are a lot of characters, each with unique portrates and all with varying degrees of skill. There are many different types of character: There are at least 5, if not 6 different races. Each race has multiple types of character. For example, humans might have Hunters, Bandits, Workers, Craftsmen, Warriors and Witches/Wise Men whereas goblins might have Boar Riders, Skirmishers, Shamen and so on. You can even recruit some beasts like the ones you commonly fight!

Equipment and Buildings! They work in a similar fasion to the Borderlands games, where each piece of equipment is made up of different parts that affect it\'s final stats. The only thing is that the system is far far simpiler, with only two component pieces per item, one primary and one secondary component. The order of the components changes the weapon too, so the main componant will give the weapon it\'s base stats and its\' appearence while the second would usually impact the general quality of the item and occasionally add a boost to the second component\'s associated skill. The amount of combinations mean that you can find all sorts of varients for just one weapon. 
The weapon stats themselves are very easy to understand but also complex enough for you to really get into designing your whole group. For example, your wise old man isn\'t going to be able to carry much, so while you might be able to make an absolute slab of a sword out of pure moon-stone that would wreck anyone, he probably can\'t lift the damn thing. So you probably want to find some dryad wood, the lightest building material for swords, and craft a less powerful but much lighter sword out of that. 

Auto-resolve: Awwwww, yis. 
I could just leave it like that but for the benefit of those paranoid of the auto-resolve option wiping their best team, I\'ll continue. 

The auto-resolve option the game gives you is actually really fair. For the most part it will make the right call and your overpowered guys will trump the slightly less overpowered enemies. When you first start out and you\'ve got no idea what stats affect what or how to play your cards to win, the auto-resolve function is your best friend. Once you get into the game and you get an idea of what you\'re doing you\'ll want to take the harder battles yourself, but you\'ll still use the auto-resolve function all the time for a number of things. I like to view it as a trust-worthy second in command. I\'m crap at fighting large numbers of enemies. One or two dragons? Easy! Seventeen wolfs, rats, bees or a mixture of the above? I\'m done. Party wiped and pride shattered. However, my trusty second in command is far better at dealing with poor quality, large quantity enemies than I am, so I let him take command for those fights. Usually works out pretty well!
It\'s also great for just skipping any low level enemies that insist on fighting you. 

Story! I\'ll keep this bit short because you can\'t really go into detail without ruining it with spoilers, but the story is excellent. Both for the main campaign, the Giants campaign and for the general random events. The choice system is diverse and rewards you differently but appropriately for the apporaches you chose. You also get different options revealed to you depending on your party. For example, in one case you might be able to use brute strength to carve out some silver from a mine using just the rocks around it, or if you have tools with you then you can do a much easier challenge for the same, or a better, reward. Planning ahead is definitely rewarded and it\'s always good to keep your people well equipped. 

That pretty much rounds up the main parts. There\'s still picking the different Gods to play as, the gathering system, the technology tree, the food and fuel system and many other parts. 

Just get it. Get it and then figure out the rest as you play. It\'ll definitely be worth it!

23221402.review:
문명과 생존성 텍스트 RPG를 묘하게 결합시킨 게임. 문명 3의 모드였던 Fall from heaven 3을 연상시키는 구석이 있다. 하지만 FFH 3이 신화적인 존재들과 영웅들의 전쟁을 통해 전략적 서사시를 지향했다면, 테아는 그보다는 훨씬 소박한 부족민들의 생존과 탐험에 초점을 맞추고 있다. 그렇다 보니 이 게임은 기본적으로 어떤 상황에 직면했을 때 내릴 수 있는 결정, 그리고 그 결정의 결과를 흥미로운 이야기를 통해 체험할 수 있어야 한다. 그러나 안타깝게도 많은 요소들이 그러한 내러티브로의 몰입을 막고 있다.

 우선 가장 거슬리는 점은 게임 세계 내의 난잡한 소재들이다. 우선 슬라브 신화에서 모티프를 얻은 신들, 정령들, 기타 요괴들이 살아가는 험난한 야생의 세계라는 점은 색다르게 느껴진다. 하지만 단지 그것 뿐, 슬라브 신화의 독특한 매력들이 생각보다 잘 전달되도록 짜여있지는 않다. 연출력의 부재라고 할까? 흥미로운 소재들임에도 불구하고 내러티브가 썩 좋지 못하고 그 전달방식도 조악하기 때문에 게임을 어느 정도 진행하다보면 더 이상 이게 슬라브 신화 모티프인지 알 수 없게 되어버린다.

 아마도 우선 가장 큰 문제는 세계관이라고 할 수 있을 듯하다. 처음 보기에는 중앙아시아와 슬라브 민담과 전설, 신화들에서 모티프를 따온 것처럼 보이지만, 사실 조금 하다보면 영 이상한 소재들이 뜬금 없이 튀어나오기 시작한다. 바위에 박힌 저주받은 검을 원하는 왕이라거나, 엘프족이라거나... 이런 것들은 포스트 아포칼립스 판타지 배경에 부합할지는 몰라도, 결과적으로 테아라는 세계가 지닌 고유하고도 독창적인 분위기와 느낌의 총합을 직관적으로 제시하는 데는 오히려 사족이 되는 소재들이다. 결국 하다보면 슬라브 신화라는 모티프는 저 먼 곳으로 사라지고 만다. 그리고 별로 다크 판타지도 아니다. 한 번 멸망한 후의 세계를 재건한다는 설정이라 다크 판타지라고 소개한 듯한데, 실제로 보면 "낯선 세계"라는 설정이지, 별로 어두컴컴하거나 절박하거나 위험한 느낌은 별로 안 든다. 그렇게 느껴지게 만들 만한 소재들이 많이 배치된 것도 아니고.

 그렇게 기본 세계관의 테마와 컨셉트 구현에 너무 많은 사족을 달아서 실패했다면, 최소한 그 모호한 내러티브라도 잘 전달했어야 했다. 하지만 내러티브 전달은 훨씬 조악하기 이를 데 없다. 간단한 삽화와 텍스트로 내러티브를 전달하는 건 좋다. 하지만 텍스트의 분량이 많은 것과, 그 내용이 얼마나 매력적으로 다가오고 선택의 고민과 재미를 주는지는 별개의 문제다. 그런데 테아는 확실히 텍스트 분량은 많을지 몰라도, 그 텍스트가 담고 있는 이야기가 대개의 경우 플레이어에게 매력적으로 다가올 만한 성격의 것들이 아니다. 생존에 치중한 다크 판타지라며? 그런데 정작 하게 되는 내용은 루살카와 사랑에 빠진 드워프의 러브레터를 전해주는 따위다. 이래서는 서사가 킹즈 바운티와 다를 바가 없다. 게다가 많은 선택지는 생존을 위한 고민이나 도덕적 딜레마 따위라기 보다는, 그냥 무작위 뽑기나 도박을 하는 느낌이다. 예를 들어 한 가지 무작위 이벤트에서는 약초가 자라는 장소를 우연히 발견하게 되서 캘지 말지를 결정하는데, 여기서 판단여부를 결정하게 할 지표로 제공되는 단서는 전무하다.  따라서 처음 하는 플레이어는 판단을 위한 전략을 세우거나 인물성에 몰입해서 결정을 내리는 게 아니라, 그냥 "더 캔다"와 "만다"라는 아무 맥락 없는 선택지를 그냥 골라야 하는 것이다. 이 선택에는 어떤 의미도 없고, 추리가 개입될 여지가 없으므로, 잘되든 못되든 그저 "운"으로 여기고 넘어갈 수밖에 없는 성격이 있다. 사실상 빠칭코나 가챠와 다름이 없다.

 게다가 심지어 게임 자체의 내러티브 전달방식은 몰입을 더욱 방해한다. 유니티 엔진의 특성 때문인지는몰라도 일단 어색한 3D 그래픽은 게임을 조잡하게 보이는 데 크게 기여하고 있다. 차라리 깔끔한 2D로 제작했으면 어땠을까 하는 아쉬움이 든다. 또한 친절하게도 모든 텍스트에 나레이션 음성을 넣어줬는데, 아마도 제작자 중 한 명이 직접 녹음을 한 것 같다. 덕분에 음성이 엄청나게 구랴서 몰입을 방해하는 큰 요인이 된다. 연기를 대단히 못하는 TRPG 마스터를 보는 느낌이다. 특히 새된 너드 아저씨 목소리로 소녀나 노파를 연기할 때. 도무지 인물성이 안 살 뿐만 아니라 웃기고 화나기까지 한다. 직접 들어보면 알 수 있을 것이다.

 분노해서 두서없이 글이 길어졌는데, 별로다.

23208265.review:
Amazing game. I can't recall any single disappointment with this title, it delivered everything it promised, and more. Rare occurance nowadays, and I hardly recall anything that caught my attention for so long at a time in single player.

Of course, you have to like this type of game - I don't think it would appeal to just anyone - but in my case it fits perfectly.

What is most amusing in my opinion:

- very well-thought mechanics of conflict resolution, based on cards. I would probably change it a bit in some details (especially in case of constantly fighting very high level monsters, which regularly drastically limit tactical choices exactly just by being high level only), but it is still awesome as it is.
- frequent development, and a lot of changes and new free content
- quick bug fixes (but frankly, I can estimate it mostly by reading dev updates, because I failed to experience any bugs on my own skin ;D)
- slavic mythology;
- a lot of events (some more interesting than the other);
- quite fun crafting mechanics (though, I want even moaarr of that and hope it will be still developed and made even better!)
- It is game under development in very good meaning of this - it is perfectly playable and interesting as it is, but still there are new additions, which makes the fun even better, and urges me to still come back and check on it.

There are a few minor issues:
- late-game it might feel a little bit tedious to manage equipment of like 30-40 characters, running multiple expeditions and actually remember who you are equiping with what, and why you decided it in the first place ;)
- I do not understand balancing of events occurance chance - some seem to occur to often. While I played some games more than 1000 days, and still took only 24% of events which I experienced - in the same time, and a few events were generated literally more than dozen times, sometimes even close to each other.
- a pity that level up bonuses seem to be totally random, i'd prefer some choices in that departyment;
- when limiting active party fight team up to 12 characters in conflict, you should be able to manually pick those who fight or don't fight, in case your party is much bigger
- personally, I would prefer a little more serious language and feel of stories, now it is in many instances a little too humorous fantasy for my taste. That is pure taste issue, though.
- I personally would add tooltips on reasearching resources/weapon, to know up front what exactly I am buying (like - of, great, I can gather the best type of something now, but then I discover, that it has really, really limited use for me, as I cannot use it to build something I thought I could.
and...

But ok, I am critical by nature, and I could find many, many more issues I consider worth reworking :), but in the end all that matters is that they are mostly VERY minor, and mostly opinion/taste-based. Whole feel of the game is very positive, and I like it very, very much.

It has a soul, kudos to devs, they showed real love and passion for gaming, creating this. Money well spent.

23201931.review: It takes a while to get into, but once you do, you realize either how deep the game is. The random events (there are many) keep the grinding aspect of the game interesting. As you progress, the baddies get tougher, which keeps the unique combat system interesting. Although, once you start traveling in huge raiding parties, you can just auto-combat most of the battles in the late stages of the game (which is fine by me). Overall, I've been pleased with Thea. I must admit, within the first couple of hours, I was a bit put off by the game. Not sure why, just was. But give it time. It will get addicting. You won't be able to level everything up right away (if at all), which makes for some interesting choices in terms of how you have to respond to you randomly generated map. Also, I'm only on the first diety after 22 hours. I'm not sure what lies ahead, but have enjoyed the game so far. Oh, did I mention that they have tools available for you to add your own events? I haven't played around with it much yet, but it should allow for more and interesting new content from the community. The sound design is pretty good (I have some of the tunes stuck in my head. They're catchy) and the artwork is excellent. Last note: while I do applaud the use of VO (and the guy does a pretty good job given the large amount of text there is, it would be nice to hear a few different voices). Small quibble though. Overall, I felt that Thea was definitely worth the 20 bucks I spent.

22949949.review:
Amazed at how this game continues growing since the release. Dev support is phenomenal. Every time I come back to this game, there's more to it, and the balance is better, and there's new UI features that add quality-of-life.

This game's got a nebulous genre identity, but at the core, I'd say the gameplay is a 4x resource management experience comparable to Endless Legend, This game has the explore, exploit, exterminate, no expanding, but for the lack of that, there's RPG pieces, roguelike pieces...

Gameplay is really deep, and by that I don't just mean "complicated." Yes its complicated to understand it at all and make it all work in your favor, but even more than that, the ability to fine tune difficulty to one's liking really lets a player poke and prod the various systems of the game to their heart's content. A lot of times "roguelike" or "roguelike elements" generally means that a game is going to be too hard and offer no apology, but the challenge in Thea can be dropped to nothing or ramped to impossible.

Even after the event sequences are memorized (and btw they've added more) the game remains interesting, simply because an instance of Thea has so many dynamic elements moving at once. The world maps feel alive.

Given the number of elements going on, there's a learning curve. Some players may feel adverse to things like the card battles, I did at first, and some may judge it for how they feel about the card battles after a few hours and throw it away. For me though, I feel like they'd be missing a great deal of what the game has.

Being the original indie material that this game is, it's really a diamond in the rough.

22908484.review:
Thea hat sich zu meinem absoluten Lieblingsspiel entwickelt. Ich besitze das Spiel seit Dezember, ursprünglich noch in Englisch. Mit dem kostenlosen, nachgeschobenen DLC wurde das Spiel komplett und sehr gut übersetzt, weswegen ich nun auch für jene, die dem Englischen nicht mächtig sind eine volle Kaufempfehlung ausspreche.

Das Spiel ist ein Rundenbasiertes Strategie-Überlebensspiel. Persönlich  begeistert mich aber die Komplexität, die dahinter steckt und die liebevolle Geschichte, die oft auch mit einer guten Portion Humor den Spielspaß weit oben hält. 
Die zahlreichen Fähigkeiten, die unsere Dorfbewohner besitzen können eröffnen immer wieder neue Gesprächsmöglichkeiten oder Handlungsansätze, und auch wenn man nach einer Zeit alle Ereignisse zu kennen meint, es gibt immer wieder eine kleine Überraschung. 

Auch ist es schön regelmäßig von den Entwicklern zu lesen, die in diesem halben Jahr wirklich ordentlich am Spiel geschraubt haben und sehr bemüht waren, Fehler und Unausgewogenheiten zu glätten. 
Mit dem neuen DLC wurde das Spiel nochmal ein wenig umgekrempelt (Und interessanter!).  Brauchten wir vorher für jeden Rescource nur 1 Forschungspunkt um sie freizuschalten, sind es nun 1-3, je nach der Seltenheit und Macht des Materials. Das kann völlig neue Wege eröffnen, da man, um z.B. Forschungspunkte sparsam einzusetzen, auf niedrigstufige Materialien oder sonst unangetastete Baustoffe zurückgreifen kann. Es lud auf jeden Fall dazu ein, neues auszuprobieren!

Der Schwierigkeitsgrad ist komplett beeinflussbar und reicht von 85% (..glaube ich) bis 250% - spätestens ab 150% spürt man, wie das Spiel sich einem mit einer feindseeligen Umgebung entgegenschmeißt. 

[h1]Klare Empfehlung. Volle Punktzahl von mir![/h1]

22877337.review:
Wow... The devs put a LOT of effort into this game, and it really pays off.

Gameplay overview: Hex based fantasy world based on Slavic mythology. You have a village and some people (who can either stay in the village and craft/build things or roam the world gathering materials, fighting monsters, solving puzzles, and completing quests. Bring back resources to craft more buildings and items to help you out. See how long you can survive in the darkness that has fallen over the world... or complete one of the many endings! (PS you can keep playing after an ending too)

As you wander around, there are many events to encounter (or have occur to you or your village). Combat is a card battle game based on your party's equipment and skills. Crafting is fairly deep with many variations of each item or building. At first glance, the game seems a little bland... but shortly after, you will realise just how deep it gets. You will want to keep exploring the magical world, seeing what comes next and building up your party with all manner of people and creatures!

Worth full price before, even more so with the DLC

22823204.review: Thea is a very good game. Its 4X fantasy game set in Slavic mythology. You play the role of a Slavic god guiding a few of the remaining humans in an attempt to restore your power. Researching opens the ability to farm resources which leads to the crafting of better items and weapons. Your town grows randomly, either by children growing into adults, visitors wanting to join your village, or sometimes, just because you rescued someone during an event. Not just humans either, you can get goblins, dwarves, even ghosts and demons! You expand by sending your people out on expeditions that can encounter events, complete quests, or simply gather resources for your next best weapon. My current game I have 5 expeditions now with a dozen peeps in each, all exploring and conquering different areas of the map. The exterminate part is a card game: its a brilliant, original idea. In fact, there are many different types of card games, not just combat, but also magic, hunting, sneaking, diplomacy to name some - and you can auto-resolve. There are many quests that you can follow, or choose to ignore if you want. The events add a role playing aspect to the game - and they are narrated. There is a nice event editor that MUHA provided graciously for free. The devs are very active in responding to emails and fixing bugs. One bug I reported, they fixed and I had the patch within an hour on a Saturday. They are also very willing to discuss enhancements to make their game better. I have spent 162 hours in game and counting. Its not getting old. And a really cool part is it doesnt matter if you win or loose your current game: when the game completes, it adds all the experience to a running total, which increases your ability as a Slavic god. I've played several games now and Veles (the god I have played in the previous game) is up to level 3 - as an example. There are several other gods to choose from, each with their own bonuses, and you can swap between them as much as you want. Its a really cool, inventive approach to a game. Very original. I'd love to see a similar space 4x game.

22819721.review: Really enjoying the game thus far. Only thing i hope they can add is like a family lineage type of thing or something. I get pretty attached to some of my characters as is, but if my characters could have sons/daughters i would be even more invested into each game.

22802326.review:
Well worth the full price.

The game mechanic focuses strongly on crafting and resource locating and gathering.  For example, units can gather resources more quickly if they have baskets, but to build baskets might require a material you don't see on the map.  So there's some frustration to try to find that resource.

Sending expeditions into the wild, they will encounter fights with the local wildlife and a cardgame creates a 1 dimensional (line) battle that becomes the majority of gameplay.  The fights are more interesting than I expected.  Units can be equipped with armor/weapons found in the field or crafted, and where the strongest units are placed can allow meat shielding with weaker units to allow a stronger unit to survive longer.

There are variations on the standard "fight" card battles.  I just did a "everyone has a hangover from drinking too much alcohol, so they must all fight the hangover" battle!  Significant effort went into making about a dozen or so different forms of battles - so it's not all armor and dexterity and strength.  It throws enough of a twist into the game to keep it very fresh and foreign to RPG players.

Add to all that some very good dramatic opening stories and quests generated on the map or in towns, and the gameplay has wide variation that doesn't stagnate.

The stories are well written and engaging.  The stories provide multiple choice dialog but they are still very short.  That quality starts to push this game into the educational domain - the concepts provided in the stories are ethical, and provide good food for thought.  So far all the writing I've encountered has been uplifting.

It's almost like the game is a "choose your own adventure" story, stretched out with challenging gameplay. I _always_ leave that one character trapped, but I wonder how it would play out if I freed them instead.  There are plenty of "make a deal with the devil" scenarios.

The voice acting is really good with one small exception.  I notice good voice acting, and even more so bad voice acting, and this game gets it right for the most part.

Don't be fooled by the review or even the videos.  This is a Grand strategy 4x experience.

My main complaint WAS the lack of multiple save-files - but that has been fixed - with a small penalty of changing your game difficulty rating if you choose to save files!  Hahaha! :)

There is some tedium of micromanagement around 100 turns in, clicking the same stuff over and over every single turn or so.  They've helped that out a little, with craft batching which turns the crafting system into a cottage industry system, but other places in the game are still horrendous click-fests, the worst being army equipment management.  Yes you will spend hours upon hours dragging items around, in mind-numbing tedium to optimize each little character.  But hey -- you asked for it!  Just drop the difficulty down a bit if this is so unbearable.  It's your choice.

------

Addendum

If all that isn't enough, there is a node-based adventure editor which allows creating your own storylines.  You could potentially add a whole many-hours-long game this way, or you can modify the vanilla game or DLCs as you like to even increase or decrease the game difficulty to be as brutal or generous as you like!

See the Event Edittor thread in the discussions, which ultimately leads to the developer's forum here:
http://muhagames.com/theaevents/viewforum.php?f=2

22790176.review:
Fantastic little gem. Simple concept polished to a shine, updates are frequently every other day, bug-fixes are extremely quick, and the devs have released updates on Sunday more than once. :)

New features include:

- as you explore the map, you can see unresearched resources that are next in line in your gathering tree BEFORE you've researched them, leading to more diversity in resources you use as you might unlock and use resources that are closer to your town rather than more powerful resources that are far away and thus inaccessible except for late game.

- a new quality system, with three levels of quality: good, standard and bad. Good quality items are unlocked by having at least one blacksmith made from any resources, so it is often good to unlock and build the blacksmith early, even if it's just made from wood, and then upgrade it later for a higher crafting skill bonus.

- standard quality is the regular item as all items used to be before the quality system.

- a good quality item has 120% (20% more) of the standard quality's numerical stat values, rounded to the nearest whole number, and also weighs less.  You can increase the chance of crafting a good quality item (after passing the low quality check, which is easier with higher craft skill) by using a better catalyst, up to a maximum of 15%.

- a bad quality item, chance of crafting these is minimized by having a high crafting skill on your lead crafter when the product is finished (minimum chance of crafting bad quality is 1%), has 70% (30% less) of the standard quality's numerical stat values, rounded to the nearest whole number, and also weighs more.  However for items that have standard quality giving +1 to stat/s, there is no difference apart from weight and the "Bad Quality" tag.

- loot can also have good, standard and bad quality too, making it actually useful when you get good quality items, though bad quality loot items, like bad quality items you craft, still often get dismantled for resources (but check, it may be that apart from a weight difference it still provides all or much the same stats if the standard quality only gives minor stat bonuses).

- new Bloodbath mode, worth an extra 50% difficulty (new maximum 350%) where if your units get overkilled (take more damage than they have health) they can be at extra chance of dying by having received more wounds than health from fight challenges (overkill is prevented when Bloodbath is off, although there are other ways in the normal game to have more wounds than health).

So if your rat or low health unit gets whacked for 60 damage, it's not going to come back unless you can reach and fulfill the requirements for the Herbalist Hut wound healing that same turn, or are lucky enough to get a wound healing event that same turn. :)

- and of course the new Giants content, which includes many new non-Giants themed random events. There are now so many random events that every game is truly different, and even with frequently appearing events (such as the herb-picking spider nest encounter), different resources are given as rewards each time, making a big difference in what you craft on higher difficulties.

This new content also includes full English voiceovers and text localization into French, German, Polish and Russian with the ability to create custom text localizations as well.  The voiceovers and text localization are for the whole game, not just the new stuff.

- that's not to mention the event editor, which allows users to create their own events and share them with others on MuHa Games' website. The editor is powerful and great tutorials and support are provided. This will be fantastic for the longetivity of Thea, even without new stuff added by the devs.

Best $20 I've ever spent. The devs are in my opinion the most competent, hard-working and responsive devs I have EVER met, and they're extremely friendly and consider community members frequently, and fit things into the game with all of their love of their baby, Thea: The Awakening. :)

22774638.review:
Great game! It surpassed all my expectations...Recommended for Civilization fans especially.

+ Slavic mythology. I was so bored already with Greek/Egyptian mythology in all the games. Finally something new! 
+ Very responsive and proactive developers (...they just released a free DLC!)
+ Love the part where you are exploring the map finding different resources (it is like in Civilization)
+ Crafting system. Quite deep, lot of options.
+ Interesting combat system. All the combat/challenges are resolved through a card game. 
+ Random events. Huge number of random events occurring = Endless re-playability
+ Gods. When you start the game you have to choose a God (it is like choosing a faction or race in other strategic games). The more you play the more abilities you unlock for your Gods (they become stronger). 
+ Permadeath (this might not be positive for everyone). If one of your villagers get killed they stay dead.  

I cant really think of any negative side in this game. Maybe I would just say, that if you like visuals in a game you might be disappointed because of the Card game element in the game. There are no animations... It is also quite time consuming like turn based games usually are.

Overall rating 9.5/10 

Buy it now! ;-)

22770148.review:
I reccomend this game, but not if you are looking for 30+ hours of gameplay out of it. It is absolutely excellent, a refreshingly new entry to the 4X (3X?) genre. It's not like anything you've ever played before, it's a genre hybrid between a large-party questing RPG, a card-battle game and a 4X strategy sim; very cool. I would reccomend anyone buy it for that reason.

The voice acting is spectacular as well! It really emerses you in the game; it feels like a dungeon master. 

Alas, each new game is the same quests (though you can make different choices). With a very simple tech tree and limited class choices, you will play nearly the same game on each playthrough. Yes you unlock "Gods" but this is like unlocking a new Civ Team... Not particularly exciting enough to justify an additional playthrough if the map and enemy teams and quests were all identical. 

All said, if you don't mind spending $20 for 20-30 hours of play like me - I can't reccomend it enough!

22663180.review:
Okay so I could write a review like: slavic mythology and piroggi for lunch 10/10! But that is really not a sufficient review so let me explain a bit why I enjoy the game and recommend it.

Positive:
[list]
[*] I don't know many games (in fact none) that is focused on the slavic mythology with its pantheon and dark creatures and in my opinion it is lovely adapted into this game
[*] The story makes sense and although not perfectly explaining everything still combines the gameplay with the characters etc.
[*] Things can turn pretty bad quickly for you if you are not careful in how you proceed. E.g. if you just go out carelessly and leave only farmers and craftsmen in your village then they might die when the village is attacked  but on the other hand you HAVE TO move out to find new resources, food or items.
[*] I like the pictures made for the characters and monsters but also for the items. You can see a lot of love for the game and the details there.
[*] That is also true for the lore they wrote and the texts they wrote. You learn a lot about different creatures in the world and you can decide for yourself if you would like to negotiate with Orcs or if you just try to smash their skulls. 
[*] You have a big variety of food and items you can craft. Of course they have different values and there are probably only few items if you want to have maximum effect (important for the combat stats) but I just love the fact that I can cook and roast not only the mentioned Piroggi but also Leczno, Roastbeef, cooked vegetables, cooked fish, rabbit stew and a lot more (there are 3 ways how to prepare your food namely cooking, roasting and baking and I already have ~15 recipies without the baking I think). Also you have to find out what ingredients have what effect for the item. Yesterday I sat there 5 minutes just trying to find the best values between armor and a +stat for my new armor with what I currently have in stock thinking back and forth.
[*] Personally I like the combat system because it is something different (you place your characters as cards, depending on their items and stats they will have different use in the fight) and you will have to think about your turn and what you want to do always with the risk of losing one or more of your important people.
[*] Even though the setting is dark and it is a hard game at times, you will still find little jokes or funny things in the game making you smile.
[*] The replayability is high because you can unlock new abilities of your chosen god as well as unlock other gods of the pantheon for your next game. Each god has other strong points so it should change the difficulty and the way you play. I also think some quests change depending on your god (can't say that for sure as I am still in my first play-through)
[/list]

Negative:
[list]
[*] Sometimes the game can be too hard because if you lose people in the beginning it will be tough to impossible to survive long enough. Later on after you have a critical mass of people you can afford to lose one or two. It'll set you back but you will survive. On the other hand thats why it calls itself a survival game as well I guess. And there is always the possibility to reload the save game.
[*] Sometimes the combats can be a bit unfair as the fact if your "cards" are in the combat stack or the support (tactical) stack is based on chance just like the type of weapon of the enemy cards. It can be a big difference if they have big cards with just "sword damage" or if they have blunt or piercing weapon effects. 
[*] I am not sure if it is planned to add more villages in the future  but so far you only have one village and you can't create more as the game progresses. Even though it is a post-apocalyptic setting (middle age style) I think it would be nice if there were other villages (blessed by the other gods e.g.) or if you could at least establish new ones later on.
[/list]

Overall I think it is a great game with a lot of love. So far I played around 30 hours and I am still playing my first play-through. Also I am certain that after that there will be another one with a different god. Also important to note is that there are still things being added (like the free dlc Return of the Giants) and bugs being fixed. But even in its current state the game is worth its 20€. the only thing you should ask yourself beforehand is: Is this the type of game I like where your decisions count and influence your progression? Maybe also watch a Let's Play before you buy it but if you are still interested afterwards you will have a game in which you can sink hours and hours. So far I had no crashes or progression stopping bugs. Maybe a spelling error once but thats about all I experienced so far.

22651177.review:
OH, I love this game! 

This game has all that I have been looking for in a game recently: Crafting is rather deep, important and meaningful, the quests are well-written, exciting and fun, exploration is cool, the resource management is complex and keeps you interested, the survival elements are quite entertaining while not being too hard, AND it is turn-based (and it is turn-based in a very addictive and exciting way)! 

It even has a great atmosphere with awesome shifts between day and night cycles and a good story in a post-apocalyptic fantasy setting. The card game first looked a little weird, but after learning it, I must say that it actually works incredibly well for fighting tactical battles that are both engaging, quite tactical and exciting, but still rather quick and not too hard to understand. I have never chosen the auto-play option for the fighting, since this fight mechanic keeps me interested and entertained. And, since it is each party member who are represented by a card, and the card abilities and stats change as your people level up and get better gear, it actually adds to the immersion and feels very much alive and real. You will learn to love each and every one of your survivors, and their unique abilities, and you will be overwhelmed by sorrow if they die (and they will on occasion die - from wounds, sickness or curses). 

Thea: The Awakening is sometimes said to be a 4X game, but technically it is 3X - as it actually lacks the eXpand part. This lack of eXpand is actually really cool and one of the things I love the most about this game! It really makes the gameplay very different from other games in this genre, since having only one single city forces you to travel far off with expeditions that need to be well equipped, carry enough food and wood (for keeping camp-fires burning), and needing to be well-balanced with different traits and abilities to perform well and survive. This adds to immersion and survival themes, and it also avoids the micromanagement overload that you get in mid- to late-game in other games such as Civilization V, since you only have this one city to attend to thoughout the game. 

The other X'es are well done: you eXterminate a lot of different kinds of monsters, and having no other factions is also a welcome difference and change from other games, since it makes this game stand out as one of a kind. The eXploration is exciting, with lots of different resources, locations, monster nests and quest givers to be found, and you must always attend to your expeditions food and firewood levels, their equipment, abilities and health to assure they will safely return home from one more travel. The eXploit part is also really well done, as you must travel to places where the resources needed to craft different objects can be found, set up a camp and harvest resources, while defending the attacks of marrouding monsters. So all of the 3 X'es are well done. 

All of the above are pro's for this game, but there are a few con's, too. The first being that since you only get one city, starting resources in that city is important, and while it seems you always get firewood and one food source, I have sometimes gotten 1 or 2 bonus resources inside the city radius that makes early game easier - and this encourages re-spawning the world at least 5-8 times when starting a new game, to get a decent start location (but, I must admit I have used even more time doing this in both Civilization V and Endless Legend before). The second problem is that at present you cannot make any sort of seafaring vessel, and I miss being able to travel the rivers and lakes/oceans by boat. The third problem is that they made unlocking new deities to play with ridiculously slow, but I guess this will be tweaked prior to release. The fourth problem is that I miss some more buildings, and even some more equipment and stuff to research and craft (there is a decent amount of both buildings and craftable stuff, but I still want more!). But, I am guessing that some of these problems will be addressed by the dev team prior to release, as the dev team seems very professional and dedicated, they update the game regularly, and from what I have seen so far they will manage to improve this great game even more before it is finished. 

Conclusion: 9 out of 10. I am loving it!

22600077.review:
Every part of the game has enough depth to keep the entire experience rewarding accross multiple play throughs. Even after multiple attempts and a successful completetion of the campaign (with a rouge-like level of difficulty and permanence, it will take several attempts) I still feel like there is more to explore: different combinations of technologies, buildiings and combat.

It feels very much like the beggining of a game of civilization, with high risk high reward exploration mechanics. You will want to push for more, stronger resources, but in doing so you risk your units that have taken time to develop and equip. This encourages a purpetual opprotunity-cost analysis and makes success feel very rewarding.

Good Game, worth trying if only to see how it shakes up the turn based civilization building stategy genre a bit with some influence of rpgs and rouge likes.

22598561.review:
Awesome game that is quite the underdog here on Steam. I think this game should be much higher on the charts.

The game offers great replayability with its new map each time you play on top of you being able to set the difficulty of the game via several choices prior to launching a new game.
You have several gods to play, only a few at first but they unlock as you play more and more.
In the game you can craft items just like you want according to the resources you have at hand. There are no limits to the amount of people you can have in your community (had like 48 individuals in my last game at the end).
There are several ways to end the game, especially with the super hot update they have added lately. The giants are deadly, stay away from them unless you want to die or you have a party of at least 16 individuals with excellent gear and with an average level of 6 or higher.
The update also diversified the graphics, especially in the items department. This is superficial as graphics are not the drive of this game, it is the high replayability, but who would complain having a better looking game in the end?

Great game, to buy even at full price. Good lot of stuff in the game, and the designers seems to be interested in adding even more stuff... and if you try the game you'll realize that it has an almost infinite possibilities for expansions and big updates that adds things.

Oh! Did I mention that the game's universe is quite detailed and has good background. Most of it is read by a man, especially the important encounters and stories.

Three Thumbs up! I think this game will be as good as Heroes of Might & Magic III if they continue to develop it even though it is not quite the same genre (turn-based and random maps yes, but those are the only similarities.).

22586411.review:
This one rocks! 

Civ meets Neo Scavenger with it's exploration, random events and an intricate crafting system. I totally recommend this  game. At first I was somehow unsure about the card combat system, but it can be actually very tricky at first. Do yourself a favour and give it a shot.

22582292.review:
Игра затягивающая, интересная, бурлящая событиями и в связи с последними обновлениями еще частично редактируемая! (да добавили редактор случаев, теперь можно как и усложнить игру, так и облегчить, слегка посидев и поделав так дабы навыки ваших жителей летели со скоростью молнии Перуна!) 

Плюсы:
+ Игра обладает своей атмосферой , чем то можно отнести её к некому пост апокалипсису (в том мире примерно то и случилось) 
+Русифицировали , это однозначный плюс для большего населения, т.к тут много диалогов, решений и читать приходится часто. 
+ совмещения игр. Как большая часть народа хочет выживания тут добавлена эта возможность. Экономический план этой игры так же затрагивается сполна ,а выбора, отдать детей ведьме дабы получить защиту демонов, или убить существ и наслать на себя проклятий так же вам решать. 

Чего бы хотелось увидеть:
   Мультиплеер. 
Да было бы интересно увидеть как две (или больше) деревушек развиваются, борятся за выживание на этой земле, торгуют друг с другом или же наооборот , истребляют друг друга за прославления своего бога! 
   Большее разнообразие. 
Как ни странно, хоть и игра очень и очень напичкана разными событиями и ответвлениями от глав сюжета, он у всех богов един, и выбор различается лишь в действиях игрока. Было бы интереснее что например бог тьмы не мог бы посадить семя древа дабы все его черные твари опять сгинули в лету, или же наоборот ,бог света уничтожить. Так же хоть и игра растянута на много много часов игры ( в плане того что чтоб выполнить все на максимальном уровне понадобится довольно много времени), она будет поднадоедать тем что утром -бегаем ищем ресурсы, разведываем территории, выполняем задания, а ночью сидим у костра и добываем важные вещи, и ждем пока монстры перестанут вас атаковать, после 150-200 хода игра будет некой рутиной, от чего её лишь будут разбавлять случайные события , которые заставляют тебя в неё играть и думать. "что произойдет в следующий ход\шаг\секунду!" 

Вывод. 
Игра заслуживает своих денег, а тот факт что разработчики её не забросили добавляет ей дополнительного уважения! Надеюсь что все же со временем они добавят больше интересных событий, разнообразия и возможно даже богов других цивилизаций!

22543163.review:
This game was almost right up there with Civ.  I absolutely loved the card combat.  I was actually enjoying the card battles more than the rest of the game.  The terrain and world graphics were good for what the game is.  

The story is fun for the first play through, but after a few games, it is boring.  The research / tech tree is stupid.  It isn't confusing or long winded, it is just...pointless.  After you get a decent sized war party, you just smash your way through everything the game can throw at you.  Research points just roll in and you just unlock stuff you already have, or unlock resources that are way too far from home to be worth retrieving.

Pros: Card battles are a blast

Cons: Can't build more towns, you are stuck in one city challenge mode.  Getting new people is completely random.  Getting classes you actually want is a pain in the butt.  Game gets really boring after your first couple of play throughs.

22537263.review: It is amazing game. Thank a lot.

22536224.review: At first it seems like a simplified Civ game. Then it feels like a kinda ugly survival game. Finally it reveals its inner complexity so deceptively hidden and blossoms into the impossible to pigeon hole wonder that it is. Give it a chance really it just gets cooler and cooler. Hint: don't be a dick to every living thing but don't be a push over either. Slavic demons aren't Christian demons, they can be pretty cool dudes.

22532484.review:
A week ago I'd have said I loved this game. A complex, unusual, deeply themed strategy game with a surprisingly subtle card combat. Most importantly, a wide range of difficulties that actually mean something: a new player on Easy can probably win unspoiled. A modestly experienced player at 150% will be challenged. Anybody playing at 300% is going to have to sweat every single move.

But the developers listened to their hardcore players too much. The April update totally upended the difficulty curve. New player who hasn't figured out how to win by turn 200? Die. Skilled player playing casually who hasn't won by turn 200? Die. Player playing at the limits of your skill who can't win by turn 200? Die.

The hardcore player's fun is not every player's fun, and game developers who think so are deluded.

22529365.review:
A sophisticated, deep, and thoroughly enjoyable 4X hybrid.

The learning curve is steep, the tutorial meh. Thankfully, the game itself is fantastic, but only after you get your head around the slightly left-of-centre gameplay and learn to navigate the clunky UI. Highly recommended, especially for jaded strategy players who are looking for something a little unusual to occupy their time.

22526289.review:
Amazing game.  Good tutorials, tons of replay value.  Very skill based and a good difficulty scale to use as you get better.  The only two complaints:

1. UI needs work.  I need to be able to sort and filter my characters and items better than the current system.  Sometimes I spend 20 mins just re-distrubuting my items to my characters when it could have taken less than 5 with a better sorting system.
2. Game kills your children too easily.  Some events literally just say "Oops, 4 of your kids died".  No skills involved, no card game to play.  They are just dead.  Game seems to do this more often when you have lots of kids.  Don't get me wrong, I love how the random events keep you on your toes.  But no even should say "X is now dead" without you getting a chance to make decisions/fight for them.

Minor annoyence: Game often quits taking itself seriously and throws in too much modren day humor.  I like the imersion Thea brings, I don't see the point in breaking it so often.

Otherwise no complaints.  It's in a genre all on it's own and it's fantastic.

22519729.review:
Very nice game. Combines elements of survival, crafting, strategy AND has a nice story behind. After release of the first DLC and a patch became slightly better, I noticed several visual changes plus new tracks in the soundtrack.

NOTE: it is NOT typical 4x strategy!

22512894.review: Прекрасная музыка, красивая графика, фольклор равный Ведьмаку... Вроде как скучноватое начало, втягивает в процесс игры, работают все части мозга- скучать уже на 5м ходу не хочется абсолютно. Врядли разработчики работали только ради денег-добро и качество видно и чувствуется. Жду DLC , второй части.... Уже :)

22502419.review:

22494228.review:
Good new and Finally. 

Спасибо большое разработчикам за то, что добавили язык и поддержку. Движок unity лично мною нелюбимый, но зато этот движок позволяет реализовать идеи, которые у других вызывают трудности и сложности по сравнению с другими движкам.

Хорошая работа.

22465189.review:
Вот теперь, после добавления Rus локализации, можно запилить небольшой обзорчик. Игра, ух давненко я так не погружался в игровой мир.  Всё красиво для своего уровня игры и очевидно уровня финансирования. Лагов не замечено, вылетов так же. Музыка весьма тематичная и приятная. Главное громко не делать. В лёгком фоне просто прелесть. 
По самой игре можно много чего сказать и в основном положительное, но лучше попробывать самим. Лишь бы не забросили проект. 
Тематика игры - квестовая рпг с небольшим олдскулом (как только запустил игру, сразу вспомнил про втророй Diablo и в 2000 годах была схожая рпг только без карточных боёвок на тему старой руси. Как называлась уже и не вспомню (из прошлого приходит только память на три разные деревни в начале игры и фраза "Чего изволите, княже?") Так вот тематика игры хороша и не излизана конвеерными играми. Это жирнющий плюс!!! Как было заявлено - игра в стиле мифологии. Суть выдержали, а вот наполнение всё в кучу. Может быть со временем что-то и подпрявят. Но это если захотеть к чему-то придраться, то...
Добыча ресурсов - хорошо (и главнео мнооооого разных)
Крафт - менее разнообразен, но весьма вариативен в пределах конкретных построек из разных ресов.
Боёвка - по началу кажется замороченной и не понятной, но это вопрос пары десятков боёв, дальше не сложнее тетриса в понимании.
Квестов множество любых и разных. Суть у них в основном не блещет оригинальностью (дай,подай, уходи не мешай), но текстовый контент квестов весьма наполненный и порой устаёшь читать (кстате по началу интересно) в поледующих играх уже не очень, т.к. квесты меняются только по очерёдности и во времени, наполнение и последовательность одна и та же.

Не совсем понятен баланс игры на высоких уровнях сложности, вроде всё играбельно, но в некоторых моментах наступает сразу же тотальных и полный бздец за несколько ходов при чём по 100% инициативе компьютера. Как пример, 171 ход бегал, копил, воевал, делал квесты и не трогал лишь мобов от 3 черепушек (видел крайне редко, может 2-3 раза  за игру, выше не видел (видимо 171 ход - это мало), так вот, как только решил построить предтоповый вариант строения единственный за всё это время игры, засел в городе всеми своими 9-тью персами и начал ждать постройки 15 ходов (персы кстате сказать были неплохо прокачены и экипированы), всего лишь за два хода к моей деревни сбежалось 9 отрядов мобов по 2-3 черепа и сменяя одна пачка другую выкосили всех жителей. Я за всю игру столько мобов в одном месте не видел (ну бывало по два, три набега за ночь и то не страшные и типовые) а за время осады города я увидел наверное большую часть двух черепковых и трёх черепковых мобов. Короче удивлён, заинтригован и сижу думаю как строить стратегию развития при таких делах)))) 

В общем много букв, итог один - КЛАССНО!!! Одназначно в копилку.

P.s. кстате сказать, это не чистый выживатель, игра имеет свой фишин по ряду показателей, выполненный глобальный квест, по кол-ву жителей, по убийству сильнейших мобов и что-то там ещё. Так что затянуть одну игру до пенсии не получится, ну если конечно совсем ничего не делать в игре, то можно))))

22432036.review:
Спасибо за помощь IMPERATOR DORAN  
Скачай бесплатное ДЛС.Русский язык теперь есть. В главном меню, в правом нижнем углу есть флажок, кликаете на него и выбираете язык игры.

**Игра довольно интересная. 
Thea: The Awakening:выживание, текстовые квесты, карточные  бои, пошаговый режим.
 Мы являемся богом, ослабленным и павшим на землю. Настают темные времена,  чтобы выжить, мы управляем горсткой верующих еще в наше могущество людей. Основав деревню, нам требуется добывать жизненно необходимые ресурсы (еду, топливо) с развитием технологий в деревне появляются новые ресурсы, с помощью которых можно делать оружия, броню, новые строения, инструменты для добычи, создания новых строений.
 
Через некоторое количество ходов происходят события, решить мы их можем несколькими вариантами у каждого варианта есть свои последствия или вознаграждения.
Бои проходят в своеобразном карточном режиме. Картами в колоде являются люди, которые находятся с вами при обнаружении события. Каждый человек имеет свой класс. 
Основное направления классов: Воин, Собиратель, Мастерство (изобретатель-строитель).
Каждого жителя можно снабдить экипировкой. Экипировка даёт бонус к добычи, боям, или вариантам решения текстовых квестов.
От создателей хотелось бы, чтобы они доработали интерфейс. Во вкладке работа не видно профессии. Приходится по портрету назначать собирателя.

22431909.review:
如果尋求一款結合營地建設、探索、採集的策略遊戲，Thea正是你的好選擇。

雖然一開始挫折感滿重的，因為它類似聖火系列，你的隊伍跟村民是脆弱的，很容易一不小心讓辛苦栽培的士兵死去，
但隨著資源不斷擴大，後期的成就感是十分強大的。

他的戰鬥系統為獨特的卡牌模式，你不見得需要跟敵人硬碰硬，透過隊伍屬性可以用其他對戰模式，避免傷亡並贏得勝利。

另外促使我上來分享的是~免費且十分有誠意的DLC，
除了增加相關要素及任務外，最有感是程式的優化。更新後真的順超～～多!
加上更新後全語音任務，整個誠意滿點。

誠如其他玩家所評，唯一缺點就是一輪的時間較長，及神滿等後無新增要素(此次更新後尚未知有新破關要素)
有任何問題可互相交流，謝謝！

22430212.review:
hab mir thea im sale gekauft, wenn ich mich recht erinnere für 14,99€ 
hierfür bekommt man ein spiel mit einer grandiosen idee, hinter der sich eine gute umsetzung verbirgt

heute ist das erste dlc herausgekommen (gratis), mit der thea nun auch komplett deutsch ist, bei mir wird das dlc noch heruntergeladen, sollte die übersetzung so schlecht sein, dass es wert ist die review umzuschreiben werde ich das anfügen

mit englisch kentnissen machte das spiel aber bereits sehr viel spaß und ich empfehle auf jedenfall bei entsprechenden kentnissen erstmal auf englisch zu spielen, weil es wie in fast allen spielen, humor und tiefe besser rüberbringt

zum spiel selber, die welt wurde bestraft wodurch nurnoch wenige menschen übrig sind, man selber steuert dann ein gläubiges dorf mit einigen einwohnern, das versucht das böse zu besiegen und den menschen eine neue chance zu geben
hierzu muss man verschiedene ressourcen sammeln, die natürlich auch verschiedene effekte mit sich bringen (seltene materialien sind natürlich besser, verschiedene nahrung zu haben gibt den menschen boni usw.)
hierbei gibt es ein ausführliches crafting bei dem man verschiedene gebäude waffen rüstungen und co bauen kann

das kampfsystem läuft wie ein kartenspiel ab, jede person hat unterschiedliche skills die sich bei level ups entwickeln (hier gibt es zum beispiel krieger, ärzte, jäger, sammler usw.) 
je nachdem was man nun machen will, kommen diese skills zum einsatz, ob man nun eine gruppe skelette im kampf auf leben und tod stellt, oder sie jagt, oder einen hinterlistigen angriff macht, ist dem spieler überlassen

das dorf alleine kann natürlich nicht alles machen, also kann man gruppen erstellen die sich in einem tag-nacht zyklus durch die welt arbeiten, hierbei gibt es nicht nur monster sondern auch verschiedene zufällige ereignisse die einem das leben schwerer oder einfacher machen, natürlich braucht auch eine solche gruppe nahrung und ausrüstung, die man allerdings auch unterwegs mithilfe eines camps sammeln bzw craften kann

meiner meinung eine der besten spielideen seit langem und wert es zu kaufen (bei der entwicklung des spiels legen die entwickler viel wert auf community, wenn du dich also entscheidest das spiel zu kaufen und du hast eine brilliante idee, dann teil sie doch den entwicklern mit)

ich hoffe ich konnte dir bei deiner entscheidung helfen :)

22428976.review: Erfrischend anders, mir hat's sehr gefallen!

This game is very unique. It is a board game, roughly like the settlers of catan.
On some hexagons of the map, there are resources that you can farm. You can do this through sending out a  group of villagers to scavenge the materials. But you have to keep in mind that the villagers need food and warmth. Also, the group is more prone to get attacked by many monsters that roam the world freely.
The battles are very unice and well thought out. The battles are in the form of a card game, like magic the gathering or yu-gi-oh!. It makes you think about how to utilize the abilities from your villagers in that battle and about how it can support other villagers.
The extra element of not being able to create new settlements, gives a new deth into the game. It makes you second guess whether it is a good idea to get some materials and what the group will need during their journey.
The game sets you thinking about how to survive and what the best way of doing things are. Futhermore, every game is different as the world is randomly generated. There is a fast diversity of events that all end up differently depending on your abilities and your choices of how you want to deal with it.
I would like to see a multiplayer function incorporated into this game, as it would be very interesting to be able to trade  and/or be at war with other settlements.

22310461.review:
Firstly i should explain what games i like for context (mind you i'm not saying that Thea: The Awakening is like these games). I really love city building games: Tropicos 3 and 4 are my current favorites, also Cities: Skylines. I play 4x games but i'm not that good at it. Civilization V and Endless Legends are the 4x titles i play occasionally. Dwarf Fortress is too hard for me although i like playing it. Now on to the review.

I reccomend Thea: The Awakening because it's a fresh take on the 4x genre. They pride on classifying it as a 3x game though, you manage only one village so no need for expansion here. I won't spoil the story here but i do love the mythology and i think it's a huge factor for the game. 

Now in this one village that's randomly generated from the start you can gather two resources, craft equipment for your people, and erect buildings. The thing is the resources you need to craft and build stuff are scattered all around the map. The only way to gather it is to create an 'expedition', a unit consisting of some of your people, and send them on a fetch quest.

Expedition units can also do quests, hunt monsters that may threaten your village or destroy their gosh darn ding-dang lairs. This will earn you experience points to level up all your people and get you research points which you can spend on new crafting recipes, reveal new resources on the map, or get a new building blueprint. Oh and your people are divided into different classes like warrior, or gatherer, or ... the other peasants that make stuff for you, and many more. You can even have characters from other races!

Does it sound exciting to you? Does it? If it does you should buy it! If not, maybe i'm not reviewing it right because it's hella fun. I have a total of 24 hours gameplay when i wrote this review and i suspect there'd be many more because a DLC is coming.

22234208.review:
First, the bad: The card game used to determine outcomes of events feels out of place. Though I would rather see a tactical combat layout or a combat screen similar to Final Fantasy type games, the odd 'card game' mechanic does have its advantages. The primary advantage is valuing character skills that can frequently be overlooked in a traditional rpg.

That being said, this really isnt an RPG, though it feels like one a lot of the time. It definitiely isn't a 4x, because you have only one village that never grows its borders. Its a cross of both, in a Rogue-Like map generation with the goals setup to require you to replay new maps (unlock new gods to play as when you 'level up' your current gods by completing the maps).

Now the Good: This game is unlike anything you have played before. It is a fresh idea, it has some entertaining writing and dialog, and it allows you options to skip through the monotonous storyline parts that you see when you replay very easily. Even the bad (the card game) has its upsides by highlighting the skills your characters have.

I find the random generation of upgrades your characters receive, the random events (including gaining new characters), and ability to skip most of the tedious stuff to be very refreshing. I bought this game on sale a few days ago and have alredy posted nearly a work-weeks amount of time into the game.

I am still captivated by it, and I am looking forward to unlocking more gods to see how their boosts impact the gameplay. If you like RPG games, 4x games, and games like X-Com heavily focused on group building, I highly recommend this game. It is not perfect, but it has such a great blend of familiar and new game mechanics that it is worth a look from any gamer.
