22185295.review:
Where do I start? I am being very generous to give it a thumbs up because I saw the great effort coming from the developer, so I am writing this review without any mean spirit but rather expressing my personal thoughts. There are many charms in this game while some areas require a lot of improvements. Who am I to critique and nitpicking specks before removing the plank from my own eyes.

The Writing Style:
This is where I hope for further improvement. I love the narratives and the description of the events; it's beautiful. I can visualize the events, and some of the beautiful visual arts completely paints my fantasy. Like reading Lord of the Rings it pulls me into their story. However, when the game is telling a Slavic mythology, we are expecting old school dialogue. In fact, most of the visual arts of our characters are mid-age or older, but many dialogues are spoken through as a modern day teenager. The immature dialogue itself completely kills my fantasy. Just imagine Aragorn or Gandalf responding to Frodo with "whatever, Frodo, don't waste your time, let's get on with it." Those are poor choice of words even the young Frodo wouldn't speak like that. How about Frodo greets Gandalf with "Hi, so how are things? Let's hang out." These type of dialogues don't belong to the medieval ages. I was very frustrated with the writing style because the push and pull effect. If you ever read old school writings like "Dante's Divine Comedy" or "Beowulf", the characters wouldn't speak in modern slangs or idioms. 

The Story:
The main story is rather short. On my first play through, it was very interesting to read the story. However, on my second play through, there is no variety on the main story; no matter what I choose from early or mid-game, the main story is the same other than at the very end choosing to restore balance or not. After two play throughs, there isn't any reply value looking at the story line perspective. While there are many side events which are very interesting, I find myself roaming around to trigger these random events. After a while, it gets tedious.

The game plays:
I like the combat style; it's creative. There are complexity on character stats, however, it gets boring after a while because the enemy composition is static. Early on, it's fun to figure out your enemy. Once you have some decent gears later on, it gets dull. It's no longer challenging. On my third play through, I find myself auto resolve most of my combats. Imagine playing card games like Magic the Gathering or Hearthstone, you wouldn't auto resolve your games. While those card games have a variety of cards, this game have a variety of character stats and used in different type of combats. For example, if the team have some magic users, I will do well in a magic challenge. But once I beat this type of challenge a couple times, I just auto resolve to instant win because the enemy is the same. 

I am excited to see the new "FREE DLC". I thank the developer expanding the story. In fact, they are giving us the ability to create and add our own events, I hope other talented writers will further expand this fantasy. I look forward to it.

22178723.review:
[b]The Short of It:[/b]

Thea: The Awakening is at its core a turn-based 4X game, but it's so much more. Crafting, gathering, construction, combat, exploration, research, all the elements have a distinct set of mechanics and challenges to them that make Thea a wonderfully rich game, and a massive vector of "Just One More Turn Syndrome." It is most certainly worth the price despite a few small imperfections.


[b]The Long of It:[/b]

As a fallen God, stripped of his or her power, you have only a ragtag band of people and a small village left, and Thea: The Awakening is your struggle to help your villagers survive an unforgiving world, to lead them through their trials and dangers, and to hopefully ensure their survival while you work to regain your lost power. With very few allies and a great many enemies, however, your best efforts may only serve to temporarily stave off the starvation or devouring of the few men, women and children you have left.

As your villagers overcome dangers, however, they and their village will grow in strength, and only through maintaining a constant curve of growth can you continue to face the hardships coming your way. Organising your villagers into expeditions who will scout the surrounding land, gather resources and defeat enemies is indispensible to your survival, and it is these expeditions which bring in the experience, research and resources your villagers in the home base need to craft new items, construct new buildings and learn new blueprints. 

As your village grows more powerful, however, so too will resistance, and sitting still for long is not an option. The world wants you dead, and frequently your villagers will have to defend themselves, or (hopefully) pre-emptively mount an attack against the various denizens of Thea. Combat is resolved through a tactical card game that is a mix between tactical strategy and Random Number God decree. While complex and difficult the grasp, the card system offers many possibilities and is used for all kinds of challenges (not just combat) with your villagers and enemies having many different values based on their abilities relevant to that particular challenge, requiring a diverse group to counter the dangers thrown your way. Equipping a doom squad of ironclad soldiers who stomp on everything they see is certainly a possibility, but fighting takes a heavy toll on your villagers over time, while other challenges, if available, will often see them emerge unscathed. Diversity is absolutely essential in Thea.

As your expeditions brave hardships, dangers and starvation, your villagers on the home front work tirelessly to bring in resources close to home, to craft weapons, armours and other items, and to construct buildings, using the resources your expeditions bring in. The crafting system is very complex, with every item requiring a combination of materials and every material changing the item, depending on the combinations you use. This makes it a constant choice of whether or not to use a combination of highly advanced and mediocre materials to craft a decent item, or to take the risk and wait for more advanced materials to make a more powerful object.


[b]The Right of It:[/b]

As already mentioned, Thea is wonderfully rich, complex and vibrant, with your villagers being more than just units, but truly characters you will come to care about and know very well, and the death of one of them will strike you hard, and not only on the tactical front. As they grow, they will become more developed and unique, giving every character a complex mix of abilities. The game is essentially classless - while characters will be marked as having a certain class, in reality every character will be able to learn every skill and so your village will become a melting pot of all kinds of people, and it's great to see it develop that way.

Combat is complex and tactical, with quite a bit of Random Number God malarkey thrown in, and the card system, while working differently for all challenges, does remain recognizable and needs no constant attention shift from the player as challenges change. So while it does call upon different skills, the core remains the same, and requires character versatility while not constantly bogging down the player in different types of systems.

Crafting and construction are a fun and useful, and the research system is streamlined, yet versatile. Having different materials available to you will completely change what kind of items you can make, and you will often have to make tough decisions on how to best use your materials, as well as which villagers you assign to which task. 

Quests are many, and although many fall under the "go to X, overcome challenge Y" variety, they're always given some more depth and life through writing and player choices, and players can clearly tell the developers have poured much love into their world from the writing and lore, based loosely on Slovenian mythology. It's not without the occasional typographical error, but if you're not willing to overlook such a minor thing, you missed out on a career as a surly English teacher.


[b]The Wrong of It:[/b]

Let me make it clear right now that I am nitpicking, because Thea is a wonderful game in almost every respect. However, some small imperfections are worth mentioning (and then briefly forgetting, believe me).

Given the many varied builds you'll have in your group of people, it can sometimes get seriously overwhelming to keep track of it all. Sometimes it really is too much information, and while the devs have tried to mitigate this somewhat, there will still be times when you feel like you're trying to earn a degree in accounting instead of playing a game. It's complex, which is good, but it can be a bit daunting at times.

The card system, while certainly solid, has two drawbacks. Firstly, it's very complex and very little of it is explained in depth, so in the beginning, you'll often have no idea what you're doing until you've played it a significant amount of times. Sure, there are tutorial video links embedded in the game, but this isn't a very good solution. However, the computer can auto-resolve challenges and is reasonably adept at it, if you find things too complicated. Also, the card system is a bit too dependent on RNGesus, with the main determinator of combat (Initiative) being completely out of your control and determined completely randomly. Getting to go first makes or breaks a challenge in most cases, so making the player entirely dependent on a 50/50 coin toss about such an important element is a strange decision from MuHa.

The Random Number God will determine many more elements, and often, these elements could have been determined by other things just as well, giving the player some control where now he has none. For instance, you have zero control over when a child is born, when it matures, and what class it will be. No matter what kind of buildings or villagers you have, the game determines these things completely randomly and independently. Some children may mature in three turns, while others remain children for over a hundred. Even though a random element is always nice, this is a bit exaggerated, and it's a serious headscratcher.

Loading times can be deplorable, and especially for new players who are still learning the ropes, and who will have to reload more often, this can require some persistence. It sometimes takes more than a minute to load a game (on an SSD!) and that's really too long in this day and age. The save system is also not entirely reliable, with the game sometimes loading an autosave even though you manually saved several turns later. It's not disastrous, but still important for MuHa to take a look at it for the free DLC/patch which is slated to be released soon.


[b]The Last of It:[/b]

I would have finished this review sooner, but I was too busy playing... just!... one!... more!... turn!

22172538.review:
Great game, and worth the buy as is....but...


So much room for improvement too. Here's to hoping the developers read these reviews, because there is just so much potential here. This is review is basically going to be a wishlist of sorts of how I think this game could be made even better. It's already quite entertaining, so kudos on that front, but I just wish there was more to it.

First off, as has been noted by others, the city development tree is criminially limiting. One could easily play the game without ever building a single structure. I can understand why it's not about copying Civ and focusing on starting new settlements all over the map, but seriously, why can't I turn the one struggling hamlet into a thriving metropolis? This would be pretty easy to implement now that the game is a finished product. Have a set of graphic assets that represent the city in a tiered series of growth stages, each one taking up an additional hex on the map, where growing the city correspondingly expands influence for gathering. Have all manner of new buildings available, plus an upgrade option for improving existing structures once you have access to better resources. Churches, stone walls, schools, fish ponds, mage towers... so many possibilities.

Make these higher level structures resource sinks just the same as population is a resource sink. If the required resource is not available, the bonuses are not provided. Churches can provide divine protections by accepting resource offerings of prepared food from the people. Mage towers allow for the crafting of exclusive mage tower only magic gear and further boost the magic stat above the totem, but only if it is supplied with gems and precious metals. An advanced blacksmith that also provide unique craft recipies but needs coal to operate. Monster repellent towers that lower the incidence of negative events and attacks on the village in response to having such attacks increase as a built in game mechanic in response to a player's prosperity (e.g. tier 2 villages are attacked twice as often, tier 3 three times as often, and so on...) Conversely, a player could build a totem of battle that would actually draw more attacks to the village. A lot of possibilites that would only require minimal adjustments to the game.

Next, it wouldn't hurt at all to simply be more liberal with movement points. The primary reason the game is so glacially slow (which is it's greatest sin) is because it takes forever and a day to get from one place to another. Have a higher MP base value, and another unit stat that gets averaged out over the party that further augments MP (something that is also improved with gear, such as the speciality gear suggested above).

Last is the rarity of new units. Especially in the early portion of a game. I spend an inordinate amout of time savescumming in the first 200 rounds out of simple necessity. I know anyone I lose is basically irreplaceable. It's mildly annoying. Cabbage patch kids should be more frequent.

Hopefully the developers will take this into consideration, as it seems like this game is just inches away from being truly great. Now it's just really good but... eh....

What an amazing game, it reminds me to FTL, you have one and only one town (ship), you have people on it (crew), each one of them with their unique name, habilities, stats, etc., you get them to explore the world around them (the galaxy) trying to survive and get enought resources and equipment on the way to be able to fight back the increasingly tough enemies.

That's the core base of the game, but it delivers way more than FTL. It has an amazing story, a beautiful world, an incredible music (oh the music), a lot of side quests, a lot of gather and crafting, you even have to cook the food your people need to eat, the battles, which are a card-based, have a lot of depth but at the same time are very fast. This, for people like myself who enjoy the most the exploring, gathering and crafting part, is totally a plus.

And the game has a kind of meta-game where the god you choose at the beginning of each game earns experience with the playthrough and unlocks new powers that give you bonuses on the next games you play with him.

Totally a must if you like the 4X genere (this is more a 3X, as it has no expansion, which makes it more difficult and satisfactory), and the devs (who are really nice) already have in the way free DLCs for the game.

22139997.review:
The best survival game I've ever played, hands down.

There is a level of micromanagement and detail in this that is just beautiful. You craft and equip your villagers with tools and weapons and send them on explorations. You can freely combine materials and create a big variety of items. And since higher tier material is hard to come by, you have to consider who to give your equipment. There is a very good balance in this and lower tier materials never feel obsolete as crafting items is also a good way to gain research points for more materials and recipies.

On the other hand, the combat system is a simple but very tactical card game. And all of your statistics can matter as these challenges can be a variety of things. You can try and fight the orcs off and risk losing a few villagers, but you might just as well convince them to join forces with you! The amount of things each individual villager can do is amazing and it never feels forced to play a villager in a certain way (Your craftsman might be unusually strong and put up a good fight. Or maybe you have a smart Gatherer who can poison your enemies so you don't have to fight them)

I cannot recommend this game enough.

22105234.review:
Купить игру Thea: The Awakening меня побудил сеттинг, основанный на славянской языческой мифологии. Потом, правда, выяснилось, что на эту мифологию накрутили grimdark-овое фентези по типу Толкиена или вархаммера с эльфами, гоблинами, орками и демонами и любопытную хозяйственную модель. Судя по проведенному в игре времени, микс оказался чрезвычайно удачен!

Чем дальше я играл, чем глубже я погружался в сюжет, тем сильнее мне нравилась эта игра. Сам сюжет, на мой вкус, незамысловат (хотя в нем и есть немало оригинальных находок), но над текстом работал весьма талантливый литератор, читать его одно удовольствие. Увы, надо сказать, что тот, кто не владеет английским свободно, пропустит процентов 90 удовольствия от игры. 

Из недостатков можно отметить слишком мелкий текст на некоторых разрешениях экрана (глаза болят от продолжительного чтения, а читать приходится много) и карточную систему боя/переговоров/охоты/ядоварения/т.д., которая может быстро надоесть, если играть на низких сложностях. Отмечу, что на сложности приблизительно 170+ "альтернативный способ разрешения конфликтов" обретает второе дыхание. 
Еще один недостаток игры - у владельцев медленных машин может быть долгая загрузка. На этом мои претензии оканчиваются.

Ну и, конечно, в игре имеется тот чудесный рандом, что так любим ценителями хардкора и рогаликов.

22103745.review:
Отвыкла очень от пошаговых стратегий, так что первые полчаса очень туго въезжалось. Взорвали мозг скиллчеки, оформленные как бои - первый такой бой офигевала, потому что не понимала, где враги (и невнимательно прочитала туториал). Зато как только стало понятно, игра пошла более-менее ровно. 
Музыка хороша, стрыги и Живия в подземельях радуют, транслитерация русских названий вообще очень веселит. Боевка интересная, только решаффл глючит периодически. Пока что интересно, и особых багов не замечено, хочется продолжать дальше. 
9 из 10 за баг с полноэкранным режимом - активные области кнопок уезжают в сторону.

22095905.review:
Thea is a unique turn-based strategy title, where it takes the idea of a 4X and mutates it to what I'd call a 3X, by removing expansion. Thea is not about gorwing your nation or tribe across multiple settlements but rather exploring and questing in order to expand your single settlement. As you play and fail (you will) you will gain XP which will increase the power of your god and unlock access to play as other dormant god's - who have different bonuses which encourage different styles of play.

I was hesitant at first due to the card game style of play, and it felt a little convoluted at first. But it starts to make a lot of sense as you play and you weigh in on the importance of different kinds of equipment.

The writing and lore is great and would recommend it to TBS and rogue-like fans alike.

22095440.review:
8,5/10
This game brings "one more turn" addiction to a new level.

+ Good mixture of strategy and rpg elements. Explore, Exploit, Exterminate and Roleplay. (3X1R, perhaps a new genre)
+ Good story telling with possibility of different routes to progress.
+ Nice art
+ Nice variety of skills, challenges, items and resources to use
+ Good replayability to try different strategies or alternative storylines
+ I like card game

- Micromanagement needs optimization and user friendliness
- Card game lacks some randomness. Once i figured correct play it quickly became repetitive. Perhaps new additions to piercing/blunt/first action to increase possibilities.
- Lack of Unique items (not a big minus, but still)
- Every individual is so valuable but still we should have some interaction with our people. Story and guest lines for individuals will be both rewarding and more immersive
- Lair guardians or mobs can be more varied. Tired of killing rock trolls :)

Final word: I highly recommend this game to both rpg and 4X strategy fans. We should support developers who try new things and still put up a very good product.

Are there additions I would like? Sure: I'd love to see the ability to have more villages and some more open play (e.g. just a touch of a more civ like option.).  But still, I highly recommend it and would easily buy it again.

22080625.review:
Disappointed so far. After spending more than 400 h on Fallout 4, I wanted a complete change for a new game. After a long research, I decided for Thea: The Awakening. Bad luck. It didn't take me off. 

The game is probably a fine 4X but I can't get into it. Your village is just an hex, the country around some more hexes, your characters are just cards with no substance and no way to "feel" them, enemies are other cards with some statistics. You move from hex to hex and battle against generic enemies with a cards system which never appealed to me. 

I'm OK with the lack of animation but you basically play a board game where the game master throws random tasks and fights at you without a real ambience.

In a word you are never immersed in the game. Hopefully it will get better after some time but for now I'm back in the Commonwealth.

Wonderfull and well thought game!

Adictive gameplay, good quests, great ambiance and variety.
If you like games that excel in story and gameplay, not on graphics (that are quite good in Thea), this game is for you.

22013418.review: I have not seen a strategy game like this in a while where your people are all unique and not stock clones of certain types as you build your civilization.  No two games are exactly the same due to all the random events and there is a lot of freedom to do what you want to do (although initially limited by resources and technology).  There seems to be a lot of room to expand upon the game such as building additional cities.  Trading, while present, seems limited.  The RPG aspects of the game are woven in very nicely and it is easy to get invested in your characters as they grow.  The card game used for encounters and challenge events takes getting used to but can help you get through situations where auto resolve might wipe your group.

22004414.review:
You start with a small group of survivors in a village after the fall of the various gods.  You venture out from your village to gather resources, explore, and figure out what to do about this whole "fall of various gods" thing.

It is interesting and quite a bit of fun, and different than anything I've played, but it can be very RNG heavy and there are some flaws as well.  One of the central themes is that you split up your survivors and leave some at the village while others go out to explore.  I have had more than once when a powerful enemy waunders in and pretty much kills off your village.  There isn't much you can do about it other than never really split up and explore, which makes the entire game sitting at your village.  Because of this, you pretty much have to figure there is a chance you'll lose the game for no good reason every time you go out to explore.  I can think of a half dozen examples of game design failure like this, but it hasn't stopped me from enjoying the game.

It isn't perfect by any strech of the imagination, but just the originality of the game makes it worthwhile for a few playthroughs of fun.

21989601.review: A very nice game. Simple yet entertaining. RPG/crew managment survival. Worth your time to try

21884717.review:
[b] Thea: The Awakening 3/5:[/b] Originalita za každou cenu není vždy ctností a stěží hledat lepší příklad než právě Theu, která by ráda přinesla oživení do zatuchlého rybníčku 4X strategií. Snaží se o to skrze na papíře sympaticky vypadající, ale v praxi poněkud nešťastně implementované inovace. 

 Skládá se ze tří hlavních částí - na těžká rozhodnutí bohaté strategické 4X, kde vylepšujete svou vesnici, sbíráte zdroje, vynalézáte, vyrábíte, bloumáte po mapě světa a však to znáte, dále pak z bojové části, která je zpracována jako takticky komplexní karetní minihra (jejíž slabinou je, že je zdlouhavá a tak na běžné střety se záhy uchýlíte k automatickému výsledku), ze „zvol si své dobrodružství" rozhodovacích textových pasáží jak je znáte z [i]King of Dragon Pass[/i] a k tomu všemu je v tom i element survival žánru, RPGček či managementu kde čeho. Asi již tušíte v čem je problém, že? Ano, nejde to dohromady, jakkoli ty mechaniky samy o sobě špatné nejsou. Nemáte pocit, že hrajete strategickou hru, kde jsou souboje řešeny karetní formou. Máte pocit, že hrajete solidní strategickou hru, kterou před souboji vypnete a pustíte solidní karetní hru. Po skončení souboje karetní hru vypnete a zapnete zase strategickou. A tak stále dokola.

 Šťastný není ani „rogue like" element, kdy každá hra je jiná. Respektive chtěla by být jinou, ale bez ohledu na náhodně vygenerovanou mapu či zvolenou strategii se to hraje stejně (jen se mění bonusy dle toho, které bohy a úkoly jste si v minulých hrách odemkli) a to až do té míry, že se některé úkony stávají rutinními až hanba. A to jsem ještě nezmínil špatně napsané textové pasáže či uživatelsky vyloženě nepřátelské rozhraní, kdy každá akce je skryta v podmenu jiného menu/tabulky. A tak na i ty nejběžnější akce, kde byste si v jiných titulech vystačili s jedním či dvěma kliknutími, se zde předem obrňte trpělivostí. Tady se kliká a kliká a kliká až se proklikáte tak kam chcete.

 Dalším příkladem špatného designu je, že na začátku každého kola vám vyjede v pravém horním rohu seznam všech důležitých informací a událostí. Ovšem krom případů, kdy máte přetíženou či hladovějící výpravu, pak se to zobrazuje miniaturní ikonkou v levém dolním rohu. Detail? Ano, nebýt toho že takovéto otravné detaily, nedodělky a nedomyšlenosti jsou tu na každém druhém kroku. Vyloženě otravné je i úvodní z-d-l-o-u-h-a-v-é načítání mapy či že i dobře rozehranou několika hodinovou hru vám může zcela poslat do kopru jedna náhodně vygenerovaná obtížností naprosto přestřelená událost.

 Přesto všechno je Thea v jádru dobrou hrou. Proč? Protože pokud (a je to velké pokud) se přes tyto problémy přenesete, tak narazíte na solidní především strategický titul se sedícím fantasy hávem vycházejícím ze slovanského folklóru. A nelze tomu upřít ani poznávací znak kvality všech podobných titulů; a to sice „ještě jedno poslední kolo a jdu od toho... ehm, no tak ještě jedno a jedno". Jenomže to platí o několika málo hrách, pak se Thea stane natolik rutinní a bez překvapení, že není důvod ji hrát. I tak vystačí na pěkných pár hodin zábavy, ale tento typ her obvykle vydrží desítky až stovky hodin a nikoli jednotky hodin. 

 Thea obsahuje větší než malé množství zajímavých nápadů (jejich úspěšnost/prospěšnost je fifty fifty) a lze ji doporučit, zvlášť pokud jste již veškeré klasiky žánru hráli a máte chuť na něco, co si se zavedenou formou a žánrovými pravidly nebojí pohrát; jakkoli ne nutně vždy v dobrém slova smyslu. Jen počítejte s tím, že to nebude láska na první pohled. Nejdříve jí pro její mušky a mouchy budete nenávidět, ale o to hlubší pak možná bude váš vztah k ní. A třeba také ne a zůstane čistě u té nenávisti. Buď jak buď, tak Thea je především rozporuplná hra, v závěsu zatím inovativní a až poté i dobrá.

21821251.review:
I enjoyed playing this game.  I really liked the way different skills were integrated into dialogue options.

The only criticism that I have is that it starts of difficult but you quickly reach a break point that allows you to dominate the remainder of the game.   Changing the game's difficulty level only ramps up the challenge of reaching the break point, but once that is obtained the remainder of the game is dominated by your gear, abilities, and knowledge of the storyline.

21789875.review:
Okay. I DO enjoy this game. However, I recognise that not this game's market appeal is rather low.  Most people won't enjoy it because it is quite simply not accessible.

This game's main issue is that it has a stupidly large learning curve. It is that simple. There IS a tutorial available for the game, but the game is extremely poor at guiding you through the nuances of the mechanics and giving tips along the way on how to improve your play and keep villagers alive.  It really doesn't help that the game is on permament Iron Man  mode so you cannot take back moves and experiment with different approaches to the same problem.

Once you get over this learning curve however, the game suddenly becomes easy. Some folks say trivially easy.  Since I'm over that stupidly large learning curve, I'm now playing the game and I'm enjoying navigating my way through all the challenges and experimenting with different strategies.  So yes, in spite of the negative tone of this review, I actually recommend this game. It is a good game once you can get past the learning curve.

Recommendation: Before you start a battle or any type of challenge, learn how the card battle system works exactly. Do not try to learn it on the fly. The game does a very poor job of explaining, yet the card battle is a core gameplay activity that is used to resolve all encounters.

Edit: 350 hours later.... wow, I really got a lot of value from this game! Somehow I keep coming back for more even though the higher difficulty settings are kind of ridiculous haha. I guess I should say this game is highly recommended?

21698468.review:
I've only played for a bit so far, and i have to say i appreciate the mix between roguelike/RPG/strategy gameplay Thea presents. This might be the birth of a new genre, although a bit of a niche.

It goes without saying, if you don't like micromanaging, this game may not be for you. 

On the other hand, i've just received a quest where a Dwarf wants me to convince a Water Demon to date him. 
That armor he promised better be good!

21656419.review:
I am an older gamer and for my taste I find Thea the awakening one of the most enjoyable games on Steam.   The artwork, story,  and music create a beautiful, engaging environment.   Thea has very unique game play.   I find that many RPG and 4x strategy games are overly complex and the process of learning the game not very enjoyable.   In Thea, you only have one villiage and one, or maybe two, adventure parties to manage unlike other 4X games where you may have 10 or more cities (planets, etc) to manange which soon becomes unwieldy.   This simplicity allows you to put more thought into the choices you are making in the game.     The technology tree is another example of where less is better.   The technology tree is relatively simple and intuitive compared to other 4x games that I have played.   But rather than making the game play simple, it makes your choices understandable and strategic.   FInally, I agree with those previous reviewers who like the card game system of combat.    It is refreshingly different from the Hex based squad combat that is ubiquitous.  

I highly recommend giving this game a try.

21638957.review: Horribly bad game. Slow tedious and rubish. No redeaming features.

21609482.review: Amazingly fun. Rogue like meets old school Civ. Great for a short game, or longer periods spanning many sittings.

21582315.review:
I'm a bit hooked after playing 13 hours the first day I bought the game. I LOVE strategy games, and this one is unlike most I have played. 
PROS: 
Good story. The events that happen are constantly changing and have different outcomes. 
Leveling up and equiping my teams with great gear has become an addiction, and despite the world being small, there's a ton to do. 
The game is tough, even when played on easy novice, but not too tough that you don't want to play. Just tough enough that you aren't bored. 
Getting the hang of the game is quite easy, and is done in the first hour, but mastering this game could take ages. 

CONS: 
No save, other than an autosave every 5 turns, which is super annoying for someone like me, who hates every negative outcome or the death of a person. *** I have been informed there is a save feature by one of the developers. You have to change the settings before you start playing the game to turn on saves, and then, while playing, you press esc to access the menu that allows you to save. You can NOT turn on saves after you have been playing, it has to be done before you start a game (which still makes it a con in my book)****
Every time I die and reload (and sit through a two minute load screen), the tutorial popups start over at the beginning. There's no way to turn them off without starting a new game, and losing the hours and hours of building my little town. 
The battle screen is done in a card battle format, which is absolutely NOT for me. I just press "auto resolve" or I lose. AND sometimes they will give you a starting twon where the people you begin with all do literally no damage. You can't kill even the first mobs of the game. 
They rate the enemies with a 1-5 skull toughness system, but it's very difficult to tell how many skulls your team can safely go up against. 

All-in-all, I really like it. worth the cost, especially if you get it on sale.

21578664.review: just one more turn... 15h later... oops it's 7am

21570352.review: Ehhhh once you get the hang of it... kinda feels like you just downloaded hacks and ptthhh.   No more fun.  Then again I much prefer turn based multiplayer strategy rpg games because there's more to do with / against friends.  Hasn't been a real good one though in a long ass time~!

21550044.review:
Refreshing to say the least. 

I know my hours aren't the longest, but rest assured this game is a lot of fun. I'm deeply impressed with the mechanics and how the game works. It's engaging, has replayability, and is overall a breath of fresh air. 

Tips:
 I find my luck is much better with the gatherers. Not only do they bring in a hunting attribute, but they are also able to find vital rescources. Hunting saves me from a full frontal assault (and being maimed by a large rabbit). 

Scouting is important, however staying close to the village in the start is more important. I can't tell you the number of times I've gone and veered off to a higher level to only be clobbered immensely. Quests, scouts, monsters, and other things will pop up so it's best to stay close to home. 

If mortally wounded, ALWAYS camp immediately. Your chances of surviving increase dramatically. 

Note that loosing one member will not stunt you, but loosing too many can land lock you. You won't be able to go through terrain, move, or camp. Your members will die of hunger unless you are able to send help from the village. 

The game ultimately works against you. If it's not dark dwarves stealing your gold or an ice queen frozen at heart, it's a problematic situation which you can't get out of. Diplomacy is your friend to most of the random situations. Attacking wisps and travelers will only get you killed. Take the kindness and use it well. 

Thanks for reading!

21528390.review:
This is really a unique game that I'm enjoying greatly so far.

From the pictures of the game it may seem like any 4x game, but in reality the pace and feels to me more similar to an old school RPG, with a card mini game instead of turn based combat.   
TLDR: If you like games that have RNG, RPG elements, and management, this is for you.  Pick it up, as I haven’t played a game this unique in a while. 

Pros:
-Everything meshes well, from inventory management to exploration to resource gathering, you really get engrossed with the mechanics while trying to win.
-Great artwork and art style.
-The card game is challenging and has enough depth to keep it fun, without being too time consuming and complicated to the extent that you'll get fatigue from the number of encounters you'll have in the game.

Cons:  (I’m more writing this hoping the devs will gets some ideas how to make improvements)
-The writing is subpar, oftentimes throwing walls of text at you or being sort of silly.  I haven't gotten much into the main quest, but I can't say I'm very interested in the story, just more into the gameplay itself as you try to complete it.  Sometimes individual encounters will have interesting folklore or mythology to it (the game is inspired by Slavic mythology apparently) but in general I would have preferred a more concise text based storyline and a better story in general.
-The “skull” system for giving you an idea how difficult an encounter could be needs some work in my opinion.  I’d much rather have a statistic screen showing me the likelihood of outcomes (i.e. % chance you’ll win, % chance you’ll win but a party member will be gravely wounded, % chance you’ll lose etc.)  In addition, the skulls don’t really give you a good prediction of the difficulty of enemies you’ll be fighting.  I might not have played enough to see the patterns better, but a 3 skull fight sometimes surprises me as a cake walk while another 3 skull fight throws creatures at me that will guarantee to kill my entire party. 
-The U.I. is in general good, but the most “busy work” time seems to be when you’re adding and comparing equipment for your individual villagers.  It needs streamlining, for instance: when I have a villager selected and look over a weapon in the general inventory I should get a box that appears that compares that item with what he has currently equipped instead of having to individually hover over each item to determine stats.  Another aspect is that all the stats numbers for characters seem to be jumbled on the screen instead of alphabetized, so the attack power of one character will be on a random spot on his stat screen that’s different from another character’s position.  In addition the production screen will state you have enough material to build a certain item when you in fact don’t, as 3 different items of the same type can’t be combined to produce something.  Though these seem kind of nitpicky, for a game like this small U.I. difficulties really add up the “busy work” time wasted.  I hope to see some of this updated in the future. 
-For a game that forces you to only have 1 village, the village maintenance mechanic is fairly Vanilla.  I would like a way for you village to expand its gathering zone (while having some way to keep it balanced) as well as having different options for buildings.  Right now, you have only a few options for buildings (with a 10 building cap), and you destroy and rebuild the same buildings just with different parts to try and get a bit better buffs.

Everyone fulfills a purpose and the loss of even a single vilager is devestating. This game is an excellent breath of fresh air into the turn based strategy genre.  It appears at first to look like a Civilization type game, but then you have mixed in with that card battles to resolve conflicts and roguelike type elements for actually managing your people.  You'll grow very attached to specific members of your city and then wail in despair when they finally die for good.

21391421.review:
Alors, ce jeu est génial et terrible.

Honnêtement, au point de vue du fond, c'est une perle : mécanismes novateurs, idée original, scénario sympa. C'est joli, c'est bien fait, ça change de ce dont on a l'habitude, il y a plein de bonnes idées de çi de là. D'où ma recommandation : n'hésitez pas, ce jeu est très bon. Même si je vais développer le contraire après, le message principal est : bravo aux développeurs. Good job.

Ensuite, un bémol sur le fond : le jeu pèche par un certain manque de rejouabilité : 
> une fois que l'on connaît la quête principale, les parties se ressemblent un peu. Il eut été intéressant peut-être d'avoir une quête principale différente pour chaque dieu, par exemple ? Ou des "embranchements" dans la quête principale qui permettent d'affronter des événements différents au lieu de suivre toujours la même ligne ? Peut-être qu'il est encore temps de les développer pour une extension...
> de plus, les caractéristiques des dieux ne modifient pas suffisamment profondément le gameplay. Certes, vous allez avoir des opportunités légèrement différentes, notamment à travers les quêtes qui permettent de récupérer des personnages. Mais vous ne pouvez pas faire l'impasse des compétences de combat, ne serait-ce que parce que vous êtes attaqués toutes les nuits, et que dans la majorité des cas, seule le combat ordinaire vous est proposé quand vous êtes en défense. Plus de diversité serait bienvenue.
> enfin, l'arbre de développement n'offre pas suffisamment de choix. Certes, chaque type d'armes a ses avantages et vos choix influent sur vos forces et vos faiblesses (typiquement, contre les abeilles et les araignées, et autres groupes qui font des dégâts en jouant sur le nombre de petites bêtes plutôt que la résistance de quelques grosses créatures, les marteaux sont parfaits ; dans d'autres combats, des armes faisant plus de dégâts comme les haches sont préférables). Mais ça ne change pas radicalement les parties. De même, on peut s'orienter vers la production d'une foule de bébés, ou aller plutôt vers les totems de magie pour attirer des créatures différentes, plus intéressantes. Mais ce dernier choix est rendu moins attrayant dès lors que la collecte de ressources rares nécessaires à la création de telles structures fait qu'au moment où vos premiers elfes, trolls, orcs, etc. arriveront, vous serez déjà à deux doigts de gagner... Et vous n'aurez pas vraiment le temps de savourer leur présence.

Pourtant, mon copain me fait remarquer que j'aime tellement le jeu que mes critiques ne m'empêchent pas de relancer des parties. Disons que ça permettrait aux développeurs de faire encore mieux.

Maintenant, ma vraie critique : en deux jours supplémentaires de développement, l'intérêt du jeu pourrait être multiplié par dix. Parce qu'il y a vraiment des trucs prises de tête, et pourtant si faciles à corriger. Les voici :
1. Le temps de chargement. Ca prend 2 à 3 grosses minutes pour charger une partie. Ca, c'est lourd à corriger, alors concentrez-vous sur la suite.
2. L'accès au chargement. Vous ne pouvez pas charger dès que vous êtes en combat ! Or, les combats durent longtemps. Très longtemps. Il faudrait avoir accès au menu de chargement à tout moment dans le jeu, y compris en mode combat.
3. L'accès à la retraite. Vous ne pouvez pas abandonner un combat à tout moment ! Vous ne pouvez le faire que sur l'écran où votre équipe est sélectionnée, ou après un premier tour quand il reste des personnages vivants. Dans le combat lui-même, le mieux que vous puissiez faire, c'est indiquer que vous ne souhaitez pas jouer vos autres cartes. A ce moment-là, l'ordinateur joue toutes les siennes et résoud le combat de façon normale au lieu de zapper pour donner directement le résultat.
4. Le combat automatique. L'IA est très spéciale et permet 0 pertes sur des combats compliqués (notamment contre une bande de guêpes ou d'araignées conséquentes) mais des pertes lourdes sur des combats simples (typiquement 5 humanoïdes costauds... Mais qui souffrent de n'être que 5, justement). Du coup il est difficile d'estimer à l'avance le résultat du combat automatique. Or, les combats sont longs. A un moment, vous ne souhaitez plus jouer que les combats techniques. Pourtant, c'est très risqué de choisir l'option "résolution automatique". Au-delà d'une certaine amélioration de l'IA (qui pourrait enregistrer par exemple vos résultats sur un combat antérieur similaire), il faudrait tout simplement que le résultat du combat automatique vous soit proposé, et que vous puissiez le refuser en passant au mode combat manuel.
5. L'estimation des puissances. Cela se traduit par un nombre de crânes. L'estimation des demeures est bugguée par rapport à l'estimation des troupes : 3 crânes peut représenter un combat équilibré quand il s'agit d'une troupe mobile, et 17 orcs armés jusqu'aux dents quand il s'agit d'une demeure fixe. Mais bon, peu importe, une fois qu'on le sait.
6. L'estimation de votre puissance. Si elle n'est pas indispensable en terme de combat classique, le système des rencontres alternatives (diplomacie, hex, sneak, hunting, etc.) est plus délicate. Il serait intéressant que l'IA nous propose une évaluation sommaire de notre potentiel sur chacune de ces caractéristiques. Je m'en tire avec une feuille de papier me rappelant les caractéristiques d'ATT et de DEF pour chaque type de rencontres, mais c'est fastidieux.
7. La carte. Il serait bon qu'en cliquant sur une ressource, dans l'arbre de développement, cela nous renvoie aux différents gisements que l'on connaît de cette ressource sur la carte. Pour le moment, c'est information n'est disponible qu'à la découverte de la ressource. Si on la loupe à ce moment-là, c'est un peu frustrant ensuite d'avoir à balayer sa carte, y compris les zones dans le brouillard...

Voilà, tout cela constitue des détails, facile à mettre en place, qui rendraient le jeu ô combien moins chronophage, et par conséquent plus excitant.

En dépit de la longueur de mon post, ma conclusion reste : Théa est une perle inattendue. Un jeu vraiment sympa que je recommande chaudement.

21297385.review:
Really good game, but surely can do better. Few things that I particularly dislike :
1. Repetitive Event. There's good amount of event in this game, but after playing for a while you will keep encounter the same event. Not to mention the main quest. Maybe add some more event?
2. Bad Tech/Science Design. Aside for crafting tech, the gathering tech and building tech are sorta useless as you mainly gather item from event/battle while advanced building offer little improvement over the basic building. The crafting tech also have its own flaws. In all my games I need only unlock one type of weapon. Well, why unlock another weapon if you already can create strongest weapon of that type. Better spend it on shield and armor. Maybe better Tech/Science design will do. Like combo between gathering and crafting tech, so you can only build Mithril Sword if you unlock Mithril from gathering and Sword from crafting?
3. Blind Chance. I'm not an expert at rogue-like games but to rely a matter of life and death to pure luck? Really? If there's no chance to save someone then I'll just let it go, but because there's always a CHANCE for that someone to survive, it will always make me feels bad to let them die. And that's definitely not a good experience I want. (Most of time I just load from save, yet sometime I just start a new village out of regret.) Maybe give them last chance to save their life that not based on pure luck? Doctor and herb lessen the chance to die, but still it's only a "CHANCE". Maybe if you give rank to the injury like "Serious, Beyond Help, something" then specify how much doctor skill / herb required to heal them everything will be fine, right?
4. The Gods. While chose certain God give different benefit, it will be nice to see the Chosen God have greater effect to the story/event. Currently God have a little impact to the events aside from the God related event.

While I mainly complaint, I really like the game and just want to see it improved.
Well, I let the reader discover the good thing. Don't worry, there's many of it. It just better if you find it yourself.

Overall, the game is much fun. I give score 8/10 as there's room to make improvement.

21164361.review:
(Disclaimer: I tend to leave this game running in the background, so the hours played is more like 1/10th of what is shown here) - a testiment to the games stability.

Just Enough Rogue-like:
One of the features I like about this game, is the ability to customize your difficulty level by specifying various aspects of the game elements. Research speed, enemy progress speed, disabling saving, etc ... Changing these also impacts the rate of experience gain for unlocking and leveling your gods.

Thea: The Awakening gameplay consists mostly of crafting/research, exploration/combat, and quests (some random, some more story-based). You begin by selecting from several gods (some of which need to be unlocked by playing), which determines some bonuses for your villagers (such as research bonuses, combat bonuses, etc). Each of your villagers has their own typical RPG elements like levels, stats, equipment, etc...

Although there is a main quest line (which is basically the same) and diety quest lines, the game doesn't necessarily stop once those have been completed. You can choose continue on, or even stop before completing the quests lines. Gameplay is pretty simple and you can micromanage combat, or auto-resolve to speed things along.

The UI is simple enough to use, though could use some improvement in areas to make accessing some screens / information easier - but it is no reason to avoid this game.

Research is plentiful, and straight forward. There are lots of recipe combinations for crafting that consists of basically a primary and secondary material - keeps things interesting enough -- though I would enjoy more complexity or variance.

Overall I have not been able to play much of anything else, as I keep coming back to this one.

A really solid strategic gameplay and a gripping adventure . Thea TA provides hours of fun and has great potential for developements in the future .

Per gli italiani: giusto a metà tra strategico a turni e RPG. Il sistema dei combattimenti è basato su un gioco di carte (ogni carta rappresenta un personaggio). Gli scontri possono essere di vario tipo (combattimento, socialità, tattica, caccia, stealth, ecc) per cui un personaggio con stat scarse nella lotta può diventare determinante per altri tipi di scontro. Ci sono un sacco di risorse e una marea di modi per craftarle. All'inizio sembra un giochino ma poi ci si accorge di una profondità davvero notevole. L'avventura principale non è molto lunga ma ci sono molte quest secondarie dove reperire risorse anche senza combattere. A livelli di difficoltà più elevati è un gioco veramente difficile, dove ogni decisione è importante per cercare di sopravvivere. Molto consigliato se piace il genere "ancora un turno" 
PS:  solo in inglese

21108723.review:
The mythological background, the narrative style and the visual atmosphere totally brings you in the world of Thea. The gameplay is really rich and pleasant with a gather, craft, construct, loot & xp core and an innovative card-based challenges system in which each member of your people is represented by a card which stats evolve according to their type, level and equipment. The strategy  resulting from this system can be very challenging in high difficulties level, a single bad choice can cost the life of many of your people. Hence the survival aspect of this game gets stronger.
You can also count on an incredible replay potential to get once again in this fabulous world, to try with increased difficulty, to unlock other gods, to test other paths or other approaches.
If you like, stategy mithology/fantaisy immersive games, don't hesitate anymore !

21098469.review:
This game is so complex but rich in flair, story, advice and tool tips. Where to start. I haven't played the first part of the campaign through, so bear with me.
(wall of text/)

You are a god! Cast out from the heavens or suchlike by the Darkness (evil stuff!). Fortunately you have believers and you set about finding your way back. (grossly shortened - I really like the story)

Characters: Each character (toon) can do two thing I guess: Fight and craft or gather. All toons can fight, but if it's a gathering toon he/she is strong in that respect. I started with 10 toons; 6 in a exploring party (think kinda D&D/roleplaying here) and 4 in the village - crafting and gathering. Each toon is very very different with different skills and abilities. You can merge the exploring party with the village and pick and choose which to go where. Food and wood and most critical to survive, and if your exploring party runs out of food you will starve and die.
When the party is exploring you will find some areas that has a icon above it. Event time! A screen comes up with your possible choices on it. You select one > Search ruin, and sometimes the ruin is abandoned and sometimes it's not. And this is leading to...

Fighting: This is where I was most sceptical because it's card driven, but I must admit I was wrong. I dislike card driven games but I really like it. Your fighters are the cards, some fight and some stay back supporting. The supporting toons use their skills to help a toon fighting. There's more to it than this. Oh, and keep some armour and weapons and the village. There's other partys running around with ill intent!

Crafting: This is where the game really shines. It's so simple and yet so complex. You can use nearly everything you gather or find. To make a hammer I used a iron bar, some wood and some other stuff (I can't remember). But if I used some other material, like steel, the time it took to make would be longer but the weight and the Research (see tech) would be greater. You can cook meals, develop tools, weapons, clothes and construct buildings. And when you click on a item, for instance a weapon, you can see what it's made out of! YAY!

Tech: You have a tech-tree and I noticed that when you search ruins and develop new tools you develop Research to do new things. There's Gathering, Crafting and Construction Research. I just researched and few Gathering things and when it's done I get 5 pieces at my village and a known location where I can get the stuff.

Village: It's fairly like Civilization and not like Civilization. There's children that grow up and you get another toon. But here is the smart thing: You decide if you need another fighter, gatherer or crafter. Sweet! You can do so much more. But the wall of text is growing too long.
(/wall of text)

In short: It's something like Civ/D&D/Warlords all put together. This game is so deep! But the game not fan of playing in full-screen mode. When I play it full-screen I have difficulty clicking on the buttons. There, I've said something bad about the game at last. ;)  Please look at the tutorials! You can't live without them!
It's something that the devs need to fix, but I'll play it nonetheless. It's too good to pass up!
...and yes. I played the game in window form not full-screen.

Edit: Full-screen now supported. :)

This is a really, really great game. There is a slight learning curve with combat; however, after a little bit of time, you will feel right at home with selecting which members of the village to bring with you to adventure. Most of the quests or events in the game at the beginning of the game will have you fight "monsters", or creatures to harvest their resources; however, as the game progresses, you'll need to use other means available to you in order to solve certain quests IE you may have avoided a battle if you had an experienced hunter with you that could have set traps before engaging in battle with enemies to weaken them. Another situation that comes up is solving conflicts, and disagreements and you will fail the 'skill check' if members of your party aren't intelligent enough or savvy enough.

The list goes on.

The game is quiet deep with wonderful lore and story around every corner. 

Not all demons are bad, nor are some of the other humanoid races IE orcs, elves, and dwarves; however, that doesn't mean that they're all good either. There will be a lot of trial and error when you play this game. Sometimes you'll want to  take a chance, other times it may pay off to play it safe to avoid conflicts; however, don't take too long because as the number of turns you take increases, the world around you becomes more inhospitable with more enemies spawning with greater and greater strength.

EDIT: I forgot to mention, the crafting system is very deep. Certain building materials will yield different effects IE bonuses to attributes and tactical abilities, and attracting different races to your settlement to join your villagers IE dwarves, elves and etc.

21015103.review:
Thea: The Awakening is an indie 4X game developed by Muha Games. For the unfamiliar, 4X games stand for Explore, Expand, Exploit, and Exterminate, similar to the famous Civilization series. 

Gameplay revolves around developing a single outpost by exploring the surrounding areas, collecting resources, and crafting items and equipment based upon what is available to you. The 3 primary character classes: Harvester, Warrior, and Craftsman make up the trinity of the explore, harvest, build cycle that fuels the expansion of your infrastructure and power.

Combat is card based (each character is a card), and the uses of each card depend on the characters abilities. There are many ways to engage an enemy in combat; if your exploring group is weak but has strong gathering abilities you can engage in a hunting challenge instead. These alternative fighting methods are preferable because characters can only die or suffer wounds in direct combat. Death is VERY punishing, on higher difficulties with "Realism" (no duplicate buildings) it is difficult to acquire more characters, losing harvesters or craftsman can be a huge setback. 

And you will have setbacks. Thea introduces a system of random events that make each game a fresh experience. The random events are typically problems or encounters, where the player must select choices based upon the abilities of their characters. An example: a group of robbers confronts you, you can try to manipulate them through a social debate, fight them head on, or bribe them off with food and equipment. Choosing incorrectly in a higher stakes event can mean the end of your run.

This brings me to one of my favorite aspects of Thea: the level of challenge and adjustable difficulty. Nearly every aspect of game difficulty can be modified when a new game is created, anything from number of starting villagers, the difficulty of challenges, or the rate at which enemies grow stronger can be scaled from novice to expert level. Thea is a hard game in that it's easy to make mistakes that get your people killed and cripple your production, but the benefit is that you will see your progress as you improve your ability to avoid risks and adapt to what game situations you are given.

Thea: The Awakening is an enjoyable indie game and a bargain even at full price. The developers are still very active in updating the game and responding on the forums, I look forward to what else Muha will bring us.

Rather than the same old 'go there, kill that, bring me this' quests you get lovely little stories and a lot of different options.

Wrestle the boars, just hide from the black smokestorm, invite the starving would-be robbers to join you for a meal instead, follow the suspicious cat and just end up watching it play with a ball of string, or just watch the nightmare catching demon do his thing and have a good night's sleep. The atmosphere is lovely (well, gloomy but very well done) and the art just suits it nicely.

Mechanically there are a few issues, like the time it takes to properly equip your people, but the devs are very active in the forums and still working on improving the game. Gotta give em props for that.

Long story short, if you like stories and atmosphere rather than bright colourful 3d animations and cutscenes this game might just be the one for you.

You start of with a village and a few villagers, workers, gatherers, craftsmen and a number of different types of soldiers. You can craft, build and explore, research and gather.

There are randomly generated events, such as having to take cover for a curse, or having to deal with orcs that are semi hostile to you.

While only having one village causes some limitations, but opens up a great deal of thought behind your actions, do I leave my town undefended or not, do I send it out during daytime, or risk it during night where hostile mobs are more aggressive and the line of sight is very limited. 

I enjoyed my 100+ hours with this game, and I cannot wait for future updates that will improve of all systems. Easy to play, hard to master, more depth then you might think, a great game.

20913012.review:
Thea is a curious mix of turn-based strategy and survival with a combat system based on a card game, and a story and setting based on Slavic mythology. The premise of the game is that darkness fell over the world, the gods went afk and only now a hundred years later is light returning. Along with light, the gods return (the player character being one of them) and you take control over a single village plus a small band of survivors. Your goal is to discover what happened to the world and restore your full power as a god.  In reality though, the goal is to gather enough food to survive and enough warriors to not be eaten by monsters.

The gameplay looks like Civilization at first as it's turn-based and the map is a hex grid, but the comparisons soon end. You lead your band of warriors around the map, searching for resources and treasure. Along the way you encounter quests, potential allies and enemies. Success or failure then depends on a card game, with the cards either based on your skills (hunting, social, poison etc) or your warriors prowess. The card game would take a while to explain so I recommend watching some gameplay, but it's fairly intuitive. It's good fun, rewards strategy and heavily punishes mistakes. 

You also have a village to care of. Your villagers gather local resources, construct buildings and defend themselves from attack. Earning experience in the game grants you research points which can be used to unlock the means to construct new buildings, craft armour and weapons, as well as ever important recipes for food.  You'll require your warriors to bring back the rare materials needed to craft the good stuff of course. 

The game is held together with a uniquely Slavic soundtrack and a choose your own adventure style story, entirely text based. Presented each game slightly differently thanks to an impressive amount of random events. I really like the game, even if part of me wishes it could evolve further towards Civilization in an expansion.

20829663.review:
Man lenkt als gefallener Gott auf einer zufällig generierten Karte die Geschicke einer kleinen Siedlung und ein paar wenigen Dorfbewohnern, die sich entweder als Gatherer (Sammler), Crafter (Handwerker), Krieger, Heiler oder Magier spezialisiert haben. Dabei ist die Mischung entscheidend, da jeder Bewohner mit Nahrung, Schutz und Ausrüstung versorgt werden muss, aufgrund der Survival-Komponente im Spiel. Da man im Dorf zu Beginn nicht alles Sammeln oder Bauen kann, schickt man seine selbst zusammengestellte Truppe (Expedition) los, um die Gegend zu erkunden, zahlreiche Quests zu lösen und benötigte Ressourcen zu sammeln. Dabei können die Charaktere aufgrund der RPG-Elemente im Spiel mit der Zeit mit verbesserter Ausrüstung versorgt werden, die man im vielfältigen Crafting-System herstellen oder in den zahllosen Kämpfen erbeuten kann. Das Spiel führt einen zwar durch ein Tutorial wenn man möchte, aber durch die leichte Handhabung kommt man schnell rein und vertieft sich in die liebevoll gestaltete Umgebung, die sich rundenbasiert auf Hexfeldern anordnet (wie bei Civ5). Die Charaktere schließt man dabei schnell in sein Herz und ist dann umso entsetzter, wenn einer von ihnen das Zeitliche segnet. Das Kampfsystem ist in einem Karten-Modus gehalten, was meiner Meinung nach sehr innovativ und tiefgreifend ist, sodass die Kämpfe, die mit der Zeit immer anspruchsvoller werden, durch die vielfältigen Monsterdesigns nie langweilig werden. Dabei müssen sowohl das Dorf, als auch die Expeditionen verteidigt werden. Ziel des Spiels ist es, seinen Ruf als Gott in der zerstörten Welt von Thea wiederherzustellen und die Alleinherrschaft an sich zu reißen.
Fazit: 
Mir persönlich macht dieses Spiel Riesen-Spaß und ich halte es deshalb für ein sehr gelungens Indie-game, was noch viel zu wenig Beachtung findet. Kleines Manko ist, dass das Dorf seinen Einflussbereich nicht vergrößern und man eben nur ein Dorf errichten kann. Ich hoffe, dass der Entwickler diese Features noch patcht, sodass aus einem guten Titel ein hervorragendes Game werden kann. Wer auf Mittelalter-Aufbaustrategie mit RPG-Elementen steht, sollte hier unbedingt zugreifen.
8,5 / 10

20778797.review:
So I rarely write reviews as it is but this game compelled me to write something about it.
So first of all: I initially disliked the game. There were a few movement issues, some commands I didn't get, and the combat felt rather nonintuitive.
What changed was that I explored a bit more into the concept.
Combat/events are actually quite easy, once you realize how it is set up; the first card set down has initiative over the next card, damage is most likely dealt to the card immediately adjacent -although some do skip over, every single stat counts for something...and depends deeply on the event.

Survival is a bit rough for the first few moments, mostly because you are scrambling for resources. But soon enough, you start to stockpile primary food source, and start to try for secondary supplies.

People are hard to come by, so treat them kindly. Retreat is your best friend if you are facing insurmountable odds. Don't get greedy; even a medic can die. And camping beside at least one food and one fuel is an amazing way of stockpiling even more resource to send back home. But becareful to take care of the expidition too.

Don't want to spoil too much, but I absolutely recommand the game. There are a few thing about panning and buttons but they become just another quirk of the game soon enough as you become immersed in the awe-inspiring land of Thea.

20778707.review:
[b][u]Short Version[/u][/b]

An atypical blend of turn-based strategy and survival RPG where resource management doesn't have to play a primary role, because the player's choice is king in Thea: The Awakening. Highly customizable difficulty settings and auto-resolvable battles allow you to choose a  level of challange that suits your personal preferences. The well-presented user interface also has helpful topics that drop down when you hover over any stat or icon.

Combat is fun, refreshing and simpler than you may think. Your characters (represented by cards) are randomly placed into the offensive or defensive positions on the board, you choose positions for your offensive cards on the battle area, use your defensive cards for buffs/debuffs and then each side will auto-battle by attacking opponents at either side of them.

Becoming familiar with the large number of icons and how to gather food and resources is a learning curve, but once surpassed reveals a highly rewarding combination of exploration, crafting and encounters with many curious characters, mysterious monsters and bizarre beings. 

The main story arc is nicely voice-acted but in my opionin it's outdone by the excellent storytelling found in the numerous sidequests. Every encounter is accompanied by beautiful, painterly artwork (there really ought to be an artbook of some form available). The high-quality soundtrack is very easy on the ears, a nice fit for the fantasy theme.

For anyone on the fence about this due to the strategic/management/4x elements: just go fot it. Thea: The Awakening is the most rewarding, enjoyable RPG I have experienced on PC for a long while.


[b][u]Longer Review[/u][/b]

If you're interested in reading an extended review with screenshots click [url=https://www.bobmanbob.com/games/thea-the-awakening-review/]here[/url]


[i]This game was provided to me for review purposes. The opinions expressed above were not influenced by this.[/i]

20608444.review:
This is my first review ever - so please forgive me its flaws. I never considered writing a review however I am so delighted with this game it would be unfair to developers not to express in this modest way my appreciation for their creation. But enough with the intro.
	
Game is simple yet complex. It is somehow combination of Banished (survival in harsh and unfriendly environment, where you need to take close eye on resources and food), Civilization (hex based map with nice 3D elements and player-world interaction and turn-based mechanics) and card game (all encounters are resolved via card based tactical mechanic). Plus many elements of RPG.

What is most important to me and what makes this game unique is beautifully created world based on Slavic mythology with interesting and well refined story line, together with random side quests and events. It is obviously not a big production with high budget - yet game has something in it that makes you stay with it for one more turn, and then another, and another...

To sum up:

Pros:[list]
[*] Big, interesting world based on Slavic mythology
[*] Refined story line, side quests and random events
[*] Pantheon of Slavic gods from who you can chose your patron - it has influence on your game
[*] Card based encounters which encourages player to focus on tactic and development of his expedition forces
[*] Many possibilities of item crafting 
[*] RPG well combined with strategy and tactic
[/list]

Cons: [list]
[*] It consumes much more of your time that you would think...
[*] At some point encounters with monsters are too easy when your squad is big enought and properly equipped
[*] Sometimes world is created in frustrating way when you need to spend a lot of turns to get anywhere - basically you need to start a new game because of it
[*] Magic aspect in the game especially when it comes to characters is unfortunately neglected (perhaps a good idea for a dlc)
[*] Limited village development possibilities
[*] I am really trying but can't find much more...
[/list]

If you enjoy this type of strategy, tactic and hex map based games, and most of all you enjoy fantasy games - this game is a definitive must-have. 

I hope developers will create some additional content, either a bigger DLC or expansion - game most certainly has a potential for further development. Fingers crossed!

Cheers.

This is an enjoyable game, the voice acting is well done if not a bit cheesy. Graphically it is ok, although the static artwork is fantastic. The quest system is good with interesting quests and side-quests. Once you get used to the combat system it opens up a wide range of tactics and makes you think.

Pros: 4X (Civ like)
         Turn based
         Quests are good, no kill # rats or fetch/deliver this (although you do on one quest have to deliver a few items as
         part of the quest-line, can forgive that).
         You can aquire others races as followers, not more than one of each as far as I know.
         You have only one settlement, if you don't like multi-tasking. Creates the image of a last hope.
         Unlockable gods with levelling.
         "Fun" element, the game keeps you on your toes with random events and you trying to balance resource 
         collection, defence of your settlement and exploration.

Cons: 4X (Civ like)
          Turn based
          You can only have one settlement, although you do send out expeditions but no mutli-bases. 
          Unlocking the gods can have you restarting often as you try to raise your xp from 190/200 just to get a new god.
          "Fun" element, things are going great then Wham! a random event CAN upset your game, plans, etc.
          The pure ******* frustration of unlocking a needed resource, e.g. a tier 2 item of which the tier 1 is not near or 
          even found near you starting spot, only to find it "spawns" 5+ turns of travel away from you.

There are many ingredients in this soup that you will recognise, but the way they are put together is purely magical. giving a truly unique experience that is not just a gimmick, but the template of a very enjoyable game.

Because of this game having a different slant on game-play it takes a little learning, but that time spent will be well worth your time.

It's a survival game, a RPG, a crafting game, a game of exploration.  It's a card game, a strategy game, and a game immersed in lore, there is no soup quite like it

20503217.review:
I like card games and I like turn-based strategy so this caught my eye.  It's a fresh approach to the 4x category and holds together well.  The support team are very active being a big plus.  I had wondered about its long term appeal but the fact you can select certain options to cater the difficulty is something I really like as you can cater the game to just the right level which helps. 

A few small changes will need to keep happening as the game goes on to smooth out small bumps but for 20 euro it's a good buy.

20496632.review:
Info:
====================
The hours played shown on my profile do not reflect how much I really played because you can play this game without Steam! In fact I played around 20 hours by now.


Rating:
====================
So far it is a beautiful and great game! It is complex and a fantastic mix of RPG and Survival. I love this game beside it's shortcomings I'll talk more about next. I refrain from repeating all the good that can be said about this game and has already been said hundredths of times here in the review section by others. If you want to know more about why exactly this game is so great please read theses reviews. If I could rate it by stars I would give it 4 stars out of 5. The fifth it would get if the following issues I have with the game would get fixed. 


Constructive Feedback:
====================
1. UI Shortcomings
1.1. General UI Shortcomings
The UI is in dire need of some tweaking! The player has too much to click to get an overview and to do certain things. Another thing is the radial menu, it is often in the way of where I want to click leading to the click getting not recognized. Beside that I realized is that the UI is not consistent e.g. you can move your party via right click and drag but when you choose to move your party via the radial menu you have to left click on the target. One more thing that is irritating that you can't double click on things like towns and parties or whatever to open their dialogue windows like inventory and so on.
1.2. Quest Information
When hovering with the mouse over a quest marker on the map it should show a short quest description. Clicking on a quest marker on the map should open the quest window showing the latest information for that quest. Besides that the quest marker should indicate the difficulty of the quest like encounters are marked with skulls. Additionally the skull should be color coded for the different kind of fighting challenges so that the player can easily see that for example this one quest is a 3 skull social challenge and so on.
2. Repetitive Art Usage
Character portraits and character names get used repetitively leading to characters having the same name or character portrait. However, the user can at least change the name of the characters. Even better would be if a character name generator would be incorporated and if the user could use his own custom character portraits.

20478814.review:
其实是发在别的网站的安利，直接贴过来了

游戏的大方向算是一个生存游戏：你管理着一个村子里的若干村民，让他们在荒野中找到各种原材料建设村庄，击败各种各样入侵的敌人和怪物，在生存下来的同时寻找大灾变的线索。“不就是生存游戏嘛，老子玩得多了”就在你自信满满的开始探索世界收集材料的时候，怪物找上了你。于是这游戏画风一变，变成了卡牌游戏。是的，你没看错，卡牌游戏。


咱万智牌游戏王炉石打了一万年，区区卡牌游戏难得倒我？当你坐下来开始打牌时，发现事情又有不一样。这卡牌游戏根本不是一个公平的卡牌游戏：敌人噼里啪啦甩出十几张牌，你手上却只有五六张。敌人攻击力几十血量上百，你的攻击力个位数血量十点出头，卧槽这游戏玩个毛线。

到了这时候你终于明白，这游戏原来是个养成游戏：学会了哥的运营，剩下的只要A过去就好了。当你在对手面前噼里啪啦甩出十几张牌时，你也会有一种“哈哈哈不服来咬我啊”的爽快感。然而你很快发现：如果在前一场战斗里受了伤，下一场战斗的时候你的血量就不满了。如果你在前一场战斗里死了人，后面的战斗里就再也不会有这张牌了。卧槽我玩炉石的时候没听说过这张牌死了以后就从牌组里删掉啊？

好吧这其实是个Rougelike类游戏(当然还是可以简单SL的)，虽然战斗方式披上了一层卡牌的外衣，但实际上那些卡牌都是你手下的村民，伤了就是伤了死了就是死了。作为一个生存游戏死人倒算不上什么奇怪的事情，可是我这个人属于比较纠结的类型：如果游戏里的俩步兵都叫“步兵”，那么我让他们去死不会犹豫；但是如果俩步兵一个叫比尔一个叫盖茨，他们中死了一个我就会相当郁闷的读档重来。这游戏恰好属于后者，每个村民都有名字，所以我只好不断读档避免死人，话说祭出SL大法的时候这游戏就不能叫Rougelike了吧

单从前面所列举的每一个游戏类型的角度来看，Thea都没有对相应系统挖掘深入太多。生存部分和专业的生存游戏相比应该是非常简化(我并没玩过生存游戏不对请指正)，卡牌部分也并不是一个平衡的卡牌对战系统，Rougelike部分不开铁人居然可以读档……但是组合起来配合上一个故事情节后就具有了相当的魔力。随着冒险的深入，你从信息的碎片中逐渐发现了灾难的真相，同时各个不同的势力为了各自的理由想要拉拢你……为了自己的神？为了人类？还是为了崭新的世界？大灾变带来的漫漫长夜已经过去，你的选择将决定Thea的走向。明天的Thea将会迎来怎样的黎明？

20472118.review:
Dieses Spiel ist der absolute Geheimtipp. 

Ich kann dieses Spiel jedem empfehlen, der rundenbasierte Strategie, Survival, Crafting und Kartenspielkämpfe...oder auch nur eines davon mag.

Dieses Spiel wirkt wie von einem AAA Studio gemacht und beinhaltet so viel. Die Geschichten, die man erlebt. Den Horror, den man manchmal durchstehen muss. Die harten Kämpfe und die Möglichkeit auch durch soziale,intellektuelle etc. Herausforderungen voran zu kommen, ist einzigartig.

Um es mal in einer Por/Contra Liste zu zeigen:

Pro:
-unglaublich viele Gegner, die alle unterschiedlich sein können (von Werten etc.)
-super Storytelling
-8 Anfangsgötter, die bestimmte Vorteile bieten und einen speziellen Quest
-schwierig. Und ich meine das auf Normal. Wenn man nicht lädt, kann einem das Spiel vernichten. ABER nicht ZU schwer und ZU unnachgiebig. Eine klasse Herausforderung, die sich im Laufe des Spiels steigert und sich anpasst
-das Craftingsystem. Man kann unglaublich viele Dinge bauen über unglaublich viele Materialien, die die Dinge immer besser werden lassen.
-das "Forschungs"system oder "Advancementsystem". Es gibt so viele DInge, die man erforschen kann und am besten sollte man sich spezialisieren, denn es dauert sehr lange alles zu erforschen (es macht aber spaß immer neue Dinge zu craften, damit man weitere Fortschrittspunkte erhält)
-Eure "Dorfbewohner"(Helden) leveln permanent mit jeder Aktion.
-sehr viele Quests
-düstere Stimmung in einer super Atmosphäre mit super Musik (slawische Mythologie)
usw. usw....

Contra:
-das Einzige, was mir negativ aufgefallen ist, ist dass jeder Gott die gleiche Hauptquest besitzt, die im Endeffekt zu einer Siegbedingung führt .
--> (man kann sie ignorieren und die allgemeinen Bedingungen (Fortschritt, Dorfbewohnerzahl, teure Gebäude etc.) erfüllen). 
Es liegt vielleicht an begrenzten Mitteln des Studios, wäre aber für JEDEN Gott eine andere Geschichte/Kampagne vorhanden, wäre das wohl mit unter den besten Spielen, die ich je gespielt habe.

Es ist SO schade, dass dieses Spiel so wenig Beachtung bekommt, nur weil die Grafik nicht SUPER ist (sie ist aber absolut stimmig und passend) oder wegen anderer seltsamer Gründe. 

Ich hoffe trotzdem darauf, dass dieses Spiel noch VIELE Erweiterungen (möglichst schnell, bitte :D) erhält. Neue Quests/jeder Gott eine eigene Story. Mehr von Allem halt!

Ich lege dieses Spiel, das übrigens zu einem extrem günstigen Preis zu erhalten ist (Preis/Leistung), jedem ans Herz. Anfangs muss man mit den ganzen Möglichkeiten zurechtkommen, aber dann wird man gefesselt und taucht immer tiefer ein in Thea: The Awakening.

!!!HYPE!!! :P

P.s.: Das Spiel besitzt natürlich eine gewisse Niveaustufe (Verwaltung der Dinge im Spiel wird nicht aufgezwungen und muss selber erledigt werden und man muss wissen, welcher Herausforderung man sich stellen kann). Es ist also nichts für Leute, die ALLES vorgegeben kriegen wollen und ein easy-going Spiel haben wollen (was ich gerade so EXZELLENT in der Zeit der "Fast-food" Spiele finde)
