20387746.review:
Thea: The Awakening is a breath of fresh air in the, most times stale, 4X genre. You aren't trying to deal with unruly civ AI asking for peace then declaring war next turn. Almost the entire world is against you and that's just the way it is. You aren't trying to build the biggest army to steamroll your enemy. You're trying to keep a ragtag group alive and strong enough to hold back the darkness. It doesn't ask you to send colonists all over the map trying to found new cities to build your empire. It gives you a handful of people and one small village to protect- and protect is the key word. 

The "combat" mechanic is a card game that takes each individual's skill and equipment and creates a series of either tactical actions or sends them into the front lines to fight, hopefully to be boosted by your tactical hand. And this is where the protect idea comes in. At first, the enemies are easy and automating the fight guarantees a win. But then you run up against your first three skull. Then four. Then five. You can't just automate everything, you have to actually play the game. Then you see just how easy it is to lose everything with a bad hand. 

The characters are individuals each with their own strengths and weaknesses that need to be monitored and cared for. Each skill affects a variety of different types of card games: tactical, hunting, social, etc. These are all benefitted by different skills. A cadre of warriors is great until you run into a magic demon you can't just swing a sword at. You start to feel the loses when one person dies, carefully camping and hoping the medic does their job. Losing children from your village can set you back, leaving you outnumbered and overrun in a couple turns. The world feels like it's pressing in on your little band, and it makes sure you feel every hit. 

Now, the story? It's interesting. The actual main plot line is well-voiced and has a rather ecclectic cast. Creatures from Slavic mythology play a huge part in the events on Thea, most of that part being to bathe in your blood. It weaves a fascniating tale showing the downfall of your world and offers abundant morale choices leaving you to wonder if the world really should be reborn. Who knows. It's up to you. My only complaint is that the story, however good, is really only entertaining to listen to once or twice. By your fifth restart- and yes, you will restart that many times and more afterwards- it gets boring and you really just want to move it along. That being said, you won't always get the same side missions each playthrough. Some will appear in one play then never again. Many will appear multiple times in a single run. And all are more than worth it.

Finally, there is the gods. You are cast in the role of one of the disenfranchised gods, hoping to spread just a little light on your poor followers and guide them in this world. Your experience and restarting matters though as each play collects experience that levels the god up to activate new bonuses for your next playthrough, greatly encouraging replaying the same god over just to get that next perk. Again, the complaint here is that experience is hard to come by and it can take a long time to get a level up depending on how hard you fight, what you research, and what your rarest item is, which can net you a hefty amount of points. 

This game has my whole-hearted recommendation. If you love the idea of a card-combat game, 4X, or are just looking for something new to wet your whistle, this game with provide everything you need. Combat has a small learning curve, but, once you get it, it can easily become the best part of the game; micromanaging is simple and watching your little tribe of nothings grow into powerful warriors, craftsmen, and gatherers is rewarding and feels worth it; and watching the world of Thea open at your fingertips is astoundingly beautiful.

20365748.review:
Not sure if my review will help anyone but here goes, I like this game because it is very different from anything I have played so far,  I guess this would be a mix of Magic the Gathering (computer game) , Colonization and maybe those choose your own adventure games from Steve Jackson (those books from the 80s...)

I will say that I did play this game till 4 am a few times so it means it was addicting for me,  the game was a bit short however (I beat it on easy though) but I am sure the developers will crank out more of these games with more extended game play.  I do know some folks playing this again on harder levels so I guess you can play this for the replayability but to go back to the game review,  it is a Slavic mythology exploration game with the opportunity for a bit of base building and party development but everything is a bit limited in scope as in the base building isn't too complex and the management of your exploration party isn't all that fancy like regular rpg games.

I mentioned magic the gathering and I may have to apologize for that as I cannot think of any other example of how the combat system works with the card system but every fight encounter involves cards and how you place them during combat, so it might throw some people off on this kind of game play but anyhow overall , the game is pretty damn good, I think mostly due to the presentation (mythology)  , the voice and music in the game, and the story line isn't bad at all, much better than some other games I have bought that were more expensive such as Diablo 3...   

I also mentioned MTG the computer game because that was how you played it, you would go around the 2D map encountering monsters or dungeons etc.. and fight with cards and win or lose cards based on that.

I guess if you suck at CS:GO kind of games (like me) and you want a slower pace game hehe, then this game is for you :D

20358096.review:
В фентезийном мире, основанном на славянской мифологии произошла катастрофа и большая часть человечества погибла. Вы управляете небольшой деревней, обитателям которой удалось выжить после этой катастрофы. Выбираете покравительствующее божество (среди прочих есть Перун, но только если получите его благосклонность и выполните соовтетствующие ачивки спустя много сыгранных игр). В этом игра похожа на Циву, за исключением того что вы управляете только одним городом. Как и в Цивилизации, необходимо получать доступ к ресурсам, самые нужные и редкие из которых могут находится вдали от поселения -- за ними вы экипируете и отправляете в экспедицию дружину, прорываясь сквозь орды лесных чудищ (бои в стиле коллекционных карточных игр), попутно исследуя интересные места, выполняя квесты и исследуя прекрасный фентезийный мир (карта случайно генерируемая и каждый раз разная)

В этой игре все что вы любите: выживание, TBS, отличный сюжет, великолепная работа художников, бои в стиле ККИ, великолепный сеттинг.

Со времен Mass Effect не помню чтобы игра так серьезно затягивала. Сам Перун, узнав о ней, поставил бы ей 10 коловратов из 10!

20302369.review:
[i]Key supplied by developer for review.[/i]
[h1]======================================[/h1]
[h1][b]Thea: The Awakening[/b][/h1] (Read on for the full review!)
[h1]======================================[/h1]

[h1]TL;DR:[/h1]

Being part strategy-game, part board-game, part RPG, part survival game, and more; Thea: The Awakening is a charming, qualitative, and refreshing addition to its many genres that has something to offer almost everyone. This game is absolutely worth your time.

[h1]======================================[/h1]

[h1][b]Pros:[/b][/h1]
+ Graphics: Familiar, cozy, easy on the eyes. Runs well.
+ Audio: Simple, effective sound effects. Great music.
+ Narration: Very good. Reminds me of old P&C/hidden object adventures.
+ Tutorial: Extensive, simple, not as daunting as you would expect.
+ Genres: A well executed mishmash of genres is always a plus!
+ Depth: There is a multitude of mechanics, events, and playstyles.
+ Controls: Efficient hotkeys and mouse interaction once acquainted.
+ Story: Fun, well written lore, dialogue, and events.
+ File Size: A game with few assets that uses them well. Small and quick download.
+ Progression: Whether research, equipment, or units, the 'RPG' mechanics are fun.
+ Bugs: What bugs?
+ Everything else.

[h1][b]Cons:[/b][/h1]
- ...Uh...um...hm...*scratches head*

[h1][b]Neutral:[/b][/h1]
+/- Hover elements in UI like to stick, queuing of actions is hit and miss. No big deal.

[h1]======================================[/h1]

[h1][b]Introduction:[/b][/h1]
Hello and welcome to Thea; the most badass thing you've ever looked at! While not truly a 3X or 4X game, it has a lot going for it, and that is going to be the most easily made comparison in terms of how it feels and plays. Let's dive into more detail.

[h1][b]Gameplay:[/b][/h1]
In Thea: The Awakening, you are a freshly awakened deity, powers diminished, desperately clinging to your hold to this world and your followers, so your goal is to lead your followers to victory and establish your place in the world once again. You start with a nice, simple tutorial to get you going with actual experiential learning, while the help text that will pop up along the way will provide more in-depth information on the mechanics involved. You start with a set amount of villagers, on a set difficulty, with two of the gods to pick from. Each god or godess has their own bonuses, which are unlocked through gaining experience in your campaigns with them.

Both movement and combat are turn-based, with movement being tile or hex-based, and combat being card-based. If you don't want to optimize your combat results, or deal with the tedium, you can have the game auto-resolve it for you. You can gather two materials at your village, a food and building material, and you can send an expedition party out to gather specific materials while camping. Materials enable you to construct, cook, and craft. Your expedition party is a major part of your progression, though, as they are primarily how you fight, loot, and encounter events...all of which can provide you with more advanced or rare materials. It doesn't end there, though! Villagers can also progress individually, gaining stats as they level up, and better equipment will only serve to augment this growth.

There are many ways in which you can choose to deal with the start of your game, as there are many options for gathering materials. When a child grows into a villager, you can choose what their specialty will be, and you can even pick a default focus for your village when starting the game. Of course, you are going to need some of everything to progress, but this game is still friendly to multiple playstyles. It is also possible to get through encounters without "fighting," which can offer greater rewards, and less risk to your adventurers.
As a Torment fan, all I can say is: awesome.

Most of the options you choose to respond to an event with in Thea will involve combat, though, because you still have to 'battle' your way through sickness, social diplomacy, traps, sneak attempts, etc. The combat is tactical, card-based, and fun. You have two phases in which you place your cards in your most ideal order, left to right, and then two fight phases where damage is dealt in that order. You have plentiful options for how you want to go about doing this, from control, disable, buff, and debuff. At times this can be very fun, especially when an evenly matched enemy throws out a curveball or a good turn, and you have to respond well to get through it. At other times, you have a relatively strong party fighting a relatively weak party. Thankfully, you can auto-resolve the combat in these types of situations.

There is an impressively massive array of creatures, equipment, materials, events, points of interest, entertaining things to read, and options in this game; and all of it makes for a wildly engaging, fun, tactical experience, with a skillfully intertwined list of genres to keep anyone happy. RPG-esque turn-based combat and character progression? Check. Board-based strategy and settlement progression? Check. An almost choose-your-own adventure style event system? Check. An actually engaging story concept, lore, dialogue, and event writing? Check. Resource management and survival? Check. It even approaches being able to be labeled a god game.

Thea offers something for any number of genre fans to get absorbed in, and enjoy all the while.

[h1][b]Graphics:[/b][/h1]
Between the colors, map, models, textures & FX, smooth little animations, actually immersive painterly art, and a UI that is easy on the eyes, there's little to dislike here, and whether you will like it or not will be readily apparent from a few screenshots.

[h1][b]Audio:[/b][/h1]
Not only is it very good and fun, but I've yet to find the background music to get repetitive. Sound effects such as attacking or event notices are satisfying. Narration is not only nostalgic, but qualitative. There is also very little you could dislike here.

[h1][b]Conclusion:[/b][/h1]
Unless you are an FPS, real-time combat, or action combat purist, this is a game that offers so much for such a small price. I can easily recommend it at full price. I would still recommend it at full price if it was 60 dollars.

[h1]======================================[/h1]
If you like my reviews, you can easily keep up with them [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/nonreviews]here.[/url]
[h1]======================================[/h1]

A great little game, and a real gem of 2015.  This game offers a great storyline, whith some variation depending on your deity choice at the start.

The game is a resource management and questing turn based stretegy but conflict resolution is with a very intersting card based challenge system.  These cards are modified by character types, equipment and stats all which combine to give a huge variety of customisation of your characters.

The game is also quite brutal, many of your characters will die along the way.  This is the kind of game where demons sweep down at night and steal all your children and eat them, or your community is crippled by plague, disease, curse, or ... insert your favourite pestilance here...

With a randomly generated map every game is different, and resource placement on that map means wach game is a different challnge.

For fans of the genre there are hundreds of hours of gameplay here without being overly repeptetive.  The game could use more quests for sure, but there are plenty enough for a few replays.

4/5 - Loved it.

20236126.review:
Sadly, very sadly I cannot recommend this.
I bought this because I thought it would be a nice blend between civilizations and RPG, and it is somewhat in that direction, true, but unfortunately there is SO. LITTLE. CONTENT.
I had great fun for the first 10 hours, enjoyed the next 5 hours, but after that I only wanted to win a game and see if there's more to it, but again sadly there isn't.

City:
You can build buildings (about 10 different ones) which all either boost a stat of people IN YOUR CITY (so it doesn't benefit your warriors roaming around the map) and/or give a chance for a new citizen to join you.
You can craft objects; different weapons, armours and crafting/gathering tools, also different kinds of food.
You can assign people to gather nearby resources ONLY in the 6 Hexes directly around your city, which may or may not have anything at all on them (random)
and... that's mostly it. There are sometimes random events like storms, demons which might be nice or naughty, or rites and festivals, in these you mostly have different options to choose from, which will give different results, but there are waaay to few of these to be interesting longer than a few hours.

Expedition:
Most of your gameplay will be your Expeditions. You form them in your City, you can send however many and whomever you want out. You need to give them food (else they take damage each turn) and fuel (else they cannot heal when they make camp), and preferably weapons and armor, as they will fight all the time. Out on the Map you encounter enemies which you can kill (or defeat through other means, like diplomacy or tactics) and different random events like a lone elven wanderer that may join you after you help them out, or a frosty queen and her escort which will send you on a quest.
You can make camp with your expedition, which allows your people to gather ressources from the 6 surrounding Hexes and heals them faster.
There IS a main-story, and quite some backstory if you are willing to read a lot of text, however I didn't find it intriguing enough to keep reading after the first 10 hours.

Bonus Hate:
Events sometimes let you trade items with travelers, but what you give them is ALWAYS RANDOM. So you might give your best weapon away for something useless, or you may offer someone fuel, and instead of giving them normal firewood you give them extremely rare ancient wood instead.

tl;dr:
TOO LITTLE CONTENT
if you're fine with 20 hours of fun, I DO recommend this!
If you want more, get something else.

Also I have to say that the combat is VERY well made, once you get behind it. It is less random than many people say, the trick is that you have to get the initiative and plan from there ;)

20034844.review:
Wow, this game really struck me like thunder. From the pictures and video's on the steam page, you might think it's just another 4x like Civilization or one of the many clones, but this is something different entirely.

The more oldschool players here might remember a title called "King of Dragon Pass". Like that game, in Thea your goal is to help your village survive by interacting with the world around it. You have to send out explorers, all the while managing your village growth and resources.

Some things this game absolutely did right:

- Crafting 
The crafting system is very dynamic, where you get to use the materials you manage to conquer off the land to build buildings, armor and weapons. The amazing part is that the result differs per item you use. For example, if you build a watch tower with monster bones, you gain less vision, but the chance to attract animals to your village. The same way, different materials become different armours, and you can even add gems for a random bonus on the result.

- Challenges
That is what the combat is called in this game, and rightly so it is much more than combat. It is a challenge. Your characters get lain across the table as cards, and so do the enemy's. From here on there are many ways to resolve the conflict, in a very tactical manner. This challenge is also the result of alternate conversation/discovery options, where it is not always about fighting, but sometimes a battle of Will, or Speech, or Stealth. For me, it doesn't get old or repetitive.

I aim to update this review later as i make more hours into the game.

19978352.review:
A 4x Turn-Based game where you have only one city and your units are survivors with varied skills.  Your goal is to survive a hostile monster overrun world.  To do that you must gather resources that will allow you to build up your city and craft better gear for your survivors to equip.  You will have to balance sending units out on adventuring expeditions to gather resources and experience or leave them at your city to protect it and upgrade it.  The number of units available to you is very limited they are your main resource but there is no way to regularly produce them you may build upgrades that will increase the chance of units finding there way to your town and you may acquire them through events but the same events may also kill them off.   There seem to be a good number of different events and each of them has different methods of approach or retreat.   My party came upon the path of a black cat and chose to follow, it ended with my healer in a witches kettle, We fell into a cave after a cave in and chose to explore rather then try to climb out, down the path we went right at the fork and ran into a dragon, we chose to run for our lives and not attempt to steal from it or attack it.

   Combat and other event challenges are done in the form of card duels, the cards represent each of your survivor units and the card abilities vary depending on their gear and stats. A combat event can lead to the death of your unit but there are ways to mitigate that possibility, Challenge events may some times be done instead of combat  your characters will be safe from death but will likely receive less reward.

   When you start the game you select one of several fallen deity, most of them require some kind of accomplishment to unlock, each can be leveled up and provides different starting bonuses and seemingly have a series of events related specifically to them.  


  The tutorial is somewhat helpful but also bugged the dialog to instruct me on the next turn button came up after I hit next turn and indicated it was the third dialog in the chain, I hit the go back button on the dialog to review what I had missed and the game had not gone to next turn yet and the game froze there.  On my first combat the tutorial dialog came up and indicated it was 1 of 20 I hit the next button and it vanished only to reappear many game hours later after I had already gone through many advanced fights, it let me then go through the no longer needed dialog.
     
    This is a very entertaining game recommended to fans of Fantasy, Strategy, Turn-Based, Party Management, Exploration and Variation.

 I have nominated this for best implemented multiple tag game.  What I mean by this is they way they have perfectly combined elements of RPG, card game, 4x, rogue like, survival, crafting, choices matter.

I'm very much enjoying this game, despite some flaws. I don't think it's for everyone though. 

[b]Pros[/b]
+Highly customizable difficulty levels
+Challenging gameplay
+Good variety in types of gameplay
+High replay value (at least until completion, see below)
+Pretty good soundtrack

[b]Pros/Cons[/b]
+/- Very punishing for small mistakes
+/- Auto-resolve feature almost always succeeds on lower level challenges (I personally love this)

[b]Cons[/b]
-Repetitive gameplay in the challenges
-Poorly written dialogue / quests
-Initiative queue at times very arbitrary and frustrating
-Lack of endgame content

[b]Post-completion rambling / final thoughts[/b]
The game has quite a few annoying and/or frustrating aspects but honestly the good outweighs the bad generally. The main problem I have, is that all motivation for replays sort of dies down after you've beaten the game once. I played on moderate difficulty settings (125%-165% usually) and needed quite a few attempts to actually beat the game. Not lastly because I usually restarted after losing an important villager. This didn't bother me, as I would immediately get back to it and try to beat the main quest with another group. Once I had actually done that however, there wasn't really anything interesting to do. I had a huge, fairly high level group, pretty good equipment and all the buildings so the only thing left to do was run around the map and clear hives / enemies, which frankly feels a bit pointless after a while. Of course you can then do another run with a different god but the gods don't really differ too much, apart from a few perks, so why bother? 

Anyway, I had 60 hours of (mostly) fun with this game for ridiculously little money, as I bought in on sale. Would easily have been worth the 20€ they ask for normally. 

Generally, don't buy it if:
-You're specifically looking for a great story or fantasy universe
-You have a low tolerance for frustration
-You don't like calculating damage values (pretty much the main thing you'll be doing in all challenges)

Otherwise, definitely recommended.

The in-game tutorial is not good, but the in-game help section quite makes up for that.  The combat system is difficult to understand for beginners and is . . . well shallow isn't quite the right word, maybe "limited" because once you have loads and loads of people/cards it's very difficult to lose.  (edit:  it's a struggle for survival on harder difficulties so . . . not necessarily easy to get to that point)

A really fantastic game. You can tell it was a labour of love, and that the developer's put a lot of thought into mechanics and gameplay.


Despite the amount of effort they've put in though, they slacked on one key detail: UI.

I've found that my major frustrations rarely, if ever, come from gameplay mistakes. It comes from navigating menu after menu to do simple tasks like analyze my party's equipment and stats. You have to constantly switch items between parties, click through each and every party member to see their equipment, there is no 'skip animation' setting for the combat, which can get drawn out and annoying after a while. 'Overview' menus for equipment and stats (a menu JUST for party stats would be great, actually), combining inventory and equipment.

The gist of it is: streamline menus. The combat can be dicey for some people, but I really enjoy it. The lore is really well done. Graphics are on par with a normal 4x game, audio could use a little more variety. Some bugs, but not overly rampant. 

The core of this game is solid as diamond, just a little bit more polishing and this could easily be goty.

19842801.review:
When I first got this game, I wasn't expecting much. An RPG element game with a card based battle system. Done before, and most of them are mediocre at best, with bland card combat, so I wasn't expecting much, but it got good reviews, so I might as well try. 

Am I glad I did... I cannot suggest this game enough. 

Thea: The Awakening puts you into a darkened world,  where the underworld has leaked into the world. Consuming, and darkening everything it touches. You're task is to survive, and take your small band of people into an adventure to reverse this. 

The game itself is beautifully balanced, with an awesome music track that sets the tone, and feel to the rest of the game and art style. 

[b]Managing your people and town[/b]

Unlike other 4x games, this one truly makes you feel like you're struggling to survive in a world that's quickly falling apart, and turning on you. 

You start with a small village with only a few people, and a few warriors. The Gatherers gather the goods around the town, the crafters make whatever it is you sent them to do, and the warriors of course protect them. However, what sets this apart from most 4x games, is that again, it's set to feel like you're a small band of people struggling to survive. 

Resources are scarce, your village influence range around your town does not expand, and you don't build new towns either. To properly gather the resources you need to build things, you will need to make adventurer parties with a few warriors, and gatherers, maybe a witch and healer, and find the resources you need, setup camp, and gather, then bring them back to your village. 

[b]Crafting and your people[/b]

In Thea: The Awakening each person is their own. You can give them equipment, see their individual stats, and what makes them them. As I mentioned before, resources are scarce, and rare, and therefore planning is needed for the future of your people. Who's going to be what, and where are they going to be going. A gatherer you plan to bring out in an expedition for resources will need better protection than a pitch fork and shirt. 

Another wonderful addition to the game is the kids. Kids will randomly appear and be born, who will then grow into adults. Once they hit adult hood you can choose if they will be a warrior, crafter, or gatherer. On a random RNG roll you may also get a special option of something else, such as a witch, medic or one of the other specialties. These are rare however so you can't plan on them, but are always a welcome addition. 

The fact the game simulates a true hardship of surviving in a dieing world being overtaken by darkness, the death of any of your members can be a real blow. Deaths are permenant, and you will need to bolster your ranks should you lose someone. They will take time to level up, grow, and become strong like the one you lost.

This to me is a very welcome addition as well over other 4x games where a loss is no big deal and "I'll just make another one". In this game, just waiting for a new kid to gain a new warrior is only a band aid on the warrior or high experienced member you lost. 


[b]Battle System[/b]

The battle system is card based, however there are multiple ways to "fight" depending on the situation, and party members. Hunts, Negotiations, Hex's, Combat, are just a few. Each type of "Battle" determines your members cards stats, depending on the type of battle it is. 

This is very important when constructing a party, and just adds to the depth of RPG element to the game. If you build a party with nothing but warriors, and you attempt to hunt, or negotiate your way out of a situation, you'll find your cards suddenly have no damage, and little health, because the stats are not going off of strength, weapons, armors, and  health, but instead off of speech, and mind of that particular person. 

The card battle system itself is very well setup, and has quite alot of strategy and depth once you get into it, and understand all its aspects. Different weapon types, armors, etc. all effect the battle, and the card of that person in battle, and may even give them special abilities. 

Damage taken in the battles is realistically simulated outside of the fight. The lower health your member is after the battle, the more chance the bleeding will be severe enough for them to die from their wounds if you aren't careful. Every turn there's a chance they don't heal, and instead lose health. This can be countered by camping the party, and making sure you have enough fuel(wood) and food to properly tend to them. However if they got out of the fight with only a few hitpoints remaining, there's still a small chance you could lose them. 

[b]Conclusion[/b]

Thea: The Awakening is a great RPG game, with a real feel of conflict, and struggle in a dark world. The smaller size of your settlement, and party allows you get a connection with your people in a way, as you grow them, and give them equipmnt, and give them a spot in the society you're building. Watching one die can be a real blow in many ways, as you dishearteningly replace them with a new member who just grew to age. 

One big mis step could see your entire party quickly hastening from a very dangerous area as they struggle to make it back to the village after a brutal battle, bleeding, and desperately low on health, unable to make camp due to the number of hostile enemies surrounding them, as turn after turn a few more die along the way, just hoping you can make it back to the village to save the rest.

19834310.review:
気付いたらsteam上で一番長くプレイしたゲームになりました。

★どんなゲーム？
見た目はCiv4(FfH)やAge of wonders、Endless Legendなどのファンタジー4x、中身はサバイバルRPGな感じのゲーム。
各地に探索隊？を送り、資源を収集したりモンスターの巣などを破壊したりしながら経験値や研究ポイントをため、収集した材料で拠点を拡張させたり武具を作成したりしながら戦力を整えていきます。一連のメインクエストを終了させるか、一定のレベルまで勢力を発展させるとクリア。

★自分的に好きな要素
収集や武具の作成が楽しいです。各地を回って資源採取やそれを使って武具などを作成するのもまた楽しい。同じ物でも使う材料により能力が違ったり、宝石を混ぜることで更にランダムな効果が付与されます。
またモンスター（Civとかでいう蛮族みたいなもん）に対していろんなアプローチの仕方があります。Fightだけではなく、SocialやHuntingなどで、その解決方法によって求められる能力が違います。なので、いわゆる戦士だけのパーティじゃなくてもモンスターに対処することが可能なんですね。失敗したら結局力推しになるんですが。
あとプレイヤーは神なんですが、失った能力を取り戻すという目的があって、最初に選べるのは二人（？）だけ。また最初は弱っちい特殊能力しか使えません。クリアしたり、詰んでやり直したりするごとに神自体に経験値が蓄積されていき、新しい神がアンロックされたり、特殊能力が解放されたり、いわゆる‘強くなってリスタート‘が可能になります。それによってあと一回、もう一回やろうという気にさせられちゃいます。
また4xは4xで好きなんですが、こういうのはこういうので張り合う相手がモンスターしかいないため、まったり出来ていいですね。とはいっても時間経過によってモンスターも強くなっていくので何もしなくていいというわけではないですが。負けず嫌いの自分としては順番つけて比べられて下の方だと萎えてもういいやーってなってくるので、個人的には好きです。ほらオセロで負けそうになると台ひっくり返す残念な子いたでしょ。・・・私です。
（あっ、念のため言っときますがもう大人なので人と対戦してる時はそんなことはしません。）

★戦闘は？
カードゲームにより解決します。人＝カードなので、人数が多ければ多いほど有利。また単純な戦闘だけではなく、SocialやSicknessなど、その他の行為判定も全て同じカードゲームで解決します。前述したようにその行為により求められる能力が変わってきますが。めんどくさい人はオートで一発解決もできます。

★英語は？
恐らくこれが一番のネック。長文多いです。選択肢も多いですしね。
参考までに、私は最初の方は読んでましたが途中からめんどくさくなって選択肢以外流し読みしてますけど私はそれでも楽しいですよっと。英文自体は英語がある程度得意な人はそんなに難しい内容ではないと思います。ただ英語が苦手な人で、物語をきっちり理解しながらやりたい人は気合いが必要。英語は出来る限り読みたくない！選択肢失敗してもいい！めんどくさいからシステム的な部分を楽しめればいい！って人はなんとかなるかなと。

アプデも頻繁にされてるし、個人的に素晴らしいゲームだと思うので気になった人は是非チェックしてください！
他の人のレビューでも同じようなこと言ってましたが、いっぱい売れてDLCで拡張いっぱい出して欲しいと切実に思った良ゲーです。

19753656.review:
Kurz nur, was ist es. 
Vieles aber doch eines ganz gewiss, ungewöhnlich.
Man leitet ein Dorf durch eine finstere Zeit damit die erstens überleben, also Resourcen sammeln und verarbeiten und zweitens die Welt und die Geheimnisse darin und darauf erkunden.
Dazu trennt man die Bevölkerung in erstens, Dorfbevölkerung die sammelt und verarbeitet und zweitens Kundschaftertrupps die erkundne und neue Resourcen finden oder ferne Resourcen einsammeln. Dabei dürfen auch gartige Monster nicht fehlen und es gibt natürlich Quests wie es in jeder Phantasiewelt halt so üblich ist.
Das könnte ein gewöhnliches Fntasy RPG-Strategiespiel sein, wie HoM&M oder AoW, oder auch Elemental. Ist es aber nicht denn es ist dafür zu ungewöhnlich. Meiner Meinung nach stellt das den Prototyp einer neuen Spieleidee dar, da es nichts zu kopieren oder verschlimmbessern versucht sondern neue Wege geht. Der Hauptaspekt der Thea: The Awakening von anderen Titek unterscheidet ist, dass man hier keine Truppen aushebt und Städte erobern muss, sondern, dass trotz Karten-Charaktersheet jeder Bewohner des Dorfes eine Persönlichkeit ist und mehrere Aufgaben haben kann und es hier vorwiegend um Überleben und Geheimnisse geht.


Thea: The Awakening hat mir erst auf den zweiten Blick gefallen, aber dann richtig gefallen.
Zunächst ist es ein wenig gewöhnungsbedürftig und das ist einer von drei negativen Aspekte:

Negativ:
- Tutorials unübersichtlich (liegt teilweise an der fehlenden Überstzung)
- Menüs umständlich, keine Minimap, unübersichtlich, viel Klickerei (was ermüdet)
- keine deutsche Übersetzung (wird aber bestimmt nachgereicht, hoffentlich)

Kommen wir zu dem was daran meienr Meinung nach so gut ist und das ist eine Menge:

Positiv
- Nachwuchs bringt nicht der Storch sondern die  Krautf und Rübenfeldern (also sehr ungewöhnliche Phantasiewelt und Atmosphere, lehnt an slawische Mythologie an)
- Permatod und zwar so, dass es nach dem Tod eines Helden nicht aus sein muss, und wenn dann ist der Neugebinn motivierend (ähnlich wie bei FTL)
- Ungewöhnliches Überlebens und Schmiedesystem, viele Resourcen die alle wichtig sind, aber keine Resource ist unersetzlich.
- Trotz Permatod geht das Spiel in die Tiefe. Man kann in Story eintauchen oder einfach versuchen sich zu verbessern, Neue Strategien austesten, alles macht Spass.
- Massig Events (leider einige davon linear, aber meist zufällig)
- KArtenspiel-Kampfsystem zwar gewöhnungsbedürftig aber unterhaltsam und doch taktisch fordernd. Es gibt zudem nicht nur Kämpfe, es können auch Diskussionen oder Schleichaktionen und vieles mehr wie Kämpfe ausgetragen werden und dann machen auch die unzähligen Skills der Helden Sinn
- Habe ich bereits erwähnt, dass es immer wieder was zu entdecken gibt ?

Ich denke die über 90% positiven Bewertungen gehen hier voll in Ordnung.

19731614.review:
一場摸了快20hr才結束，還是因為突然贏了才放棄不拚了...

RPG加上SLG，以及roguelike的不可反悔...噢這句應該說 permanent death
你扮演一個在thea生存的最後一個村莊，在黑暗籠罩整個thea大陸之後的倖存者，為了復興信仰的神而戰

如果村莊被怪物推掉，遊戲就輸了

遊戲中可以準備武器裝甲等給隊員，組成隊伍到外面探險、採集資源，回到村莊進行建設、生產裝備等

遊戲裡最重要的人力資源，同時也是遊戲的主要系統就是排隊戰
敵我雙方皆分成兩半，一邊為戰鬥組、一邊為戰術組
雙方輪流出牌，完成出牌後依照順序輪流攻擊 一方無剩餘人員時結束戰鬥

戰鬥不只有單純的格鬥戰，同時也有其他種挑戰可以迂迴的避免傷亡，有時候則會被遊戲裡大量的事件觸發特定的挑戰
但如果別種挑戰失敗，最終還是會格鬥戰，在這種戰鬥中，角色一旦被打下場成為出血狀態，在沒有治療的情況下有30%的機率會死亡
不管你角色多強，裝備多好，只要出血了就是祈禱

調整裝備應付各種挑戰、採集資源保持角色活力、生產裝備建設村莊著急更多倖存者、承受那些被掩蓋的過往者
（以及做裝備拆裝備洗研究點數...等等這是評論不是攻略）
然後不知不覺就贏了　（默）
事件部分則有一個主線要拚，每一場結束都會為能扮演的神累積經驗讓下一次遊戲能有更多的加成
固定事件相當於一個在thea發生的故事
隨機事件則是遭遇到特定的魔物襲擊，做決定並承受後果

整體來說優點就是上述部分結合起來的樂趣
缺點則是設計跟開發的問題

本身材料等級很容易搞到上限，搞懂邏輯後大概就知道要怎麼抄捷徑，後面就會只做最高等級　太容易達成了
太多過渡時期的材料，建築物實用性太低，裝備甚至有幾個類別是無用的

開發或者優化的問題，開全螢幕滑鼠會偏移，似乎一直沒修正，瀏覽地圖很容易亂跑，感受很差
音樂雖然有些很獨特，但還是會膩　尤其是戰鬥的時候很煩

以及玩一場要花太長的時間了...(咦?)

19724266.review:
I rarely review games, but felt like I owed it to the devs to post a review of this excellent title.  Thea is basically a mash up of every genre I like: 4x, CCG, RPG, strategy, etc.  The story is great, the strategy makes sense, I like the graphics.  This gets my vote for best game I've played in the past 6 months at least.  

First the good:
[list]
[*]Insanely addictive
[*]Extremely customizable challenge wise
[*]Lots of content/quests/events/things to do (I've put in 35 hours and only seen 20% of the quests)
[/list]

What I didn't like:
[list]
[*]For some reason I just wasn't as motivated the second play through; can't put my finger on it
[*]There is room to grow in the tech tree, but the devs have promised free DLCs, which I believe should address this.  
[*]End game can be too easy if you don't dial the challenge level just right
[/list]

If you're a fan of the genres I've listed above, or games like Eador, Age of Wonder III, etc, I think you'll really enjoy this game.  Grab it!

19681914.review:
I love the art sytle of the creatures, humans, elves and even the dragons. The game has a rich story and lore to it, if your like me and can get sucked into a good story based game then I highly suggest Thea. 

Its combat system might take time to get used to but in the end it is stil very well thought out in how it works. In the start you might need to play each fight yourself but once you have good gear and skills under your belt you can let the characters fend for themselves in battle without guidence, yes I know its not an AI based system but still, being who you are in the game why not take liberties of playing the role?

19681357.review:
The premise of the game is actually quite good, typical Civilizations theme with its own style and the card game system is a  mostly fun mechanic. Unfortunately for those of you who are like me and can't stand unwinnable situations or any form of RNG then you won't find much enjoyment in this.

To be a bit more specific, this game is a resource management, exploration, economy progression system, that has a card game mechanic that influences all combat (And several non-combat) situations.

Your cards have an offensive stat value that determines the damage they will deal, when you play a card and end your turn your opponent gets a turn to play a card to the right of that card, barring certain skills. The leftmost card acts first in the combat phase and when each card attacks, they can only attack the nearest card to the left OR the right. Now at first this all seems fine and fairly easy to manipulate and keep enemies attacking who you want, but it doesn't just target the nearest, it chooses a random direction, THEN targets the nearest in that direction. In other words, you may have a formation set up for best efficiency and safety if your cards all attack in the proper directions, but they choose not to and instead use their 27 damage attack to kill the 1 health 3 damage spider instead of the 26 hp 32 damage spider queen, allowing the said queen to attack next turn, killing a card of yours which wounds your character. 

Which brings me to the next subject, wounds. Wounds are fine, for the most part, until it becomes completely impossible to save a wounded character. They get a little hurt, get gravely wounded, you set up camp to keep them alive, a turn passes, they die. For seemingly no reason, my characters will die from wounds that should be healing whilst in camp and whilst having a medic. As far as I can tell there's no way to manually heal a wounded character. On a similar note, it's very much possible to run into enemies that are far beyond your power level who will just absolutely wipe the floor with you, and even if they don't SOMEONE will get wounded. Characters have to either be strong enough to win, or they will simply lose. Skill doesn't seem to have much to do with the combat and that disappoints me.

The next real negative thing would be the grind. Haven't played enough of it yet but there are several gods which each require a different god be levelled up to 3 to unlock, and you don't even get to choose who is unlocked. 

TL;DR The game has the potential to be great, but with very little control over certain situations it's hard to like it. Cards randomly choosing which way to attack and completely ruining your plans, or randomly running into an enemy you have no chance against is just demoralizing.

Pending further investigation and a little more game time, this review/recommendation is subject to change. As it stands, with the knowledge I do have of it, I would not recommend it as I feel out of control.

19666417.review:
If you like the idea of investing 5-10 hours into a game before the game engine starts having the enemy numbers increase drastically and outscale you massively with combats and events you cannot avoid, this is the game for you.

Masochists, this is your outlet.

Normal people, avoid at all costs.

It doesn't stop with the AI basically cheating to cover the lack of talent on the dev team, either.  There is one save state, and you aren't allowed to know when it is, either.  So if you hit load, you just magically load the save state from whenever it is - you can't see it before loading.  Just hitting the load button abandons your pogress and loads the save state from whenever the Hell.  

Stupid.  That's just plain stupid.  It's anti-fun, anti-player, anti-norm stupidity.

The combat/challenge mechanic is extremely weak.  Basically, if you take a normal CCG and then dumb it down to the point that you have as much chance of winning if you played with your eyes closed, that's this mechanic.  The auto-resolve is hilariously awful.  Want to lose a combat where you are 3 levels higher than the opponents and want to do it fast?  AUTO-RESOLVE!  I genuinely do not think I have ever seen an auto-resolve so bad.  It's a mini-game within the game - will you lose a gatherer that the AI decided should be the main tank?  Will the AI cause a party wipe?  PLACE YOUR BETS!

When a dev basically admits that they have no idea how to balance a game and create a logical difficulty progression, then maybe they shouldn't develop games?  Go back to the thumbscrews and whips, guys, you're better when the torture is honest.

19645174.review:
Thea: The Awakening is my current obsession. I've been playing it hours on end during my night shifts.

Who is it for: Players who love rich, mythological dark fantasy, and Slavic lore; strategy game fans; players who love exploring a new world map each game, and building up their settlement and party; fans of crafting and survival genres; players who enjoy focusing on a single settlement and each of its individual inhabitants rather than building a large empire; people who can stand disasters befalling their beloved villagers; players who love that "just a few more turns" feeling; people who like a card game element to their RPG combat; RPG fans who enjoy well-written events that can unfold in different ways at each playthrough; players who want to see gameplay elements from various genres combined in a new and clever way.

Things that should be improved: The interface needs significant fine-tuning. It's manageable, but the game lacks features to filter and sort villagers and inventory items; you can't see an expedition's condition at a glance from the world map; there aren't hotkeys for everything; it just feels clumsy at times. It may test your patience.

What it isn't: It's not a 4X game, despite what many reviews say. You don't settle more areas, and there aren't other factions competing towards the same objective with whom you can parley or wage war.

19643388.review:
This is a really strange one to write a review for as it doesn't exactly fit into any of the established categories.  This is a good thing and a bad thing at the same time.  A good thing as original thinking and ideas are very thin on the ground in the video game industry these days, so kudos in gratuitous amounts to the developers for that.  A bad thing as the developers are breaking virgin ground and whenever that happens a few unexpected sinkholes are bound to open up beneath them.  If I were to sum up the game in a few words I would say that it's a 4X game that has a couple of X's missing, that tries hard to be open world while directing you along a somewhat linear quest path.  See how confusing this is?

Some clarification is in order.  4X stands for Explore, Expand, Exploit, Exterminate.  Thea has the Explore and the Exploit part but is completely AWOL when it comes to the Expand & Exterminate.  Expand is missing as you only have a single village to look after with no mechanic available to settle new ones.  Exterminate is missing as there are no Ai opponents, just generic fantasy critters wandering around in groups that get tougher to beat as the turn count rises.  There are lairs that spawn these groups ( at least I think they spawn at the lairs ), so taking these out gives a little respite.  Then there are ruins to explore and numerous random events and encounters to either screw you over or give a boost.  As far as the 4X goes though, that's it.  The main game is supposed to revolve around you being a weakened deity trying to direct your last few followers so that you can reclaim your powers and save the world from the darkness ( shades of the neverending story ), seriously, the devs couldn't come up with something better than THE DARKNESS?  Sounds okay I suppose and at the start the game is interesting and keeps you engaged.  After a few hours though the sheen wears off and it devolves into boring inventory management, equipment swapping, gathering, etc. while you attempt to put together an expedition hard enough to take on the next part of the main quest.  Combat comes down to a card mini-game that needs a major redesign as at the moment it is barely fit for purpose and quickly gets bloated with large groups.

The game as it stands feels like an unfinished, early access offering that still needs a few mechanics adding to it, but these developers are trying to break new ground while being very active, which is a brave thing to do in the current market.  The game receives regular updates and I am recommending it as new thinking in the industry deserves to be supported.  Thea has huge potential ( how many times have we heard that before ) and my hope is that these devs will polish that hidden gem.

19631311.review:
Thea: The Awakening is a 4X survival strategy roguelike with card based resolve mechanics and strong rpg elements, and also some choose your own adventure style events and quests that happen at random. Seriously. There's a lot going on. Here's a video review of Thea based on my first impressions, or see below if you prefer to read:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=573240923

Do you like RPGs? 4X strategy? Survival games? Roguelikes? Good, because I don't know which one Thea: The Awakening is and I'm pretty sure it doesn't either. All I know is it was created by MuHa games, and features a Slavic mythology setting. The story goes that the world Thea was engulfed by by a mysterious force called The Darkness. In Thea: The Awakening, it is up to you to find a way to rebuild Thea, banish the Darkness and strengthen mankind. There are 3 basic modes of gameplay in Thea. The world map, choose your own adventure style events, and card challenges.

The world map is a familiar hex grid. From here, you can manage your village and also your expeditions, which are mobile groups of people sent out to explore the world. Although I called Thea a 4X game earlier, it would be more accurate to say it's a 3X game. There aren't any expansion options. You can't build new settlements, or even grow the size in tiles of your village. Although this is missing, it is for good reason. Different tiles have different resources in them, and your units can only gather resources from the tiles in and adjacent to the village, or camp in the case of an expedition. As the village is fixed in size and can't move, expeditions are the primary means of gathering important resources. This is good because it rewards you for venturing beyond thre settlement's walls. The downside is that there isn't a lot to do each turn. Gathering, building, and crafting can all be automated, so I sometimes found myself burning away the turns waiting for something to do. It is possible to create multiple expeditions and have them do different things, but that requires manpower, which is a little rare in the early game. It is an apocalyptic world, after all.

Both the village and expeditions require food and fuel, and can be attacked by enemies. This means there is a bit of a balancing act between keeping people in the village and sending them out on expeditions. The random attacks also mean it's safer to create one big expedition than many small ones. Although this should lead to a situation where the reward is proportional to the risk involved, it doesn't really. High level crafting materials are more important than low level ones, and sources for these are often near high difficulty mobs which require more people to handle. For example, dragon bones will probably be near dragons. Sending people out to gather lots of low level materials isn't very beneficial, and there is no looming threat that requires you to grow as fast as possible. Enemy civilizations don't seem to exist, so you can take your time to grow. That said, I don't think Thea is too easy. Even on normal mode I had to deal with some character death, and there are many difficulty options available beyond that.

Although Thea: The Awakening lacks some aspects typical of 4X games, it replaces them with new features. For example, choose your own adventure style events are a common occurrence in this game. These range in complexity, with some events leading to ongoing quests, and others being simple attacks by enemies. There seems to be a good variety of events, and you often have multiple ways to deal with the problems you face.  For example, even when dealing with random mobs, I got options to sneak attack them and poison them, in addition to a straight up fight. It's beneficial to take these options, too. Fighting can result in wounds, reducing a character's health and increasing the chance they die. As there are so few characters, it is important to preserve them. There is no chance of injury when choosing any of the alternatives to fighting. The rewards may also vary depending on the chosen option. One time, a group of orcs had kidnapped a few children, and I was sent to rescue them by a demon. Surprising none, It turned out that the demon was the one planning to harm the kids and the orcs were protecting them. I could have just killed the orcs and taken the kids, but instead I used the power of my words and won a speech challenge. They handed over the children, who would one day grow into new characters, and even gave me some rare materials with demon warding properties.

Most of these events, like the orc example from earlier, are resolved through card challenges. The same card game is used for all challenge types, but different stats are used for each one. For example, weapon damage is what affects a character's offense in fighting challenges, but speech skill is what affects offense in social challenges. During the setup phase, the card minigame splits your character cards into two hands: offense and tactical. The offense cards are placed directly on the board, and can attack the enemy. The tactical hand uses a variety of abilities to provide support. For example, a character with medicine skill in a cure sickness challenge can provide a defense boost to an ally on the board. You can use the tactical hand to cause the opponent to discard cards from their hand, give your units first strike, increase their offense and defense values, confuse enemies, and even place the tactical card itself on the board. However after the initial setup phase, just 2 rounds of belligerence play out. Cards brought onto the board from the tactical hand are confused for the first round and can't attack until the second. After the second round is complete, the setup phase begins again. This goes on until either team loses.

Thea's card minigame is a very interesting way of making different skills as enjoyable and involving as combat. Due to the high level of abstraction, the same resolve mechanics are used across the board. This leads to a slight lack of variety, but only just. The varied skills of each character in the group are enough to differentiate the overall feel of the challenge types. More importantly, the character attributes are tied into the resolve mechanics in a meaningful way, and have a strong impact on the gameplay. For example, crafters might not be of use on the front line of fights, but they can be powerful in the tactical hand. My only problem is that sometimes the challenges take a long time because of the slow animations and repetition of the setup phase. Thankfully, there is an auto-resolve option to quickly deal with very weak foes.

In addition to the gameplay modes I spoke of earlier, Thea: The Awakening is advertised for its crafting mechanics. I'm not a huge fan of crafting in most games. I avoid it whenever possible, but in Thea it's a core part of the gameplay. To my surprise, I found the crafting system quite enjoyable. The way it works is that each recipe gives you the option of using different materials as substitutes, so if you don't have thread, for example, you can still make a shirt with leather. The higher the quality of the materials you use, the better the bonuses you get. Shields made of regular wood work just fine, but shields made of elven wood give a dexterity bonus. You unlock recipes through research, and you gain research points the same way you earn experience; by exploring the world and by defeating enemies. The crafting system also applies to construction, except buildings require more resources and provide different types of bonuses.

Going back to the story and setting, it feels a little generic. Although Thea claims to be based on Slavic mythology, it's more like they took the pantheon and some of the demons and threw them into a typical medieval fantasy setting. You've got the standard orcs, dwarfs, elves, and wizards running around, and the rare Baba Yaga seems more like a novelty than a c

19630748.review:
Цивилизация + РПГ + Карточная игра + Славянская мифология = Thea: The Awakening (а еще это сюрвайвал)

С первого взгляда игра кажется сыроватой и в чем то недоделаной. При чем местами это действительно так. В игре нет разных сценариев, режимов и прочих настроек привычных по более крупным играм. Настроить можно только сложность игры и сразу в бой. В плане самого процесса игры, по началу так же начинает казаться, что все просто и довольно примитивно, но налет однообразия и кажущейся простоты быстро исчезает как только начинаются проблемы. (А ОНИ НАЧИНАЮТСЯ).

Что касается самого геймплея в общих чертах, то это изометрическая стратегия, в плане цивилизации, но только с одним поселением (выживание которого и является целью игры). Главный ресурс в игре - это люди, которые и будут вашими добытчиками, войнами, крафтерами и т.д. Каждый человек тут будет на вес золота, так как получать новых довольно сложно, а потерять старых не так уж и трудно. Каждый имеет свои уникальные характеристики, коих довольно много, базирующиеся на его классе, снаряжении и прокачке (тут и подходит сравнение с РПГ). Все события в игре такие как - битва, различные проверки, случайные события, будут проходиться вашими отрядами за счет этих характеристик, и все это будут карточные мини-игры, в которых ваши люди и будут выступать картами.

Так же в игре присутствует система исследований и крафта. После исследования определенной технологии, возьмем для примера лук, эту технологию ваши крафтеры смогут превратить в определенный предмет (капитаню). При чем не будет какого то кол-ва разных рецептов лука, рецепт только один, а крутость предмета будет определяться типом ресурсов вложенных в этот рецепт. Можно использовать примитивное дерево и веревку, а можно редкое дерево с шелковой нитью, все так или иначе влияет на конечный результат. Таким образом не придется исследовать или искать где то "легендарный рецепт" на тот же лук, а нужно будет исследовать/искать и добыть "легендарные" ресурсы (что зачастую гораздо сложнее). Интересность системы так же в том, что это полностью затрагивает даже постройку зданий в поселении. Сделаны они из обычной глины, либо же из гранита, повлияет на характеристики самих зданий.

В целом игра довольно уникальна и весьма интересна, этакое стратегическое выживание в мире славянской мифологии. Реиграбельность весьма большая, учитываю, что игра заточена на сливы и начала новых прохождений, но уже с более прокаченным богом (ах да в этой игре вы выступаете от лица одного из славянских богов), прокачка которого влияет на ваше поселение и людей. Карта, ее содержание и ваши люди процедурно генерируется с каждой новой игрой. Как я уже писал, в начале игра кажется довольно легкой и ненапряжной, но сюрвайвал на то и сюрвайвал, что бы подкидывать вам проблем в самых неожиданных ситуациях, что кстати делает ее только интереснее. 

Ну и о звуке. В этом плане игра порадовала довольно приятными славяно-скандинавскими фолк композициями, что весьма хорошо сказалось на задумке и атмосфере. Хотя и хотелось бы, что бы их было несколько больше. Пока создается впечатление, что на всю игру всего 3-4 мелодии.

В общем игра о том, что бежать из уже начавшегося боя, рискуя потерять одного или нескольких столь драгоценных людей, не такое уж и зазорное дело.

19625658.review:
[h1]My Background:[/h1]
After 50+ hours of gameplay and achieving most of the achievements on this game, I can now review it. First of all, this was my first 4X "roguelike" strategy game (I've yet to truly understand what that really means... something along the lines of: eXplore, eXploit, eXpand, eXterminate). However, the artfully designed characters and *almost* open-world caught my interest. Purchased it and it was definitely well worth it!

[u][b]Game Mechanics[/b][/u]
In Thea, there are many combination of skills you can develop/train into your villagers. The availability to customize what gear you want to assign to each character also allows you to build a flexible team that can withstand any obstacle. Tools/Armors/Weapons/Structures can be crafted or constructed using different materials to develop different attributes or (in the case of structures) attract certain class of characters.

The combat system in Thea is an offense/tactic card game. I picked up the combat mechanics pretty quickly with the use of the available tutorial. It is intuitive and is not always the same. Monster movements are randomized which keeps you always on your feet. You don't know when the next wave of T5 monsters will come... When that time comes though, you better hope you have the gears to defend yourself or the insight to attack first!

[u][b]Game Environment[/b][/u]
The game environment is absolutely amazing. The details of the monsters and your characters are superb. Over time, you'll begin to pick up a few things about certain terrains. Some terrains have more quanity of one resource than another. Understanding this and developing your build strategies around this will definitely make you a better player.

The quests in this game is also worth noting. The quests, based on your decisions, can lead to different results. The voice-over definitely allows you to immerse yourself into the environment. There are several main quests that appear to the player at different times. In addition to quests, there are randomized events that could help or hurt your settlement. Again, keeping you on your feet!

[u][b]Game Community[/b][/u]
Thea has a very supportive community. New contents are still being developed and updated. A lot of these changes have been guided by suggestions made by the player-base so that is definitely a plus.

[u][b]Overall Ratings[/b][/u]
Music - 10/10
Design - 10/10
Content - 10/10

Average hours of gameplay per run - 5+ hours ([i]This especially happens when you fall in love with your villagers and don't want any of them to die!!![/i])

19608465.review:
A very good strategy game with some RPG flavor.  It combines various traditional elements in a both unique and famliar ways.  For example, there is exploration, but it's liimited by food and party strength.  You start with 1 village/city and cannot add/found more.  The combat is quick and card-based.  There is a story and interesting quests to find.  Finally, the developers seem to really support the game.  The end result is a game the does not require a lot of micro management and gives the 1-more-turn feel.  Tremendous number of choices and decisions. 

I cannot recommend highly enough, especially if you are a strategy fan.

19607630.review: I love to play this on the 300% difficulty - it taxes all of your strategy in managing both resources and party.  Essentially, your community is alone in the world and you have to delve out into the hostile world to progress your party and community.  If you don't the world will sooner than later come calling in ever more powerful groups and your "life" will end - so, you really have to go out and explore; and collect resources; craft many, many items - and survive long enough to finish the story quest; or become powerful enough to dominate the entire "world" - both very, very difficult on the hardest setting.  HUGE replay value, as each adventure is different; each encounter different; as each party is different and encounters situations differently.  The battle system is very tactical; the resources you collect and when you collect them; and what advancements those allow is very strategic.  I really love the game and have never gotten even to 10% of the game explored before being killed off - it's that tough!  Highly recommend!

19606629.review:
Mostly enjoying the game so far, and defiantly happy to have in my games library. Large scale adventure with a small village of people in a random world. Your village really is just a village with a handful of people so everyone counts, even a crow (yes I'm talking about a bird) that joins your people has it's uses. 

Your enjoyment of the game hinges highly on how well you take to the card system all challenges (combat or otherwise) are resolved by, in which relevant stats become the offense, defense, and special abilities rating for your villagers. Those villagers are represented as cards played from a hand. Takes a little getting used to all the stats and how they'll play out, but for those whom love that sort of thing like myself will find the options very engaging. Added to that the permadeath risk gives you some investment in challenges you might have seen before. Although there is a auto-resolve feature to quickly breeze through pushover challenges.

The story writing is solid and flavorful, with some quality world building which makes up the heart of the game. The art design is very endearing, and I like how the cards representing you villagers and their opponents go for the hand drawn/hand crafted look. Defiantly one of those game I wish there was more of, both in terms of more content for this game (which the developers are working on and adding too), and more game following this RPG, management, & strategy combo. 

Big note: There is a fixed start location that CANNOT be changed (where your only settlement is permanently - though you can make multiple indefinite camp sites). It significantly impacts the difficulty of the games, and can be extremely frustrating for 4X fans whom are used to picking their settlement sites and trying to optimize resources, but does give a bit FTL or Bedlam feel to it.

19604980.review:
Из за этой игры отложил Ведьмак 3 и Фаллаут 4, мне как фанату пошаговых и карточных стратегий эта игра практически идеальна.

Радует в первую очередь огромным потенциалом реиграбельности, она просто бесконечна, постоянно происходят события, на каждом шагу поджидают враги или будущие друзья, то есть тут фактически получился живой мирок со своей спецификой и каждый раз преподносит сюрпризы. 
У меня прямая ассоциация с Banner Saga, но тут у разробов получилось превзойти многократно глубиной проработки и сложных механик. Я люблю карточные стратегии просто влюбился в эту боевку, а добавить сюда ещё и крутой крафт и что нужно реально рассчитывать свои действия наперед чтобы хватило и ресурсов и оптимально распределить свои силы, в общем в этой игре нужно действительно думать и это меня очень радует. Серия героев и дисайплес уже давно не радуют, а тут как глоток свежего воздуха в пошаговых стратегиях, взяли все самое лучшее. 
Отдельно хочется отметить очень красивые арты, и хорошо подобранную музыку, идеально поддерживают нужную атмосферу в игре.
Было бы неплохо добавить возможность отвоевывать какие то особые места у нечисти и там делать как аванпосты где можно крафтить и скидывать полученные за время путешествия вещи и ресурсы. Даже не именно город, а хотя бы перевалочный пункт ) С другой стороны то что город один тоже превносит долю атмосферности, что остался один оплот, да и в нем себя не сможешь чувствовать в безопасности. 
Отлично продуман крафт, редкие ресурсы нужно прокачивать и добывать их не так уж просто да ещё и дойти до места нужно, с другой стороны редкие ресурсы можно получать разбирая на компоненты вещи, что попадаются после квестов и боев, можно и вообще не заморачиватся с крафтом и носить то что попадается, но имхо на высоких сложностях так долго не протянуть. 
Ещё не совсем освоил охоту и магию, прокаченных персонажей в этом мало попадаются. Что бои проводятся с разным подходом и используются в каждом варианте разные аотрибуты это вообще идеальная система, единственное считаю для эпических боссов типа драконов надо оставить поменьше выбора, чтобы победить его было очень сложно. По сути группа змей с ядом с 5-ю черепами доставит больше проблем чем мощный дракон, который в пачке врагов один. Но вообще по балансу и уже правят, и не сказать что его нет, хардкорность чувствуешь даже в глубоком лейтгейме с сильными воинами. 
Единственный минус игры это относительно долгие загрузки, я не понимаю что так долго может грузится на моем мощном пк, но есть подозрение что это сделано специально для большей хардкорности игры, чтобы не злоупотребляли сейв-лоад. Игра действительно хардкорная на сложности выше 200%, в начале по крайней мере точно, дальше когда бойцов побольше и одеты получше бои даются легче, но все равно надо следить чтобы не умер кто то из группы в боях распределять урон и жизнь бойцов, использовать тактику и тд. Больше люблю бои именно в режиме обычного боя, по мне так они самые интересные и сложные зачастую.
Русский язык я думаю сделает сообщество, фанаты у такой замечательной игры обязательно будут, и надеюсь будут и продолжения или просто значительные дополнения к этой, в плане городов миссий, квестов и тп.
Приятно, что патчи и доработка идет активно, разробы большие молодцы.
Забавно, что каждый квест и все тексты внимательно перечитываю, хотя редко это делаю когда игра даже и на русском, вот что значит интересные истории, которые хочеться читать и понимать )

10 из 10 однозначно. И пока лучшая игра последних лет что мне встречалась.

19589957.review:
Surprisingly cohesive and thematic game.  I enjoy the blend of eastern-european folklore and traditional "D&D Fantasy" feel.  The distinct nature of resources is handled well, and the random availability thereof actually makes for a surprising amount of replayability.  The card / battle system is a little bit opaque, not so much because of the actual mechanics involved, but because there are so many statistics that each influence different types of combat in different ways, it's hard to keep track of who will be good at what sort of combat (Fight, Physical, Social, Hex, Sickness, etc).  That said, it's still quite fun.

I do wish there was a bit more "personal interaction" on the god level - you're supposed to be playing as a god looking through your people's eyes, but ultimately that's not the feel you get.  You could just as easily be a chieftan, and god selection would just represent what god your people held dearest.  That's the feeling I get, anyway, kind of a King of Dragon Pass sort of treatment of the gods.

A bit more diversity in production options would be nice too, as far as buildings go at least.  Maybe in addition to producing goods and structures, those with magic could produce "spells" or "blessings."  Then again, it might be too late to add in something like that, given that it's no longer in beta as of November.  Perhaps a later expansion or something similar.

The events are probably the highlight, especially the more detailed ones that lead to questlines.  Quite interesting and immersive.  If nothing else, more and more variety of those would be awesome as well.

All that said, I've enjoyed the game immensely, and my comments above are more nitpicking than anything else.  Great game that keeps you coming back for more.

I wish there was a middle option for recommending... I bought this game based on the great reviews and while the game has many finely tuned options compared to most others, its really not all that. 19551513.review:
One of the most interesting games of 2015. Interesting in a way games like Planescape Torment or Sunless Sea are (although the quality of writing in Thea may not be quite on par with those two). The fantasy post-apocalyptic setting, based on slavic mythology, is intriguing. The world feels strange and hostile, learning it's workings is engaging. 
The gameplay blends 4X strategy (well, 3X really, you won't be expanding beyond your village in Thea), Choose Your Own Adventure gamebook style events, branching story with multiple endings (you can ignore the story altogether though, and win by achieving set strategic goals), crafting, rpg-like gearing, and card-based challenges. Oh my, what a surprisingly well put together mix! 
Card combat is probably the weakest part of the game. Though it requires some degree of tactical thinking, ultimately it becomes a chore, except the most challenging encounters. Hopefully auto-resolve feature is entirely adequate. Another bugbear is that the game may sometimes feel grindy, leveling/unlocking gods in particular may've been faster.
Inspired by games ranging from King of Dragon Pass to Witcher, Thea's most important influence may be Civilization: it absolutely retains the "one more turn" feel to it.

Oh and kids are a resource in this game. You can use them to lure spooky monsters into traps, rescue cats, trade spare children to orcs or just throw them away, if you so desire. Best parenting experience possible.

Edit 24.11.16: Now nominated for the “I Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Award” award by me! Tremendous honor!

19551468.review:
As an author primarily of dark fantasy allegory, myth, and bleak science-fiction, Thea: The Awakening speaks to my soul.  As a woman, it's nice to see some grave lady deities represented - Mokosh being my favorite.  Whoever did the art for this game deserves special recognition. 

So much about this takes me back to my childhood, poring over old books and fantasy accessories for CRPGs and the old artwork in the Diablo booklets.  It has that classic, gritty 90's American pop-art style that will always be a part of my mental landscape.

As a game it functions well.  I'm a strategy addict, and a survival-game addict, so putting these two together ALONG WITH gorgeous art and serious mythological chops?  I couldn't be happier.

Well, I could.  There are issues.

- Tedious micromanagement.  I'm not a huge fan.  Some quality of life improvements would be great, chiefly, the ability to hit a single button when creating a new expedition and automatically supply it with, say, twenty or thirty days of a variety of food and fuel.  As it stands, this is the single most tedious thing in the game, having to manually drag every single item and manually enter in the numbers.  I'm old.  It hurts my poor hand after a while, and interrupts the flow of the game.

- Weird card game combat.  Am I the only one who just clicks auto-resolve every time?  Like, EVERY time?  Even if I liked the card game (I don't really care for it) it doesn't add much to the experience, in my opinion.  This isn't Age of Wonders 3, we don't have the budget for a serious hex field and some turn-based combat, I get that.  It just feels like a waste of time.  But since it doesn't force itself on you, I suppose it's not a big deal.

Those are my only two issues, really.  Some people have complained about the 'writing' being bad because the person who wrote this game's events and designed the world clearly has some incredibly MINOR issues with English.  I wouldn't even call them issues, it's more like reading an accent, which I enjoy, as it gets me looking at my native tongue in different ways.  "weakened, lost, and scared" I would have used 'frightened' or 'afraid' but they chose 'scared.'  Somehow, I find that more compelling.  It has a child-like quality to it.  It conveys that sense of helplessness better.  It is an excellent word choice, but I would have never done it.

As a professional, let me tell you: this writing is exceptional.  Some of the best writing I've ever seen was ESL.  Why?  Because of earnestness and enthusiasm, and storytelling.  Atmosphere.  See, the stray odd word usage actually spices up the world for me.  This game has soul.  It has so much obvious passion pushing behind every word and paragraph.  This game loves itself and it loves its players.  And with its sincere roots in myth, it can't go wrong.

The orcs I especially like.  They have this strange way of speaking with semi-modern slang.  I heard one reviewer complain about that - I've looked.  It's only the orcs who do that.  Chalk it up to cultural differences.  I found it charming, but, that's just my opinion.

Buy this game, on sale or not.  I have four friends on my list who want this game but haven't bought it yet.  It's twenty dollars.  It's worth thirty.  Buy it.

19541310.review:
Começar a falar sobre esse game é meio complicado porque ele é uma mistureba imensa. E, no fim das contas, acaba sendo um daqueles raros casos em que o produto final acaba sendo muito superior à soma de suas partes. E olha que ele tem muitas partes!

Thea: the Awakening é uma mistura de estratégia por turnos, RPG e card games, com fortes elementos de survival que o tornam bem próximo a um roguelike. 

O game tem um visual bem interessante, contando com uma pegada medieval clássica com leves diferenças da estética medieval europeia tradicional. Thea é inspirado na mitologia eslava, e você controla um Deus ou Deusa que acabou de despertar após ter perdido seus poderes, e precisa levar o seu povo ao progresso.

Você é jogado em um mapa gerado aleatoriamente e precisa explorar o mundo com os poucos recursos que tem. Um detalhe interessante é que você não pode construir mais de uma cidade, então sua exploração é limitada à força do seu time de exploração e dos recursos que você é capaz de obter. E a pegada de roguelike vem daí: é possível, e até comum dependendo da dificuldade, perder todos os seus aldeões por conta de má sorte e não conseguir proceder no jogo. Reinicie e tente novamente.

O jogo conta com um sistema de crafting extremamente complexo, com centenas (possivelmente milhares!) de itens a serem criados a partir dos recursos obtidos no mapa. Mais recursos são abertos conforme você consegue pontos de pesquisa, obtidos derrotando inimigos, craftando itens ou cumprindo missões no mapa.

O combate é um dos pontos altos do jogo: o minigame de cartas parece simples a princípio, mas se torna extremamente complexo quando você tem uma compreensão melhor das dezenas de atributos disponíveis a cada personagem. De fato, ele pode ser tornar tão complicado que o jogo permite que você pule completamente os combates, deixando a IA resolvê-los sozinho.

A narrativa é fenomenal. As inspirações da mitologia eslava são um ponto fortíssimo em um mundo em que games baseados nas mitologias grega e nórdica são cada vez mais comuns. O jogo tem uma main quest (que, como é de praxe você pode optar por não seguir) e uma quantidade enorme de sidequests disponíveis, todas muito bem escritas e com ótimo desenvolvimento.

Você vai comemorar quando finalmente conseguir craftar aquela arma feita de mithril.
Vai rir quando aparecer a quest em que a cegonha deixa uma criança numa plantação de alface.
Vai pular de alegria quando derrotar o avatar do seu Deus ou Deusa na main quest.
Vai ficar put* quando três pessoas da sua party morrerem DO NADA por causa de um evento aleatório.

E depois vai começar tudo de novo.

Desde Civilization a frase "só mais um turno" não é tão bem aplicada.

19523714.review:
Wer das Hex-based 4X genre, Rollenspiele mit mythologischem Hintergrund mag wird dieses Spiel mögen. Man startet mit einem Dorf ohne irgendwelche Gebäude und einer kleinen Gruppe von Verehrern seiner selbst. Man spielt das Spiel als diese Gottheit und entscheidet darüber wie Ereignisse gelöst werden. Ob Sozial, Hex (Gift/Krankheit), Physikalisch, Kampf,Schleichen, Jagd... ist egal, es kommen aber immer andere Talente und Attribute deiner Anhänger zum Einsatz. 
Gelöst wird das ganze in Form eines Kartenspiels, wobei die Gegner als Karten dargestellt werden und deine Anhänger. Am Anfang wirkt das ganze noch recht simpel, wird jedoch schnell komplexer.

Der strategische Teil des Spiels besteht daraus, sog. Expeditionen zusammenzustellen, und speziell im mittleren bis späteren Spielverlauf, mit diesen Camps an seltenen ( meist weit entfernten ) Ressourcen aufzustellen um diese zu sammeln. Die Ressourcen werden dann in einem wunderbar vielfältigen Craftingsystem verbraucht, wobei jede Kombination, je nach produziertem Gegenstand ( oder sogar Gebäude ) verschiedene Effekte hat. Für diese Anfertigungen erhält man dann Wissenspunkte, die man entweder in das Erlernen neuer Gebäude, Items oder einer seltenen Ressource (Ort wird aufgedeckt) investieren kann.

Es passieren immer wieder Ereignisse, die zB eine Quest auslösen oder bestimmte Boni im Dorf verleihen, man hat dabei immer wieder eine Auswahl an verschiedenen Reaktionen, die verschiedene Konsequenzen haben.

Insgesamt ist die Stimmung sehr mystisch und märchenhaft, man kann ( insofern man sie freigespielt hat ) als 7 unterschiedliche Gottheiten spielen und hat dementsprechend einen Recht guten Wiederspielwert. Ich persönlich habe meinen 2ten Versuch am stück durchgespielt und gebe auf jeden Fall eine Kaufempfehlung, das Spiel ist die 20 Euro wirklich wer. Störend fande ich das es kein Skillsystem gibt, sondern die Talente und Attribute scheinbar willkürlich vergeben werden. Lediglich beim übergang eines Kindes in das Erwachsenenalters hat die Auswahl zwischen Arbeiter, Gelehrter oder Krieger und einem Zufallsereigniss für einen besonderen Helden, bei dem allerdings höchstwahrscheinlich 5 andere Kinder drauf gehen.

;tldr

Pro
-Vielfältige Möglichkeiten Ereignisse zu lösen
-Gute Mischung aus RPG und Hex4X mit einer Prise Hearthstone
-Wiederspielwert
-Atmosphäre
-Preis/Leistung
Contra
-Grafik eher geht so
-kein Skillsystem
-Manche Ereignisse tauchen immer wieder auf
