19265796.review:
Preface: I wrote this review after 50 hours of gametime, now 200 hours in I'm not less impressed. With the expansion packs that has been released for free (!), I must say that this game gives and gives. It now also has a coop-mode, that I have not tried yet. Very much recommended to all strategy-gamers.

My old review:

It's hard to praise this game too much. For 1/4 the price of games like Civilization and the new HOMM games, you get a sort-of-hybrid between the two, that so far seem better than them. Yes I said it, better. This comes from a long-time fan of the Civ games, spending thousands of hours on 2 and 4 and hundreds on 5. Unfortunately they have not managed to renew the concept in a way to my liking over the years. While those games where revolutions in their own time, as HOMM 3, Thea seems like the new wine in 2015. However I am only 50 hours in, so I cannot say anything about the long-term playability yet. At least it's been a total blast so far.

This makes Thea so good:
- 1 village, perfect! Basebuilding always got tedious and repetitive in the late-game of other games anyway. It increases the feeling of beeing lonely and lost in a hostile world.
- Great resource system! You can build a ton of different weapons and other gear. Because the game emphasises several different challenges in addition to regular combat, you want to have specialists in a wide range of areas, like hunting, healing, magic etc. Because of this your characters, that will multiply in numbers after a while, will sport a wide range of different gear and abilities. Resources are scarce in the beginning and the game always provides newer and better resources that you can reach for, while providing use also for most of the low-tier ones.
- The combat system is easy to learn, but hard to master. The potential for micro-management is very high, as in the rest of the game. Protip: When you have learned the system, turn up the animation speed (took me a while to realize this).
- A limited supply of people. This means that you need to take extra care of all of them, to make sure that they survive. You can give them names, etc. By the way, your camp can attract members of non-human species. Right now my civilization consists of 24 humans and a rock troll by the name of Brick.
- The icing on the cake is that the game seems virtually bugfree, no crashes, everything works as it should, like a clock. I've tried many indie-games where bugs take away from the experience, not with this one!

I'll get back to gaming, this game is recommended to all hobby-kings and nerd-rulers. *insert generic addiction warning here*

19265354.review:
An amazing atmosphere and soundtrack, an innovative, challenging and fun combat/challenge system, and replayability out the ears. It's been a while since I felt immersion while playing a game. Each session tempts investment, you will want your people to survive and thrive. Unlockable 'classes' (Gods with sets of attribute bonuses) provide progression between sessions. High difficulty. A day 1 release purchase that I don't regret.

Game system is like a combination of Civilization (hex based 4x, but without eXpand like another reviewer pointed out so 3x), FTL, and the classic RPG. You get one city only, and start with ~10 named villagers who gain experience and grow as you explore Thea. You will earn more villagers as time passes, but in short, your people are a finite resource and not disposable. 

In-game events can provide positive or negative effects to your group, but so far i've not been hit with any penalties that seem like super RNG, or unfair. So it's a bit more forgiving than a true roguelike in that aspect.

19262445.review:
I honestly did not expect to like this game as much as I did. I backed it on Kickstarter, it failed and I thought "Oh well, that's that." I didn't even have that much of an investment into it on Kickstarter. I was like "Ehh, cheap, looks vaguely amusing."

However, it's a freaking gem. I don't know exactly how, it just seems to do everything right. I've played similar (in elements) games  before, like Fallen Enchantress et al but I've found them merely competent rather than engaging.

There's a very RPG feel to your expeditions that doesn't exist in other titles. It's less of a 4X game and more of a party RPG. You're equipping your characters and they have NAMES. You get to know that Luba is a great combatant and you have her slug it out with the tough stuff after loading her up with your best armour and weapons, but when there's sneaking to be done, you leave it to Jasia. Zlatina's who you call when you want a hunter and when you want a diplomat, you'll want to pull Vladymir from the forge to join your expedition.

I absolutely refuse to have any of my people die. I've worked out the card-based combat system (which is used for any "combat", whether it's social, physical, sneaking or intellectual) which does take a bit of getting used to where I'm letting my tanks soak up the damage and my rogues and hunters smash through enemy defenses.

Honestly, if any of the aspects I mentioned appeal to you, give it a try, especially while it's on special. Some stores are even offering even better specials (like GMG).

19262249.review:
Village pacing was fairly slow and unintuitive.  Aquisition of resources looks to be either based on lucky start position, or on sending out gathering expeditions.  I didn't get to a point where either of those seemed safe, interesting, realistic, or fun.  Research options don't look to advance the game in any meaningful way.

The card mini-game is incredibly high stakes.  Which is unfortunate; it looks like the meat and bones of the game.  Failing a combat challenge costs the expedition party.  I earned 2-3 villagers over an entire session, and lost 4-6 in a single failed combat round from a single bad expedition encounter.  This wasn't interesting, or challenging.

My best luck was skipping the encounters with the automation option.  However, the outcome of encounters I'd play through in the card mini-game was completely decoupled from the automation option.  I don't think the AI actually uses the mini-game at all.  Negative outcomes from success (wounds, etc) were much more marginal than my experiences playing the card game manually.  Even then, encounter "difficulty" was hard to judge.  The skull system implies scaling challenges, but I didn't advance far enough to tell if that's absolute (HERE BE DRAGONS) or relative (THIS IS EASY FOR YOUR AMAZING PARTY).

Exploration and combat with my first expedition party was fun, when automating encounters.  I didn't feel like I got anything meaningful as a reward though.  More resources I couldn't use back at town yet?  Skimming research options doesn't show much meaningful short-term choices.  It was difficult to judge the awesomeness of long-term choices, or the power spikes from going down a gathering/crafting path 10-20 turns away.

I would not recommend this game.

19257590.review:
From the darkness, a ray of hope sees my eyes flick open: I am a god. How long have I slept? A century? My worshippers, so few now, I must guide them...

For this player, 'Thea: The Awakening' has been a love at first sight affair. The player takes the role of a deity, who in turn takes the role of a group of followers. These followers have emerged from an apocalypse of darkness only to have the new dawn illuminate further perils to come. Despite this premise, set in a decidedly dark fantasy world, I cant help but think of Rick from the Walking Dead as I direct my group of survivors to scavenge supplies and fortify, survival our primary concern. I begin to grow attached to each individual in the group. I realise this as night approaches and the sunlight retreats. The dead walk tonight, not far from my settlement, and my four best fighters are out on a salvage mission. To the north my lookouts spot giant spiders scuttling through the dusky gloom. Supplies are getting low, and our resident medic may be about to have a very busy night. My non combatants arm themselves as best they can and they pray for me to guide them to dawn...

What is not to like? Buy this if you like fantasy games, survival games, games with crafting and gathering, heroes that have to eat, games where you can rename every villager and hero you own, card games, TBS games, games where combat is an option but not the only way to get through the night... This hybrid is something special. Just one turn more, right? Yeah right.

19257443.review:
In an era of game creation where you either get a cookie cutter, or a marginally completed beta launch, the makers of Thea: The Awakening arrive on the scene to restore my faith in the video game industry. 

I've played decades worth of strategy games, from old school blizzard and Lucas arts games, through the heroes of might and magic roller coaster ride (that is still disastrous) to the occasional glimpses of brilliance that was from giants like Total War, Red Alert, and Warcraft/Starcraft. I've seen good games. I've seen far more forgettable games, and I can count on one hand how many games caused me to sit down and lose track of time playing a strategy game. Thea made this list for me. 

The approach for resource management is unique: you have a limited amount around your village, but you have to go out and earn the rest through conquest, dungeon delves, and the like. I found it quite engaging. 
I found myself relishing the victories of my band of warriors, mourning the losses of the fallen, and being dumbfounded when my small band somehow took down a dragon, losing two and nearly 4 others in a random encounter where they fell through a pit in the floor. 

I wish I had noticed the game back on Kickstarter, but I somehow missed it. I haven't been as pleased as I am now, however, supporting this tiny crew of game developers who put out an absolute jewel of a game. 

I will be looking for more from these folks in the future...

19255285.review:
This game is pretty original and hits all the right buttons: It's addictive, fun and challenging with a high replay value.

It's basicly a roguelike 3X game. Why not 4X you ask? Because it only has the eXplore, eXploit and eXterminate parts. There is a very small part of eXpand in that you build up your main settlement and attract new villagers, but you are restricted to one village and can't expand its borders like in for instance Civilization or Age of Wonders.

You play as a re-awakened god or goddess in the world of Thea, which is just recovering from an era of utter darkness. Your goal is to help the few people who still kept their faith in you survive and rebuild what they've lost while also trying to figure out what happened in the world that caused this darkness.

At the beginning, the game seems pretty restricted and simple because of the missing of the 4th X: You build weapons, armor and buildings with the materials that your expedition brings home, which in turn generates research which unlocks new materials, buildings and crafting recipes.

However, after you horribly fail the first few attempts, you start to notice how deep the game actually is. Do you want one large expeditionary force or multiple smaller ones? If you bring along a lot of gatherers in your expeditions, you can rapidly collect that valuable steel, but your wood and vegetable production in your village will suffer.

The game is also very clever in the way it handles conflicts. Most conflicts can be resolved in a number of ways depending on your expedition composition. You can not only fight a pack of wolves traditionally, but you can also opt to hunt them if you've got a few people with the proper hunting skillset. If you have a few intelligent people with herbalism and medicine skills, you can choose to just set traps for the wolves with poisoned meat.

These conflicts (named Challenges by the game) are all played out using a card game that is part luck and part skill. I'd say it is more skill-based than Hearthstone for instance.
The cards are the people in your expedition (or village, if it's under attack) and the stats and abilities on those cards are determined by the type of encounter.

During fights, the Damage statistic (which is mostly determined by strenght and the damage of your equipped weapon) will determine, you've guessed it, the amount of damage a card can do. However, during social challenges, damage is determined by the character's Speech skill. That beefy warrior with the giant two-handed axe can suddenly be completely useless if you're trying to convince a group of slave traders to let go of their cargo.

It's a very interesting system and it makes party composition extremely important, as you never know what's around the corner.

When you (inevitably) meet your demise, you are awarded a score based on all that you've done and the difficulty modifier. This score is then added to the experience of the god you've used, unlocking extra passive abilities. When any god reaches level 3, you will unlock a new god with a different playstyle. I enjoy this system, it gives a sense of progression and although the gods' abilities seem subtle at first, they have quite an impact on the way you play.

Additional things that I like are the art style used (the cards are very pretty), the music and the setting. You will encounter very unusual creatures that you may sometimes recognise from the Witcher series, as both games take inspiration from the same mythology.

All in all, I highly recommend this game, it's a lot of bang for your buck. And you will think about what you did wrong that cost you that precious Crafter's life long after you've shut down the game.

19252848.review:
This game really is a hidden gem.

It consists of an overland map upon which you gather resources, complete quests and fight enemies.

The combat, and many other tasks are carried out using a cards system, where the chance of success is determined by a range of stats.

The graphics are nice, and the sound is well done.

My only criticism would be the save system is a bit shoddy. There is an autosave which overwrites itself at the start of each turn, and the option to perform a manual save. However, you only get one manual save which is overwritten each time. This of course means that if anything happens to that save you lose all progress, I've also had my manual save overwritten by the autosave.

In the scheme of things though it's only a minor concern, and hasn't taken anything away from the gaming experience.

19252332.review:
What  a refreshing game!
Mixing different types of games usually produces Frankenstein monster with half baked parts, each part being a weak game in itself.
Then comes this game, part civ-type, part FTL, part survive and craft, part King of Dragonpass (the distinguished players will know what I mean) and it all clicks together!
I'm not very found of indie game (being allergic to pixel art) but I love the art in this game, I love the original setting with a slavic mytho, I love the card confrontation game (not another poor man's HoMM/AoW). Getting into the game was much easier than I feared, Mordheim designers should take notes!
The review I read were so-so but it was the steam reviews that got me to buy this game and man, am I happy I followed them.
I can't think of a better way to spend your money if you like any of the above-mentionned game types.
(I can't remember a better gaming surprise in the last 6 months!)

19250439.review:
O que falar deste jogo que conheço a pouco tempo e já considero muito!

[b]Motivos que posso recomendar Thea: The Awakening:[/b]
[list]
[*]Visuais agradáveis.
[*]Interface um pouco complicado mas rápida de se acostumar.
[*]Não adiciona informações desnecessárias a sua tela.
[*]Foco no Single Player (não oferece multiplayer), então se costuma jogar X4 sozinho, ele é uma ótima escolha.
[*]Ilustrações dos inimigos e aliados excelentes.
[*]Ótima trilha sonora
[*]Muitas possibilidades de customização da sua campanha.
[*]TEM CARTINHAS DO STEAM!
[*]Muitas opções de escolha nos eventos.
[*]Grande variedade de eventos aleatórios, as vezes eles te ajudam e as vezes te ferram.
[*]O jogo sempre lhe dá a escolha de evitar algo que possa complicar a sua vida, porém você não ganha nada com isto.
[*]História muito intrigante e muito boa.
[*]Narração ótima
[*]Sistema de combate em cards muito mais agradável que a maioria dos 4X que já joguei.
[*]Ótimo custo benefício
[*]Foco em poucas unidades, então você não fica perdido com frequência.
[*]O jogo lembra muito um livro jogo em seus eventos lhe dando muitas opções de reação.
[/list]

[b]Motivos qual não posso recomendar Thea: The Awakening:[/b]
[list]
[*]Distorce o tempo, quando percebe lá se foram várias horas (não sei se é positivo ou negativo isto).
[*]O combate de cards é divertido mas cansa depois de um tempo por ser muito comum, pelo menos é possível pular ele em certas ocasiões.
[*]Evolução de personagens muito aleatória.
[*]A escala de dificuldade sobe sem dó de você.
[*]Ilustrações de alguns dos eventos muito ruins, outras são ótimas.
[*]Não é possível criar várias campanhas, o jogo permite apenas um save por vez.
[*]Quando você tem muitas quests, é difícil localiza-las no mapa.
[*]Não tem um mapa mundo para você saber o que já explorou.
[/list]

19249829.review:
Oyun güzel ama halen "Erken Erişim" oyunları gibi hissetiriyor. Oyununa eklenmesi gereken bir sürü şey var. Şu an için sadece indirime girerse almaya değer.

[b] [u] + Artıları [/u] [/b]
+ Bağımlılık yapıcı (Belki sizin için eksidir)
+ Oyunda görevin vs. oluncaya kadar eğlenceli. Görevler bittikten sonra devam etmek sıkıcı.
+ Çeşitli tanrıların olması ve oynadığınız sürece level atlamaları belki 2. kez farklı bir tanrı ile oyunu bitirmeniz için bir neden sayılabilir.
+ Sık sık ufakta olsa güncellemelerin gelmesi
+ Çok çeşitli kaynakların olması
+ Çok sayıda craftın yapılabilmesi. Kullandığınız malzemeye göre kalitesinin değişmesi.
+ Bir görevin birden fazla yöndem ile halledebilinmesi. Bunu ekibinizdekilerin özelliklerine göre en uygununu seçerek yapabilirsiniz. (Savaşarak, zeka ile, konuşarak, büyü yaparak, avlayarak, gizli saldırı yaprak, zehirleyerek vs. rakiplerinizi yenebilirsiniz)
+ Çok sayıda karakter çeşidinin köyünüze katılabilmesi (beast, goblin, elf, demon vs.)

[b][u] - Eksileri [/u] [/b]
- Bina sayısı yetersiz. Ayrıca binalara upgrade yapılabilirse daha iyi olur.
- Oyunun ileriki aşamalarında çok fazla eşyanız ve çok sayıda köylünüz olduğu için hepsini tek tek ekipman ile donatmak çok [u]uzun ve sıkıcı[/u] hale geliyor. Bunun otomatikleştirilmesi lazım. Şahsen bir yerden sonra sıktığı için en iyi ekipmanı koymak yerine hızlıca iyi gördüğüm ilk ekipmanı koymaya başladım.
- Ana hikaye kesinlikle çok eksik.
- Yan görev sayısı çok az.
- Research point kazanmak ilerde çok zaman almaya başlıyor. Sırf research point kazanamk için ihtiyacım olmayan eşyalar craft yapmaya başlıyorsun.
- Bir binayı yıkınca verdiği damage veya shield gibi bonuslar gitmiyor. Bu sayede bina yıkıp yaparak bonusun artırılabilir olması. İyi bir bina yapmak ucuz sayılmadığından bunu yarım eksi gibi düşünebilirsiniz.
- 2. kez bitirmek için yinede bazı eksikliklerin giderilmesi daha eğlenceli olabilir.
- Arayüz çok profesyonel durmuyor.

19245112.review:
Thea: The Awakening is a turn based game that seems to borrow a lot from roguelikes and 4X games, as well as being very detailed on the management of your group. With events and quests that will help immerse you and a refreshing slavic mythology to break up the constant western mythology everywhere.

You are in control of a small group of survivors who need to brave the hostile world and survive and for this you get a very detailed, in-depth control over them all. Every piece of equipment can be custom-made within certain limits provided you have the materials to do so, and you can manage the equipment of all your warriors, your workers, and everyone else in town too. Of course, this can get overwhelming and the interface may appear cluttered at a time (Tip: If it is, uncheck 'equipped' to not show equipped items in the item list), but that is a small price to pay for the function of being able to customise everyone to your liking. You do not settle any more villages, instead sending out expeditions to gather resources and bring them back home. These expeditions can stay out as long as they have food to stay out safely to ultimately can bring back treasures and resources, clear out monster nests, or work on quests.

You gain experience and technology through quests and fighting, so it is a good idea to keep going around to find more with your expeditions, but at the same time you will need to balance the need for tech points with the need for resources. It gets fairly complex, and with a large amount of resources there are a massive amount of options for your strategies to lead to victory or defeat. This comes with a few issues as well, namely things you can find or do that are just not as good as others, or the unlocking of a resource that is not anywhere near you to gather. With limited tech points to spend on these, you will need to be sure of what you want and then plan around getting it, preferably with a contingency plan, or you will end up directionless, with random equipment looted from the enemies, and no real battle plan. And this takes some knowledge of the game before you can be reasonably expected to do well at it.

Combat, and any other challenge is done through a cardgame. At first it is a difficult and complex one, but with practise it quickly becomes clear how it works and what ability is a good idea to use when. There is a button to skip it if you just can't wrap your head around it, and it will automate it for you behind the scenes, which I have found to be a blessing when something trivial attacks you, or when you're just not feeling up for it at the moment.

Not all is great though, balance is a bit difficult to find, with some weapons being flat out better than others, and nearly all non-human characters just plain being better than your human survivors. As well as some resources just plain being inferior to others, while yet others still are so incredibly good that a deposit nearby your settlement will almost guarrantee you'll win. It can use some work, but it's not too big of a deal and doesn't hurt your experience too much.

With a large amount of events - Many of which I've not even seen after 17 hours of play, Thea: The Awakening is going to keep you busy for hours, and even though it may have its flaws, its strong points and the detailed events of slavic mythologic origin by far outweigh them and make it a very worthwhile game to play

19241058.review:
The follwing is copied from my review on pressa2join.com/thea-the-awakening-review
[Disclosure: Game Copy provided by Developer/Publisher]

Thea: The Awakening is an Isometric turn-based strategic survival game, steeped in Slavic myth and monstrosity with RPG, 4x, rogue-like and card game elements, published and developed by MuHa Games. While this is Muha games first major release they have previously created a number of flash games such as: Town of Fears, Road Wolves, Racing Toys and Zack’s Hardware. Individual members of the team have worked on titles such as: The Witcher 2&3, DiRT Showdown, GRID 2 among others. It’s also worth noting that the studio also has created the (fast becoming popular) Honey Hex Framework available from the Unity store which Thea uses.

Welcome to the world of Thea; An apocalyptic force known only as ‘The Darkness’ has engulfed the world for an age, warping and transforming the land and its creatures. Even the Gods themselves have been stripped of their power, only able to watch as their followers dwindled in the face of the horrors. Just as the last embers of hope began to fade the light returned to Thea once again, the Gods and the land awoke; the few remaining survivors are left with the daunting task of trying to rebuild and survive. There are many creatures warped by darkness and there are no heroes, monster slayers or great armies able to combat them. As one of the gods reawakened you must guide your people through the land that by day is at best; dangerous, but as night falls the creatures become even more aggressive. You must find out what happened to the world and how, as the return of the light may be fleeting.

Thea is a strategy based game that at first glance looks very much like “Civilisation” or “Heroes of Might and Magic” there are however a number of differences in gameplay and mechanics which turns the game into something unique and interesting. For starters the player only has one settlement throughout the game, there is an ability to set up small camps which can gather nearby resources and as such can act as a forward base of operations. However, players will only possess the ability to operate and defend these camps in mid to late game. Thea also has a heavy “choose your own adventure” influence in that random events will occur and often the player is given a number of choices in how to deal with this occurrence. This choice will not only effect this instance but may affect other events and possibly even elements of the main story. There are two available starting deities to play with, an additional six being unlockable each of which have different perks/abilities and therefore playstyles. Thea also features a deep and interesting crafting/research system.

Whilst there exists a number of different ways to face the challenges in the game, one of the easier ways is through combat, and indeed the combat system is familiar yet different. The player cannot train new units and is reliant on new survivors joining their cause as well as children being generated and growing up. There are a number of different types of survivor from warrior to farmer and a few more in-between. Those joining your village will already have a type, however children growing up will have a choice of what they can become, which can prove extremely useful. The combat itself is done via a card based mini-game, as are the different challenges, each with their own unique twist. The card mini-game is reminiscent of “Magic: The Gathering” and indeed as such whilst having the appearance of being very simple has a number of different mechanics in play that can change outcomes drastically. The game does have a high learning curve but the player is assisted with an excellent tutorial/help system that teaches the basics and is also available on hand upon request.

The game as a whole has a very substance over style feel to it, which in a game were mythology and lore are key is definitely the way to go. Being an isometric turn-based strategy the graphics are not the priority however the animations and textures are still extremely nice and help bring the lore of the game to life. One of the things players will likely notice is the graphics in combat as the various characters and creatures are as mentioned cards which are hand drawn in appearance, but as indicated what it lacks in graphics it makes up for in gameplay mechanics. The music and sound assets provide an excellent undertone for the game as a whole and like all good music and sound assets give the game that little extra boost.

Overall I have to say that although the game has a fairly high learning curve it is extremely interesting and rewarding particularly for those like myself who have an interest in mythology and lore. However, that being said there is still lots of nice elements that would interest 4x, RPG and rogue-like players alike. One of the biggest surprises for me was a fully customisable experience not just with the “choose your own adventure” elements but indeed the difficulty be can be completely customised to suit different play styles. Also as mentioned there is a rogue-like continual progression system so even if a playthrough ends in disaster the player will get some experience towards levelling up their chosen deity. One addition I would like to see is a multiple save system so different deities can be tried out. There is much more to the game than what I can cover here, if you like what you see check it out. Thea is completely mouse driven although I used the steam controller in my playthrough.

Overall: 8.1/10 For full breakdown, screenshots etc, please visit website.

Mais alors l'équlibrage de la difficulté, pour moi qui suit habitué à beaucoup de jeu de type CIV, est juste catastrophique. Même en mode "facile", je me fait atomiser par des mobs 4 tdm qui pop et qui détruisent mes personnages en 1 ou 2 attaques. Sans parler des quêtes qui nous sont données et qui nous amène à une mort où même en fuyant, on se fait décimer tellement le niveau est déséquilibré. Et ca arrive TRES souvent. Combiné au fait que les naissances sont beaucoup plus rares que les morts, qu'on passe beaucoup de temps à équiper et monter en puissance ses personnages, les voir mourrir aussi vite en masse est vraiment mauvais.

Donc à part jouer avec la sauvegarde constamment (une seule de dispo...), c'est plus de la frustration qu'autre chose.

19240105.review:
Grosse surprise que ce jeu à 15 euros ! 

En voyant les screens, on pourrait croire à un clone de Civilization, mais il n'en est rien. Les seules choses que le jeu emprunte à Civ sont les hexagones, la recherche (arbre technologique), les ressources à exploiter apparentes sur la map et les conditions de victoires variées. Mais quand bien même ces éléments sont présents, ils sont traités différemment.

Pour tout le reste, on est bien dans du pur jeu de survie avec pas mal de points bien originaux. Notamment les combats sous forme de jeu de carte (simpliste en apparence) qui se révèle assez stratégique à partir du moment où on veut éviter les pertes. 

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=561426348

Il y a également un système de craft qui donne le vertige tellement les possibilités sont énormes. Il y a des milliers d'items à crafter. Leur qualité dépendra des matériaux que vous utiliserez lors de leur confection. Et c'est le même principe pour les batiments que vous construirez dans le village : leurs bonus seront différents selon si vous utilisez, par exemple, principalement du bois ou de la pierre.

L'obtention des matériaux est au coeur du gameplay. Vous avez un seul et unique village peuplé d'une poignée d'individus. Vous devrez choisir qui, parmi ces jeunes gens, devra partir en expédition pour tenter de ramener la matière première qui vous fait défaut. Il sera alors temps de former un groupe, en choisissant parmi des personnages qui seront soit portés sur les armes, la médecine, le crafting et/ou l'exploitation de ressources (récolter, pêcher, miner, etc.). Il faudra également leur donner les équipements et les vivres nécessaires à leur survie dans ces terres hostiles. Mais hors de question d'embarquer tout le monde : si le village se fait attaquer alors qu'il est désert, c'est le game over.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=561426632

Lors de l'expédition, votre groupe sera confronté à divers dangers : les monstres et bêtes sauvages qui rôdent, le manque de provision, certains terrains difficiles à pratiquer, les évènements aléatoires, etc. Dès que vous considérez qu'un endroit est propice à l'exploitation, vous pouvez monter un camp de fortune, le temps de récolter tout ce que vous voulez. Selon le talent de vos "ouvriers", la tâche mettra plus ou moins de temps. Il faudra donc garder un oeil constamment sur le stock de vivres, histoire de s'assurer qu'il y en aura assez pour revenir au village. Vos villageois pourront en effet mourir de faim ou être dans l'incapacité de soigner leurs blessures s'il n'y a plus de nourriture ou de quoi allumer un feu près duquel ils pourraient se reposer.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=561149615

Le retour au village sera l'occasion d'upgrader un peu l'équipement des villageois, de récupérer des provisions et de repartir, peut-être cette fois, pour une quête qu'un Dieu vous aura donné ou vers un lieu digne d'intérêt que vos éclaireurs auront repéré. A l'issu de chaque quête, combat ou autres challenges, vos personnages gagneront de l'xp qui leur permettra de progresser dans leur voie. Il deviendra donc de plus en plus important de veiller à la survie de chaque individu.

Bon, ça fait déjà un sacré pavé et pourtant j'ai oublié plein de choses... Y a vraiment de quoi faire dans ce Thea, surtout que le jeu est loin d'être facile... D'ailleurs, à la manière d'un rogue-like vous serez amené à recommencer encore et encore vos parties qui seront générées aléatoirement (carte, localisation du village, matériaux en votre possession, villageois, quêtes - plus de 200 d'après le dev - ...), mais chaque fois que vous perdrez, et comme c'est un peu la mode en ce moment, vous débloquerez des trucs qui faciliteront vos parties futures, en l'occurence : des Dieux et de nouveaux pouvoirs passifs pour ces derniers.

En résumé, quelques points positifs et négatifs : 

[b]+[/b] mélange de survie et de rogue-like réfléchi et super intéressant
[b]+[/b] combats et challenges traités de manière originale par le biais d'un jeu de carte assez stratégique
[b]+[/b] plutôt joli pour un jeu indé
[b]+[/b] le contenu énorme du jeu (plus de 200 quêtes aléatoires, des milliers d'objets à crafter, etc.)
[b]+[/b] le thème dark fantasy post apocalyptique inspiré de la mythologie nordique
[b]-[/b] l'interface un poil lourde parfois, même si je sais qu'il y a des raccourcis clavier, j'aurais aimé ne pas avoir à cliquer plusieurs fois sur mes groupes ou mon village pour accéder à des infos... de base (genre le temps qu'il reste pour récolter x matériaux)
[b]-[/b] maitrise de l'anglais obligatoire (pour les quêtes seulement, tout le reste est assez compréhensible grâce aux icônes et autres)
[b]-[/b] et vraiment pour chercher la petite bête : les musiques un poil répétitives et pas toujours géniales (je pense à celles des combats qui s'enchaînent super mal par exemple)

19239274.review:
Disclosure: Thea: The Awakening was played on retail code provided by the developer.
You can read the review with images and captions at [url=https://voxludicus.wordpress.com/2015/11/23/review-thea-the-awakening/]Vox Ludicus[/url].

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In Thea, you play the role of a god stripped of its divinity, a once powerful being now relegated to dominion over a dozen villagers. Your objective is to restore yourself to power and remove Thea from the somber period it is now in, just awoken from an era of darkness. Drawing elements from 4X, trading card games and roguelikes, the main question I asked myself when I first started playing was how these elements would come together. Twenty hours later, I have a verdict.

As you start the game you are immediately greeted with the choice of one out of eight different deities, of which only two are initially unlocked. The game has a progression system where you can level up and unlock new bonuses and traits for each god as you play with them, as well as other members from the pantheon. The tiers you unlock with each deity grant you lore-appropriate bonuses: Horos, Lord of the Night and Master of the Moon, grants boons to his followers that allow them to perform better during the night and in stealthy tasks; while Mokosh, Mother Earth, facilitates the gathering of resources and food for her followers.

Each new run features a unique landscape, with your village having access to random types and amounts of resources. The game is, essentially, divided into two distinct parts: managing your village and your expedition(s). While you can scavenge resources and treasure with your expeditions, by camping and gathering on the map or acquiring it via events and battles, your village will be responsible for the steady income of fuel and food. It is a functional hub, where you can bring the resources and items your expeditions find for storage or use in crafting and construction.

The crafting system is elaborate and tied-in with another strategic element: research. As you complete events and battles you gain advancement points and experience points – while the latter will improve your villagers, advancement points allow you to unlock new buildings, different types of craftable items and “discover” new resources, which then show on your map and are subject to gathering by your expeditions. These advanced materials yield better crafted and constructed objects: a pasture that is built with simple components yields less meat than one constructed on materials that are further down the research tree.

Your expeditions will handle the exploratory part of the 4X (which is actually 3X, as you can’t grow your village) and are a compromise between the usual exploration in 4X strategy games and Thea’s survival and roguelike elements. You can only walk over a small amount of tiles in a single turn, and each turn consumes your party’s food – which when varied and plentiful also offers bonuses to their attributes. The fog of war is dictated by a day/night cycle, as is monster behavior – you can expect added aggression during the night, be it directed at your expedition or your settlement. Completing quests and battles grants you a global amount of experience, which then levels up your villagers – in the settlement or expedition – assigning them random attributes according to their designation (Warrior, Gatherer, Craftsman, etc.).

Combat is where the card aspect of the game comes into play. Before you draw any wrong conclusions, you don’t collect cards or build a deck – they are merely a representation of your villagers. Combat itself can take on many forms, some of them not necessarily lethal: your social interactions, such as trying to convince or intimidate someone, will be played in the same way as your fights, debates, physical tasks et. al., each time tapping into different attributes of your characters and setting them as the primary offensive and defensive attributes. While you can’t necessarily solve every conflict with a debate or in a sneaky manner, most quests have multiple solutions that you can choose according to how you’re role-playing or the strengths of your party: the Orc warrior that joined your group might make for poor conversation, but in turn the social interaction will allow your silver-tongued medic to shine.

The game’s setting immediately struck me as unique: inspired by both Slavic mythology and Tolkien-esque fantasy literature, you are as likely to meet an Orc chieftain as you traverse Thea as you are Baba Yaga or a Striga. The lore is well crafted and throughout the several pages of dialogue and interactions I had with the most varied creatures – benign (and malign) demons, dragons, witches and elves – the attention to detail from the Polish developers was evident.

Events are more or less independent from one another, though there are specific event chains – the main quest in particular – that can last throughout your entire playthrough. While some seem to appear with a certain frequency early on, for the most part the discovery of events and quests, much like the game’s geography and your party members, is procedurally generated. Your group’s attributes – of which there are dozens – and your previous actions will often unlock additional conversation/interaction options and allow you to solve quests in varied manners, allowing even repeated quests to have unexpected outcomes.

Now is where I apologize for the overly descriptive review and explain what I intended with it. If it hasn’t become clear from what you read, the different systems in Thea – the exploration, the village management, the crafting, the research system and the combat – do not only come together in a cohesive manner, with purpose and intent, but are introduced in the game in elaborate and developed ways. None of these mechanics feel unnecessary or shoehorned, and even less so do they look like side-thoughts or are they casually implemented.

That’s not to say Thea doesn’t have its share of flaws. The UI takes a while to get acquainted with; the difficulty isn’t forgiving, and I died several times before making decent progress into the main quest; the fact that your character can strike out at two different enemies – the closest to his left or to his right – adds an unwelcome element of surprise in a game that otherwise downplays RNG in favor of strategy; and it doesn’t cope too well with its earlier segments, which become boring after you’ve already played through the game – to your death or success – multiple times.

Thea isn’t a game for everyone. It takes the natural complexity of well-done strategy games and adds a layer of roguelike to it – something that might be appeased if you play with the save function on, a travesty I did not commit. If you’re willing to be challenged, if you want to venture into a world with unique lore and characters, if you don’t mind starting over and over and over again, Thea: The Awakening might be just the game you wanted: a strategy roguelike which values forethought and rewards caution, with plenty of progression systems to incentive your return to it, and something entirely different from what I’ve recently seen released.

19238223.review:
В первый же день покупки этой игры я просидел в ней 7 часов. Семь часов!!! Игрушка очень атмосферная, детально глубокая по своим взевозможным вариантам прохождения и развития, при этом легка в освоении. К персонажам действительно привыкаешь, каждого стараешься использовать максимально продуктивно, прокачивая те или иные сильные стороны. Исследовать игровой мир интересно, приходится постоянно думать и просчитывать свой путь. Загрузился в деревне по-полной проивантом и снаряжением, персонажей разодел до зубов - путь экспедиции будет долог, победоносен, но вернешься домой едва ли чего прихватив. А прихватывать стоит, иначе грошь цена твоим постройкам и прокаченным технологиям. Тупо ничего не скрафтишь и не построишь нового. Вот и приходится постоянно анализировать, за каким ресурсом отправиться, каких мастеров набрать в отряд и т.д. Единственное, чего пока не понял - как увеличивать популяцию своих подопечных. За всё время у меня взрослели только дети из базового комплекта + однажды ко мне подселился новый персонаж. Строю кучу ферм, в описании которых сказано, что каждая привлекает 2 человечка, но новобранцев не заводится. А жаль, я бы по две экспедиции запускал - одну чисто на добычу рерусов, вторую отправлял бы в логова мобов за добротным оружием и шмотом. 

В любом случае - горизонта в этой игре я пока не достиг, куча всего впереди. За такие деньги игру крайне рекомендую всем, кому близки жанры РПГ, карточных игр, пошаговых стратегий и сурвайвла.

UPD: разобрался с увелечением популяции - фермы, всё-таки, привлекают людей (и не только). Нужно время и благоприятные условия.

19236683.review:
[b]Live by the RNG, die by the RNG.[/b] Sometimes, you die by the RNG but don't know it for 20 turns, because you lost a powerful unit and newbie humans can't fight dragons.

*OR* you can use The One True Strategy and fight the same card game battle the same way 500 times, because the auto-resolve will eventually kill that really powerful unit and then you'll lose 20 turns later.

You'd think that with half a dozen different ways to win a battle you'd need to build a generalist party. [i]Nope.[/i] Because that nerfs your ability to use the win method (combat) that can always be used, and then you lose that powerful unit, and then you lose 20 turns later. Because if you have a balanced party half the time your front line fighters will be half gatherers who can't carry heavy armor. That pesky RNG!!!

Just a tip - if you want to play this game, turn saves on in custom options and savescum. This is a really bad design for a Roguelike.

19235094.review:
Ein klasse Spiel.
Mit guten Englischkenntnissen sehr tiefgründig.
Die rundenbasierten Kämpfe im Kartenspiel-Overlay wirken frisch und abwechslungsreich. easy to learn, hard to master, das gefällt und motiviert. 
Grafik 9/10 natürlich etwas altbacken, aber einen Vergleich zu The Witcher sucht das Spiel sowieso nicht. Tolle Artworks!.Mehr braucht dieses Spiel einfach nicht

Die Menus sind intuitiv,sofern man das System dahinter verstanden hat :) 
Die Economy ist sehr übersichtlich.Es gibt zwar viele Ressourcen, die aber erst von Zeit zu Zeit an Bedeutung gewinnen. 
Es fehlt dem Spiel an Einsteigerfreundlichkeit. Nach 40 Stunden nun, habe ich den Dreh erst richtig raus (habe mir keine Let´s plays oder andere Tutorials angesehen)

Man managt ein kleines Dorf mit etwa 12 Bewohnern, die man kennenlernt,benennen kann und die eine Charakterentwicklung haben.
Die Hälfte der Leute schickt man auf Erkundungstour, sie bildet unsere Kampf- und Explore-Gruppe. Der Rest ist von Natur aus eher sesshaft und bleibt im Dorf. Ihr Fokus liegt eher auf Fähigkeiten im Sammeln, Bauen oder Craften.
Unsere Bevölkerung wächst (im besten Fall stetig). Neue Menschen u.a. schliessen sich uns an und Kinder werden gezeugt.
Kinder kann man später zu neuen Sammlern, Kämpfern oder Handwerkern ausbilden. Aber auch das Dorf wird angegriffen und muss entsprechend gut geschützt und verteidigt sein.
Am crafting gefällt mir das Herumprobieren. Gegenstände erhalten bessere Werte, je höher die Qualität der verwendeten Materialen ist.

Ich bin sehr gespannt, ob die story was taugt, denn ich bin bisher noch nicht wirklich weit gekommen.
Man kann für 15€ getrost zuschlagen, wenn man Fan von Civ oder eher noch Fallen Enchantress ist.

19234805.review:
King of Dragon Pass meets Dwarf Fortress meets Don't Starve meets Civilization IV.

With a deck of cards.

The art caught my eye for this game, but the reviews were largely positive and I gave it a shot. I'm extremely glad I did.

The gameplay is extremely fun. Managing both your village and expeditions is a lot of fun and the landscape remains hostile and varied enough to keep you interested. In fact, there never comes a point where you feel "safe" when you step outside your village walls. There's always something worse coming out of the distant mists.

The crafting system is much deeper than it looks on the surface. Materials gathered from your expeditions are used to create items such as armor, tools, weapons, or structures and the quality of said materials reflects in the items. The crafting reminds me slightly of Star Wars Galaxies played at a strategic level ... find the best resource, send a team out to extract it, then come back to your base to build it. Only instead of the view of a single individual, you manage the entire village.

The storyline ... I haven't finished it yet. I'm intriqued by it, but it's not very invasive. I find myself putting off going to investigate some distant point on the map that my deity wants me to look into just so I can go gather a little more wheat to make some bread (sorry, obscure deity).

The interface felt clunky at first but a lot of my problems with it were due to poor documentation. Once I found the appropriate hotkeys things moved along a lot better. The graphics on any setting look great.

The card game that is used for combat is tough to figure out. At first I just auto-resolved all the battles to avoid it. Then later I found that I was getting into the card game in order to play extremely difficult battles. I don't know that I do better than the computer, but at least I know what went wrong.

There's some warts in the game still. I haven't encountered any game-breaking bugs but there's some text errors. There's also some balance issues in that one thing you do will seem vastly overpowered compared to every alternative (goblins, I'm looking at you).

I'm giving this a hearty recommend. Deep strategy players will feel like they missed out without this one in their library. I'm also intriqued by what a small, independent team did. This game grabs me as much as Civilization ever did, and I thought I'd become completely jaded by those sort of hex map genres. A lot of flops trying to recapture Master of Magic and Civilization burned me out. And then along comes a tiny, obscure studio who knocks it out of the park without making any of those outrageous claims or trying to follow tired old formulas. AND they're still working on it! Another sign that the big studios may be on their way out and we're entering into an exciting new era.

It's like a craft ale produced by a really good microbrewery by experts who really like craft ale.

Were all the issue fixed this would a AAA strategy game. I for one wishes this to be a success and for an even better sequal.

19232095.review:
Heres my take on this game...
I beat it after a few practice runs.

Overview:  Beat without the last tier crafting; and about 30~ residents. I ended up recruit 3 Elves, 1 Demon, 5 Hunters, 1 Sage, and 1 Witch. Not to mention my other standard guys. I was able to beat the entire main quest fairly easy, (mind you this was on normal).  MY main method was Social/Hunting/Attack. While there were other ways to overcome obstacles these became the most powerful as things like magic or hexing / sneaking become really hard to stack as you need specific character types. 

While there were a few instances I felt confused such as the attack order which is used for every conflict resolution; sometimes its predictable who the enemy will attack so you can strategize; other times its just hectic. 

The dialouge is ok; the story telling is nice; there are a few quests that are empty that will probably be filled later. 

In the end; the crafting was very rewarding as was the gathering. 
But the thing that I felt the game lacked was village options. Such as expanding my village to include more tiles; or being able to terra-form tiles; such as making a tile near your base wheat. Also; being able to found a new village or repair an abandoned village. Or traded with another village; as many of the tiles in the game can only be triggered once or for specific reasons like lifting a curse but it doesnt have the shops or traders that you can frequent that arent temporary.

In the end; this has potential and I honestly feel like this would be the template for an incredible FTP online game similar to Travian. But as it is a Solo-P at the moment the idea is brilliant and I cant help but feel like 15.99 was a complete steal. 

RECOMMEND!

-分：多样战斗模式后期然并卵，末日生存还是要拳头大，嘴炮不能拯救世界。
-分：战斗卡牌模式略简陋，玩过几次后就用自带的自动战斗打全程了。
-分：剧情：世界，”又要被拯救了，好累。“
-分：摸清游戏模型和爆发曲线后，游戏仍有难度但是相对无脑。难度主要来自随机资源点，游戏模型本身还是很简单的。
-分：后期太繁琐，不友好。你要给35个小人一个个换左右手武器，胸甲，首饰和远程武器，这你敢信？？

19230877.review:
I have a 3 month old daughter called Thea, who regularly awakens me at ungodly hours of the morning.
On one such occasion, i found myself browsing the Steam store...
And there it was... Thea: The Awakening 

Even having no real clue what this game was about, i knew i had to buy it.

I now secretly go to bed, hoping she wakes me up at 2am so i can get more time on this captivating game.
It's all turn based, so if she needs a nappy change or rocking to sleep, i'm always there on call.
The game can be pretty much controlled with just the mouse, so i can cradle Thea in one hand, while i play Thea with the other.
To all the dads out there... Get this game. Even if you baby isn't called Thea...

It's basically a turn-based, post apocalyptic, fantasy, survival, crafting, exploration game.


----Tips----
-Build Cabbage fields (3-4):  More kids/humans = More villagers = Safer expeditions
-Build Pasture (3-4): Same reason as above
-Your expedition group can be larger that 6 (sounds stupid, but it took me a while to figure this out).
-Warrior Focus seems to be working best for me (you can create crating tools and gathering tools and equip them on your warriors)
- Create your expedition teams carefully (Especially check tactics, speech, stealth, hunting) this will help with missions other than fighting.
- Use your research points wisely (i hold-off researching of "gathering-materials" until later - Just because you haven't researched it, doesn't mean it can't drop, it just means you can't "gather it")

19229058.review:
When I first saw this game it looked pretty cool to me, was still a bit iffy whenever I read some of the reviews on it but I decided "why not", Here are some of my Likes and dislikes of the game.

 I really loved the creativity of the game such as how the map was really flush and not just a bunch of random tiles put together to make "terrain", it was more like looking at an actual fantasy map. Another part that I loved was the uniqueness of characters, their own art syles, and their proficiencies, everyone is different and they all grow in their own unique way. Also im a big fan of survival RPG games and this game really hit the spot for me by bringing a variety of stories that actually progressed or hindered your ability to survive against so many different possibilities. Lastly, there is the part about the UI, I think it could still use a little work but I havent really played a game that is unique as this one. Theres a bit you have to get use to but its like any other "4X" game, reason being is that they offer so much to the game it probably makes it hard to make it flush out nicely, but I wouldnt let that discourage you, I quickly learned it and was glued to the game all day on my day off.

Now for a few parts of the game that I didnt care for.

One of my biggest concerns was that I felt like the game grew more difficult the more you barely progressed, maybe I suck at playing the game, wouldnt doubt it, but I felt like once I got to a certain point I just had a bunch of higher level guys thrown at me while im still a lower level. Another thing would be is trying to find more people to join you in the game, I would rescue or raise someone and soon after I would lose a guy or two. Finally, I wish I was able to either or- make more settlements, have growing domain range, or atleast be able to set up a middle man to run between my base and camps if possible.

Like I said I probably just suck at playing the game but I feel like some people would agree with me on a few points. I dont know wether the team will come out with those in later patches or not, but even with all that said I still really loved the game they made and I would definetly recommend this game to people who like RPGs, 4X games, or to whoever was looking for a new kind of game that feels different than the others.

Sehr gelungener Genremix, aus Heroes of Might and Magic, Civilisation, Banished und Magic: the Gathering.
Man sollte schon ein bischen Englisch verstehen können und auch bereit sein einige Texte auf Englisch zu lesen.

Es gibt rund um das Dorf genug zu tun, jede Runde ist wohl überlegt.
Das Bonussystem mit den unterschiedlichen Nahrungstypen ist auch super!
Es entstehen im Laufe des Spiels immer wieder neue Orte und Events, die mit fortlaufender Spieldauer immer härter werden.
Komplett zufallsgenerierte Karten in 4 verschiedenen Größen.
Schwierigkeitsgrad frei einstellbar.
Die paar Siedler aus dem Dorf wachsen einem nach der Zeit wirklich ans Herz und man trauert auch um sie wenn sie es nicht lebendig aus einem Kampf schaffen.
Forschung und Levelsystem zwingt einen immer aktiv zu bleiben.
Events stellen immer andere anforderungen an deine Truppe, so hat jeder seinen Nutzen und pure Gewalt ist nicht immer eine Lösung. Man kann Drachen auch einfach mal nett fragen ob sie mir nicht einen Teil ihres Schatzes so geben wollen! :-)

Einziger Kritikpunkt bisher: Das aufleveln der Siedler hätte bisl mehr Tiefgang gebraucht, zb. das man jeden einzeln hochleven und dann aus unterschiedlichen Fähigkeiten wählen kann.

Für den Preis eine ganz klar Kaufempfehlung für jeden der die 4 oben genannten Titel und ähnliche mag.

19226853.review:
Off the bat, I want you to know that just about everything in this game comes together in an amazing package. You craft because the fighting is so fun, you fight because the exploring is so fun, you explore because the looting in this game is so fun, you loot because the crafting is so fun, you craft because the fighting is so fun, and you did that whole cycle because advancing the story and raising a group of survivors into a hardened army is so fun. Many far greater budget games with far greater hype only manage to make one or two of their systems truly great, while the rest of the game act strictly as support. This is not the case with Thea.

So what is Thea? Thea is a strategy game where you attempt to guide a ragtag band of survivors in a post-apocalyptic world. At first, you will be trying to stabilize your situation with enough food and fuel to not starve. Later, you will explore the world to attempt to find better ingredients to craft into ever-better gear. As time goes on, enemies get fiercer and quests get harder,but you are racing against that with your own technological development. 

The best part of Thea is that you are never playing the game on auto-pilot. The combat system is *excellent*. It is never easy to figure out a best way to equip your party, but it is apparent you need a mix of specialties. When you're sitting at the card game, looking at the board in a close battle, it is always apparent you need to do something crafty... but it's rarely apparent whether you'd want to be crafty by putting down a big, well-shielded blocker, confusing an enemy to stall its turn, or go on the offense. Everything matters in the card-based minigame - how your hand is dealt, when you play your cards, which cards you play and hold, and what stat you play your cards for. Even hours and hours through this game, after I've played and replayed sections, I'm still finding myself putting down a bigt 2-handed hammer fighter against spiders, only to have him caught out without a shield for the Spider Queen's attack because the computer played its tactisc in a way I never expected.

All that said, Thea does have some flaws that bear mentioning, All 3D models in this game come from Unity... which means all the characters are disgustingly ugly and generic. Fortunately, there are not very many 3D models of characters, and you don't have to look at them very closely. Battles are played with drawn cards, and special events have a 2D picture. The question, of course, is why have the 3D models at all if the game's 2D is so much more beautiful than the 3D. The overworld map could've easily been purged of the ugly 3D Unity models with some clever abstract represenation in 2D.

The writing is also flawed at various points. The dialogue of the game is tone deaf. Here it is, trying to tell me an epic story of heroism, betrayal, monsters, and gods, but the language of the dialogue makes everyone sound like a modern teenager trying his best to simulate wit. This pulls me out of the epic storyline every time I reach the dialogue box.

Still, good game? Yes. Would I recommend? Definitely. Will this drain hours and hours of your life? It should.

Take everything you love about 4x games, throw out the 1 "x" I never liked, expand, toss in RPG elements, multiple ways to resolve conflict that greatly vary depending on the skills of your people, randomly generated maps that can make your game easy or insanely difficult even on the easiest level, perma-death of your people that WILL affect you, and you have a highly addicting game based on Early Slavic mythology.

19222516.review:
Seeing a lot of positive reviews for Thea I decided to try it out.  The sad reality is, this game is pretty much Endless Legend without the beautiful art or depth.  The main selling points peopel will use for Thea are the Slavvic folklore and the card battle system.  While I have no particular opinion on the folklore, the card battle system is in my opinion, uninspired, repetitive and boring.  Characters seem to become wounded at random, I had characters who lost all their HP in combat receiving no wounds while characters who were hit only for 1/4 their HP received heavy wounds.

Bulding, research, expansion and actual conflict all feel lacking.  It's not a traditional 4X as you do not play against other civilizations, tribes or groups in your own situation, just AI controlled encounters.  It is a very slow game with many turns passing simply gathering the materials you need to build or craft.  I would recommend people try Endless Legend over Thea: The Awakening unless you have a particular penchant for Slavvic folklore.

19221971.review:
I bought this because turn based survival sounds pretty awesome. Also, other reviews titled this game as "deep", "challenging" and "rich of content".

Unfortunately, I must disagree. There is nothing deep about this game. You collect resources and do some multiple-choice quests, that is it. The game itself is not challenging, the random number generator (RNG) is the challenge. Or, at the same time, it eliminates the challenge because it blesses you with strong artifacts. 

As for the content. Yes, there are a lot of characters, items and quests in the game. But they are all way too similar. Even worse, regardless whether you do combat, use speech to convince your foes or try other means such as "tactics", "hunt" and "stealth", it always results in the same card mini game.

Which would necessarily be bad, but since the card game is 80% luck and 20% skill/planning, it is the same RNG that creates or takes the challenge.

Finally, the game, while not exactly great looking, is poorly optimized. Which means that I cannot play it on my laptop (5200U, 8GB RAM, GeForce 940M) which runs Endless Legend just fine (which looks better and is also based on the Unity Game Engine). Even at only 720p, it get only about 10 fps. It runs ok on my desktop system (i5 4670K, 16GB RAM, GeForce 660 Ti), though.

19220953.review:
เป็นเรื่องยากมากจริง ๆ ที่จะอธิบายว่า "Thea: The Awakening" เป็นเกมแนวใดกันแน่ เพราะตัวเกมนั้นได้หยิบจับรูปแบบการเล่นแบบ 4X, การดำเนินเรื่องแบบ RPG, การพยายามต่อสู้เพื่อเอาตัวรอดแบบเกมแนว Survival, การบริหารทรัพยากรแบบ Strategy, การไล่ Loot สิ่งของแบบ Rougue-like และการต่อสู้แบบเกมการ์ดเข้ามาไว้ด้วยกัน อาจจะฟังดูมั่ว ๆ อยู่สักหน่อย แต่หลังจากที่ได้สัมผัสกับตัวเกมไปชั่วครู่ใหญ่ ๆ ความเห็นของผมที่มีต่อเกมนี้ก็คือ...

"น่าประทับใจมาก"

ดังที่กล่าวไปเมื่อครู่ ตัวเกมนั้นมีรูปแบบการเล่นที่หยิบจับนู่นนิดนี่หน่อยมาผสมเข้าด้วยกัน กระนั้นถ้ามองโดยภาพรวม ตัวเกมนั้นก็คือ "RPG" ดี ๆ นี่เอง โดยภายในเกมนี้คุณจะได้รับบทเป็นเหล่าชาวบ้านผู้ที่อาศัยอยู่บนโลกที่ล่มสลายและมีภารกิจหลักก็คือการเอาตัวรอดและฟื้นฟูโลกใบนี้โดยอาศัยอำนาจของเทพที่คุณเคารพรัก (คุณสามารถเลือก Deity ของคุณได้ตอนต้นเกม โดยเทพแต่ละองค์ก็จะมีจุดเด่นและจุดด้อยต่างกันออกไป) คุณจะใช้เวลาส่วนใหญ่ในเกมหมดไปกับการรวบรวมทรัพยากร ต่อเติมเมืองของคุณ และออกสำรวจดินแดนโดยรอบคล้าย ๆ กันกับเกมแนว 4X แต่ก็แค่คล้าย ๆ เท่านั้น เพราะหมู่บ้านของคุณไม่อาจขยับขยายไปเป็นอาณาจักรได้ ถ้าให้เปรียบง่าย ๆ หมู่บ้านของคุณก็จะเหมือนกันกับฐานบัญชาการใหญ่ที่มีไว้เพื่อรวบรวมทรัพยากรและคุณต้องคอยรักษาให้อยู่รอดปลอดภัยนั่นเอง

จุดเด่นที่น่าสนใจของเกมนี้ที่ผมชอบมากก็คือชาวบ้านแต่ละคนนั้นไม่ใช่ตัวละครโนเนมแบบใช้แล้วทิ้ง ตัวละครของคุณล้วนแต่มีชื่อและลักษณะเฉพาะเป็นของตัวเอง ซึ่งพวกเขาสามารถที่จะสวมใส่อุปกรณ์หรือแม้แต่พัฒนาทักษะของตนเองได้ โดยค่า Attributes ต่าง ๆ ที่พวกเขามี ก็จะส่งผลต่อตัวเลือกต่าง ๆ ในเกมและความสามารถพิเศษที่พวกเขาสามารถใช้เพื่อสนับสนุนในการต่อสู้อีกด้วย

"Thea: The Awakening" อาจจะไม่ใช่เกมระดับที่ไม่ควรพลาดหรืออะไรเทือกนั้น แต่เป็นเกมที่เน้นขายไอเดียและรูปแบบการเล่นเป็นหลัก ซึ่งถ้าคุณชอบเกมแนวอินดี้ที่มีเอกลักษณ์เฉพาะไม่เหมือนใคร นี่ก็คือเกมสำหรับคุณครับ

7.5 / 10

ข้อดี:
+ ฉากหลังและเนื้อหาของเกมที่น่าสนใจและน่าติดตามมาก ๆ
+ ตัวเกมผสมผสานจุดเด่นของเกมแต่ละแนวได้อย่างลงตัว (โดยเฉพาะระบบต่อสู้ แนวมาก)
+ เกมอาจจะมีขนาดเล็กจนน่าประหลาดใจ แต่คุณอาจต้องใช้เวลานานมากเพื่อเข้าถึงรายละเอียดทุกอย่างที่มีอยู่ภายในเกม (นั่นหมายถึงว่าคุณสามารถกลับมาเล่นซ้ำได้อีกหลายครั้งมาก ๆ ถ้าไม่เบื่อไปเสียก่อน)

ข้อเสีย:
- ตัวเกมมีปัญหากับการ์ดจอ GTX 5xx และ 6xx ของค่ายเขียว จำเป็นต้องบังคับรัน DirectX 9.0 เพื่อให้เล่นได้ (ทีมพัฒนากำลังพยายามหาทางแก้ปัญหาอยู่ขณะที่ผมเขียนบทวิจารณ์นี้)
- ตัวเกมมีรายละเอียดที่ต้องจัดการค่อนข้างมากแต่ UI ก็ไม่ได้ทำให้งานในจุดนี้ง่ายขึ้นแต่อย่างใด

19209047.review:
TLDR: Excellent game, very cool blend of 4x (Fallen Enchantress, Endless Legends etc) with Rogue-like, has a very deep crafting system and unique combat mechanic.

If you're a fan of these genres, don't hesitate and buy it, support wonderful devs so that they may continue to create great games for us to enjoy.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Longer review for those genuinely interested in whether its worth the buy.

I wont delve into the whole gameplay, just the two key things that make this game stand out above the rest.

1. Crafting system. You unlock a type of weapon, tool, armor etc to make. But each type can have a lot of variations based on what materials you use to make it. Materials give them unique properties, such as life-leech, +defenses +stats, and for weapons, rarer metals like mythril boost its raw damage. 

Why this is so cool is that its up to you what kind of things you craft, there's no set recipes like "Hunter Sword" requiring a set mat, sometimes you make something inferior just because its the materials you have available and you need that weapon NOW for an un-armed villager. 

Or, you can choose to wait and hope your adventuring finds more rarer mats to have enough to make that epic weapon. It's dynamic, its got depth, it offers choices. 

The research tree is small & at first glance, looks to be over-simplified. But this is a GOOD thing, because there's a ton of depth underneath it. This is great design not to overwhelm but to ease players into it, once they understand the quirks they can really go to town on what to craft.

2. Combat. What this game does with a bunch of simplistically drawn cards without attack or defend animations, far surpasses most tactical games in terms of offering tactical depth. Instead of elaborate level design, awesome animations, uber 3d models/textures, this is pure un-adulterated GAMEPLAY trumping all of that.

It's turn based, you play cards, how you play and position them along with using tactical card abilities give a lot of flexibility during tough encounters. Your cards represent your people, of whom you can level up and equip with all the cool things you craft or loot that affect their stats and abilities. 

Stats do matter, however, a good tactical play can get your weaker squad to beat a superior foe, which is what every strategy game should aspire to. It shouldn't be stats > all and in Thea, it is not, thankfully.

I thought it was great going 1h sword + shield for my squad, since shields offer a regenerating defense that absorbs damage, it felt like an imbalance that favors this playstyle.. but nope. I soon ran into enemies that have leech attacks or magic that bypasses shields and my 1 hand weapon lacks the damage to kill them quickly before they pwned my squad. 

This is where a balance squad with punchy 2handers backed up by tanks is required. Good balance is a measure of how different weapon or tactical play all have a niche where they excel and none is left feeling "gimped" by design. In Thea, there's great combat balance.

As an aspiring solo gamedev myself, these two key features leave me with a new-found appreciation of how effective simplistic game design can be yet still retain and ooze depth. 

At the end of the day, as a gamer, I appreciate gameplay over flashy graphics and its not to say this game is un-attractive (some UI polish is needed, given indie & small dev-team), it has a nice aesthetics to it, but here, gameplay is just top-notch with more depth than most games I've played in this genre.

-------------------------------------------

If you're still not convinced to buy this game, allow me to expand with 2 more points why this game is just so great:

3. The game can be very brutal like most rogue-likes. The random nature of it all can wreck havok on your playthrough. However, the devs have really thought it out well and offer customizable difficulty options which are quite vast beyond "Easy, Normal, Hard", with individual metrics that can be tweaked to your liking. So novices can enjoy it without feeling hopeless and veterans can really tweak the difficulty to give them a challenge. 

4. Character options are just vast, with many different races, monsters, demons to recruit through a unique village upgrade mechanic. When you build structures, depending on the materials used, you gain a small percent chance to attract adventurers or beasts to join your village. 

This is a highly fun and flexible system since it allows very different play-styles. Example, you could focus on being a Beastlord..  build structures with Monster Bones and not long you will have a horde of beasts in your army, such as Bears (maul is OP), Vipers, Snakes, Bats, etc. The good thing? Beasts don't need gear, they come buffed already, so you save a ton of materials on crafting! Or go for a full Elven, Dwarven, Orc, Goblin or even Demons & Vampires..  

Did I mention this game has depth? 

BEST 4X in a LONG TIME. 

ps. Whoever came up with the card combat mechanic deserves a cold beer, cos its just outstanding gameplay while requiring minimal time/$/resource investment to implement. 2D non-animated cards offering so much fun and deep gameplay over 3d models with realistic terrain destruction physx?? Say it ain't so! :D
